title: The T Culture Issue
description: The worlds of culture and style stretch far and wide in the latest issue of T. There is Andrew Solomons profile of Deeda Blair, a medical philanthropist, fashion icon and social mover; Andrew OHagan on Miuccia Prada, the fashion designer (and also art curator, film producer and more); and Katie Roiphes look at the French intellectual Bernard-Henri Lvy and his new exhibition on the relationship between art and philosophy.

title: U.S. Says It Pursues More Prosecutions on Indian Lands
description: The Justice Department said this week that it had increased its rate of criminal prosecutions in Indian country by more than 50 percent in the past four years, a period in which violent crime on the nations Indian reservations has soared and tribes have complained of lawlessness.

title: Bill Austin, Pro Bowl Guard, Dies at 84
description: Bill Austin, a Pro Bowl guard who played for the Giants 1956 N.F.L. champions, coached the Green Bay Packers offensive linemen for Vince Lombardis power sweep and was twice an N.F.L. head coach, died on May 22 in Las Vegas. He was 84.

title: British Columbia Opposes Planned Oil Sands Pipeline
description: OTTAWA  A pipeline for exporting oil sands bitumen to Asia-bound tankers was dealt a severe blow on Friday when the province of British Columbia urged a federal review panel to reject the $6 billion plan.

title: Mississippi: Civil Liberties Groups Sue Over Prison
description: A state prison for mentally ill inmates is so poorly maintained that prisoners sell rats to one another as pets and defecate into plastic bags because toilets are broken, a federal lawsuit filed Thursday says. The East Mississippi Correctional Facility operates in a perpetual state of crisis, with inmates resorting to setting fires to receive medical attention, the class action suit filed by the A.C.L.U. and the Southern Poverty Law Center alleges. It claims that the prison, a privately run facility near Meridian, has ignored complaints for years from inmates who later went blind or lost body parts to amputation after not receiving proper medical care. A spokeswoman for the state Department of Corrections declined to comment.

title: The Politics of Free Food
description: Today, lets talk about Virginia, host of the nations most interesting off-year election. True, the New York mayors race has been pretty frisky since we acquired Anthony Weiner as a candidate, but Im still going with Virginia.

title: Going Mobile: Pies That Really Roll
description: Each spring, George Triola invites his golf buddies and their families over for a backyard party at his home in Milltown, N.J., to celebrate the end of the Masters golf tournament. As the guests watch the finale on an outdoor TV, the beer flows, and most years, Mr. Triola, 35, grills hot dogs.

title: Concern Grows as Group Disappears in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Partygoers reveled inside a nightclub in the trendy Zona Rosa neighborhood here as the morning sun burned the asphalt outside.

title: California: Marijuana Seller Takes Plea Deal
description: A medical marijuana store owner whose prosecution by the federal authorities highlighted vast disparities in how California and the Justice Department are responding to the medical marijuana industry abandoned a six-month battle against Washington on Friday and pleaded guilty to 10 charges of marijuana cultivation and distribution. The man, Matthew Davies, 35, had argued that his store in Stockton operated in accordance with California laws, after working extensively with accountants and lawyers before opening the business. But Benjamin B. Wagner, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of California, said, Our investigation showed that it was all about the money. Mr. Davies will serve a minimum of five years.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Robbed, She Moved Swiftly, but a Dawdler Got the Cash
description: She was born and raised in New York City and is quick to add a preface to her story: Yes, she fully realizes she should have known better. But still. It is a stretch to say she could have seen coming what happened to thousands of her dollars in two different banks.

title: U.S. Leaders for Olympics Mending Ties With I.O.C.
description: Like schoolchildren called to the principals office, two new executives for the United States Olympic Committee walked into the Westin Bayshore hotel in Vancouver to face International Olympic Committee officials. The U.S.O.C. and the I.O.C., at odds over how to split millions of dollars of revenue, had little mutual respect.

title: An Elizabethan Cyberwar
description: NEW HAVEN  AS Barack Obama and Chinas president, Xi Jinping, prepare to meet in California next week, Americas relations with China are feeling increasingly like the cold war  especially when it comes to cybersecurity.

title: Woods Is Not in Top Form at the Memorial, but as Usual, He Makes the Cut
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Neither gusting winds nor searing heat nor fast greens nor slow play shall keep Tiger Woods from his appointed four rounds.

title: Don Oliver, NBC Correspondent, Dies at 76
description: Don Oliver, who reached a nightly national audience as a correspondent covering major events for NBC News for more than 25 years, died on Tuesday in Spokane, Wash. He was 76.

title: How Big Is That Park? City Now Has the Answer
description: A funny thing happened while backers and critics of a proposed Major League Soccer stadium were battling over 13 acres of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Three hundred and fifty eight acres of the heavily used park seemed to disappear.

title: Dramatic Scenes From Houston Fire
description: Friday may have been the deadliest day in the history of the Houston Fire Department, officials said, with four firefighters killed while battling a five-alarm blaze that ripped through a large motel on the citys busy Southwest Freeway. Five more firefighters were taken to area hospitals with injuries, but little information about their condition was available on Friday evening.

title: The Frills Are Few. The Fees Are Not.
description: There is a joke in the airline business that you could make money giving out free beer and charging a fee for the bathroom.

title: To Compete, G.M. Alters a Sedan
description: DETROIT  General Motors introduced its revamped Chevrolet Malibu sedan on Friday  just a year after it put out the latest version of the car.

title: Hunch About Bloomberg Brought Rivals Together
description: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are usually bitter rivals, competing for lucrative banking and trading business. But one day in April, the Wall Street titans found common ground: frustration with the Bloomberg news and financial data empire.

title: Orioles Davis Emerging as Special Slugger
description: BALTIMORE  Before the Yankees and the Orioles began a three-game series at Camden Yards last week, Chris Davis, the Orioles starting first baseman, chatted with Robinson Cano. Davis playfully instructed Cano not to hit any home runs against the Orioles; Cano probably should have made the same request of Davis on behalf of the Yankees.

title: Inquiry Into Obama and Bloomberg Ricin Letters Leads to Search of a Texas House
description: NEW BOSTON, Tex.  A quiet neighborhood in this small town in Northeast Texas has become the focus of the investigation into threatening letters laced with the deadly poison ricin that were mailed to President Obama and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, the authorities said Friday.

title: Father Greeley, Defender of the Faithful
description: The Rev. Andrew Greeley, who died this week in Chicago, gained fame and lots of money writing best-selling novels combining Catholicism, Irish America and sex.

title: Untamed Melody
description: Lately Ive been reading the memoirs of the 20th century Russian composer Dimitri Shostakovich. In one section, Shostakovich talks about Shakespeare, whose work was banned by Stalin. Shakespeare speaks to us like a small child, the composer writes. When you talk to a child the words arent important. Its what lies behind the words  the mood, the music. He goes on: When I speak to small children I often dont delve in to the meaning of their babble I just listen to the timbres. Its the same with Shakespeare. When I read Shakespeare, I give myself up to the flow. It doesnt happen often. But those are the best moments. I read  and listen to his music.

title: Two Races in Two Days Add Up to Little Rest After Indianapolis 500
description: DETROIT  Helio Castroneves acknowledged that he was tired, then yawned and apologized to his onlookers.

title: 4 Firefighters Are Killed in Houston Motel Blaze
description: Four firefighters died battling a five-alarm blaze that ripped through a large motel on a busy highway in southwest Houston on Friday, the authorities said. The Houston Fire Department said it was the single deadliest day in department history.

title: The Gun Rampage Next Time
description: In a postscript to the Newtown school massacre in Connecticut, a trauma physician from Hartford Hospital has been meeting with experts from medicine, law enforcement and the military to plan better emergency responses to mass shootings so as to improve the chance for survival of gunshot victims. Just as wartime battlefields historically produce advances in trauma medicine, professionals in Connecticut and elsewhere in America where gun violence has become all too common are seeking to improve such emergency care  a development that concedes that future bouts of gun carnage are inevitable.

title: What Makes the D.C. Circuit Different?
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, is pushing a bill misleadingly called the Court Efficiency Act, which would eliminate three unfilled seats on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Next week, President Obama is expected to nominate three highly qualified lawyers for those seats, to bring the court to its full complement of 11 active judges. The Senate should confirm them quickly.

title: Next Years Health Plan Rates
description: Republicans are doing their best to persuade Americans that the Affordable Care Act will drive health insurance premiums so high that consumers will experience rate shock. That fear-provoking tale seems much less credible now that the rates proposed by health insurers for individual coverage on the new health care exchanges have been made public in several states. For the most part, the premiums will increase only slightly or even decrease for individuals and family coverage on the exchanges, electronic marketplaces in which consumers choose among a variety of plans with differing benefits and costs.

title: Teixeira and Youkilis Return to Lineup, Just in Time to Add Some Pop
description: A little over a week ago, when the Yankees were atop the American League East, some fans wondered if the team was somehow better without its injured stars. Lyle Overbay was proving to be one of the most clutch Yankees, and David Adams was showing potential at third base.

title: Michigan Woman Killed in Syria War, Reports Say
description: About 4 a.m. on Wednesday, Janice Wilson got a Facebook message from the mother of a longtime friend, Nicole Lynn Mansfield, who was worried that she had not heard from her daughter since before Mothers Day. She asked Ms. Wilson to please do some homework and help track her down.

title: One Obstacle Wont Budge in Japans Fight With Deflation
description: TOKYO  Vending machines stocked with sodas are ubiquitous here, tucked away, it seems, in every nook and cranny of the country. They are found along Omotesando, the tree-lined shopping avenue known as the Champs-lyses of Tokyo, and their glow lights up the back streets of hot spring towns like Hakone. They are even atop Mount Fuji, Japans 12,000-foot, snow-capped mountain.

title: Jamess Solo Act Undergoes a Revival
description: MIAMI  Perched on a familiar dais, sitting on the verge of another trip to the N.B.A. finals, LeBron James took a moment to reflect, while his train of thought took a curious detour, to another time and place and state of mind.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 1, 2013
description: "I think people go into this with good hearts, but like many who go into the developing world and want to help, they dont know how easy it is to hurt.

title: Is Force-Feeding Torture?
description: Nearly four months into a hunger strike that has now spread to some two-thirds of the detainees at the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, the question in this headline can no longer be avoided.

title: One Mans Music Is His Neighbors Headache
description: On Thursday night, just past 10, a knock came at the door of a brownstone on Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn.

title: William Demby, Author of Experimental Novels, Dies at 90
description: William Demby, whose novels, written while he was an expatriate in Italy, challenged literary conventions and expectations of what a black writer should write about, died on May 23 at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 90.

title: A Citys Artistic Rebellion
description: A mention of the East Village in the 1980s carries a distinct cultural message: artists living in a gritty, post-punk universe, making art that critiqued mass media, consumerism and traditional art boundaries. It turns out that despite the Us-Versus-Them, Capitalism-Versus-Communism rhetoric of the late-cold-war period, Russian artists of that era were working in a very similar vein, albeit under different circumstances. You can see this in Leningrads Perestroika: Crosscurrents in Photography, Video and Music, an exhibition at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.

title: Zimbabwe: Court Speeds Up Vote
description: Zimbabwes highest court ordered that national elections be held before the end of July, speeding up the expected timetable to choose a new Parliament and hold a presidential vote. President Robert G. Mugabe hopes to win another term and end the uneasy power-sharing arrangement put in place after the 2008 election. The new Constitution approved in March requires extensive changes to electoral laws before a vote is held, which has led the opposition Movement for Democratic Change to push for elections later in the year. The opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai said that the court had no power whatsoever to set an election date, and that enough time must be allowed for voter registration and electoral reforms.

title: Lebanon: Elections Postponed
description: Lebanons Parliament on Friday voted to delay elections, which had been scheduled to take place on June 16, for at least 17 months. It is the first such delay since the end of Lebanons 15-year civil war in 1990. The Lebanese newspaper The Daily Star said the measure authorizing the delay was the result of the Parliaments failure to agree on a new electoral law and the worsening security situation in the country linked to the crisis in neighboring Syria.

title: Some Say the Spelling of a Winning Word Just Wasnt Kosher
description: The national spelling bee spelled it wrong.

title: Playing and Persevering at an Uncommon Level
description: PITTSBURGH  The face of the N.H.L. has been rearranged, but Sidney Crosby is still smiling, undeterred. The Penguins Crosby has notched 7 goals and 8 assists in 10 playoff games, a higher scoring rate than his career average of 1.35 points per playoff game, the best among active players and No. 4 in league history.

title: Circumcision Device Approved by World Health Organization
description: A nonsurgical circumcision device that relies on a rubber band was approved by the World Health Organization on Friday, opening the way for its widespread use in Africa. The device, known as PrePex, is the only adult circumcision method, other than conventional surgery, to gain W.H.O. acceptance. Dr. Eric P. Goosby, the United States Global AIDS Coordinator, said that it would truly help save lives and that he was prepared to use funds from the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief for it. For a heterosexual man in countries where AIDS is common, being circumcised lowers the chance of getting infected by about 60 percent. In the past few years, the United States has paid for more than two million circumcisions in Africa; the W.H.O.s goal is 20 million by 2015. PrePex can be quickly put in place by a two-nurse team. The foreskin dies from the pressure of the rubber band in a grooved ring, and drops off or is clipped off a week later. The procedure uses only topical anesthesia and is safer than surgery.

title: Organizing Black Soldiers
description: For an army beset with unprecedented casualties resulting from Shiloh, Antietam, Fredericksburg and other bloody battles, the ability to tap into an entirely new pool of recruits was a godsend  which is precisely what arrived on Jan. 1, 1863, when the Emancipation Proclamation declared that persons previously held as slaves will be received into the armed service of the United States. But it took another five months before the federal government decided just how to do that.

title: An Old Standard, a Fresh Take
description: A generation ago, nearly every Long Island community had a restaurant like Stangos in Glen Cove  a place that had a bar filled with neighborhood regulars and a separate dining room with families making short work of pizza, pastas and dishes that ended with parmigiana, piccata and pizzaiola.

title: Corrections: June 1, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats Often Blowing In the Wind
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Opening a puzzle with the entry CREEPSHOW is a little unsettling, but its such a good entry that I almost didnt mind. Im not an enthusiast of the horror genre, but I do like an interesting opening to my puzzle.

title: Georgia: Prosecutors Investigate Spending of Government Funds
description: Prosecutors in Georgia are investigating allegations that President Mikheil Saakashvili misused government funds, including more than $11,000 for Botox injections during visits to the United States in 2009 and 2011, according to local news reports. Mr. Saakashvili, whose term expires in the fall, has accused Prime Minister Bidzina Ivanishvili of pursuing politically motivated prosecutions. A spokeswoman for the general prosecutors office said an investigation into whether federal funds had been misused was under way, but she did not name any suspects.

title: U.S. Targets Irans Petrochemical Industry
description: The Obama administration on Friday escalated efforts to isolate Iran economically, blacklisting Iranian companies in the petrochemical industry for the first time and punishing five businesses in four other countries for conspiring to evade American sanctions aimed at restricting Iranian oil sales and air transportation.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Blind to the Past  and Future
description: As a new effort at comprehensive immigration reform inches its way forward in the Senate, dissent from many conservatives is revealing their true contempt for, and fear of, the possibility that demographic groups who look different from their base will accrue power.

title: Love and Angst, in Hair Products and Leather
description: Admirers of more cerebral musicals may sometimes wonder why Grease, the nostalgic tribute to adolescent angst and blooming love at Rydell High in 1959, continues to find its way to numerous stages. The original Broadway production, which opened in 1972 and closed eight years later, set a longevity record for its time. It has been turned into a movie and had two major Broadway revivals and countless other productions. Its beloved songs, like Summer Nights and Those Magic Changes, are by now easily mistaken for iconic 1950s ballads instead of the fond sendups they were meant to be.

title: Chicagos Praise for Quick: If He Sees It, Hell Stop It
description: CHICAGO  Sweat still dripped from the Chicago Blackhawks playoff beards after their Game 7 overtime win over the Detroit Red Wings on Wednesday as they described the thrill of overcoming a three-games-to-one deficit.

title: Environmentalists Complaint Exposes Rift Between Green Certification Groups
description: WASHINGTON  The legal watchdogs at the Federal Trade Commission have been trying to police the proliferating  and often false  claims in recent years that products are green or environmentally friendly.

title: Seeking Coach, Nets Are Said to Contact Jeff Van Gundy
description: The Nets have contacted Jeff Van Gundy in their search for a coach, a person with knowledge of the discussions said Friday.

title: A Police Killing That Seemed to Go Against Type
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.  It is a sadly familiar story: A police call to an apparent disturbance; a sudden encounter between an officer and a suspect believed to be armed; a snap decision; pops of gunfire and the terrible aftermath of blood and regret.

title: A Frog of Special Skill
description: The song of the gray tree frog (Hyla versicolor) is a poignant reminder that our local woodlands have reached their spring peak. The threat of frost has passed, and the woods are fragrant now with showy wildflowers and soft, bright green leaves.

title: 5 Killed as Tornadoes Tear Through Central Oklahoma
description: 7:56 a.m. Saturday | Updated At least five people were killed and 50 others injured when multiple tornadoes tore across central Oklahoma Friday night, causing extensive damage less than two weeks after a tornado killed 24 people and ravaged Moore, a suburb of Oklahoma City.

title: After Putting Away Their Brooms, the Mets Do Little With Their Bats
description: MIAMI  All week, the Mets had not looked like themselves, and certainly not like a team with only 17 victories a week ago.

title: Illinois House Ends Session Without Vote on Marriage
description: CHICAGO  With time running out on Illinoiss legislative session, State House members on Friday night chose not to call a vote on whether to permit same-sex couples to wed, apparently because supporters of same-sex marriage did not have enough votes to pass the measure in the Democratic-controlled House.

title: What to Watch on Day 7 at the French Open
description: A dry Friday got the singles draws back on schedule at Roland Garros, so Day 7 will consist solely of third-round matches from the top half of the mens draw and the bottom half of the womens. Here are six of the best bets for intrigue Saturday.

title: Sabathia Highlights a Night of Returns
description: The Mets had finally and mercifully departed the city, leaving the Yankees behind to contend with a more formidable and important foe. Intracity rivalry turned to intradivisional rivalry Friday as the Yankees felt the pressure to end a five-game losing streak.

title: Surpluses Help, but Fiscal Woes for States Go On
description: While the fiscal picture is brightening around the country, with many states expecting surpluses this year after years of deficits and wrenching budget crises, mounting Medicaid costs and underfunded retirement promises are continuingto cloud their long-termoutlook.

title: New York Tenure Shaped F.B.I. Nominees Security Views
description: One fall day in 1977, a high school senior and his younger brother were at home alone in Allendale, N.J., when a gunman broke into their house and ordered them to lie on a bed. The intruder aimed the gun at the younger brothers ear and threatened to blow his head off if the older boy moved.

title: Lottery Numbers
Lower East Side Troubadour
description: There is plenty of schmaltz at Sammys Roumanian Steak House on the Lower East Side.

title: Catching Thieves of First Editions
description: Decades before Abbie Hoffman told prospective readers to steal his book in 1971, professional thieves were raiding libraries and peddling collectible volumes to their fences on Fourth Avenue between Astor Place and Union Square.

title: Scramble for Female Votes in Mass. Senate Race
description: BOSTON  With less than four weeks before the special Senate election in Massachusetts, Representative Edward Markeys campaign is turning its attention to one of the most important constituencies in the state  women.

title: Wait for Reinforcements Gives Way to a Revival of Patience at the Plate
description: In last three Subway Series games, the Yankees failed to draw a walk. The impatient approach was an indictment of a lineup filled with replacement players who had filled in admirably for a core of injured stars.

title: Want to Hang Out, Maybe?
description: New York City can be a difficult place to keep up with your social commitments. Plans are easily made, but just as easily forsaken. Say your boss asks you to stay a little late, the F train is running along the Eighth Avenue line, or a cellphone suddenly dies.

title: Local Stop: East Harlem
description: East Harlem is a neighborhood marked by different forms of artistic expression.

title: Crossing 96th Streets Great Divide
description: Ninety-sixth Street was long the border between the Upper East Side and El Barrio, Spanish Harlem. To the north, the train tracks beneath Park Avenue leapt aboveground, and Carnegie Hills regular grid and uniform prosperity gave way to a patchwork of public housing and poverty. Today, the old divide is less visible, and the blocks to its north are intriguingly animated by contrasts and surprises.

title: En Garde, All the Time
description: For Adrienne Jarocki, 17, an international fencing champion from Middle Village, Queens, Sundays are only partly a day of rest. She may not have classes at the Bronx High School of Science, but she is usually holding a saber  either at Sheridan Fencing Academy on the Upper East Side, where she has trained for three years, or in competition in the United States or abroad. Though she came to fencing on the late side, after getting tired of competitive ballroom dancing and the beauty pageant circuit  she was Miss New York Preteen 2008  Ms. Jarocki won a silver medal at the Junior and Cadet World Championships in Porec, Croatia, in April, and will fence as a freshman at Harvard this fall. But first, she will graduate from high school on June 21 and spend a month in Poland, where her parents  Jaroslaw, 54, and Anna Jarocki, 47  are from.

title: A Family Struggles to Reopen Its Red Hook Bar
description: Sunnys, a beloved hangout by the Brooklyn waterfront, has remained shuttered since it was severely damaged by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Fighting for Sunnys
description: I cant think about that, said Tone Johansen, her eyes wide and anxious, her blond hair aglow as the sun warmed the little patio behind Sunnys Bar in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Movie Review: 'The Kings of Summer'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Kings of Summer."

title: The Faces of H.I.V. in New York in 2013
description: Those who learned they had H.I.V. years ago thought they faced an early death. Many died, but many are now in middle age, struggling to live with the virus.

title: One Year Later, Collins Has Mixed Feelings About Santanas No-Hitter
description: MIAMI  It is a bittersweet anniversary.

title: People Think Its Over
description: Steve Schalchlin would be the first to tell you he lives in a time of miracles, and about how hard that can be. In 1995, as his body wasted away from AIDS, he took the limited time in front of him as a challenge: he would write songs, make amends, fill his remaining days with life. And by the end, with his digestive system shut down, his figure skeletal, he was ready to die. Then he won a lottery for a new AIDS drug that had been rushed through the approval process. Almost overnight his health began to return, and with it, another, more open-ended, challenge: life.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) TROUBLE WITH THE CURVE (2012) Clint Eastwood stars as Gus Lobel, a longtime scout for the Atlanta Braves whose eyesight is failing and whose job is threatened by a younger hotshot (Matthew Lillard) for whom baseball revolves around numbers and computers. But Gus has a secret weapon against the front-office man who would take him down with newfangled nonsense  and the washed-up pitcher (Justin Timberlake) sent by the Red Sox to check out a high school slugger (Joe Massingill): his daughter, Mickey (Amy Adams, above, with Mr. Eastwood), a lawyer whose eye for talent is almost as sharp as her gnarly dads used to be. The pat and occasionally preposterous story is really just a pretext, a serviceable scaffolding for a handful of expert, satisfying performances, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Eastwood has the good sense to realize that, much as we may adore him, wed sometimes rather spend time with Ms. Adams, who somehow grows tougher, funnier, scarier and more charming with every role. The film, Mr. Scott added, may be an exhibition game, with nothing much at stake, but Ms. Adams brings the heat. She swings for the fence. Snags the line drive, tags the runner and makes the throw to the plate. Find your own metaphor.

title: A Housing Solution Gone Awry
description: In the early 1970s, the architect and city planner Oscar Newman came forth with a book and theory called Defensible Space, which relied in part on data from New York City public housing to propose a set of design solutions to the mounting problems of urban living.

title: IHT Quick Read: June 1
description: NEWS Its as if Leipzig, Hanover and Dresden had disappeared in the blink of an eye, statistically speaking. Germany, which has been deeply concerned about its rapidly dwindling population, released the results of its first census in nearly a quarter of a century on Friday and found 1.5 million fewer inhabitants than previously assumed. Chancellor Angela Merkel was already worried about the shrinking numbers of taxpayers and able-bodied workers. How future smaller generations will repay German debts, much less the mounting liabilities and guarantees meant to contain the euro-zone debt crisis, is a central question here. Germany had not conducted a single census count since reunification, not even an effort to tally those in the former East Germany after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989. The disappearance of 1.5 million people, equal to almost 1.9 percent of the population, only exacerbates the longer-term downward trend. Nick Kulish and Chris Cottrell report from Berlin.

title: Hagel, in Remarks Directed at China, Speaks of Cyberattack Threat
description: SINGAPORE  In remarks directed at China, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel spoke Saturday of a growing threat of cyberattacks against the United States and called on America and its allies to establish international norms of responsible behavior in cyberspace.

title: For Kerber, a Gritty Win in a Tough Draw
description: PARIS  The primal scream emanating from Angelique Kerber said it all. Relief, joy and pure adrenaline were all perfectly encapsulated in that one spine-tingling moment as she sealed a pulsating 6-4, 6-7 (3), 6-4 victory over the gritty Varvara Lepchenko in just over two and a half hours at Roland Garros. Tennis is a gladiatorial sport, and both women played out the final few games as if their lives depended on it.

title: Oklahama City Tornadoes
description: Drivers filmed the storms that tore through central Oklahoma on Friday.

title: The Weekend Word: Reach
description: In Todays Times:Navy investigators are examining a female students claim that she was raped by several midshipmen at the Naval Academy who were not punished after the assault even as she faced discipline, Jim Risen reports. The investigation at the elite academy, which has sputtered along for about a year, has come to light as the military faces intense pressure to reverse a rising tide of sexual assaults within its ranks.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Meghalaya: A local resident has decided to ask the Meghalaya High Court for permission to perform mercy killings of three of his sons, who suffer from thalassemia, a blood disorder, an Indo- Asian News Service report in The Assam Tribune said. I can no longer see my children suffering, Abdul Rahim, a 50-year-old shoe merchant said, ascribing his troubles to the high costs of treatment.

title: Police Retreat as Protests Expand Through Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Violent protests against the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan engulfed Istanbul, Turkeys largest city, on Saturday and spread to other cities, including the capital, Ankara, as tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets in a second day of civil unrest and faced the tear gas and water cannons of a harsh police crackdown.

title: Why Big Data Is Not Truth
description: The word data connotes fixed numbers inside hard grids of information, and as a result, it is easily mistaken for fact. But including bad product introductions and wars, we have many examples of bad data causing big mistakes.

title: What We Have Here Is A Failure To Communicate
description: Interest rates are rising! Head for the hills!

title: Deadly Storms in Oklahoma Bring Flooding and More Tornadoes
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Twelve days after a tornado killed 24 people and destroyed hundreds of homes, this battered city and its surrounding suburbs awoke Saturday morning to the aftermath of Round 2. A storm on Friday set off tornadoes and severe flooding, causing widespread damage around the region and claiming at least nine victims, including two children.

title: Far From Track, Millionaire Racehorse Keeps Up Winning Ways
description: Nothing could shake Dry Martini. Not the dogfights of horse racing, where he won more than $1.4 million, and certainly not foxhunting and jumping, where he dashed through the wilderness of the Pennsylvania foxhunting territory with the cool-headed aplomb of James Bond.

title: For Bruins Defenseman, Best Deal Was No Deal
description: BOSTON  On March 27, Bruins defenseman Matt Bartkowski  called up four days earlier from the minors  was preparing to play his third game for Boston.

title: I.S.S. Backs Sprints Deal With SoftBank
description: The biggest of the proxy advisory firms, Institutional Shareholder Services, lent its support to Sprint Nextels proposed sale to SoftBank of Japan late Friday, amid ongoing criticism of the deal by investors and a rival bid by Dish Network.

title: For the Jockey Gary Stevens, the Rides the Thing
description: After watching on television as Gary Stevens rode Oxbow in the Preakness Stakes, I was probably not the only one who was surprised. After a Hall of Fame career as a jockey, he had been a horse trainer and a TV analyst for seven years, and he had done some acting, in the 2003 film Seabiscuit and the HBO drama series Luck. What was he doing at Pimlico, dressed in black-and-yellow silks and brandishing a riding crop in a victory salute?

title: A Competitor Tees It Up Again for the Open
description: For Casey Martin, trying to qualify for last years United States Open at the Olympic Club in San Francisco started as a nostalgic quest. He experienced his greatest week as a professional golfer on that course, finishing tied for 23rd at the 1998 Open, and he wanted to return.

title: At Combine, Top Russian Prospect Makes His Case
description: TORONTO  Valeri Nichushkin is the type of player that makes the N.H.L. scouting combine vital to teams as they research prospects prior to the June 30 draft.

title: Action Moves From Clay to Canvas
description: PARIS  In an age of ballistic serves and blinding strokes, not much remains of the artistry of slice and angle in international tennis. But a Parisian artist, his brush strokes creating a swirl of movement and color, has returned for a 10th French Open visit to revive the art of watercolors and stack it against the flash of modern digital images.

title: Focus on Safety and Rules Quiets Buzz About Racing
description: CONCORD, N.C.  A rope strung over the front stretch at Charlotte Motor Speedway snapped and fell last Sunday, injuring 10 fans, damaging racecars and stopping the 54th running of the Coca-Cola 600 for about 27 minutes.

title: Bostons Center Fielder of the Future Gets a Second Chance at Now
description: It was 86 degrees for the first pitch at Yankee Stadium on Friday, but Jackie Bradley Jr. was not about to adjust any of his game-day routines. He wore a long-sleeve undershirt, spandex leggings and a black do-rag out into the afternoon swelter.

title: Drug Used to Treat Kidney Cancer May Hold Off Relapses of Ovarian Cancer
description: CHICAGO  Women with ovarian cancer may be able to stave off relapses for an extra half-year or so by taking a drug already approved to treat kidney cancer, researchers reported here on Saturday. But it will not be clear whether the drug prolongs womens lives until the patients are followed longer.

title: Wave of Grief and Political Reverberations Grip Britain After Soldiers Killing
description: LONDON  The sidewalk where 25-year-old Lee Rigby died, beneath a cascade of blows from bladed weapons, has become a place of popular pilgrimage like none other in Britain since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in 1997 in a Paris car crash.

title: Big Golf on a Little Course
description: Merion Golf Club in Ardmore, Pa., is hosting the United States Open, but the grounds are so small, its like bringing the Super Bowl to a small college football field.

title: U.S. Open Will Test the Limits at Merion
description: ARDMORE, Pa.  St. Georges Episcopal Church is about 150 yards from the sixth green at the Merion Golf Club, where the United States Open will begin June 13.

title: Tigers Cabrera Lives and Hits in Zone of His Own
description: BALTIMORE  Kevin Boles was 24 years old when he was named manager of the Marlins Gulf Coast League affiliate in 2000. Because he was so young, he thought it best to avoid any bold declarations about the organizations prospects, at least for the time being. Who would believe him, anyway?

title: Spurs, as They Age, Remain Sustainable
description: SAN ANTONIO  A signature moment in the San Antonio Spurs sweep of Memphis in the Western Conference finals came when Tim Duncan, 37, the archetype of methodical basketball even in his more vivacious days, beat all five Grizzlies down the court to haul in a long pass for an easy basket.

title: In Russia, Living the High Life; in America, a Wanted Man
description: MOSCOW  The waiters hovered as Alimzhan T. Tokhtakhounov worked through a platter of chilled mussels, shrimp and octopus one afternoon last month at the restaurant Palazzo Ducale, one of the finest here. The staff could afford to be attentive: there was no one else to serve.

title: Royals Look Again to Brett for a Lift
description: Dayton Moore believes it can happen for the Kansas City Royals. He has seen it before. The night the Royals won their only World Series, in 1985, Moore watched from a hillside between Interstate 70 and the ballpark. Down on the field, it was George Brett who lifted the pitcher into his arms after the final out.

title: Variety: A Last-Minute Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I was sorely tempted to solve and blog the Sunday puzzle before doing the acrostic. You know how it is. The main Sunday puzzle is so big, so daunting, that it almost seems like I have to get to that before the acrostic just so I can really feel like Ive gotten something done. Ill blog the acrostic eventually, really I will. [Stop dilly-dallying and get to the point. Ed.]

title: Stephens Rides Out an Early Stumble
description: A day before the French Open, Melanie Oudin said she thought that if five American women made it to the second week of the tournament, it could be considered a success. That number seemed outrageously high then, given the well-documented discomfort of Americans on clay and the perception that the womens ranks consist of Serena Williams and, well, almost nobody else.

title: East Finals Look Even More Rugged
description: Throughout the Eastern Conference finals, much of the attention has been on LeBron James, the Miami Heats quest to return to the N.B.A. finals for a third consecutive year and the spirit exhibited by the young Indiana Pacers. Yet another topic  one that has vexed basketball for years  has surfaced for players, coaches and analysts: flopping.

title: Sunni Cleric Issues Appeal for Worlds Muslims to Help Syrian Rebels
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A prominent Sunni Muslim cleric influential in the Syrian uprising has issued a fatwa, or religious decree, calling on Muslims around the world to help Syrian rebels in the embattled town of Qusayr and labeling Hezbollah and Iran, which support the Syrian government, enemies of Islam more infidel than Jews and Christians.

title: The Banality of Dont Be Evil
description: THE New Digital Age is a startlingly clear and provocative blueprint for technocratic imperialism, from two of its leading witch doctors, Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen, who construct a new idiom for United States global power in the 21st century. This idiom reflects the ever closer union between the State Department and Silicon Valley, as personified by Mr. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, and Mr. Cohen, a former adviser to Condoleezza Rice and Hillary Clinton who is now director of Google Ideas.

title: Available: Vociferous Coach and His Baggage
description: The Rangers dismissal of John Tortorella has prompted plenty of speculation about who their next coach might be. But what about Tortorella? Where will he land?

title: Can You Guess What This Is?
description: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

title: Chemicals in the Neighborhood: Three Urban Plants
description: Chemicals in the neighborhood: three urban plants.

title: Hamlet Meets The Hangover
description: Every summer, Hollywood plies international audiences with sequels, prequels, remakes and spinoffs. This years offerings include The Hangover Part III, Fast & Furious 6, Star Trek Into Darkness, Iron Man 3, Man of Steel (the new Superman) and a slew of other familiar story lines.

title: After Years of Progress, a Setback in Saving the Wolf
description: The 1973 Endangered Species Act provides federal protection  breathing space, in a very real sense  to plants and animals threatened with extinction. Had this task been left to the states alone, almost none of the species that have returned to health would have done so.

title: The Global Plight of Disabled Children
description: A United Nations report, The State of the Worlds Children, underscores the moral bankruptcy of Senate Republicans who blocked ratification of a treaty to help disabled people around the world. There is scant data on how many children have such disabilities or how their lives are affected. One outdated estimate is that some 93 million children, one in 20 of those 14 or younger, live with a moderate or severe disability of some kind. The issue is how they might be helped to overcome their disabilities and become productive members of their societies.

title: Restoring the Vote in Virginia
description: Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia enlarged democracy on Wednesday when he announced an order requiring the automatic restoration of voting rights for nonviolent offenders who have historically had to fight through a bureaucratic maze to gain access to the polls.

title: A Failure to Police Chemical Plants
description: The deadly explosion at a fertilizer plant in West, Tex., in April has highlighted glaring shortcomings in federal and state regulation of facilities that produce, store and use toxic chemicals.

title: We Are Not Having A Serious Discussion, Obamacare Edition
description: I fairly often receive mail pleading with me to take a more even tone, to have a respectful discussion with people on the other side rather than calling them fools and knaves. And you know, I do when I can. But the truth is that on most of the big issues confronting us, there just isnt anyone to have a serious discussion with. Ezra Klein offers a nice illustration of this point today, in his takedown of Avik Roy on Obamacare in California.

title: The $2.7 Trillion Medical Bill
description: MERRICK, N.Y.  Deirdre Yapalaters recent colonoscopy at a surgical center near her home here on Long Island went smoothly: she was whisked from pre-op to an operating room where a gastroenterologist, assisted by an anesthesiologist and a nurse, performed the routine cancer screening procedure in less than an hour. The test, which found nothing worrisome, racked up what is likely her most expensive medical bill of the year: $6,385.

title: The Beautiful Game From a Different Perspective
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden  When I was 10, I remember a mentor telling me and my father how important it is to watch soccer games.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Schools Are Not Cool
description: As temperatures rise, life will become more unpleasant for teachers and students in New York City schools, which remain open through June 26, and many of which do not have air-conditioning. In New York roughly a third of public school classrooms lack this basic amenity; in other major cities, especially in poorer districts, the figures are comparable or worse.

title: The Triumph of the Working Mother
description: FIFTY years ago, Betty Friedan made a startling prediction in her controversial best seller, The Feminine Mystique. If American housewives would embark on lifelong careers, she claimed, they would be happier and healthier, their marriages would be more satisfying, and their children would thrive.

title: Sunday Dialogue: More Regulation, or Less?
description: Readers discuss governments proper role in the marketplace.

title: Too Little for So Many, Even in The Times
description: ART auctions or soup kitchens? The cost of a luxury loft in SoHo or the number of children in homeless shelters?

title: Who Needs Reporters?
description: FOR her big announcement last week, Michele Bachmann neither convened a news conference nor waited for some other moment when she was in public, reporters and television cameras nearby. She didnt even pick a favorably inclined journalist for the kind of one-on-one interview in which politicians have often parceled out their revelations and answered a few tame questions.

title: Single-Minded Mission to Block an Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON  These are hectic days for the federal deportation officer who has made it his single-minded mission to stop a bipartisan bill to overhaul the immigration system that is making its way through the Senate.

title: Prisoners of the Euro
description: TO its custodians and admirers, the European Union is the only force standing between its member states and the age-old perils of chauvinism, nationalism and war. That was the pointed message that the Nobel Committee sent last year, when it awarded the union a Peace Prize for its role in the advancement of peace and reconciliation, democracy and human rights. And it is the message hammered home relentlessly by the Continents politicians, who believe their citizens face a stark choice, in the words of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, between continued integration and a return to centuries of hatred and blood spill.

title: Quantity Over Quality in Bank Profits
description: BANK stocks are back, and with a vengeance. Last week, the KBW Bank Index of 24 leading national and regional bank stocks climbed to its highest closing price since 2008. The index is up 20 percent so far in 2013 and 40 percent if you measure from 12 months ago.

title: Fuchsia Dunlop
description: Fuchsia Dunlop is a British chef who in 1995 became the first foreigner to train as a chef at the Sichuan Higher Institute of Cuisine. She speaks fluent Mandarin and is the author of several cookbooks, most recently Every Grain of Rice.

title: Heres My Vision, and Heres Yours. Lets Make It Work.
description: This interview with  Jenna Fagnan, president of Tequila Avin, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Shes Getting Her Boots Dirty
description: WASHINGTON  SO when a woman is rolling in millions and has no need to work ever again, what does she do?

title: The Price of Rebellion
description: DANVILLE, Va., a small city perched just above the North Carolina border, was the last capital of the Confederacy. Its crumbling Millionaires Row still includes the brick Sutherlin mansion, where Jefferson Davis, having fled Richmond, met his cabinet for the last time.

title: The Myth of Gatsbys Suffering Middle Class
description: Another decade, another Gatsby. The actors change but the message put forward in the adaptations of F. Scott Fitzgeralds 1925 book stays the same. The 1920s were as ephemeral as a Champagne bubble. A fake stock market, an illicit liquor business and other falsehoods made Jay Gatsby and others like him into correspondingly false millionaires. The pleasure of the rich, careless people, as a character calls them, came at a cost to the rest, especially the middle class, the small people, mere ants in black tie to be trampled by giants like Gatsby at their parties.

title: Can You Guess What This Is?
description: RULES

title: Sabbath Gasbags, Speak Up
description: Nearly a week after the television news coverage of Memorial Day, Im still thinking about how much I envy Tom Brokaw for having managed to slip a phrase into the language. He slipped in the greatest generation. Ive never slipped in anything.

title: When It May Not Pay to Be Famous
description: WASHINGTON  RYAN HART played quarterback for the Rutgers football team from 2002 to 2005. These days, he works in the financial services industry.

title: Chinas Global Reach
description: Selected countries where China was a major trader, foreign investor or lender.

title: How to Play Well With China
description: PRESIDENTS Obama and Xi Jinping will meet in California for two days starting this Friday.

title: Chinas Economic Empire
description: HONG KONG  THE combination of a strong, rising China and economic stagnation in Europe and America is making the West increasingly uncomfortable. While China is not taking over the world militarily, it seems to be steadily taking it over commercially. In just the past week, Chinese companies and investors have sought to buy two iconic Western companies, Smithfield Foods, the American pork producer, and Club Med, the French resort company.

title: House of Death
description: Death and dying had been my trade for the last four years, but that morning, I didnt want to deal with it. One of my long-term patients, a man in his mid-90s, had become suddenly and seriously ill a few days earlier. His family knew he didnt want aggressive treatment, and so they had moved him to an inpatient hospice in a nearby beach town.

title: Whither the Hatchet Job?
description: Watching High Noon again the other day, I wondered how postwar British culture ever found the strength to continue breathing. Americas global economic clout can be belittled only if you believe that no American cultural product is any good. Since it is undeniable that the occasional American cultural product is marvelous, I was left looking for cultural things that the Americans couldnt do. The only one I can think of is hostile literary criticism.

title: Does Great Literature Make Us Better?
description: You agree with me, I expect, that exposure to challenging works of literary fiction is good for us. Thats one reason we deplore the dumbing-down of the school curriculum and the rise of the Internet and its hyperlink culture. Perhaps we dont all read very much that we would count as great literature, but were apt to feel guilty about not doing so, seeing it as one of the ways we fall short of excellence. Wouldnt reading about Anna Karenina, the good folk of Middlemarch and Marcel and his friends expand our imaginations and refine our moral and social sensibilities?

title:
For Bloomberg, Gun 
Control Fight Shifts
to State Capitals
description: CARSON CITY, Nev.  John W. Griffin is a fast-talking, whiskey-loving, fifth-generation Nevadan who spends his days as a lobbyist courting lawmakers in Stetsons. He advocates for luxury casinos, once brokered a dispute between a brothel and a nightclub, and has helped feuding families resolve tussles over cattle crossings.

title: 2013 Fantasy Football Preseason Schedule Analysis: Quarterback
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the 2013 season.

title: Costa Rican Turtle Defender Found Slain on the Beach He Patrolled
description: | Updates below | This quiet stretch of beach near Limn, Costa Rica, was photographed on May 19 by Jairo Mora Sandoval, a 26-year-old conservationist who regularly patrolled there to protect endangered sea turtles and their nests from poachers (photo of him at work).

title: Daughter of Michigan Woman Killed in Syria Wants Body Returned to U.S.
description: As we reported Friday, friends and family of Nicole Lynn Mansfield, a 33-year-old Michigan woman, knew she was traveling abroad but were stunned to learn that she had been shot and killed in Syria in a confrontation with pro-government forces.

title: Heats Andersen Has No Regrets Over Altercation
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Chris Andersen will not be soaring, dunking or flapping his long limbs for the Miami Heat on Saturday night. He will not admit any regrets, either, over the blowup that prompted the N.B.A. to suspend him for this critical Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Learning From Other Sports, Tennis Coaches See Advantages of Video Analysis
description: PARIS  When Gilles Simon faces Roger Federer on Sunday in the fourth round of the French Open, Simon will have multiple weapons at his disposal  his speed, his signature two-handed backhand down the line and his world-class ability to absorb world-class power and snuff out attacks that would sink less resilient men.

title: Prison Breakout Thwarted in Niger
description: NIAMEY, Niger  Three prisoners said to be associated with terrorist groups tried to break out of the central prison here in the heart of the capital on Saturday afternoon, officials said, drawing crowds into the streets in a nation anxious after two recent terrorist attacks.

title: Breadwinning Wives and Nervous Husbands
description: GIRLS are generally outperforming boys in high school, and then proceeding in greater numbers to attend and graduate from college. And as women take the helm as chief executives of more major corporations, including Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and PepsiCo, there are hints that the glass ceiling may be at least cracking, if not breaking.

title: 2013 Fantasy Football Preseason Schedule Analysis: Running Back
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the 2013 season.

title: Focus of Protests Widens in Istanbul
description: Demonstrators took to the streets in a second day of civil unrest. The police later withdrew from Istanbuls central Taksim Square.

title: When Interest Rates Rise, Stocks Dont Have to Fall
description: LOW interest rates have helped to fuel the stock market rally, and a climb in rates is eventually expected to snuff it out. At least thats the theory.

title: A Traders Crash Landing
description: REMEMBER Bud Fox, the callow, young go-getter portrayed by Charlie Sheen in the 1987 movie Wall Street? Ever wonder how Buds career would have gone had he lasted another 10 years or so? Frankly, me neither.

title: If Our Gadgets Could Measure Our Emotions
description: ON a recent family outing, my mother and sister got into a shouting match. But they werent mad at each other  they were yelling at the iPhones turn-by-turn navigation system. I interrupted to say that the phone didnt understand  or care  that they were upset.

title: Before the Job Interview, Do Your Homework
description: Q. Youve just graduated from college and are entering a tough job market. What kind of interview preparation will help you stand out?

title: Building Companies to Last
description: MY parents divorced when I was 5. When I was 9, my mother and my future stepfather decided to start organic farming in South Washington, Vt. We cleared land and built a house with a post-and-beam style of construction. Id help skin bark off trees and chisel mortises in the timber we used. The experience has served me well in starting companies. I understand the effort to build something that lasts.

title: Jean Stapleton, Who Played Archie Bunkers Better Angel, Dies at 90
description: Jean Stapleton, the character actress whose portrayal of a slow-witted, big-hearted and submissive  up to a point  housewife on the groundbreaking series All in the Family made her, along with Mary Tyler Moore and Bea Arthur, not only one of the foremost women in television comedy in the 1970s but a symbol of emergent feminism in American popular culture, died on Friday at her home in New York City. She was 90.

title: Once Again, Isner Loses in a Major, and in 5 Sets
description: PARIS  What was most surprising about Tommy Haass victory over John Isner on Saturday at the French Open was not that it required five sets. Or that it lasted 4 hours 37 minutes. Or that it included a dozen match points saved by Isner, who won the longest match in tennis history (11:05) at Wimbledon three years ago, who had been eliminated from each of the 2012 Grand Slam tournaments in five-set matches, and who had played a five-setter in this tournament Friday, rallying from a two-sets-to-love deficit to win.

title: 2013 Fantasy Football Preseason Schedule Analysis: Wide Receiver
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the 2013 season.

title: Stir Crazy
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Id like to think that todays puzzle by Elizabeth C. Gorski is dedicated to me. I realize how selfish that sounds, but my all-time favorite color since I can remember has always been THE COLOR PURPLE. And not just any purple, mind you, but that perfect blend of RED and BLUE that makes a purple that almost tastes of grape inside your head when you gaze at it. You know the kind of purple Im talking about, right? Thats the purple that makes my heartstrings play fast and low.

title: U.S. and China Agree to Hold Regular Talks on Hacking
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and China have agreed to hold regular, high-level talks on how to set standards of behavior for cybersecurity and commercial espionage, the first diplomatic effort to defuse the tensions over what the United States says is a daily barrage of computer break-ins and theft of corporate and government secrets.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 2
description: Though he wont appear on any of the Sunday shows, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. will still be in the hot seat. He has already testified before the House Judiciary Committee on the controversy surrounding his departments secret monitoring of journalists, but lawmakers in Congress continue to raise questions.

title: This Man Is Not a Cyborg. Yet.
description: GET right up close to Dmitry Itskov and sniff all you like  you will not pick up even the faintest hint of crazy. He is soft-spoken and a bit shy, but expansive once he gets talking, and endearingly mild-mannered. He never seems ruffled, no matter what question you ask. Even if you ask the obvious one, which he has encountered more than a few times since 2011, when he started this project, as he sometimes calls it.

title: Pugnacious Builder of the Business Lobby
description: THOMAS J. DONOHUE is not one for sweet talk. No sooner had he been named president of the United States Chamber of Commerce in 1997 than he promised to make life miserable for Bill Archer, a powerful member of Congress. In the next breath, he suggested that John Sweeney, the union leader, needed to be punched in the mouth.

title: Biggest Lobbying Spenders in the U.S.
description: Under the leadership of Thomas J. Donohue, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce has exerted much more influence, spending more than three times as much as the second- biggest lobbyist last year.

title: Brothers Search Comes to a Grim End in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For more than seven months, Naimatullah hunted for his two brothers. He agitated with the American and Afghan authorities over their disappearances, dug fruitlessly around the outskirts of a former American Special Forces base where they were last seen after being taken into custody and organized public protests.

title: Hampton, Ranked 54th, Upsets Kvitova
description: PARIS  Jamie Hampton of the United States shrugged off a tumble onto the red clay that cost her one match point and bore down moments later, completing a 6-1,7-6 (7) upset of seventh-seeded Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic on Saturday.

title: Fracking Tests Ties Between California Oil and Ag Interests
description: SHAFTER, Calif.  Scattered on either side of Shafter Avenue just north of the town center here, new oil pump jacks, some bobbing and others thrusting, tower above this corner of Californias prime farmland.

title: Three Days Old, Subway Series Seems So Long Ago
description: MIAMI  Enigmatic is becoming problematic for the Mets, who can make one of baseballs best teams look like the worst and the worst team look like the best.

title: Russian Force Arrests Mayor Tied to Killing in Dagestan
description: MOSCOW  Commandos in armored vehicles surrounded the residence of the mayor of Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan, and arrested him on Saturday, bringing a swift end to his 15-year rule of one of Russias most violent cities and to his ambition to eventually lead the region.

title: Policy Ending Criticized Lesson Plans Leaves Schools in a Bind
description: Last month, State Senator Dan Patrick, the chairman of the Senate Education Committee, announced what he called the end of an era in Texas public schools.

title: Ready to Run for State Office? Get in Line
description: What a difference a fact makes.

title: Free After Six Years in a Cell, Now She Is on Her Own
description: COLDSPRING, Tex.  Megan Winfreys first Mothers Day after being released from prison was a sweet mess. Her 7-year-old daughter, Danielle, served her breakfast in bed, leaving behind a colorful trail of cereal from the kitchen of her trailer home in this tiny East Texas town.

title: Carwash Workers in Queens Strike in Solidarity With Fired Colleague
description: In April, workers at the Jomar Car Wash in Flushing, Queens, voted to join a union, a move they said would help them improve working conditions. But on Saturday, they walked off the job after one of the workers was fired over a confrontation with an owner.

title: Window or Aisle Stall? Equine Frequent Fliers Check In
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  A worn and yellowed catalog for the 1937 Annual Sale of Thoroughbreds at the Lexington Sales Paddock offered 547 stallions, broodmares, yearlings and weanlings. Every page is marked in faded pencil with prices and codes like O.K., good class, poor and W, which possibly denoted the horses won by the catalogs original owner. Each page notes the final auction price ($85 to $2,000). Many famous Kentucky farms offered horses, and sires included the Kentucky Derby winners Omar Khayyam (1917), Morvich (1922) and Burgoo King (1932). But equally fascinating are the notes on the back cover with estimates of train transportation costs.

title: With Kuroda, Yankees Depend on a Pair of Aces
description: C. C. Sabathias command performance Friday night lent assurance to the notion that he was still the Yankees ace and could be depended on to pitch well the rest of the season. But Sunday nights starting pitcher, Hiroki Kuroda, has been every bit as good, if not better, since the Yankees acquired him before the start of last season.

title: Military Sniper and Author, Leaving His Legacy
description: On the night of Feb. 2, William Doyle was working on American Gun, a book he was writing with Chris Kyle, the retired Navy SEAL who had vaulted to celebrity status with his first book, American Sniper: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History, one year earlier.

title: What to Watch on Day 8 at the French Open
description: With the French Open singles fields whittled down to 16 men and 16 women, all singles matches from here on out will be held on one of the two grand stadiums at Roland Garros: Court Philippe Chatrier or Court Suzanne Lenglen. Here are the eight singles matches on tap for Sunday, by court and in order of play:

title: With a 44 for Nine Holes, Woods Avoids Peaking Too Soon
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Tiger Woodss win at last years Memorial Tournament was not a springboard to victory at the United States Open two weeks later. He flopped at Olympic Club, finishing outside the top 20 for his worst showing as a professional in the championship except for a missed cut in 2006 shortly after his fathers death.

title: As Syrians Fight, Sectarian Strife Infects Mideast
description: BAGHDAD  Renewed sectarian killing has brought the highest death toll in Iraq in five years. Young Iraqi scholars at a Shiite Muslim seminary volunteer to fight Sunnis in Syria. Far to the west, in Lebanon, clashes have worsened between opposing sects in the northern city of Tripoli.

title: Billionaire and Science Academy Create Annual Prizes
description: Len Blavatnik and the New York Academy of Sciences are scheduled to announce three $250,000 national prizes for young scientists on Monday, building on a smaller seven-year-old program in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

description: CHICAGO  The Blackhawks shot high, and they shot low. They shot glove-side and stick-side, from close range and long range. They tried one-timers and wristers. They screened, and they chipped. And finally they cracked Jonathan Quick.

description: The New York State education commissioner broke a long and acrimonious impasse on Saturday by imposing a new evaluation system that would rate New York City teachers in part on their students test scores and streamline the disciplinary process.

title: Seeking a Fresh Start, Holder Finds a Fresh Set of Troubles
description: WASHINGTON  At the end of last year, with the election decided and the Obama administration in office for four more years, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. considered stepping down. He decided against it, in part because before he left he wanted to move beyond the disputes that had characterized his tenure, accomplish some of the goals he had set for the job and leave on his own terms.

title: Long Ball Sends Hughes and Yanks a Step Backward
description: Phil Hughes is not an overly demonstrative pitcher on the mound, his expressions of excitement and disappointment barely noticeable from the stands. The best indications of his emotional state are usually reflected in tiny gestures.

title: A Port Authority Commissioner Resigns
description: James P. Rubin, a former professor, diplomat and journalist who was once forced out as an editor of the Bloomberg News opinion section, has resigned as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey just a year and a half after he was appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Heat Falter, Fume and Fall
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Ninety minutes before tipoff Saturday night, LeBron James stretched out his lengthy frame on the floor of the visitors locker room at Bankers Life Fieldhouse, headphones over his ears, lyrics flowing from his lips.

title: Postbop Sax, Plus Strings
description: Melody is always paramount for the saxophonist Joshua Redman, to a degree that sets him apart from his postbop peers. Still, there hasnt been a more sublimely lyrical gesture in his 20-year recording career than Walking Shadows (Nonesuch), an album that sets his tenor and soprano against a string orchestra, in tremulous but thoughtful new arrangements.
