title: Amrita Ford and Hrishikesh Hari
description: Amrita Virginia Ford, a daughter of Sharmila Ford and Alfred Brush Ford of Gainesville, Fla., was married Monday to Hrishikesh Navnit Hari, a son of Pushpa N. Hari and Navnit P. Hari of Orlando, Fla. Pandit Gregory Jay, a Hindu priest, officiated at the St. Regis Princeville on the Hawaiian island of Kauai.

title: Overlooked Napoli Makes Opponents Pay
description: Mike Napoli had to smile to himself when, standing in the on-deck circle in the third inning Saturday, he saw Yankees catcher Chris Stewart extend his right arm, signaling an intentional walk for David Ortiz, loading the bases for the Red Sox.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (AMC) THE KILLING With the killer of Rosie Larsen finally revealed at the end of the second season, this series  which was canceled and then revived  returns with a new case, which the network says will be solved in a single year. And while Sarah Linden (Mireille Enos, above) is no longer working as a Seattle detective, she is drawn back into that life by her former partner Stephen Holder (Joel Kinnaman). During a search for a runaway girl, he discovers a string of gruesome murders seemingly connected to an investigation she headed several years earlier. Peter Sarsgaard joins the cast as Tom Seward, the psychopath who was convicted in those murders and is just weeks away from execution. Still, even with new colleagues, victims and suspects, Season 3 looks an awful lot like the first two: brooding clouds; menacing, slate-colored skies; and leaden seas are still featured players, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. The creators take a fresh start but cling to the sepulchral atmospherics that too often take the place of narrative. The series is still suspenseful, but the dread that once again follows Sarah through damp forests, deserted tenements and shadowy, rain-washed streets diminishes with overuse.

title: Doctor Who Star Matt Smith Is Leaving the Series
description: Somewhere, the Daleks are waving their telescopic appendages in celebration that another Doctor has been exterminated. But there is no joy among fans of Doctor Who, the long-running British science-fiction adventure series, whose lead actor, Matt Smith, will depart at the end of the year, the BBC said.

title: President or Puppet?
description: Theres an ayatollah pulling the strings in the Iranian presidential race.

title: Egypt Court Chips Away at Influence of President
description: CAIRO  Egypts Supreme Constitutional Court ruled Sunday that the laws that governed the election of the countrys only operating house of Parliament as well as the body that drafted the countrys postrevolutionary Constitution were invalid.

title: Why a Widowed Mom Sends Her Son to Camp All Summer
description: I should be the last person sending her son to camp for the entire summer. Im the widowed mother of one, and theres no one in the world who would fault me for keeping him close. Except me.

title: Head Talking Soon
description: I almost forgot  I did a taping for Fareed Zakaria, which I think will be showing this morning.

title: A Sad Story  I Mean, AS-AD Story (Wonkish)
description: Peter Dorman argues that the AS-AD model  thats aggregate demand-aggregate-supply for those of you who ignored the wonkish label  plays no role in the economic blogosphere, and suggests that its fairly prominent role in textbooks is there only to occupy student brain cells until something actually useful comes up. Mark Thoma says hes wrong, and among other things provides several examples (including one of my own) of the AS-AD framework being applied to current issues.

title: The Rail Bookshelf: The Racehorse That Brought Us Together
description: The last good time I had with my father was June 9, 1973, watching Secretariat win the Belmont Stakes.

title: Disruptions: The Echo Chamber of Silicon Valley
description: In San Francisco, a bad habit can be the spark that leads to starting a company.

title: Spared Demolition, an 1889 Building Gets a Second Life
description: To create a modern subway interchange in Lower Manhattan, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority first had to contend with an exquisite antique, one that stood eight stories tall.

title: French Appear Ready to Soften Law on Media Piracy
description: SERRAVAL, France  A French experiment in cracking down on digital media piracy by threatening to kick copyright cheats offline is about to end  without solving the problem.

title: Transport Madness
description: Oh, boy  this is truly amazing. I guess Im not surprised that the WSJ doesnt like the idea of providing New York with a European-style system of rental bikes. But accusing Bloomberg and company of being totalitarians for the vicious crime of  making bright blue bikes available to tourists  seems like it has to be parody.

title: Youth Coach Helped Djokovic Fulfill Many of His Hopes
description: PARIS  It was Wimbledon they dreamed about together, Jelena Gencic and Novak Djokovic. And it was easy for a golden boy to dream when Gencic, with her luminous blue eyes and soothing voice, kept telling him that such big things were possible.

title: Excerpt: 'Far From Heaven'
description: Kelli OHara and Isaiah Johnson sing the number Miro from the new musical at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Will Smith and After Earth Have Dismal Opening
description: A box office era ended over the weekend, as Will Smith, once Hollywoods most dependable summer performer, imploded in spectacular fashion at North American theaters. Mr. Smiths After Earth, a Sony Pictures Entertainment movie that cost $135 million to produce and roughly $100 million to market worldwide, took in an estimated $27 million from Friday to Sunday  or 18 percent less than the lowest of prerelease expectations.

title: McCain Says Assad Has Gained the Upper Hand in Syria
description: Senator John McCain, back from a surprise trip to Syria, offered his bleakest assessment yet of the hostilities there on Sunday, saying that opposition fighters were being massacred and that President Bashar al-Assad, with growing outside support, was tightening his grip on power.

title: Trial on E-Book Price-Fixing Puts Apple in Spotlight
description: Government lawyers are set to face off against Apple this week in a Manhattan courtroom, trying to prove that the company conspired with publishers to raise prices in the e-book market.

title: In China, Concern About a Chill on Foreign Investments
description: China was booming, and Nina Wang, a Hong Kong billionaire, wanted a piece of the action.

title: Chasing the Storm, but Hoping Not to Catch It
description: When Tim Samaras began chasing tornadoes more than two decades ago, he was one of a small, mostly anonymous group of scientists and thrill seekers armed with paper maps, weather radios and a sense of wonder.

title: The Miracle of a Ditz With Depth
description: Its not easy playing dumb. But Jean Stapleton, who died on Friday in Manhattan at 90, did it spectacularly for more than 200 episodes of All in the Family, a watershed television show that never would have worked without her daft, poignant portrayal of Edith Bunker.

title: France Puts UBS Under Investigation in Tax Evasion Inquiry
description: New York  A unit of the Swiss bank UBS has been placed under formal investigation in France following allegations that it designed investments to help its clients evade taxes.

title: The Other Women, Still Trying to Find Their Place
description: Summer beach reading for those with portable video capability has arrived. Mistresses makes its debut on Monday night on ABC, and its everything you want a beach book to be: sexy but not pornographic; nontaxing yet not idiotic; and peppered with enough decent writing that you can tolerate its clichs.

title: Apple Is Said to Be Pressing for Internet Radio Deals
description: After months of stalled negotiations over its planned Internet radio service, Apple is pushing to complete licensing deals with music companies so it can reveal the service as early as next week, according to people briefed on the talks.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: A Break After Streak Ends
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls will have 21 days to ponder an opportunity squandered after a steamy 2-1 loss to the visiting Vancouver Whitecaps on Saturday night.

title: Federer Falls, but Not Out of Contention, Rallying to Victory
description: PARIS  When his right toes caught in the clay and Roger Federer tumbled to the ground Sunday, he looked, for a rare moment, like a clumsy weekend player out for a hit. Federers grace is his calling card, and to see him stumble is as unusual as the thought of him failing to make a deep run at one of tenniss most important tournaments.

title: Clarinet, With Cicada Chorus
description: As billions of cicadas enter the brief, noisy mating stage of their 17-year life cycle, David Rothenberg performs with some of the insects to show how animals use musical sounds to communicate.

title: F.D.A. to Reconsider Restrictions on Diabetes Drug
description: Three years ago, in one of the more notable drug-safety scandals in recent history, the diabetes drug Avandia was all but banned from use in the United States after researchers found that thousands of people had heart problems after taking it. Today, it is a drug of last resort for people with diabetes who are so sick that a heart attack is worth the risk.

title: A Place for Cicadas
description: At a hub of cicada history and scholarship in Connecticut, the 17-year periodical cicada is the subject of study and respect.

title: Here, Cicadas Get a Warm Welcome
description: HAMDEN, Conn.  Lawrence F. Gall, an entomologist at the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale, bushwhacked his way through the muddy thickets leading to the River Road colony here, the epicenter of what is believed to be the worlds only preserve dedicated to Magicicada septendecim, the 17-year periodical cicada.

title: Gay, Hispanic, Adoptive: A Triple-Threat Family
description: The Fosters is a conventional family dramedy about an insistently unconventional family: lesbian mothers (a white police officer and a black charter-school administrator), the officers biological son, adopted Hispanic twins and a foster daughter fresh out of juvie.

title: Hibberts Remarks Result in a Fine
description: The N.B.A. fined Indiana Pacers center Roy Hibbert $75,000 Sunday, hours after Hibbert apologized for using an antigay slur and an obscenity in a news conference after his teams victory against the Miami Heat in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Ripples of Rumination
description: VENICE  They park their hulking yachts with names like Lady Nag Nag, Wallys Love and Sea Force One on the choppy waters of the lagoon just outside the main entrance to the Venice Biennale. Every two years, scores of superrich collectors arrive here by sea, joined by museum directors, curators, artists and auction-house experts. They come to see and be seen and to take the temperature of contemporary art today.

title: Sharing a Festive Touch Of Iceland and Korea
description: There are two schools of thought about how to proceed when confronted with unfamiliar music, particularly a new piece. One school embraces a kind of Zen approach: the listener faces each work with no predisposition or prejudice, accepting and interpreting whatever comes. The other endorses coming to the encounter armed with some basic knowledge: since composers havent worked in a single, common style for centuries now, comprehension and appreciation are enhanced by knowing where a creator was  geographically, temperamentally, stylistically  when a given piece emerged.

title: Joining Forces for a Nostalgic Journey Through Jazz
description: The last thing that Wynton Marsaliss Swing Symphony needed was another movement.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Delegates Visit Moscow for Insight on Boston Attack
description: MOSCOW  Members of a Congressional delegation visiting Moscow to investigate the background of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects said Sunday that the attack might have been prevented by greater cooperation between the United States and Russia on intelligence issues and counterterrorism efforts.

title: How Obama Prevailed in 2012
description: Jonathan Alters revealing 2010 book, The Promise, provided a detailed look at President Obamas first year in office, tracing his decision-making process on issues like health care reform and the Afghanistan war. Mr. Alters highly informed, energetically reported but often tiresomely familiar new book, The Center Holds: Obama and His Enemies, is less a sequel than a chronicle of the presidents fight to win re-election and his continuing battles with an obstructionist Republican party.

title: Kentucky Derby Winner Looks Sharp and Will Join the Belmonts Field
description: Todd Pletcher sat in the center of Belmont Parks grandstand, binoculars pressed to his eyes and stopwatch in hand. His perfectly combed silver hair gave him away, not his subdued demeanor.

title: Eastern States Regional in Manhattan
description: R. Jay Becker of New York City was the most successful player at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month. He won three events, the Thursday A/X Pairs with Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.; the Friday Round Robin Teams with Michael Kopera and Eric Robinson of New York City, and Kamil; and the Reisinger Knockout Teams with Chris Willenken, Jared Lilienstein and Michael Polowan of New York City.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Weiner Gets Mixed Reception at Israel Day Parade
description: As he marched on Sunday in his first Israel Day Parade since resigning from Congress, Anthony D. Weiner encountered plenty of fans, as well as the first real sustained display of hostility toward his New York City mayoral ambitions.

title: Defying Naysayers, Gatsby Proves a Box-Office Winner
description: LOS ANGELES  If history is any indication, a Forbes report read on May 3, The Great Gatsby will bomb rather hard. BoxOffice.com at one point projected very soft opening-weekend sales of about $24 million. Early on, several studios were so worried about the movies multiplex prospects that they passed on making it.

title: Oklahoma Campus, Ravaged by a Tornado, Draws Attention to Storm Shelters
description: EL RENO, Okla.  It takes imagination to picture the Canadian Valley Technology Center as it used to be. Hundreds of adults and teenagers packed the classrooms at the vocational education campus here in the daytime and evenings, studying the art of welding, cosmetology and graphic design and learning to fix airplanes and cars by working on actual airplanes and cars.

title: As Harvey Struggles, the Mets Are Swept
description: MIAMI  Matt Harvey was not the Matt Harvey the Mets have grown accustomed to seeing this year. Neither was Ike Davis.

title: Nonstop Screwball Antics, Choreographed and Less So
description: The sounds of gunshots  and laughter  rang through the playhouse of Abrons Arts Center on Thursday as Yvonne Meier remounted her aggressively absurd 2006 work This is not a pink pony. The plastic deer onstage did not fall, but the three straight-faced screwballs did, many times. Then came the premiere of This is not a pink pony 2.

title: Satire Born in the Face of Horror
description: The Last Cyclist isnt participatory theater in any of the usual senses. No one is called up from Row C to answer trivia questions or dance a jig onstage. But if youre attending this intriguing exercise in Holocaust history, you should plan to show up in character. To appreciate what youre going to see, you need to be not a 21st-century theatergoer but rather a prisoner at Theresienstadt, the Nazi concentration camp near Prague.

title: A Tornado Chaser Falls Doing Extreme Science
description: The fleets of camera-laden sport utility vehicles that race around Tornado Alley stalking funnel clouds these days are mainly racing into harms way to gather gripping video and, as a result, spiking TV ratings or Web views.

title: Shoulder Injury Sidelines Conductor
description: Julian Wachner, a Grammy-nominated conductor and the director of music and the arts at the Trinity Church near Wall Street in Lower Manhattan, will put down his baton for a short time after injuring his shoulder.

title: Turkish Leader Says Protests Will  Not Stop Plans for Park
description: ISTANBUL  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey dismissed the tens of thousands of protesters who battled for two days with police officers in the streets of Istanbul as looters and bums on Sunday. He vowed to push ahead with plans to demolish a public park  a trigger for the spasm of public anger that left Istanbuls main commercial district strewn with graffiti and broken glass.

title: If Chorus Lines Be the Food of Love
description: Revelatory is not too strong a word to describe Brush Up Your Shakespeare: The Bard and the Broadway Musical, the rousing season finale of the 92nd Street Ys Lyrics & Lyricists series. The program, directed and hosted by Mark Lamos, who wrote the script with Deborah Grace Winer, explores the ways in which Shakespeares plays and poems have been adapted not only for Broadway but also for jazz experiments and the movies.

title: Buzz and Bleep
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I dont recall ever solving a puzzle that made me consider changing my dietary habits before, but Im thinking of becoming a vegetarian.

title: Non-prophet Economics
description: A few days ago Noah Smith had a good piece on the many people who beat their breasts and loudly boast about having predicted the crisis. As he says, by and large, the louder the boasting, the thinner the evidence for any special achievement. And anyway, also as he says, theres the question of what youre predicting. The housing bust? The fall of Lehman? The sluggishness of the recovery?

title: Wit, Poetry and Shadows
description: As Alexei Ratmanskys fascinating, poetic, enigmatic and bittersweet new Shostakovich Trilogy proceeds, it includes overlapping expressions of ebullience, struggle, heroism, community, affection, wit, brilliance and inspiration  but also of fear, vigilance, alarm, apprehension and grief. And the movement, more than with any previous works by Mr. Ratmansky, is often powerfully charged by qualities of strain and tension; you notice how dancers move from one position to the next, sometimes as if the air is heavier than water, sometimes as if holding onto each other while the rest of life is pulling them asunder.

title: The Spat
description: Aha. That piece of my interview with Fareed Zakaria is here. There was a lot more in the interview, but anyway, in this bit I think I said what had to be said.

title: A Contemporary Conversation With Beethovens Sonatas
description: Mannes College the New School for Music has offered an institute focusing on Beethoven for each of the past 12 years. This is the first season, the pianist Thomas Sauer said before a concert there on Friday, that Beethoven has shared the bill with a contemporary composer.

title: Wiggling Worms and Fluttering Birds
description: It was an odd menagerie that slithered, swam and fluttered onto the gallery floor at the Tenri Cultural Institute on Friday evening. A pair of dolphins. A pica pica and an ortolan. A belly-dancing worm.

title: A Band Sends Blaylock a Get-Well Wish After a Crash
description: The news that Mookie Blaylock, a former N.B.A. point guard, was involved in a car accident over the weekend hit the members of Pearl Jam like a tragedy in the family. In many ways, it was one.

title: Courting Thrifty Shoppers With Value and Quality
description: ALMOST five years after the financial crisis, the economy has improved significantly, but remains uncertain enough that millions of worried Americans continue to watch how they spend. That has left marketers and agencies trying to figure out the right tone and tack to take in selling products as varied as cars and cans of soup.

title: Protests Continue in Turkey
description: Thousands of Istanbul residents marched from Besiktas district to Taksim Square, in a massive public protest to the governments plans to redevelop the public park.

title: Economic Reports to Be Released This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the ISM manufacturing index for May, construction spending for April and domestic car and truck sales for May (Monday); United States trade deficit figures for April (Tuesday); the ADP jobs report for May, the ISM purchasing manager index for May, factory orders for April and the Federal Reserves Beige Book (Wednesday); weekly initial jobless claims (Thursday); and federal unemployment figures for May (Friday).

title: Player Ratings: Germany (3) vs. United States (4)
description: The United States national team celebrated U.S. Soccers 100th anniversary by breaking out of its offensive slump on Sunday, defeating Germany, 4-3, in an exhibition match at sweltering R.F.K Stadium in Washington.

title: Two Studies Challenge Avastins Effectiveness Against a Rare Brain Cancer
description: CHICAGO  Two new studies have found that the widely used cancer drug Avastin does not prolong the lives of patients with a deadly form of brain cancer, raising questions about the role of the drug in treating that disease.

title: After Impressive Win Over Germany, U.S. Has Smaller Fish to Fry
description: WASHINGTON  Sunday was supposed to be for looking back, a day for the United States soccer team to celebrate its history. A gala here Saturday honored the organizations centennial. Banners thanking the fans for 100 years of support were plastered all over R.F.K. Stadium. The players even wore retro jerseys, modeled after the teams 1916 uniforms, in the days exhibition match against Germany.

title: Few Women on Some Senate Committees
description: Explore current and past committee assignments for women in the Senate.

title: A Billionaire Dreams of Steering Europes Future
description: PARIS  Outside the secure elevator leading to his penthouse hotel suite at Le Bristol, Nicolas Berggruen handed a visitor his key.

title: Fighting to Save an Oyster Industry

Obviously it would be nice, eventually, to actually reduce debt. But if youve built your career around proclamations of imminent fiscal doom, this definitely wasnt the report you wanted to see.

title: Secrets and Leaks

Hes a shrink-the-government-then-drown-it-in-the-bathtub Texas Republican, a global warming denier, an N.R.A. 100-percenter, a devout foe of abortion rights. He comes from a political tribe that regards the mainstream media as a hive of Bolsheviks. Yet Poe and I see eye to eye on one thing. He is the main House sponsor of a bill intended to protect journalists from being compelled to give up information about their government sources, even when the sources have divulged matters of national security.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 4:15 P.M. (Sundance) GALLIPOLI (1981) The director Peter Weir follows two fleet-footed young Australians (Mark Lee and Mel Gibson) as they journey from the countryside to Perth and into the disastrous World War I battle in the Ottoman Empire. Beginning with a footrace, the film approaches the subject of war so obliquely that it cant properly be termed a war movie, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Besides, it is prettier than any war film has ever been, which makes its emotional power something of a surprise. Mr. Weirs work has a delicacy, gentleness, even wispiness that would seem not well suited to the subject. And yet his film has an uncommon beauty, warmth and immediacy, and a touch of the mysterious, too.

Tawana Brawley, a 15-year-old African-American girl from the New York City area, was said to have been abducted and repeatedly raped by six white men. She was found with KKK written across her chest, a racial epithet on her stomach and her hair smeared with feces. She was so traumatized, according to reports, that at the hospital she answered yes-or-no questions by blinking her eyes. description: The veteran New York actress Lois Smith and the playwriting patron Emilie Kilgore are among the recipients of the fourth annual Lilly Awards, which honor women working in the theater.

title: Vine, Twitters New Video Tool, Hits 13 Million Users
description: At the start of this year, Twitter introduced the mobile video app Vine, which let people shoot and share bite-size, six-second looping video clips. The service captivated users, who began making and uploading quirky short films, comedy bits and stop-motion animation, among other things.

title: No Easy Fix for Insider Trading
description: The government has made it a priority to root out insider trading, pursuing prominent hedge funds and securing dozens of convictions in recent years. And yet, a more comprehensive solution to end the illegal practice is elusive.

title: Seized Properties for Sale, But Shapes and Sizes Vary
description: A $17.75 million cooperative on Park Avenue; a two-bedroom condominium in the Financial District; a $4.495 million mansion on Long Island, owned by Peter B. Madoff; and a three-family apartment building in the South Bronx with a rat problem.

title: Pacers Starters Minutes Negate a Weak Bench
description: The Miami Heat won 66 regular-season games, six more than any other team in the N.B.A. They had the leagues most potent offense and were captained by LeBron James, the N.B.A. most valuable player and consensus best player in the world.

title: Kochs Sister to Amplify His Support for Quinn
description: Christine C. Quinns mayoral campaign will be graced by a touch of Koch after all.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Im Not Using the Word Love
description: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Jameson, 23, from New York City.

title: The Hidden Costs of Starting a Company
description: I was at a StartupsUncensored event some time ago where a speaker, Jason Nazar, the founder and chief executive of Docstoc, said: You can have your start-up and one thing. You can have your start-up and your health. You can have your start-up and your family. Or you can have your start-up and your significant other, but you cant have multiples. If you try to have multiples, youll be poor at all of them.

title: From Dominant to Merely Mighty
description: For some reason, the Miami Heat and the Chicago Blackhawks find themselves hitched together at the cosmic hip again this season. People were once debating their dominance  whether the Heats 27-game winning streak was more or less impressive than the Blackhawks season-opening 24-game point streak  and now they are openly wondering if this superteam business is not all it is cracked up to be. Because these two teams spent large chunks of the regular season and the early stage of the playoffs looking like the only big kids on the playground, and suddenly they are together at Six Flags with metal bars over their shoulders, bracing for the next big drop.

title: Believe Your Ears: B.J. Thomas Is Still at It
description: A few weeks ago I had Late Night With Jimmy Fallon on the TV when, from the next room, I heard a voice from my adolescence: that of B.J. Thomas. He was about the most popular male singer in my pop-music-attuned house in the late 60s and 70s, and he was pretty big everywhere else, too, with chartbusting hits like Hooked on a Feeling and Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head. I hadnt heard anything about Thomas in decades, and I wondered why Fallon was playing his records on the show, because the voice sounded just the same as it did on all his classics.

title: Justices Allow DNA Collection After an Arrest
description: WASHINGTON  The police may take DNA samples from people arrested in connection with serious crimes, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.

title: In the Pursuit of Longevity
description: At some point between George Washington and Colonel Sanders, white hair and a cane turned from symbols of elegance to suggestions of decrepitude, and an industry was born. Not that the fountain of youth wasnt always sought after. But to look young, think young, feel young  those are distinctly modern goals.

title: Really? Cycling Is the Top Sport for Head Injuries
description: THE FACTS

title: Trial Portrays Two Sides of Private in Leak Case
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning, whose secret release of a vast archive of military and diplomatic materials put WikiLeaks into an international spotlight, opened here Monday with dueling portrayals of a traitor who endangered the lives of his fellow soldiers and of a principled protester motivated by a desire to help society who carefully selected which documents to release.

title: F.D.A. Scientists Find No Serious Misconduct in Avandia Drug Tests
description: A review of a disputed clinical trial on the safety of the controversial diabetes drug Avandia did not uncover serious misconduct or fraud, according to findings by scientists at the Food and Drug Administration that were made public Monday.

title: The S.E.C. Is Bringin Sexy Back to Accounting Investigations
description: In April 2003, a New York Times article discussed the push by federal prosecutors to crack down on accounting fraud in which one expert said, These have become the hot, sexy cases.

title: Rituparno Ghosh, Bengali Film Director, Dies at 49
description: Rituparno Ghosh, an award-winning, internationally known Bengali director whose films about women, sexuality and urban life challenged conservative sensibilities in India, died on Thursday in Calcutta. He was 49.

title: Weekend Gun Report: May 31-June 2, 2013
description: On Thursday, 70-year-old retired U.S. Army Lt. Col. Ralph Wald, who found his wife, Johnna Lynn Flores, 41, having sex with another man on their living room floor in Tampa in March, was acquitted of second-degree murder after invoking Floridas Stand Your Ground law. His defense? He thought the man, 32-year-old Walter Conley, was raping his wife. In fact, Conley was later found to be Floress paramour, a fact that didnt seem to faze his legal team one bit.

title: Artificial Connections
description: Q. When you get a joint replacement, like a knee or hip, how exactly is the muscle attached to the artificial implant?

title: Commuters Nearly Double Manhattans Daytime Population, Census Says
description: If New Yorks bars and restaurants seem crowded at night, consider this: during the day, commuters from the other boroughs and outside the city nearly double Manhattans population, from 1.6 million to 3.1 million.

title: The Rectangled Square Puzzle
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by a Numberplay regular, Joe Fendel.

title: Step Aside, Jon Stewart: John Oliver Prepares to Host The Daily Show
description: For a little while on Thursday, while The Daily Show With Jon Stewart was on hiatus, John Oliver had the offices all to himself. In an otherwise deserted conference room on Manhattans West Side, Mr. Oliver, 36, the British-born comedian and Daily Show correspondent, was dressed casually and lounging beneath a giant National Geographic map of the world. Asked how he was doing, he replied, Im fine. He paused. Im excited. Another pause. Im nervous.

title: Tony Awards: In Performance With Courtney B. Vance
description: For this years Tony Awards edition of In Performance, The New York Times ditched the studio and went on location. As always, the videos capture short excerpts of songs or monologues performed without costumes or makeup. But instead of using our regular backdrop, we asked selected Tony nominees to shoot a scene at a New York City locale that reflects the personality of their character and the spirit of their show. Where would a no-nonsense newspaper editor from the play Lucky Guy go to vent about a high-strung journalist? Where would a modern-day Cinderella spend a romantic afternoon with her prince? You get the picture.

title: A Minimalist Jam? Well, Less Showy
description: Its a familiar but risky business strategy: underpromise and overdeliver.

title: Ford Is Recalling 465,000 Vehicles Over Possible Fuel Leaks
description: About 465,000 2013 Fords are being recalled worldwide because of concern about fuel leaks, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Ford says the Explorer, Taurus, Flex, Fusion and police models  the Interceptor Utility and Interceptor Sedan  are included in the recall, as are the Lincoln MKS, MKT and MKZ.

title: The Long Road Ahead for Tesla
description: The chief executive of Tesla, Elon Musk, has to sell 540,000 electric vehicles a year. At least that is what may be needed for the automaker to be worth $43 billion, according to a Breakingviews calculator.

title: China Heads to Space Again This Month
description: HONG KONG  Chinas next space mission begins this month when a capsule carrying three astronauts will dock with an orbiting module, a spokesman for the space program said Monday.

title: Two Principal Dancers to Leave Royal Ballet
description: Alina Cojocaru and Johan Kobborg, two of most admired principal dancers on the roster of the Royal Ballet, in London, announced on Monday that they would leave the company at the end of the current season. Their final performance at the Royal Opera House will be in Mayerling on Wednesday, although they will remain with the company for a visit to Japan, with performances in Tokyo on July 11 and 12.

title: Image of the Day: June 3
For Kidd, a Tough End to a Brilliant Career
description: He affected games without looking at the basket, made pinpoint bounce passes in transition to teammates and often left fans wondering what he was going to do next. Jason Kidd was the ultimate point guard for much of his 19-year career in the N.B.A., but at the end of his one season with the Knicks, his magic was no more.

title: A Mosquito That Wont Ruin a Barbecue
description: There are good evolutionary reasons that some species of mosquito developed a taste for humans: We tend to live in groups and are never far from water, which mosquitoes need to breed.

title: Oxbows Pedigree Is Rife With Belmont Success
description: Oxbows pedigree is littered with big names  Deputy Minister, Mr. Prospector, Raise A Native. His ancestors have had plenty of success at Belmont Park: Bold Reasoning set a new track record there for six furlongs when he was 4 years old, and Northern Dancer ran a surprising third in the 1964 Belmont Stakes. But two stars in particular jump out from his bloodline when thoughts turn to winning the Belmont: Man o War and Seattle Slew.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Monday Motorsports: Stewart Tames the Monster Mile
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uN_oc5bcUUQ

title: Death of Senator Places Christie in Difficult Spot
description: The death of Frank R. Lautenberg on Monday has left Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with the kind of opportunity that politicians usually covet: the chance to give away a seat in the United States Senate. But the decision is fraught with pitfalls, none bigger than having to choose between improving his partys fortunes in Washington and furthering his own political ambitions at home.

title: Street Style: Denim on Denim
description: The best of readers photos from the week of May 27.

title: Dining Calendar
description: The Sud de France Festival, which celebrates the food and culture of Frances Languedoc-Roussillon region, begins Monday and will feature several dinner parties, wine tastings, concerts, seminars, festive bus tours, a sommelier competition and more. The festival runs through June 23 and it starts Monday at 7:30 p.m. with a party at The Parks penthouse, 118 10th Avenue in Chelsea, with wine and live music. A series of dinners are scheduled at restaurants across the city that will feature food from the south of France, in particular the region of Languedoc-Roussillon, with dishes like cassoulet and cod brandade.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Ayzenberg Group, Pasadena, Calif., is opening an office in London, its first outside the United States. The office is being opened within the office of Holmes & Marchant, a London branding agency; the two agencies will work together in their respective areas of expertise.

title: 11 Afghan Children Killed in 2 Taliban Bombings
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban attacks in eastern Afghanistan on Monday killed 2 American soldiers and 17 Afghans, including at least 11 children, adding to a particularly deadly season for civilians this year.

title: The Pirate-Warden of Richmond
description: Capt. George Washington Alexander dressed for intimidation.

title: Bringing New York City Dance Into the Limelight
description: Some of the best-remembered moments in entertainment are dances set in New York City, in shows and movies like Guys and Dolls, On the Town, West Side Story, 42nd Street and The Band Wagon. Now comes a campaign that urges New Yorkers to support dance as an art form.

title: Floods Sweep Through Central Europe
description: Tens of thousands of people were evacuated, some carried on the backs of rescuers or by boat, in Central Europe as heavy rainfall in the past week swelled rivers that spilled over their banks and flooded streets, businesses and houses. News reports said at least seven people were killed.

title: Ex-President of Taiwan Attempts Suicide in Prison
description: BEIJING  Chen Shui-bian, a former president of Taiwan who is serving a 20-year prison sentence for corruption, tried to kill himself on Sunday, the Ministry of Justice said in a statement.

title: Ben Bernanke Endorses A 73 Percent Tax Rate
description: OK, he didnt actually say that in so many words. But if you follow through on the logic of his excellent speech at Princeton yesterday, thats where you end up.

title: Lautenbergs Death Continues Sharp Decrease in Military Veterans in Senate
description: The death Monday of Frank R. Lautenberg, the five-term Democratic senator from New Jersey, brought the number of World War II veterans in the Senate to zero, the first time the Senate has been without a World War II veteran since the war itself.

title: Judge Says Ft. Hood Shooting Suspect May Act as His Own Lawyer in Court
description: HOUSTON  The Army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 people in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood, Tex., in 2009 will represent himself when his trial begins next month, the latest twist in a long-delayed case that is likely to raise numerous legal questions and could provide him with a stage to promote his radical Islamic beliefs, experts in military law said.

title: Haas Gains Quarterfinals After Youzhnys Meltdown
description: PARIS  Tommy Haas of Germany rolled past Mikhail Youzhny of Russia in straight sets to join the lineup for the mens quarterfinals at the 2013 French Open.

title: Bill Cunninghams On the Street, Spoke Spinners
description: Always-rushing New Yorkers finally have a chance to discover the joy, freedom and speed of the new rental Citi Bikes. No waiting for cabs or buses, or on sweaty subway platforms: just unlock one and pedal off. Some have taken to scooters that can be folded up and carried into the office. Aside from the August closing of Park Avenue on Saturdays for cyclists, a few rules to follow: stay close to the curb, avoid pedestrians (who encroach on bike lanes at rush hour) and watch for cab doors being flung open. Despite the hazards, this pedaler, who has had about 30 bikes stolen, still enjoys the mobility of two wheels. Just dont lock your own bike to a Citi Bike terminal.

title: Snapshots From Venice
description: Highlights from the Venice Biennale by the chief art critic Holland Cotter with updates each day.

title: Why Young People Dont Vote Republican
description: There has been no shortage of Republican post-mortems on the 2012 presidential election  and no shortage of apologists who claimed the party need only change its rhetoric (and stop nominating members of the legitimate-rape caucus) to attract women, minorities and young people.

title: Jordan Blocks Local Access to News Sites
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The Jordanian government has blocked local access to about 300 news Web sites under a new law that the sites editors and international journalism experts have derided as dangerous censorship aimed at quelling criticism of King Abdullah II.

title: Sharon Jones Postpones Tour to Seek Cancer Treatment
description: The soul singer Sharon Jones has been diagnosed with cancer and has postponed a tour and the release of her next album, she announced on her bands Web site. The singer said she has stage 1 bile duct cancer, which has yet to spread, and will have surgery immediately to remove the tumor.

title: Ford Showing Its Vigor as Industry Recovers
description: For decades in Detroit, there was a clear pecking order among automakers: General Motors sold the most cars in the United States, followed by Ford Motor Company and then the Chrysler Group.

title: Shifting Cargo May Have Doomed Plane That Crashed Near Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Crash investigators in Afghanistan said Monday that quickly shifting cargo of heavy military vehicles contributed to the crash of a civilian cargo plane on April 29 in which all seven people aboard were killed.

title: Checking Trees as Hurricane Season Starts
description: Hurricane season began on Saturday, and the federal government is predicting an active or extremely active year. So if you live in a hurricane-prone area, now is a good time to inspect trees nearyour home for possible weakness that could lead to damage during a storm with strong winds.

title: Graceful Aging and Loss in Paris
description: PARIS  For a French Open that has yet to have a major upset, it has surely been a tournament full of big surprises and big swings of emotion.

title: Our Driven Elite (Trivial and Time-Wasting)
description: Like many of us, Atrios is still having fun with the hysterical WSJ screed against rental bicycles. Unusually for him, however, I think he fails to fully recognize the role of class in the whole discussion. He writes,

title: Australian Teen Goes from Main Draw Upset to Junior Defeat
description: PARIS  It was a rare moment of triumph for a junior player allowed into the mens main draw at a major when Nick Kyrgios, 18, a wild card entrant from Australia,carved out a masterful three-set upset of Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic in the first round of the French Open last week. But on Monday, Kyrgios found himself on the opposite end of an upset, when he lost in the first round of the junior championship, where he was the top seed.

title: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With The Leading Women of Broadway
description: 9:21 p.m. | Updated  Tonight ArtsBeat live streamed a conversation with six award-winning actresses on Broadway this season: Judith Light and Jessica Hecht from The Assembled Parties; Cicely Tyson from The Trip to Bountiful; Kristine Nielsen from Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike; Holland Taylor from Ann; and Maura Tierney from Lucky Guy. Click on the image above to watch the event, which was moderated by Patrick Healy, the theater reporter for The New York Times.

title: Manning Supporters Are Loud and Online
description: WASHINGTON  Call it Pfc. Bradley Manning Inc.

title: Wheelies: The More Subarus Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: What Did You Think of Whats Going On in This Picture?
description: Last October we introduced a new feature in which, each Monday morning this school year, we posted a New York Times photograph without a caption, then invited students to answer three deceptively simple questions about it:

title: Angelina Jolie Does Modern Grecian in London
description: The Girl: The actress (and recent New York Times Op-Ed contributor) at the world premiere of World War Z, the apocalyptic horror film starring her fianc, in London.

title: The Distasteful Side of Social Media Puts Advertisers on Their Guard
description: As social media sites pursue advertising in a bid for new revenue, they are finding that they must simultaneously create a safe space for the advertisers they attract.

title: Roving Runner, Turned Roving Biker
description: Brian Fidelman, who writes a running column for the Well blog, shares his experience with Citi Bike, New Yorks bike sharing system.

title: Ask About the 17-Year Cicada
description: Update, June 28 | We are no longer accepting questions for this article. Thanks for all your questions!

title: Walkabout  6/3: National Parks Graying Constituency; Less Revealing Body Scans at Airports
description: Old Faithfuls When it comes to supporting national parks likeYosemite, above, few traveler sets have been as reliable as baby boomers. But this critical constituency is also a graying one. (New York Times)

title: Left-Right Problems, Cicadaphobia, Bike-Sharing Around New York
description: What can happen when your body doesnt know its left from its right; the 17-year cicada as the stuff of nightmares; the Roving Runner picks up a Citi Bike.

title: Lautenbergs Seat and Bookers Chance
description: The Timess David M. Halbfinger discusses the legacy of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who died Monday, and how Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark could benefit.

title: Conservative Party Endorses Lhota for Mayor
description: The Conservative Party of New York State endorsed Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican, for mayor on Monday, all but ensuring that Mr. Lhota and his chief rival for the Republican nomination, John A. Catsimatidis, will both carry their campaigns into the November general election.

title: Growing Left, Growing Right
description: One day in 1788, students at the Hunterian School of Medicine in London were opening a cadaver when they discovered something startling. The dead mans anatomy was a mirror image of normal. His liver was on his left side instead of the right. His heart had beaten on his right side, not his left.

title: Plastic Bags to Keep Premature Babies Warm
description: In the United States, some very premature babies are swaddled in sterile plastic wrap to keep their body temperature from dropping dangerously. Now a study of newborns in Zambia suggests that the technique can be duplicated cheaply and effectively in poorer countries  using simple plastic bags.

title: Ray of Light in European Economic Data
description: FRANKFURT  In what passes for good news in Europe these days, a survey Monday showed that manufacturing in the euro zone was deteriorating more gradually than preliminary estimates had indicated. The slight improvement in economic data fed hope that the euro zone was in a temporary downturn and not stuck in a recession that could last for years.

title: Disputed Banksy Work Brings $1.1 Million at Auction
description: In the latest and perhaps final installment of one of the art worlds most amusing controversies of 2013, Slave Labor (Bunting Boy), the satirical work stenciled by the graffiti artist Banksy on a wall in North London, was sold at a private auction held by the London-based Sincura Group  which describes itself as concierge specialists who pride themselves on obtaining the unobtainable  on Sunday for what the BBC reported was more than 750,000, or about $1.1 million.

title: App Smart Extra: Timer Apps to Keep Track of Your Life
description: If you could have listened to the App Smart column the other week instead of just reading it, youd have heard the tick-tock of timer apps counting down. Far more flexible than kitchen timers of old, or even wristwatch timers, timer apps for smartphones and tablets can be very useful in helping you keep track of all sorts of timings.

title: Opening New Frontiers of Backyard Cookery
description: Meet a new gas-powered weapon to your outdoor cooking arsenal.

title: Videos and Final Tweets From Storm Chasers Killed in Oklahoma
description: In his final post on Twitter, Tim Samaras, a highly respected storm chaser whose work has been featured on the Discovery Channel and in National Geographic, shared his concern on Friday about the dangerous day ahead for Oklahoma.

title: Breaking Symmetry
description: A tiny pit lined with cilia helps the developing embryo distinguish left from right.

title: Frying Outdoors? Its No Mistake
description: Last year we became converts to gas. The odd thing about this is that weve spent 20 years and nine cookbooks very pointedly avoiding gas grills. So when we tell friends we have added a gas-powered weapon to our outdoor cooking arsenal, we get very skeptical looks.

title: Mozart and Haydn? Hes Jazzed
description: A magical moment arrives in every concert I have seen involving the conductor Nicholas McGegan, and it comes before any music has been made. It happened on Saturday night as the Orchestra of St. Lukes sat onstage at Carnegie Hall, ready for a program of canonical works by Mozart and Haydn. The stage door opened, and Mr. McGegan bounded out to the podium, beaming and exuding enthusiasm. This, not the opening bars of Mozarts Symphony No. 29 in A (K. 201), was the real start of the concert, which turned out to be one of the most appealing, satisfying performances I have heard this season. (The concert was originally scheduled for last November, but was postponed because of Hurricane Sandy.)

title: Jason Kidd Leaves the Game
description: Images of point guard Jason Kidd, who announced his retirement from the N.B.A. on Monday after 19 seasons.

title: Mens Use of Testosterone on the Rise
description: The number of middle-aged men with prescriptions for testosterone is climbing rapidly, raising concerns that increasing numbers of men are abusing the powerful hormone to boost their libidos and feel younger, researchers reported on Monday.

title: One Early Bird Restores Lineage of Another
description: Since its discovery in 1860, Archaeopteryx was widely considered to be the earliest known bird. But in 2009 a team of scientists decided it was more dinosaurlike than avian. Because of its reptilian metabolism and growth rate (slower than that of a bird), the transitional species should be removed from the bird family tree, the scientists said.

title: A New Baton for the Little Orchestra Society
description: James Judd, a British conductor who has been music director of the Florida Philharmonic  with which he made an acclaimed recording of Mahlers First Symphony  and the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra, has taken over his first New York ensemble, the Little Orchestra Society. He succeeds Dino Anagnost, who led the orchestra from 1979 until his death in 2011, and is the third director in the ensembles history, which goes back to 1947, when it was founded by Mr. Anagnosts predecessor, Thomas Scherman.

title: Check In | A Hotel in Dallas Where the Art Is as Impressive as the Rooms
description: Over the past decade, Dallas philanthropists have carried out a Texas-size effort to reinvent their city as a contemporary art and architecture capital. Now, visitors drawn to destinations like the vast new  Warehouse, the Nasher Sculpture Center and the revitalized Dallas Museum of Art have an equally enticing place to stay. Thanks to a $78 million renovation and expansion by the local oil and real-estate magnate and film financier Tim Headington, the Joule Hotel is now the citys go-to boutique hotel. But its also an art destination to rival its neighbors in the nearby Arts District.

title: A Love Letter to New York, Written by Consensus
description: Theres a tacit understanding in jazz circles that one path to success involves a sturdy, identifiable working band, and that another rests on high concept, or at least a central idea. The bassist Chris Lightcap has long been associated with the first camp: each of his three albums has featured a version of the same group, with two tenor saxophones out front. He calls it Bigmouth  after his second album, released a decade ago  and uses the band to bridge the gap between the rougher hinterlands of postbop and its calm stylistic center.

title: A Contemporary Dialogue With Beethovens Sonatas
description: Mannes College the New School for Music has offered an institute focusing on Beethoven for each of the past 12 years. This is the first season, the pianist Thomas Sauer said before a concert there on Friday, that Beethoven has shared the bill with a contemporary composer.

title: Stamp! Clap! Its Their 30th
description: For the company Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana to survive in New York, as it has, for 30 years, Carlota Santana, the co-founder and artistic director, must have made many sage decisions. But when the troupe opened its anniversary season at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, one particular decision stuck out: her hiring of the dancer ngel Muoz.

title: Another Butter Location
description: Alex Guarnaschelli, Scott Sartiano and Richie Akiva,who have owned Butter on Lafayette Street in NoHo for 10 years, plan to open an uptown branch in July. The new restaurant, which will also be called Butter, will have a garden, and the owners plan to open that in about two weeks to take advantage of the season. They will serve cocktails and light food outdoors.

title: However You Spell It, a Knaidel Tastes Good
description: Arvind V. Mahankali of Bayside, Queens, won the Scripps National Spelling Bee last week on the strength of his mastery of knaidel, a Yiddish word of German origin (and, it turns out, somewhat ambiguous spelling) for the dumplings that go into, among other things, matzo ball soup.

title: Obama to Nominate 3 to Fill Posts on Key Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate a slate of three candidates on Tuesday to fill the remaining vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, a White House official said Monday.

title: Kerry Says U.S. Came Late to Syrian Peace Effort
description: WASHINGTON  The United States came late to efforts to find a political settlement to the war in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday, as the crisis there deepened with the political uncertainty in neighboring Turkey.

title: What Makes a Jewish Mother
description: I was 42 when my husband and I began trying to have a child. Three years later, I finally accepted it wasnt going to happen naturally. We narrowed our options to two: use eggs donated by another woman, or adopt.

title: Tony Contenders in Battle of the Box Office
description: The new Broadway musicals Kinky Boots and Matilda may be the front-runners for the Tony Award for best musical to be announced on Sunday, but theres no contest between the two shows at the box office so far. Kinky Boots has beaten Matilda nine out of the 13 weeks that they have been running head-to-head, including last week, when Kinky Boots grossed $1,340,238 while Matilda took in $1,157,633.

title: A Renewed Effort to Rename a Street Honoring a Soviet Spy
description: When Susan LaRosa became director of marketing for the Henry Street Settlement a few years ago, she peered out her window at the plaza below and wondered about its namesake: Who was Samuel Dickstein?

title: Rising Aggression Against Turtle Conservationists Preceded Costa Rica Slaying
description: The Tico Times in Costa Rica has been providing valuable updates since the murder late last week of Jairo Mora Sandoval, a 26-year-old guardian of sea turtle nests on Mon Beach on the countrys Caribbean coast near the town of Limn. Read on for an excerpt from the latest dispatch, which shows clearly that the threat to conservationists, including Sandoval, had been building before he was kidnapped, bound, beaten, shot in the head and left on the sand.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Tumblr and College Admissions, and an X-Rated App for Google Glass
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.How College Admissions Officers Vet Students Onlinebuzzfeed.com | Yes, they know about your Tumblr.  Jenna Wortham

title: Ask the Next Mayor a Question
description: The Editorial Board would like your help. New York City is getting a new mayor, and were getting ready to decide  from a field of about a dozen candidates  who we think it should be.

title: Apocalypse and Other Love Stories
description: Summers here, and so is the end of the world.

title: Damon, Baranski Join Lineup for Delacorte Event on Shakespeare, Money and Morals
description: Matt Damon, Christine Baranski and Gloria Reuben will join the lineup of noted actors scheduled to appear at What Are We Worth? Shakespeare, Money, And Morals, a one-night free event at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday, June 17 at 8 pm.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, China, Gaza City and Afghanistan.

title: The Light Switches Are in Manhattan, the Powers From New Jersey
description: Not that they would have noticed, but some Manhattanites are now using electricity imported from New Jersey through a new underwater connection.

title: Continental Grain to Walk Away From Smithfield
description: 5:19 p.m. | Updated One of Smithfield Foods biggest investors plans to drop its fight against the pork processor in light of its planned $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese meat producer.

title: Slathering on Sunscreen Shows Results
description: People who diligently use sunscreen every day can slow or even prevent for a time the development of wrinkles and sagging skin, a new study found. Although dermatologists have long told people to use sunscreen to prevent aging, this is the first research to show an actual effect on the appearance of skin, researchers said.

title: Girl Group Just Wants to Be Famous (Again)
description: The Electric Barbarellas was the name of a girl group and of an MTV reality show featuring the group that ran for six episodes in the spring of 2011. Both would have come and gone largely unnoticed, if Sumner Redstone hadnt picked up the phone.

title: In This Play Festival, There Are No Second Acts
description: Ensemble Studio Theaters annual one-act-play marathon is always entertaining and rich in solid performances, but each of the bills  Series A, B and C  often has one play that stands out. For Series B this year its A Sunrise in Times Square, by Sharr White (The Other Place, on Broadway). The play may be no better written than others on the program, but the marvelous performances by Julie Fitzpatrick and Joseph Lyle Taylor carry it to another level.

title: Still Balanchines Students
description: The three ballets performed by the School of American Ballet last weekend in its annual Workshop presentation were a heady infusion of beauty, consisting of pure dancing  nothing but dancing to music. The choreography for each was by Balanchine; the music was by Mozart, Ravel and Gounod and finely played by the Workshop Orchestra, conducted with lan by Daniel Capps. Attending the first of the three performances on Saturday afternoon, I regretted that the busiest period of New Yorks ballet year prevented me from seeing the others.

title: Microsoft Weighs Restructuring
description: Microsoft is considering mixing up the responsibilities of its top executives as it seeks to further its transformation into what Steve Ballmer, Microsofts chief executive, calls a devices and services company.

title: A Case of Cicadaphobia
description: For some the coming of the 17-year cicada is less a marvel of science, more a nightmare scenario.

title: Harmless, but They May Cause Paralysis
description: In 2004, when the cicadas of Brood X crawled out of the ground in and around Washington, Lori Milani, then a full-time student, would not set foot outside her apartment. Terrified of insects, she shut her windows tight, sometimes with the blinds drawn, for five weeks. She stocked up on food, canceled her summer classes and had friends run essential errands for her.

title: A Girls Secret Sin, Then Rarefied Exile
description: The ingredients of Anton DiSclafanis first novel, The Yonahlossee Riding Camp for Girls, sound as if theyd been plucked from two genres: the young-adult category and the historical romance. Ms. DiSclafani gives us an elite boarding school where wealthy debutantes perfect their riding skills and prepare for the big spring horse show; an impetuous, headstrong heroine, who often seems like a 1930s version of Scarlett OHara; and a mysterious accident that has left one teenager brain-damaged and two others guilty and haunted. In her story there are echoes of A Separate Peace, John Knowless 1959 prep-school classic about two friends on the eve of World War II, as well as of Curtis Sittenfelds more recent boarding school novel,  Prep.

title: Hot 97s Summer Jam in East Rutherford
description: Nicki Minaj, 2 Chainz, ASAP Rocky and Kendrick Lamar were among the performers at the 20th edition of the annual concert.

title: Making Sense of the Air
description: Advances in 3-D printing and cellphone connectivity are allowing citizens to monitor the air pollution in their own neighborhoods.

title: Who Is Xi Jinping?
description: The Timess China correspondents discuss the countrys new president, Xi Jinping, who will meet with President Obama this week.

title: Microsampling Air Pollution
description: Near the corner of Tillary and Jay Streets in Brooklyn, Michael Heimbinder stood near a blue mailbox, head down, poking at his smartphone. A graph appeared: a single line plotting ambient carbon monoxide exposure in the neighborhood.

title: Maxwells in Hoboken to Close in July
description: Maxwells, the Hoboken restaurant and bar that has been one of the most influential indie-rock clubs in New Jersey, is closing down at the end of July, The Star-Ledger reported.

title: U.S. Cites Phone Calls in Apple Pricing Case
description: The United States government said on Monday that there were 100 phone calls among top executives of the publishing industry in the weeks leading up to Apples introduction of the iPad in 2010, when they had to decide whether to sign on to a deal with Apple that would raise the prices of e-books.

title: Finding a High-Yield Checking Account
description: Interest rates on most savings and checking accounts remain anemic. But for those who are comfortable with electronic banking and who are active debit-card users, high-yield checking accounts offered by smaller, regional banks and credit unions can be a more lucrative option.

title: At 90, Still Riveting the Minds Eye
description: Ellsworth Kelly has been on earth for 90 years  his birthday was Friday  and he has been making abstract art for over 60 of them. Now the New York art world is treating him, and us, to a big party. His boldly colored, emblematic paintings and reliefs can be seen in five exhibitions around town. In unusually gorgeous terms, they attest to a lifelong fusion of austerity and high spirits, and a narrow yet deep exploration of pure colors and simple shapes.

title: Photographs From the Week in Sports
description: From the French Open to baseball to the European handball championship, a look at sports action from across the world during the week of May 27.

title: A Room of Ones Own  With a Tub
description: I have an original design sketch by the legendary interior decorator Albert Hadley (above) that my mom gave me. It is my dream room: a luxurious hideaway that combines the dressing room and study with an oversize tub. If it were mine, I would have to be wrenched from the space. And some of the finer-heeled working mothers in London seem to feel the same. Last week I went with a friend to look at a potential new house where, on the second floor, there was a double reception room split by a central staircase. We instantly felt that the oversize space should become the master bedroom suite and devised the perfect boudoir floor plan on a napkin in Toms Deli after the viewing. The bath would go in the center of the room, opposite the fireplace. A folding screen would double as shelving for bath products on one side, and a bulletin board  covered in felt and trellised with ribbon  for the desk on the other side. It would also add an element of privacy, blocking the tub from the door that opens off the landing.

title: Ancient Plants, a Cosmic Fund-Raiser, Atoms in Motion and More
description: In science, popular ideas are often discarded once new evidence comes along, then revived in the face of still newer evidence. In the Observatory column this week, Douglas Quenqua reports on the long-running debate over whether the early winged creature Archaeopteryx ought to be considered a bird or a dinosaur. Paleontologists have gone back and forth on the issue, but the discovery of a dinosaur even older than Archaeopteryx has now given comfort to the bird camp.

title: Improving Stephens Exits With 2 Other U.S. Women
description: PARIS  Two days ago, Sloane Stephens noted that she was 20 and could do whatever she wanted. The statement seemed less the mutterings of an entitled athlete as it was a recognition by Stephens that as many complications as her newfound success might cause, she has to remember her life  from serves to shopping sprees  is pretty enjoyable for someone of any age.

description: In 1936 Fortune magazines editors assigned a relatively unknown and disgruntled staff writer named James Agee to travel to Alabama for the summer and chronicle the lives of sharecroppers. When Agee returned, he was inspired by the subjects he had met and lived with, but frustrated by the limitations of the magazine format. His subjects, he argued, warranted far more than an article.

title: Continuing to Reduce Costs, Zynga Lays Off 520 Employees
description: Zynga has been trying to leap the yawning gap from Web-based games, where it thrived, to the entirely different and more brutal world of mobile. Monday, it fell into the abyss.

title: A Tale of Wall St. Excess
description: Turney Duff, former stock trader, recovering cocaine user and first-time author, stepped out the front door of his new home, the ground floor of a modest split-level house in a sleepy Long Island neighborhood.

description: General Motors is on its way to repaying American taxpayers for its 2009 bailout, but this week the carmaker will distinguish another milestone.

title: Behind the Rise in House Prices, Wall Street Buyers
description: The last time the housing market was this hot in Phoenix and Las Vegas, the buyers pushing up prices were mostly small time. Nowadays, they are big time  Wall Street big.

title: Violent Crime in U.S. Rises for First Time Since 2006
description: Violent crime rose in the United States in 2012 for the first time in six years, led by an increase in major crimes in large cities, according to preliminary data released Monday by the F.B.I.

title: Intels New Slogan Shifts Its Focus to the Present
description: THE sponsors of tomorrow have determined that consumers are more interested in the present than the future.

title: Justice Department Defends Holders Testimony
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Monday formally told House Republicans that Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.s testimony before a Congressional committee last month was accurate and consistent with the facts.

title: Treatment Still Harsh for Roma in France
description: PARIS  In the last three weeks alone, the French police have dismantled Roma encampments in Saint-Denis, just outside Paris, and along the Var River west of Nice. In Lyon, 200 Roma were temporarily housed in a gymnasium when someone set fire to their squat in a disused factory, killing two women and a 12-year-old.

title: L.I. Representative Faces Treatment for Lung Cancer
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Carolyn McCarthy, a Democrat from Long Island, announced on Monday that she has a treatable form of lung cancer.

title: An Earlier Hedge Fund Inquiry May Have Led to the SAC Capital Case
description: Some trades by Raj Rajaratnams younger brother in a technology stock nearly seven years ago may have inadvertently put SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund behemoth founded by Steven A. Cohen, on regulators radar, government documents show.

title: Stewardesses Blazed a Trail in Feminism
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago I inadvertently stirred up the ire of some flight attendants when I wrote that they complain about working conditions even more than those champion complainers, pilots.

title: Wall Street Transfixed by SAC Deadline
description: For most of the day Monday, a report about the investor exodus at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was the most-viewed article on the Bloomberg data terminals that permeate Wall Street trading floors.

title: U.S. Manufacturing Gauge Falls to June 2009 Level
description: WASHINGTON  A measure of United States manufacturing fell in May to its lowest level since June 2009 as slumping overseas economies and a pullback in business spending reduced new orders and production.

title: A Youthful Corps Whose Esprit Comes From Hustle
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Every morning before dawn breaks, Mujeeb Hamdard awakes in the mud-walled house where he lives in east Kabul, and starts his trek toward the place he feels most at home.

title: State Department Offers Rewards for Terrorist Leaders
description: The State Department announced that it was offering rewards for information leading to the location of the leaders of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, as well as other terrorist organizations operating in North and West Africa. The rewards, the first for the region, include $5 million each for the leader of the Qaeda regional franchise, Yahya Abu el-Hamman, and for Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the leader of a group that carried out a raid on a gas plant in Algeria that led to the deaths of at least 37 hostages, including 3 Americans. The department offered up to $7 million for information on Abubakar Shekau, the leader of Boko Haram, an Islamist group in Nigeria.

title: Egypt: Activist Sentenced to Prison for Insulting Morsi
description: An Egyptian court sentenced an activist to six months in prison on Monday on charges that he insulted President Mohamed Morsi and circulated false news on television. The prison sentence is the first for insulting the president since Mr. Morsi came to power last year. The activist, Ahmed Douma, was expected to post bail and be released on Monday pending the appeal of his case. He was arrested in April after calling Mr. Morsi a killer and criminal, which the court ruled could undermine state security. Egypt has seen a sharp rise in court cases for libel and blasphemy since the revolution in 2011.

title: Its Nice to Be Recognized, but Mortifying Too
description: I REMEMBER taking a flight to Disneyland when I was about 4. I was so excited. It was like I was flying to the moon. I got used to flying pretty quickly, traveling between Arizona, where I lived, to visit family in California. Then in the 1980s, I worked as a model in Japan and taught English. So again, more plane time.

title: A Dispute Over Restrictions in a U.S. Auction of Airwaves
description: WASHINGTON  In the mobile high-speed Internet market, the Obama administration believes it may be necessary to limit competition in order to promote it.

title: U.S. Adds to Its List of Sanctions Against Iran
description: The Obama administration escalated sanctions pressure against Iran on Monday for the third time in a week, taking actions that could further weaken the countrys already-devalued currency and seriously disrupt its automotive industry, a significant domestic employer and revenue generator for the Iranian government.

title: Toner, Often Met With a Shrug, Is Having Its Moment
description: As temperatures climb, our thoughts turn to toner: that post-cleansing, pre-moisturizing, cooling concoction treasured in adolescence (Sea Breeze, Bonne Bell Ten O Six) for its ability to remove facial grime onto a cotton ball. Some insist that even in adulthood, their beauty routine would be incomplete without it. Others think its an unnecessary step, scoffing that toner, while often refreshing, doesnt offer any real benefits to the complexion.

title: Blacks Are Singled Out for Marijuana Arrests, Federal Data Suggests
description: WASHINGTON  Black Americans were nearly four times as likely as whites to be arrested on charges of marijuana possession in 2010, even though the two groups used the drug at similar rates, according to new federal data.

title: Malware That Drains Your Bank Account Thriving on Facebook
description: In case you needed further evidence that the White Hats are losing the war on cybercrime, a six-year-old so-called Trojan horse program that drains bank accounts is alive and well on Facebook.

title: Promising New Cancer Drugs Empower the Bodys Own Defense System
description: CHICAGO  The early success of a new class of cancer drugs, revealed in test results released here over the last several days, has raised hope among the worlds top cancer specialists that they may be on the verge of an important milestone in the fight against the disease.

title: Chief of Staff at Rutgers Facing Discrimination Lawsuit
description: In early April, as the Rutgers president, Robert L. Barchi, was working to defuse a coaching abuse scandal, he named Gregory S. Jackson, a university administrator, to be his chief of staff.

title: Connecticut Approves Labeling Genetically Modified Foods
description: Connecticut on Monday became the first state to pass a bill that would require food manufacturers to label products that contain genetically modified ingredients  but only after other conditions are met.

title: How Christie Can Maximize the G.O.P.s Chances in New Jersey
description: The death of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, creates a confusing electoral situation in the state. There are conflicting interpretations of exactly what New Jerseys law requires  whether a special election should be held this November, when Gov. Chris Christie will be up for re-election, or in November 2014, when Mr. Lautenbergs term was set to expire. In the interim, Mr. Christie, a Republican, has the option of appointing a senator, but he is not required to do so.

title: Taking Account of Risk
description: Paul Tracy remembers it well. He had just arrived in Luanda, Angola, at 4 a.m. when an immigration officer approached him. Your visas not right, Mr. Tracy, a seasoned traveler, remembers being told. The dates wrong. The officer then asked for several hundred dollars.
