title: As Turks Challenge Their Leaders Power, He Tries to Expand It
description: ISTANBUL  After days of demonstrations that have presented Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan with his worst political crisis in more than a decade of power, the Turkish leader responded on Monday with a supremely confident flourish: he simply turned his back and left, boarding a plane to start a four-day good-will tour of Northern Africa.

title: Add Tear Gas and Stir: Images of Police Brutality Fuel Anger in Turkey
description: Last Updated, Tuesday, 10:52 a.m. As Sebnem Arsu reports, protests continued for a fourth day in major Turkish cities on Monday, one day after Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan blamed the unrest on what he called lies circulating on Twitter and other social networks.

title: Bringing a Cup to the City by the Bay
description: This years Americas Cup promises to transform San Francisco and its waterfront, though with a month before the start of the competition, some worry it wont be successful.

title: A Selfless Star of Rare Skills Says Goodbye
description: Point guard Jason Kidd, who announced his retirement Monday, two weeks after a disappointing end to his first season with the Knicks, was the most unusual of N.B.A. superstars. He was a basketball savant who could dominate a game without scoring, who preferred passing to shooting, who elevated his team with his intelligence alone.

title: Why the Court Was Right to Allow Cheek Swabs
description: SOMETHING astonishing happened Monday: Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Courts longest-serving member and one of its most conservative justices, joined three liberal justices in a sharply worded dissent arguing for the rights of criminal suspects.

title: Dont Trust the Pentagon to End Rape
description: LOS ANGELES  THE Senate Armed Services Committee will hold a hearing today on sexual assault in the military. This comes after months of revelations of rapes and other violent attacks at military bases and academies. At the hearing, the chiefs of staff of the military branches will likely admit that there is a serious problem and insist that the solution involves changing military culture. But the challenge goes far deeper.

title: The Meanest Season
description: If my body is a buffet, summer is the server who rips the metal covers off the roast beef and the scalloped potatoes so that the hordes can start feeding. And feed they do, mosquitoes and ants and for all I know spiders. (Im never sure which tiny glutton has made off with the most of me.)

title: The Way to Produce a Person
description: Dylan Matthews had a fascinating piece about a young man named Jason Trigg in The Washington Post on Sunday. Trigg is a 25-year-old computer science graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has hit upon what he thinks is the way he can do maximum good for the world. He goes to work each day at a high-frequency trading hedge fund. But, instead of spending his ample salary, he lives the life of a graduate student and gives a large chunk of his money away.

title: Turkeys Authoritarian Turn
description: THE huge demonstrations that engulfed Istanbul over the weekend were initially prompted by a small grievance: the governments decision to build a shopping mall and a replica of Ottoman military barracks in an old, much beloved park where I played as a child. The impending destruction of Gezi Park and Taksim Square, an important civic space with beautiful water fountains and flower stands, has touched a nerve because it seems an effort to erase the face of the old, majestic Istanbul, which has largely disappeared in recent years in favor of shallow, gaudy, stupefied consumerism.

title: Elite in China Molded in Part by Tiananmen
description: BEIJING  For four days, more than 400 of Chinas brightest political minds gathered in smoke-clouded halls at a Beijing hotel, vigorously debating the nations future.

title: U.S. Drops Plan on Screening of Statue Visitors
description: In the staredown at New York City Hall over the Statue of Liberty, the National Park Service blinked.

title: DNA and Suspicionless Searches
description: Alonzo Jay King Jr. was arrested in Maryland on assault charges in 2009. When he was booked into jail, the police took a sample of his DNA by swabbing the inside of his cheek without a warrant to collect his DNA or probable cause to think it would link him to any crime. His DNA profile matched evidence from a rape in 2003, and he was convicted of that rape.

title: A Smart Change in Iran Policy
description: The Obama administration has made a useful modification to its Iran policy by lifting sanctions on companies that want to sell cellphones, laptops, encryption software and other similar technology to ordinary Iranians. This should improve the ability of Iranians to circumvent their governments unrelenting crackdown on dissenting opinion and communicate with each other and the outside world without reprisal.

title: An Unnecessary Military Expense
description: At a time when the United States government is under pressure to cut spending, and every dollar counts, some members of Congress are pushing for a new missile defense site, possibly on the East Coast, that could eventually cost at least $3.6 billion. The proposal is premature at best and could actually harm Americas national security by denying resources to other more urgently needed and more effective defense programs.

But on Monday, The Guardian, a British newspaper, reported that the actor Michael Douglas believed that his throat cancer was caused by an infection acquired during oral sex, highlighting a trend that has alarmed many scientists.

title: When Billionaire Sets Rules, Its an Exclusive Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Victory in the Americas Cup of 2010 gave Larry Ellison, the tech titan who had spent hundreds of millions of dollars trying to capture sailings ultimate prize, the right to set the rules for this years regatta.

title: Young Victim Was Drawn by Street Fight, Jury Is Told

description: The New York Police Department announced on Monday that it was putting more officers in certain neighborhoods to suppress further violence after 26 people were shot and 7 were killed during a 72-hour period from Friday to Sunday.

title: Connecticut Legislature Approves Budget
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut legislators on Monday passed a two-year, $37.6 billion budget that includes a large expansion of gambling and reflects the degree to which Connecticut faces continuing financial budget distress despite passing a record $1.5 billion tax increase in 2011.

title: What to Watch on Day 10 at the French Open
description: The field shrinks further for this quarterfinal stage, from eight singles matches per day to four. But though the field is slimming, the schedule is not fan- or television-friendly; matches will remain stretched across two courts, largely to sell more tickets  meaning that the womens quarterfinals and then the mens quarterfinals will be simultaneous, making it impossible to watch all the action in its entirety. Play also starts three hours later, meaning that those who have been waking up on 5 a.m. on the East Coast for the start of play can wait all the way until 8 a.m.

title: Polio Virus Discovered in Sewage From Israel
description: The Polio virus has been found in a sewage sample from Israel for the first time since 2002, the World Health Organization announced on Monday. But no children or adults newly paralyzed by polio have been identified in Israel or in Gaza or the West Bank.

title: Computer-Assisted Vision
description: Liat Negrin, an employee at OrCam who has limited sight, demonstrates the Orcam device, which helps her cross streets, read menus and shop at the supermarket.

title: Device From Israeli Start-Up Gives the Visually Impaired a Way to Read
description: JERUSALEM  Liat Negrin, an Israeli who has been visually impaired since childhood, walked into a grocery store here recently, picked up a can of vegetables and easily read its label using a simple and unobtrusive camera attached to her glasses.

title: Hints of a Bigger Drama Awaiting Miami
description: MIAMI  Besides going the distance and sparing the N.B.A. a yawning gap at the height of its 2013 postseason, the Eastern Conference finals may best be remembered for fast forwarding the overriding narrative for the 2013-14 regular season.

title: Some Republicans See I.R.S. Troubles as Means to a Big Goal: Tax Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  When Representative Dave Camp, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, calls conservative activists to the witness table on Tuesday to talk about their experiences in seeking a tax exemption from the Internal Revenue Service, his chief aim will not be to scar the Obama administration or to fuel the continuing Congressional inquiries.

title: Viktor Kulikov Dies at 91; Led Warsaw Pact Forces

description: MIAMI  The beacon that drew LeBron James to South Beach on that fateful July day three years ago was not a glowing trophy or the bright, bright Florida sun. It was the promise of a partnership and the certain glory that would come with it.

title: How Much Is Michael Bolton Worth to You?
description: A few weeks ago, I met Barry Arakelian a minute after he got scammed at a Tom Petty concert. Arakelian had paid a scalper $375 for two tickets (face value: $135) outside the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. The tickets, however, turned out to be fakes, and Arakelian, who was getting the evil eye from his girlfriend, approached a nearby police officer for help. But the officer said that he couldnt do anything unless Arakelian could locate the scalper in the crush of people. By that point the scalper was long gone; Arakelian was embarrassed. Naturally, a minute later, he turned and shouted to no one in particular, Whos got two tickets?

title: A Company Flourishes by Selling Social Transformation

title: Check In | A Venetian Palace With a View
description: The 25-room Aman Canal Grande opens this month in Venices San Polo neighborhood. You would be hard pressed to beat its setting, perched on the Grand Canal in the 16th-century Palazzo Papadopoli, an example of Venetian neo-Renaissance and rococo architecture at its finest. The new hotel preserves much of the palazzos original artwork, including frescoes by the 18th-century Italian artist Giovanni Battista Tiepolo (now decorating the Amans Italian and Thai restaurants). San Polo itself is one of Venices less chaotic, residential districts, with the Rialto Market and the Scuola Grande di San Rocco a few minutes away by foot. Guest rooms have silk walls, twinkling chandeliers and views of private gardens. The hotels garden terrace faces onto the Grand Canal, and from the roof, when clear weather permits, you can see past Venices chimney pots and terra cotta rooftops all the way to the Swiss Alps.

title: Wawrinka Proves Tireless in Stopping Gasquet in Fourth Round

After Gasquet outplayed Wawrinka in the first two sets, Wawrinka settled in for the long haul, lengthening out points as he tried to break down his French rival. Wawrinka told reporters after the match, When I was 2-0 down, I was thinking something really simple. I was thinking: point after point I was thinking to make him work, to make him work hard, because I know if he start to be a little bit tired, then hes not doing so much with his racquet, hes not pushing so much pressure.

title: Bubbles With Bluefish, but Not Necessarily Champagne
description: Bubbles go beautifully with fried foods, but bubbly doesnt always have to mean Champagne. With these savory flavors, which will be deeper and more assertive if you choose bluefish, I would skip the cavas, sekts and proseccos to seek out a good, dry sparkling Vouvray, from the chenin blanc grape, which has a slightly richer texture than most Champagnes. Chenin blanc has a flavor that suggests a combination of lemon and honeysuckle that you feel as much as you taste; texturally it will meld well with the crisp panko crust. For a surprise twist, and particularly if you use bluefish, you could try a sparkling red, like a savory Lambrusco. Just make sure the label says secco, for dry, and not amabile, for slightly sweet.

description: CHICAGO  As the Walgreen Company expands its sales items to fresh salads, Redbox DVD rentals and digital photo scanners, among other products, its consumption of power keeps inching up.

And, yes, hes giving them away.

My first party was only 50 people, Gruosi said during a rare quiet moment in the nights proceedings, which included a fashion show, fireworks and a 500-person seated dinner. He reclines on his back and rests the airplane on his chest. Its not the smoothest of takeoffs.

They will borrow, on average, $24,803 to earn their degrees. While this continues to be one of the smartest investments they will ever make, Congress should take one step toward making it an even smarter one.

title: Transportation Security Administration Report on Profiling
description: The inspector general of the Transportation Security Administration released a report on screening practices at airports.

description: In Syria, C.J. Chivers profiles Grandsons of the Prophet, a rebel unit, on its march south toward Homs.

title: Jewish Identity, Spelled in Yiddish
description: LAST Thursday, a 13-year-old boy won the Scripps National Spelling Bee by spelling knaidel, Yiddish for matzo ball. But the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, which created the standard Yiddish transliteration now used in libraries around the world, holds that the correct spelling is kneydl.

description: Jefferson County, Ala., took a big step toward resolving its historic bankruptcy case on Tuesday, saying it had reached an agreement to refinance most of the debt at the heart of its financial breakdown.

title: Filly Will Face the Boys, and Resemble Them
description: It is not done lightly or often, leading a filly into the paddock of a Triple Crown race and hoping she is tough and fast enough to hold her own against the boys. And for good reason. Only three fillies have won the Kentucky Derby, five the Preakness Stakes and three the Belmont Stakes.

title: Gov. Christies Quick, Costly Decision
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey had a straightforward choice in filling the Senate vacancy left by the death of Senator Frank Lautenberg on Monday. He could have added the Senate race to the general election on Nov. 5, the day he is up for re-election in what is expected to be an easy glide into a second term. Instead, he called for a special election on Oct. 16, a Wednesday, with a primary on Aug. 13  a schedule that might give him a small political advantage but at considerable and needless cost to state taxpayers.

title: Advise and Consent
description: On Tuesday, when President Obama made the unusual gesture of personally introducing his three nominees for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, he said that Americans would consider it a judicial crisis if the Supreme Court were similarly shortstaffed. The president did not come right out and say it, but he should have: The severe breakdown in the process for approving federal judges in the Senate has been especially hard on that critically important appeals court.

title: Getting to Know You
description: This weeks summit meeting between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China is an important opportunity for the leaders of the worlds two largest economies to chart a smoother path and avoid the destructive conflicts that have historically afflicted relations between rising and established powers.

title: Israel Lives the Joseph Story

The good news for Israel is that in the near term its near neighbors are too internally consumed to think about threatening it. In the long run, though, Israel faces two serious challenges that Id dub the Stephen Hawking Story and the Joseph Story.

title: Im Melting! Is No Stretch
description: Am I repeating myself? asks the addled woman in the hospital bed. Yes, she certainly is, but then Evelyn Armstrong, played with starchy verve by Kathleen Chalfant, can be forgiven for this and some other lapses, like those jokes she keeps making for the benefit of her caretakers unborn baby. Evelyn is on a morphine drip, and a painful death from cancer looms.

Some constructors come in quietly and make their mark, but Mr. Bickham is bringing the noise: his grid ends with a BANG! Hopefully, Mr. Bickham is not aiming for the EMUS at 14 Across.

title: A Hunt for a Deadly Sniper From Two Perspectives
description: During the 2010 assault on Marja in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, Cpl. Thomas Gibbons-Neff was the leader of a Marine Corps scout sniper team that came under fire from a Taliban sniper. The sniper, like others in the area, had proved surprisingly effective, and Corporal Gibbons-Neffs team was ordered to flush him out. Ben Anderson, a journalist and filmmaker, accompanied the team on the assault. The two became friends, and the following is their joint account of the weeklong hunt for one sniper, told from their different viewpoints on the battlefield.

title: Critics of Health Care Law Outspending Its Supporters on Ads

The French foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, said that in one case, at least, there is no doubt it was the regime and its accomplices that used the gas.

title: Food Matters | A Sweet Take on Modern Art

Both the cafe and museum will be temporarily closed starting this month as part of a massive expansion project, but in the meantime you can enjoy the books 27 painterly confections, from a Warhol gele to a Matisse parfait. To help guide less experienced bakers, Freeman includes names and definitions for the equipment (think microplanes, piping bags and thermocouples) involved in recreating her desserts, as well as the back story behind every creation. SFMOMAs Janet Bishop provides the curator notes. There is, for example, the Build Your Own Newman, a construction of chocolate sables based on the Abstract Expressionist Barnett Newmans sculpture Zim Zum I. For her part, Freeman was determined to photograph her cookie replica alongside the original art, in this case an eight-foot-tall steel structure in the museums sculpture garden. That necessitated perching a sheet pan over the roof of the museum and assembling the pastry in what Freeman describes as hurricane-force winds while simultaneously holding lighting equipment.

description: Two years after the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, people are still worried about contaminated food, and farmers are struggling.

description: The Kentucky Derby winner, Orb, drew Post 5 and was installed as the morning-live favorite for the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday at Belmont Park. The Preakness Stakes winner, Oxbow, will break from Post 7 and has odds of 5-1.

title: Severe Flooding Cripples Germany
description: Officials in eastern Germanys river cities urged citizens in vulnerable areas to evacuate as the Elbe River and its tributaries swelled ever higher.

title: A Rooftop Garden at the Waldorf-Astoria
description: Last year, the Waldorf-Astoria installed six beehives on a 20th-floor setback; today, Top of the Waldorf honey is used in the hotels restaurants. Now the rooftop has been planted with fig and apple trees, hops, strawberries, lavender and other herbs that the executive chef, David Garcelon, can use in the kitchen, and that the mixologist, Frank Caiafa, adds to drinks.

title: Samsung May Have Passed Apple in U.S.  for Now
description: Samsung Electronics may have surpassed Apple to become the top smartphone maker in the United States in May, according to an analysts report. Sales of Samsungs new flagship phone, the Galaxy S4, combined with its bigger-screen Galaxy Note II and the older Galaxy S III, lifted Samsungs sales above Apples last month, the report said.

title: It Opens Your Mind': A Student-Made Video About a Year of Reading The Times
description: A student-produced and directed video was made, according to teachers, off the cuff, from the heart and without notes.

title: Help for Traveling Pets
description: Animals traveling through Chicago on United Airlines can now stay in 28 temperature-controlled enclosures at the carriers kennel at OHare International Airport. (Overnight stays are $100.) Staff members will walk and exercise pets, and groom and bathe them on request. The facility also has vans to transport pets to and from flights. The kennel is Uniteds third and is part of the airlines PetSafe program for animals not eligible to travel in the cabin. The carrier operates similar facilities at airports in Houston and Newark.

title: Compelling Series, but James Tilts Edge to Heat
description: The N.B.A. finals are saturated with story lines. A fifth title for the 37-year-old San Antonio star Tim Duncan would solidify his case for being his generations best player. A second straight title for LeBron James would cap one of the most dominant seasons in league history. The series pits the glitz and bombast of South Beach against the quiet diligence of the small-market Spurs.

title: Philadelphia Building Collapses During Demolition, Killing at Least Six
description: PHILADELPHIA  A four-story building that was being demolished collapsed onto an adjacent thrift store in central Philadelphia on Wednesday morning, killing at least six people, city officials said.

title: Two Liberal Voices for Intervention, but Not in Syrian War
description: WASHINGTON  In naming Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to key national security posts, President Obama has turned to two prominent advocates of liberal interventionism, a foreign-policy credo that calls for the United States to act aggressively to defend human rights  by military means, if necessary.

title: Another Senator Urges Caution on Smithfields Sale to Chinese Company
description: 5:44 p.m. | Updated

title: Toyota to Recall 2010 Prius and Lexus Hybrids
description: Toyota has announced a recall in the United States of about 87,000 Prius and Lexus HS 250h hybrids from the 2010 model year to fix a brake problem, the second time since 2010 the cars have been recalled to fix the braking. According to the automakers release, dealers will replace brake boosters, which can develop leaks.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Changes in Money Funds
description: A new effort to avert the problems that hit money market funds during the financial crisis is already attracting criticism for not going far enough while winning praise from advocates of the money fund industry.

title: Palm-Size Fossil Resets Primates Clock, Scientists Say
description: A nearly complete skeleton of a tiny, ancient primate  one that weighed no more than an ounce, had a tail longer than its body and would fit in the palm of your hand  is the earliest well-preserved fossil primate ever found, dating back some 55 million years and dialing back the fossil record for primates by an impressive eight million years, a research team declared on Wednesday.

title: A Building Collapse in Philadelphia
description: Reuters footage of a building collapse Wednesday in the Center City section.

title: Rare Look at a Baby Kipunji  One of the Worlds Most Endangered Monkeys
description: The photograph above, distributed today by the Wildlife Conservation Society, provides a rare look at a baby kipunji (Rungwecebus kipunji) on Mount Rungwe, Tanzania.

title: A Campaign Trail Lined With Words Friendly to Each Audience
description: 3:31 p.m. | Updated The Democratic mayoral candidates gathered on Tuesday night in Midwood, Brooklyn, for a debate sponsored by the Flatbush Jewish Community Coalition, in which most remarks hewed to a single informal commandment: Say nothing that might conceivably discomfort your audience.

title: Orb Draws No. 5 Post and Is Favored
description: Orb, the Kentucky Derby winner, is the lukewarm favorite; Oxbow, the Preakness Stakes victor, will try to beat him again; and the filly Unlimited Budget will try to upend them both Saturday in the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: Wheelies: The Cheaper Used Cars Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: A Magic Carpet Ride in a Venetian Palazzo
description: As if the Venice Biennale didnt offer enough art already between the Arsenale, the Giardini and the various national pavilions found on the crumbling side streets, there are also numerous palazzos that have been repurposed for parallel exhibitions mounted by some of the worlds pre-eminent private collections. The Francois Pinault Foundation owns two such mansion-seums on the Grand Canal: the industrial Tadao Ando-designed Punta Della Dogana and the quintessentially Venetian Palazzo Grassi. In the latter, the New York-based Italian artist Rudolph Stingel has created what may be the most sumptuous aesthetic experience on the island this year.

title: The First Ladys Heckler
description: Lets stipulate that heckling the First Lady at a private fundraiser in Washington, D.C., is not very politeeven if you paid admission, like the protester who confronted Michelle Obama at a party for Democratic donors on Tuesday night.

title: Hirshhorn Museum Scraps Idea to Cover Courtyard With Bubble
description: The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden on Wednesday finally abandoned its long-planned project to cover the museums interior courtyard in Washington D.C. with a distinctive, temporary inflatable bubble.

title: Is This a Government Which I See Before Me?
description: Gail Collins: Happy June, David! Hows the weather where you are? Last weekend New York felt like August. August in the tropics. Now it feels like were getting ready for an Easter Egg Roll.

title: A Noisy Semifinal Ahead as Sharapova and Azarenka Advance
description: PARIS  Maria Sharapova and Jelena Jankovic have been battling each other since they were girls, after they were plucked from their homes and settled at the Bollettieri Academy in Florida to be turned into champions. Their relationship can be diplomatically described as frosty, and Jankovic has long existed in the considerable shadow of the more successful Sharapova.

title: A Ride Around Manhattan in the Taxi of Tomorrow
description: Assuming its legal holdups are resolved, the Nissan NV200 that was shown in front of the Hilton New York Fashion District hotel in Manhattan on Tuesday will become the citys Taxi of Tomorrow. Mike Hobson, director of the Nissan commercial vehicle division in the United States, points out that tomorrow is coming soon.

title: British Judge Urges Public Inquiry Into Litvinenko Death
description: LONDON  In an unusual attempt to circumvent official restrictions on evidence, a British judge urged the government on Wednesday to hold a public inquiry into the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer poisoned in London in 2006 with radioactive polonium.

title: Racing Ambassadors Are Spreading the News About the Belmont
description: The Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes have come and gone, and with this, racing fans have also seen their hopes of a Triple Crown winner in 2013 shattered almost before they could even tell what had happened. Every year fans hope that after the Derby, that years winner will continue on and become a Triple Crown winner  something fans believe our sport desperately needs. No one said it was easy, and that is why no horse has completed the feat since Affirmed in 1978.

title: In Besieged Area of Syria, Bitterness of Sunnis Points to Rending of Sects
description: NEAR QUSAYR, Syria  In the final days of their stubborn but increasingly hopeless stand against an overwhelming assault, Syrian rebels hid among the concrete shells of destroyed houses in the village of Hamediyeh, subsisting on olives and canned beans. They tried to sleep, without much success, in tunnels dug for shelter from government shelling.

title: Trial Date Set for Former SAC Trader in Insider Case
description: Mathew Martoma, the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, is set to stand trial on Nov. 4, almost a year after federal authorities charged him in what they called the largest insider trading case ever brought.

title: Start-Up to Connect Home Appliances
description: One of Silicon Valleys favorite buzz phrases is Internet of things, a catchall for everyday stuff like home appliances and light bulbs that are connected to the Internet. Nest Labs, a company founded by a former Apple executive that makes a smart thermostat, has brought cachet to the category and gotten a lot of other manufacturers thinking about how they can bring the Internet to their otherwise humdrum products.

title: Harlem Legislator Accused of D.W.I. in Albany Suburb
description: ALBANY  Robert J. Rodriguez, a state assemblyman from Harlem, has been charged with driving while intoxicated in a suburb of the capital, the police said on Wednesday.

title: Final-Like Semifinal in Paris: Djokovic Will Meet Nadal
description: PARIS  It has been nearly two weeks since a murmur and a few groans went through the room in Paris after Rafael Nadal landed on the same side of the French Open draw as Novak Djokovic.

title: Packing Lunches, and Packing Up the School Year
description: The school my children attend ends its lunch program nearly two weeks before school ends.

title: Waiting to Be Heard
description: To the Editor:

title: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Dashlane
description: David Pogue on the convenience and security of Dashlane, a free password manager.

title: Video of Samantha Powers 2002 Remarks on Imposing Peace on Israel Could Haunt Her, Israeli Paper Says
description: Last Updated, 5:12 p.m. Even before the official announcement by President Obama on Wednesday that he would nominate Samantha Power to be the next United States ambassador to the United Nations, various aspects of her record were being picked apart and debated, weighed against the potential for confirmation.

title: The 2012 Fiction Pulitzer
description: To the Editor:

title: What to Watch on Day 12 at the French Open
description: After spreading itself thin over two courts for the quarterfinals, the action for the semifinals will be condensed onto one court, with the men getting the day off and the womens semifinals taking center stage. With the final four all ranked in the Top 5, its hard to ask for much more from Thursdays slate. Heres a look at the two penultimate womens singles matches, plus a bonus glimpse at a doubles semifinal:

title: Remember All Those Passwords? No Need
description: If you want to avoid having your identity stolen, use long passwords that contain digits, punctuation and no recognizable words. Make up a different password for every Web site. And change all of your passwords every 30 days.

title: Dells Board Puts Investors in a Bind
description: Dells board special committee has neatly painted investors into a corner.

title: Literature Down Under
description: To the Editor:

title: Daft Punk Holds On at No.1
description: This week on Billboards music charts, Daft Punks new album holds at No. 1 and the rap duo Macklemore & Ryan Lewis extends its run with the top single.

title: Cara Black, a Doubles Wizard, Shows She Is Back
description: PARIS  It was a French Open quarterfinal that felt like a final, fiercely fought by two teams of near equals.

title: Bruins Domination of Penguins Has Been Very Penguin-Like
description: It is not unusual to see at team in Pittsburgh skating circles around its opponent for two straight games, especially this postseason. But usually the team skating the circles is the Penguins, who had outscored their playoff opponents 26-10 at home entering the Eastern Conference finals against Boston.

title: Humanities Endowment to Investigate Grants Made to Scholarly Society
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities will conduct an investigation of three grants awarded to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the scholarly society in Cambridge, Mass., whose president, Leslie C. Berlowitz, has been accused of falsely claiming on various documents to hold a doctorate.

title: If You Drive on the Beach, Reduce the Air in Your Tires
description: Its beach season, and in some locales that means beach driving. The video above is a good depiction of why its a good idea to air down your tires before driving on sand. Aired-down tires have a wider footprint and float better over soft sand than hard, fully inflated tires. A good place to start is 15 pounds per square inch.

title: The Gossip Just Wont Stop
description: Around 10:30 p.m. last Wednesday, 12 days after his 29-year tenure as the gossip columnist for The Village Voice was abruptly ended by the newspapers owner, Michael Musto was in a TriBeCa production studio, dressed in a bedazzled tuxedo jacket, getting ready for his first post-Voice job.

title: A. M. Homes Awarded Womens Prize for Fiction
description: Hilary Mantel cant win them all. A. M. Homes took home the Womens Prize for Fiction on Wednesday night in London, for her novel May We Be Forgiven.

title: Obama Presents New Security Team
description: President Obama introduced Susan E. Rice as the national security adviser and Samantha Power as the new American Ambassador to the United Nations.

title: She Swims Again (Flies,Too)
description: MILLBURN, N.J.  Under the sea, things seem to have calmed down a bit.

title: Bobbys on the Lower East Side
description: Bobbys, a new night spot on the Lower East Side, is hoping to capitalize on the Gatsby-inspired rage for all things 20s. Just south of Delancey Street, a green light glows ( la East Egg) above the unmarked entrance to a formerly generic club that has been given a sleek Art Deco makeover in hopes of attracting dapper dudes and their latter-day flappers.

title: The Argument Against Oil Drilling in Arctic Seas
description: The Natural Resources Defense Council has issued a statement concluding that recent events  most notably the grounding of a Shell Oil drilling rig in Alaska  show the oil industry is not ready to safely, cleanly drill offshore in the Arctic.

title: Even Silence Is Steeped in Emotion
description: There are some good stories in Tea for Three: Lady Bird, Pat & Betty. But sometimes the silences tell the best tales.

title: Sybrinas Sorrow
description: Sybrina Fulton hasnt been able to visit her son Trayvon Martins grave site since the Florida teenager was buried 15 months ago.

title: Kirna Zabte to Move to Larger Store in SoHo
description: After 14 years in the same space with the same lavender-painted hardwood floors, Kirna Zabte, the SoHo emporium of daring design, is moving this month to a new home with twice the space. Just inside the entrance of the 10,000-square-foot store at 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street), will be a wall of quotations in neon lights, the origins of which might have been Coco Chanel. Or maybe Carrie Bradshaw.

title: Sabathia, Now Crafty, Has Perfect Start in Complete Game
description: Nick Swisher was C. C. Sabathias teammate for four years with the Yankees, observing the big left-hander mostly from right field. On Wednesday, though, he acted surprised at what he saw while facing Sabathia for the first time with the Cleveland Indians.

title: How Bad Is European Youth Unemployment?
description: My Sunday column returned to whats become a recurring theme of mine: The remarkable political quiescence of Europeansin the face of the economic devastation wrought by their rolling disaster of a currency union. In this case, my jumping-off point was what the Atlantics Derek Thompson calls the scariest graph in the world, which shows youth unemployment  for under-25-year-olds, that isbreaking 40 percent in Italy, 50 percent in Spain and 60 percent in Greece. So its worth saying something about the (fairly widespread) rejoinder that these numbers arent actually as bad as they look, because most young people are in school or training rather than looking fruitlessly for work. For instance, heres the Financial Times Kate Allen, downplaying the youth-unemployment crisis:

title: Proenza Schouler Updates Its First Collection
description: Observing some of their colleagues wearing pieces from the early days of Proenza Schouler recently, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough had a thought. If it still looks good after 10 years, why not make it again?

title: Finding Country Truths in Nature and in People
description: When I was a boy growing up in rural New Hampshire there were a few old men who always wore overalls and who lived out in the woods. And those men  Chief, Pop, Jake  knew where to find the best wild dandelion greens, sensed when the sucker fish were running the mill race, and squinted at the sky as if it were a baseball box score printed in the tiniest type.

title: Is This Senegals Answer to The Daily Show?
description: Even if you cant decipher every word of the weekly YouTube show Journal Rapp  part music video, part news broadcast delivered entirely in French and Wolof by two Senegalese rappers  its worth checking out. Especially given that Senegal happens to be on Barack Obamas itinerary when he makes his longest trip to Africa as president later this month. (Grist for the Africa Rising meme?)

title: SAPs Purchasing Power Play
description: SAP just did a big acquisition, along with a little head fake.

title: Latest Resort Collections: Balenciaga, Altuzarra and Derek Lam
description: For Alexander Wangs first resort collection for Balenciaga, presented Wednesday morning at the companys new showroom on West 22nd Street, which was formerly a Balenciaga store, the designer took a trip to Getaria, in Spain, to visit the coastal city where Cristobal Balenciaga was born. Mr. Wang and members of the design studio toured the museum there to see some pieces that were not in the companys own archives.

title: Chefs on the Move
description: Robert Moorman, who was at North End Grill, is the new executive chef at Krescendo, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, which opened last fall and is owned by Nancy Puglisi. The original chef, Elizabeth Falkner, has left.

title: The Middle Class Strikes Back
description: WASHINGTON  SINCE 2002, Turkeys sound economic policies have made it a member of the Group of 20 and turned it into a majority middle-class society for the first time in its history. Yet this weeks huge protests show that the ruling Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P., has become a victim of its own success.

title: Development Wont Ensure Democracy in Turkey
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  FOR the past few years, there has been a general optimism about Turkish democracy in Western capitals, especially in Washington, thanks to the economic strides made by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogans Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P.

title: Activists Stunt Livens Up a Routine Senate Session
description: ALBANY  There wasnt much to see in the State Senate on Wednesday: the reciting of the Pledge of Allegiance, the honoring of a basketball player and a bunch of empty seats where elected representatives are paid to sit.

title: Changes in Obamas Foreign Policy Team
description: President Obamas new foreign policy team is filled with some of his closest advisers and confidants, many of whom waited patiently for the top jobs during his first term.

title: Therapy for Victims of Sexual Violence Shows Promise in Congo
description: A type of group therapy designed for trauma victims has proved extraordinarily helpful for survivors of sexual violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, enabling women to overcome the shame, nightmares and terrifying flashbacks that had left them unable to work or take care of their families or themselves, researchers report.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Bangladesh and Germany.

title: An Evening Dedicated to Charmers
description: Orchestras sometimes use gala concerts as an occasion to ditch the Bruckner and Beethoven and focus on other genres, as the New York Philharmonic did on Tuesday evening with a lineup of Broadway, Brazilian and classical songs at Avery Fisher Hall. The program, An Enchanted Evening With Paulo Szot, featured the charismatic baritone in a range of repertory conducted by Ted Sperling.

title: Charge Your iPad in Luxury
description: Strut, a maker of grills and wheels for luxury cars, is seeking to add its touch of refinement to the iPad.

title: Lessons for the Living, Courtesy of the Dead
description: If youve avoided vampire/zombie television until now because you think its either dumb sci-fi or drippy romance aimed at teenagers, In the Flesh, a three-part mini-series that begins Thursday on BBC America, gives you a chance to find out just how well written and layered some of these shows are.

title: Jewish Folk Songs, Set to Felas Afrobeat
description: As Jon Madof worked at his computer one Friday in 2011, doing the graphic-design job that supported his life as a guitarist, he listened to the Afrobeat music of Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Then, with the Sabbath sundown nearing, he shut down his home office and began humming one of the Jewish religious songs made famous by Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach.

title: In Store | Hedi Slimanes Sleek New Saint Laurent Flagship
description: For many, marble might conjure antiquity. But Hedi Slimane has put the majestic material to thoroughly contemporary use in the new Saint Laurent Paris flagship store in SoHo, which opened today. The brands first outpost downtown is part of Slimanes revamp of the label, which until recently was known by the initials YSL. Black-and-white silk-marble panels flank the walls, lending an airiness and sophistication to the space, which also features 19th-century cast-iron columns and tin ceilings typical of the neighborhood.

title: Countries Seek Entrepreneurs From Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A bold new billboard looms over U.S. 101, the highway that runs through the heart of the global technology industry. H-1b problems? it reads. Pivot to Canada.

title: Open Trial to Select U.S. Team for Bermuda Bowl
description: The Open Trial taking place in Orlando, Fla., will select the two United States teams for the Bermuda Bowl in September. The semifinal draw for the unbeaten teams is Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Zia Mahmood, Chip Martel, Michael Rosenberg and Chris Willenken against Warren Spector, Michael Becker, Curtis Cheek, Joe Grue, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss; and Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell versus John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst and Kevin Dwyer.

title: A Rainbow of Fragility
description: A line from the Sting song Fragile  Nothing comes from violence/And nothing ever could  became much more than a sad reflection on human nature when sung by the Arab-Israeli singer and songwriter Mira Awad at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening. Ms. Awad, 37, who sings in Arabic and English and occasionally in Hebrew, was born in Rameh in Galilee to a Palestinian father and Bulgarian mother. She stars in Arab Labor, a popular Israeli television comedy about Jewish and Arab coexistence.

title: Byrons Gloomy Pirate Tale, With Bikini Tutus Added
description: Next year brings the bicentennial of Byrons heroic poem The Corsair  a literary sensation that sold some 10,000 copies on its first day of publication. In foreign translations it so flourished over the next few decades that it prompted multiple stage adaptations, including an opera by Verdi (1848) and a Parisian ballet choreographed by Joseph Mazilier to music by Adolphe Adam (1856). Yet by one of the more perverse tricks of artistic fate, the most popular version of it today is a Russian ballet that contains nothing of Maziliers choreography or much of Adams music and in which Byrons original poem, heavy with tragic emotion, is distorted into an absurd romp.

title: Share Ideas on Travel With Kids in N.Y.C.
description: Next week, the Travel section will start a new series of articles on traveling with children in big cities. The series will include tips on everything from unexpected kid-friendly attractions to basics like where to eat and find a bathroom.

title: Taking the Rockabus to the Rockaways
description: What better time than Memorial Day to show support for one of the places hardest hit by Hurricane Sandy. Sun, sand and suds included.

title: Sun, Sand and Suds
description: On the morning of Memorial Day, as the sun broke through the wet blanket of a weekend, more than a dozen 20- and 30-somethings in striped tank tops and straw hats boarded a yellow school bus idling in a bleak parking lot in Williamsburg.

title: The New Guy (With a Gun) at a Dream Beach House
description: Graceland, is a confusing title for a series that isnt about Elvis Presley or Paul Simon in his South African period.

title: Container Store Said to Prepare for an I.P.O.
description: The Container Store has begun to hire advisers to prepare for a potential initial public offering, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, nearly five years after selling itself to the private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners.

title: Cleaning More Than Cobwebs
description: It turns out that Bhakti Sondra Shaye does windows. She also scours microwaves, refrigerators, dishwashers and closets.

title: Fending Off the Bad Spirits
description: If you are a feng shui expert or, for that matter, a Jewish grandmother, you are likely to believe that a scrupulously clean and tidy home is the first defense against bad spirits. (No place to hide.) But even at the risk of cluttering, you may want to acquire a talisman or two. The following demon-repelling goods not only have the endorsements of ancient belief systems (in some cases, several), but they are also pleasing to the senses (in some cases, several).

title: Bushwick Open Studios 2013
description: The arty denizens of the neighborhood throw open their doors for the annual spate of exhibitions.

title: At Every Turn, Another Strange World
description: Bushwick is not, as you may have read (and read and read), the coolest place in the universe, though for three days every year it may be the coolest place in the five boroughs.

title: A Homestead for House Stalkers
description: Listening to Jade-Snow Carroll and Ian Rasch talk about the 1,650-square-foot, two-bedroom passive-solar house they built two years ago amid rolling farmland here, one senses it is soon to become a memory rather than a place where memories will be made. If building a house is this much fun, they seemed to be saying, why not do it again?

title: The Simple Modern Solution
description: A sun-warmed, plant-filled box for living.

title: Accessories for Outdoor Entertaining
description: With the outdoor entertaining season finally under way, its time to take stock of the accessories. And like anything that has been in hibernation for the better part of the year, they can look a bit worse for wear.

title: Shopping for Accessories for Outdoor Entertaining
description: Bronson van Wyck, an event planner, takes stock of new accessories with the outdoor entertaining season finally under way.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. Does it matter how I stock and organize my fridge and pantry before showings?

title: Beyond the Palace, an International Tour in One City
description: VENICE  Dark weather and high water were the backdrop to the start of the 55th Venice Biennale, an event that predictably combines enough cold cash and hot air to create a storm system of critical opinion. The main barometric indicator is always the big show that gives each Biennale its theme, and on this score, for the first time in years, theres fairly smooth sailing.

title: Their Annual Migration
description: An American couple make the trek every year to their house in the Andes.

title: Rampant Blooms, but No Color
description: Amika: Hairdo Bar, a two-story, 700-square-foot hairstyling salon, will open June 11 in Hong Kong. Were demystifying hair styling, making things faster and easier, said Vita Raykhman, 31, the creative director of Amika, a Brooklyn hair products company. The Hairdo Bar, Amikas first salon, will allow a woman to change her image in less than 40 minutes without the commitment of a cut or a color, Ms. Raykhman said. Customers will be offered a choice of 12 hair styles, with prices ranging from $24 to $70. Guy Zucker of Z-A Studio in Manhattan designed the space on a budget of $90,000 using the companys flower-shaped graphic identity as an architectural motif. On the first floor, the birch plywood walls are cut into floral silhouettes, and flowers are printed on the wallpaper in the rear. Upstairs, the flower shape is applied to the booths. Hairdo Bar is at 8 Elgin Street, Hong Kong, 011-852-2291-0070. Three additional shops will open in New York City next year.

title: Up in the Clouds
description: CAAR, Ecuador  Most people arent willing to drive more than a few hours to get to a second home in the country.

title: Darling of Cannes Now at Center of Storm
description: PARIS  Last month the film Blue Is the Warmest Color was the toast of Cannes. A drama about young lesbian love, it was so celebrated for its explicit sex scenes that it won the festivals top prize. Since then its being castigated for those very same scenes.

title: An Ultramodern Island Draws on Italian Styling
description: Minacciolo, the Italian interiors company, says its Mina kitchen is the ultimate accessory, but really it is an island unto itself  with cooktop, oven, dual dishwashing drawers, illuminated storage and refrigeration in a customizable package.

title: Illustrator to City: Its Personal
description: Peter Kuper, the cartoonist and illustrator, has tried to capture his three decades in New York, and the city itself, with Drawn to New York (PM Press; $29.95). You cant be comprehensive because its too big a piece of pie to swallow  or apple, rather, Mr. Kuper said. Instead, he inks his own experiences, which seem informed by the twin responses shared by many New York transplants: anxiety and wonder. In one illustration, a lone man looks out from his darkened apartment and wonders how many people are having sex at that moment. Another panel tells the story of a long-ago night when Mr. Kuper and a friend scaled the suspension cables of the Brooklyn Bridge. The artistic styles change from page to page, mirroring the frenetic, unpredictable nature of the city. As Mr. Kuper said, The thing I like about New York is the quality of feeling like youre traveling at all times.

title: Contemporary Design Lands in Antiques Country
description: Hudson, N.Y., is an antiques-hunters haven, but it is becoming more of a source of contemporary design as well, with the opening of Fern Handcrafted Furniture.

title: Garage Band Ceramics
description: Paula Greifs whimsical, wiggly, home-brewed designs.

title: Now Whats Her Line?
description: Paula Greif made some of the first music videos for MTV (on Super 8 film, no less) and designed album covers for Madonna, Debbie Harry and Paul Simon. Though she has been the art director of Mademoiselle and for Barneys New York, and worked with fashion photographers like Richard Avedon, Steven Meisel and Arthur Elgort, Ms. Greif was always a rocker at heart. When she was in the art department of Self magazine in the late 70s, she spent her nights at CBGB and the Mudd Club, and slept under her desk at lunch. Now 60, she is making ceramics, animated porcelain and terra-cotta pieces that look like wiggly line drawings (you can find them occasionally on her Web site  be warned, she is frequently sold out  and at Beautiful Dreamers, a store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn). Ms. Greif calls her pottery garage band ceramics because of its handmade funkiness and because her new career has unfolded in a typically ad hoc, no-frills manner.

title: New Yorks Clueless Election Board Drags Out Ancient Machines
description: New York City voters should be prepared to cast their ballots once again this fall on voting machines invented in the 19th century. State legislators were apparently close to a deal on Wednesday afternoon to allow New York Citys clueless board of elections to use the old mechanical machines for the citys September 10 primary.

title: Greek Regrets
description: The IMF has released a fairly remarkable piece of self-criticism (pdf) over policy in Greece. On a first read, the report seems to suggest two main failings on the IMFs part: it failed to acknowledge early on that Greece simply could not repay its debt in full, and it vastly underestimated the economic damage austerity would inflict.

title: Sales at Hable Construction, the Future Perfect and Others
description: All in-stock pillows are 25 percent off at Hable Construction, through June 13 (a 14-by-18-inch Azul Waterfalls pillow, usually $65, is now about $49); the code SUMMER should be entered at check out, (817) 422-5313, hableconstruction.com.

title: A Spiritual Center of Power Is a Required Stop on Irans Campaign Trail
description: QUM, Iran  Qum, home to some of Irans most influential clerics, is not just Irans holiest city, but one of its most powerful, a Shiite Vatican in the desert that can make or break any Iranian political career. So it is not surprising that it has become a destination recently for almost all of the candidates in next weeks presidential election, seeking to sip from the cocktail of money, politics and religion that the city represents.

title: Rockaways Rising
description: Whats open and closed on the still-fashionable beach:

title: The Tablet or Smartphone Becomes a Tutor for the Budding Artist
description: The smartphone revolution, among other things, has put a camera in everyones pocket. This has led to an explosion in the art of photography  if you can call an Instagram self-portrait art. But smartphones and tablets have another ability that is genuinely arty: they can help teach basic drawing and sketching.

title: Civil Disobedience on a Turkish Game Show
description: While most of Turkeys journalists were carefully avoiding mention of the tens of thousands of protesters who poured into the streets this week, in a show of deference to the government that enraged supporters of the demonstrations, the host of one Turkish game show found a way to raise the issue not once but 70 times during a broadcast on Monday night.

title: Painting the Lily? Hes One Up on That
description: By the time Delano Brown showed up at his first New York gallery show, a model in a white dress had been waiting  silently, fiercely  more than an hour for his paint. She was doing such a good job of staring into the distance that the phenomenally well-appointed crowd filling the Smart Clothes Gallery on the Lower East Side stopped noticing her almost entirely.

title: If Youre Not Going to Wear That
description: What girl isnt interested in seeing what her friend has in her closet? So reasoned Ambre Dahan, the design director of Joes Jeans and now the founder, with Amandine Rohmer, of Walk in My Closet, a virtual wardrobe manager and shopping site. Like many of us, she and Ms. Rohmer often shared new purchases and outfits via text. The new site (walkinmycloset.com) and app, available on iTunes this week, streamlines the whole process. How it works: You download the app and shoot the items in your closet like a pro (it silhouettes them on a white background) and essentially create a boutique of everything you own. From there, you can make packing lists, sell things you never wear  for a 25 percent commission  and buy from other users, who include founding members like Charlotte Ronson, Irene Neuwirth and Julia Restoin Roitfeld. If you ever find yourself saying, I dont have anything to wear, think of this as your new best friend.

title: Bally Offers Mountaineer Reindeer Boots
description: It is one of the 20th centurys most memorable photos: the one Edmund Hillary took of Tenzing Norgay on May 29, 1953, standing at the summit of Mount Everest, the highest point on earth. Now, 60 years later, there is an answer to the question everyone  or at least one or two people  has been asking ever since: where can I get those chic reindeer boots? The answer is Bally, the Swiss company that in the 40s began custom-making boots for serious mountaineers, among them the pair that Tenzing wore for his storied ascent. In honor of the anniversary of that climb  and the fact that the old-fashioned mountaineer has become a style model in mens fashion  Bally is issuing a new version of the boots. The sole is lighter in weight and they lace more easily. But like the originals, they are available only by order, and they are still made of reindeer fur. They may never help you get to the top of a mountain, but, at $2,495, they will definitely get you to the tiptop of your credit card limit. Bally, 628 Madison Avenue; (212) 751-9082.

title: Monoprice Introduces an LED Monitor
description: Monoprice, the Web retailer best known for its low-priced cables, continues to expand its product line with a 27-inch high-resolution LED computer monitor it showed at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last January. The price? $475, nearly a third less than many models with similar specifications.

title: Sheer Garments Make a Tasteful Return
description: Despite the sheer number of sheer garments in recent runway collections, a public display of underwear still seems vaguely  well, amateur. But were getting past it. Bras, weve noticed, are now fully (and chicly) on display. There was Julia Restoin Roitfeld, who was out and about with an opaque bra under a beautiful sheer blouse; the model Hye Park, whose bra was visible under a sheer white shirt and tuxedo jacket; and the actress Stella Schnabel, who looked impeccable in all-white tailoring, including the underpinnings. What makes the looks winning is the juxtaposition of peek-a-boo sex appeal with sharp lines and volume. Instead of grungy, the effect is sophisticated and modern.

title: Orlebar Brown Swim Trunks Use Paris Review Art
description: The British pop-meets-prep swimwear label Orlebar Brown, known for its well-cut swim trunks, does the collaboration thing well. Already it has done limited editions with Monocle magazine and Alan Aldridge, the illustrator famous for his work with the Beatles, among other imaginative collaborations. The latest (and most highbrow) is a venture with The Paris Review, in which it is reprinting select archival cover illustrations on the classic Orlebar Brown midlength swim shorts. Included are a Kim MacConnel beach scene, titled Ten Items or Less, from the summer 80 cover; Donald Sultans orange flowers from summer 96; and a Leanne Shapton figure drawing from the spring 2011 cover. Any dad with an appreciation of cool mens fashion or graphic design or literature will gladly take a pair on Fathers Day.

title: Real Housewives of the World
description: Bravos Real Housewives franchise has a global reach, inspiring versions in countries like Canada, Israel and Greece.

description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Judge Orders All Restrictions Lifted on Some Morning-After Pills
description: A federal appeals court in New York on Wednesday ordered that some types of emergency contraceptives be made available for now to women of all ages without a prescription, adding another layer of confusion to a complex and intensely political fight over the drugs availability.

title: Scouting Report
description: CFDA Winners

Komen Breast Cancer Charity Cancels Races in 7 Cities
description: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation has canceled half of its 3-Day fund-raising races around the country next year as it struggles to regain support nearly 18 months after its 2012 decision to withdraw funding for breast cancer screening at some Planned Parenthood affiliates.

title: Keith Suspended for Game
description: The N.H.L. suspended Duncan Keith of the Chicago Blackhawks for one game for his one-handed high stick on Los Angeles Kings forward Jeff Carter in Tuesdays Game 3. The stick struck Carter in the mouth and neck. Carter said he sustained damage to several of his teeth and required about 20 stitches because of various cuts. Keith said it was an accident.

title: In Nigeria, Killing People Without Asking Who They Are
description: BOSSO, Niger  For the soldiers, the young mens long, flowing robes  the traditional garb of Muslim West Africa  were enough to establish guilt, the refugees said.

title: An Old Staple of Black Culture Now Adds to a New Restaurants Dcor
description: It started with Miss Susie. Miss Susie owns a brownstone a few doors from Dennis Decker on West 119th Street in Harlem, where over the years she rented out rooms and tenant after tenant left scraps of their lives behind. Last summer, Mr. Decker helped his 84-year-old neighbor, known to everyone simply as Miss Susie, by organizing a cleaning, and in the sifting came across a handful of vintage Jet magazines.

title: Meanwhile, Back at the Resort Collections
description: The long, lean line of Francisco Costas resort clothes for Calvin Klein today seemed attuned to the moment, though we wont be seeing these designs in stores for several months. Most of the skirt lengths were below the knee, and below the belly button, and Mr. Costa kept shifting attention from bare midriffs to sorcerer cover-ups with long sleeves.

title: T.S.A. Drops an Effort to Allow Some Knives on Planes
description: Facing strong opposition from flight attendants and lawmakers, the Transportation Security Administration said Wednesday that it was abandoning a plan to allow passengers to carry small knives on board.

title: City Reverts to Its Days of Hobbling
description: It was New York Citys clunky, unsophisticated emblem of 1980s law and order  part security tool, part public shaming device  fastened to the front wheels of offending vehicles like the mark of Cain.

title: Chief of Boston Marathon Bombing Fund Stands Firm on Deadline
description: BOSTON  The fund to aid victims of the Boston Marathon blasts has grown quickly, with nearly $40 million raised since the bombings on April 15. But with just over a week to go before the June 15 deadline to apply for compensation, only a fraction of the anticipated beneficiaries have done so, raising questions among lawyers and health care professionals about whether ample time has been provided to ask for help.

title: Fort Hood Suspect Given More Time to Prepare Defense, Most Likely Delaying Trial
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The long-delayed court-martial of the Army psychiatrist accused in a shooting rampage at Fort Hood here will most likely be delayed again after a judge on Wednesday instructed prospective jurors from other posts to return home while the court clears up logistical and legal issues arising out of the defendants decision to represent himself.

title: Publishers Tell of Disputes With Apple on E-Book Prices
description: In an e-mail to her boss, Leslie Moonves, Carolyn K. Reidy, the chief executive of Simon & Schuster, dismissed an Apple executive as a minion.

title: Debt Deal in Alabama Will Cost JPMorgan
description: Under the deal to settle the bankruptcy of Jefferson County, Ala., firms that invested in its distressed debt will have the most to gain, JPMorgan Chase will face a big loss, and residents will be wondering whether there will be any relief for them.

title: As Investors Bail Out, SAC Shows a Brave Face
description: SAC Capital Advisors, the besieged hedge fund owned by the billionaire stock picker Steven A. Cohen, has told its employees that it will survive a wave of investor withdrawals during the governments intensifying investigation into possible insider trading at the firm.

title: North Carolina Repeals Law Allowing Racial Bias Claim in Death Penalty Challenges
description: A law that allowed death-row inmates to challenge their sentences based on racial bias claims was repealed by the North Carolina legislature on Wednesday, paving the way for executions to resume in a state that has 152 people on death row.

title: In Clash of Styles, Only Certainty Is Worthy Champ
description: MIAMI  On one side of the 2013 N.B.A finals is Tim Duncan, a quiet superstar who has stayed put for 16 years in south Texas. On the other is the world-renowned LeBron James, who left home in blue-collar northern Ohio for the glitterati of South Beach.

title: Betty Ford Center and Hazelden Seek Business Partnership
description: With the Affordable Care Act poised to make addiction treatment available to millions of new patients, the Betty Ford Center and the Hazelden Foundation, two of the biggest names in substance abuse recovery, are pursuing a formal business alliance, the two groups said Tuesday. The boards of both institutions have approved the alliance in principle, though neither group will so far divulge specifics of the plan. Hazelden has a network of 10 treatment centers throughout the country. Starting in 2014, Medicare and all insurance sold on Health Insurance Exchanges will be required to provide treatment for substance abuse under a provision of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Election Move Typifies Christie: Fast and With Politics in Mind
description: Even before Frank R. Lautenbergs death, Gov. Chris Christie had a solution on how to fill the United States Senate seat he would vacate, a choice the governor knew was rich with political risk and reward.

title: Fill a U.N.-Bound Double-Decker With Diplomats? Citing Risk, New Yorks Police Say No
description: The classic red London double-decker crossed the Atlantic by ship this spring. On its early runs through the streets of New York City, Prime Minister David Cameron and Prince Harry were passengers. It ventured as far away as Boston in its promotional campaign for all things British.

title: The Sizable Shadow That Wont Leave the Yankees
description: When Mark Teixeira squeezed the final out of the Yankees last championship, in 2009, he bolted across the diamond from first base. Teixeira would say later he had no plan for the celebration; he just took off, a spontaneous expression of joy. He was not trying to run toward Alex Rodriguez.

title: Can Pakistan Make Peace Next Door?
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  IN the spring of 1992, as the Communist government in Afghanistan started imploding after the collapse of the Soviet Union, seven Afghan mujahedeen leaders, pumped full of C.I.A. money, gathered in Peshawar, Pakistan, to discuss how to take over Afghanistan and share power peacefully.

title: Dont Treat Consumers Like Criminals
description: WASHINGTON  THE House Judiciary Committee will hold a much-needed hearing today on cellphone unlocking. At stake is whether wireless consumers can be prosecuted for what, not long ago, was considered a routine practice.

title: Promoter Ignored Ill Singer, Jackson Family Lawyers Say

title: The Way to Run College Sports
description: So, are you convinced yet? Do you need any more proof that college presidents are not qualified to run a major entertainment industry like college football and mens basketball? That whatever their academic and fund-raising skills, they are in over their heads whenever they involve themselves in the $6 billion-and-counting business that big-time college sports has become? Besides, dont they have other things to do?

title: Watchdog Halts Action on Researchers
description: The federal Office for Human Research Protections announced on Wednesday that it would suspend action against the University of Alabama at Birmingham, which it said in March did not adequately inform parents about the risks to their premature infants of enrollment in a large research trial.

They provided me with remarkable access to their courageous journey. (I did my best to protect their identities.) As youll see, a North Koreans pursuit of freedom comes at a price.

title: Tenniss Cloud of Dust
description: PARIS  For several months, Rafael Nadal has been vocal about his wish for fewer hardcourt tournaments and more on clay. The rationale is simple: the softer clay courts are much better for players knees.

Tseng was always better when they were juniors, and that didnt change years later when the two women found themselves half a world away competing on the L.P.G.A. Tour.

description: Wisconsin and Minnesota are neighboring states with long traditions of caring for the least fortunate, but, at the moment, only one of them is concerned about the health of the poor and uninsured.

This week President Obama proposed promising reforms to rein in lawsuits filed by businesses that buy patents with the intent of suing individuals and businesses for using or selling products that they claim violate their patents.

We all know that nothing on the planet compares to the awesome power of social media. But it may require more than a hashtag to bring this one home.

title: Paying Tribute to a Seeker of Justice, 50 Years After His Assassination
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Myrlie Evers-Williams, the widow of the slain civil rights leader Medgar Evers, said her husband was a man who saw a job that needed to be done, and he answered the call, not just for his people but for all people.

description: WASHINGTON  In an institution where seniority has long been prized, Representative John D. Dingell Jr. of Michigan is about to set a new standard with 57 years, 5 months and 26 days of House service  a remarkable tenure that spans more than a quarter of the existence of Congress.

description: Last season, Mark Appel, a Stanford right-hander, was considered by many to be the top prospect in his draft class. He did not attract the kind of attention once on Stephen Strasburg or Mark Prior, but as a polished starting pitcher who would probably need little time in the minors, he was thought to be a potential ace.

title: Helen Hanft, Master of Camp Way Off Broadway, Dies at 79
description: Helen Hanft, an actress whose mastery of camp humor, surreal scenarios and roles too risqu for mainstream comfort made her the acknowledged queen of the Off Off Broadway stage during a golden age for experimental theater in New York, died on May 30 in Manhattan. She was 79.

title: Iraq: 14 Travelers Are Killed by Gunmen
description: Gunmen killed 14 people in Nukhaib, a police official said. A local government official in Karbala, where several of the dead were from, said that the assailants had stopped the travelers at a fake checkpoint. The City Council of the Shiite holy city of Karbala issued a statement accusing Sunni insurgents and the Baath Party of being behind the killings. Iraq has been shaken by an upswing in sectarian attacks. There were no immediate claims of responsibility for the attack, The Associated Press reported.

Dwayne Johnson, a k a the Rock, above, oversees the action, with viewers voting for the winner of $1 million and the title. In 72 Hours, at 9, three teams of three strangers are dropped into the waters off the Yasawa Islands in Fiji, where they must find a briefcase filled with $100,000 in just 72 hours, supplied with only the clothes on their backs, a GPS device and a bottle of water. title: SAC Says It Will Survive
description: SAC Capital Advisors has told its employees that it will survive a wave of investor withdrawals amid the governments insider trading investigation, DealBooks Peter Lattman reports. Investors in the hedge fund, which is owned by Steven A. Cohen, have asked to withdraw a significant amount of money by a quarterly deadline on Monday, according to an internal e-mail sent by SACs president, Thomas J. Conheeney. The amount, though not disclosed, was said to be more than the $1.7 billion taken out earlier this year, meaning SAC would be left with a fraction of the $6 billion in outside capital with which it began the year, Mr. Lattman reports.

The daughter of a maid and a chauffeur, Fatima grew up in the Ismail Goth settlement near Karachis steel mills. After going to a school run by The Citizens Foundation, a nonprofit charity, she is now attending one of the citys prestigious business schools.

description: Joss Whedons adaptation of Much Ado About Nothing  perhaps the liveliest and most purely delightful movie I have seen so far this year  draws out the essential screwball nature of Shakespeares comedy. It may be the martini-toned black-and-white cinematography, the soign Southern California setting, or the combative courtship of Amy Ackers angular, sharp-tongued Beatrice and Alexis Denisofs grouchy, hangdog Benedick, but from its very first scenes, Mr. Whedons film crackles with a busy, slightly wayward energy that recalls the classic romantic sparring of the studio era.

description: Though The Simpsons has never revealed the exact location of Springfield, the familys hometown, a replica of it can now be found in Florida. Universal Orlando Resort has added a street scene and an attraction to the area surrounding its Simpsons Ride, which opened in 2008. Visitors can stroll along Fast Food Boulevard and grab a sandwich at Krusty Burger, a slice at Luigis Pizza and, of course, a Duff Beer at Moes Tavern. The busy aural embroidery of bird song that had awakened us an hour earlier had yet to fade. As we approached a man with a pungent pipe walking his dog on the main street in Giverny, an hour west of Paris by car, he nodded at us knowingly. Vous serez les premiers, he said with a chuckle. Bonne visite!

They use their baroque genitalia to deliver sperm to female reproductive tracts that are also corkscrew-shaped  but twisted in the opposite direction.

title: The Gun Report: June 6, 2013
description: As our colleague Charles Blow pointed out in his column yesterday, George Zimmerman is going on trial for the killing of Trayvon Martina killing, of course, that Zimmerman first got a pass on by invoking Floridas Stand Your Ground law. What weve come to realize in compiling the Gun Report each day is that more and more people feel completely justified to use a gun to settle an argument, to shoot first and ask questions latereven when the person who is killed is a drunk 16-year-old who accidentally climbs through a neighbors window instead of his ownand to defend themselves even when no defense is required. Stand Your Gun lawsas well as concealed carry laws, and laws that allow people to brandish weapons in publicare laws that provoke gun violence rather than prevent it, and help return us to the ethos of the wild west, where guns were the court of first resort. I would be nice to think that Zimmermans trial might change that, just a little, but were not holding our breath.

title: Rarely Together, Putins Meet Up Only to Split Up
description: MOSCOW  For years Moscow has been captivated by speculation about the apparently moribund marriage of President Vladimir V. Putin. He was in love with an Olympic gymnast half his age, some said. His wife, Lyudmila, was not seen in public for months at a time, and when she did appear with the president they behaved like strangers.

title: Fed Reports American Households Have Regained Ground Lost in the Recession
description: Buoyed by a healthier housing sector and a soaring stock market, American households continue to regain ground lost during the financial crisis and the severe recession that followed.

title: Empathy Without Boundaries
description: Jean McFee Raichle, 94, is a remarkably cheerful woman. She lives in an assisted living center in Seattle staffed by aides who are warm and nurturing. She exists in the moment, mostly untroubled by her Alzheimers disease.

title: Robbing a Gas Station: The Hacker Way
description: Thieves of the future will look back on todays stick-up artists and have a good old belly laugh. Why would anyone ever rob a cashier with a gun, when all that is needed is a smartphone?

title: A Look Back at the Films of Esther Williams
description: The swimmer-turned-movie-star Esther Williams, who died today at the age of 91, became famous for taking her swimming skills to the big screen in Technicolor spectacles from the 1940s and 50s. Below are clips and trailers from some of her memorable films.

title: President Obamas Dragnet
description: Within hours of the disclosure that federal authorities routinely collect data on phone calls Americans make, regardless of whether they have any bearing on a counterterrorism investigation, the Obama administration issued the same platitude it has offered every time President Obama has been caught overreaching in the use of his powers: Terrorists are a real menace and you should just trust us to deal with them because we have internal mechanisms (that we are not going to tell you about) to make sure we do not violate your rights.

title: A Fallen New Yorker Writer Signs With Simon & Schuster
description: Jonah Lehrer, the disgraced writer who resigned from The New Yorker after he was discovered plagiarizing and fabricating material, has sold a book to Simon & Schuster that uses his journalistic misconduct as a case study of the mysterious and redeeming power of love.

title: Portent of Peril for Muni Bondholders
description: The bankruptcy of the most populous county in Alabama moved closer to resolution this week with an agreement providing that investors will lose 20 percent of the money they invested in bonds that were rated AAA. The big loser financially is JPMorgan Chase, which underwrote many of the securities  and paid bribes to get the business.

title: Bryan Brothers Excited to Be in Another French Final
description: Fatherhood is going well for Bob Bryan: many new fathers would envy his claim that his 16-month-old daughter sleeps through the night. Things are going well on the tennis court, too.

description: With his presidential library now open, former President George W. Bush brought in new leadership for his foundation and public policy institute on Thursday, turning to one of his longest serving and most trusted advisers.
