title: Young Pianist, Younger Festival
description: Conrad Tao, a gifted composer-pianist who is in the Columbia University-Juilliard School joint degree program, will celebrate his 19th birthday on Tuesday by inaugurating the Unplay Festival. This three-day event that he is organizing at the Powerhouse Arena in Brooklyn will explore several themes, including the musicians evolving role in contemporary culture and how and why particular works come to be considered standard repertory.

title: Eager for Release on a Big Stage
description: Some choreographers might be daunted by 4,000 square feet of empty space. But in Coming Together/Attica, a United States premiere, the Brooklyn artist Rebecca Lazier plans to take full advantage of the sprawling third-floor loft at the Invisible Dog Art Center. Guided by Davison Scandretts lighting scheme, the performance migrates between the far ends of the room, a 50-minute exploration of isolation and breaking free.

title: Classic Tensions, Set to Hip-Hop
description: In 2010, Time magazine declared Venice that years best musical, but its unlikely that many theatergoers are familiar with this Shakespeare-influenced, hip-hop- and rock-infused tale of a dystopian society on the brink of civil war. In New York, the Public Theater is now providing a chance to see Venice, a collaboration between the performer Matt Sax and the director Eric Rosen, who wrote the lyrics together.

title: A Hearing to Remember
description: The annual Human Rights Watch Film Festival, Thursday to June 23 at the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the IFC Center, is as close as anything to being the social conscience of the film industry. Not that of Hollywood, mind you, but of more high-minded, noncommercial independent and world cinema.

title: Movements Frozen Into Folk Tales
description: The self-taught Alabama artist Bill Traylor is known for his flat, simple shapes. But in chronicling memories and observations from African-American life, his work also had complexity and depth. The New York Times critic Roberta Smith has called Traylor the American master of taut silhouettes, yet some of his work is literally about movement, evoking dances of his era like the Lindy Hop and the Cakewalk, with women in hoop skirts and men in high hats.

title: Hip-Hops Global Accent Finds Harlem
description: A storied New York institution imports a festival of hip-hop, that pride of the Bronx, from Britain. The notion, as Jonzi D, the founder, artistic director and host of the festival, joked in a recent Skype interview, sounds like bringing ice to the Inuit. But next weekend, for the first time, Breakin Convention will travel across the Atlantic to the Apollo Theater in Harlem.

title: A Bond Forged Over Time on the Open Sea
description: A decade ago, as the first R Family Vacations cruise prepared to set sail, Kelli Carpenter envisioned a place where same-sex couples could take their parents, their siblings and their children, and commune with people just like them.

title: Fashion Stylist Annabel Tollman Dies
description: Annabel Tollman, a British stylist known for her work with celebrities like Scarlett Johansson, Mariah Carey and Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, died in her sleep this week. She was 39. Born in Brussels, Ms. Tollman, who attended Central Saint Martins in London, was previously the fashion director of Interview magazine. She also worked with eBay and Calvin Klein and contributed to several fashion publications. Over the years, she became known for an Old Hollywood aesthetic. The cause of her death is not yet known. Police responded to a call at her West Village apartment yesterday between 4:00 and 5:00 p.m. A message signed Annabels Family & Friends was posted on her Facebook page today, which included: At this time, there is not confirmation of what caused this tragedy.

title: Is Everyone Out to Steal My Umbrella?
description: A friend walked to a restaurant and left his umbrella in the front basket. The umbrella was taken by someone else. My friend took another umbrella from the basket that was similar to his own. He hoped it belonged to the person who took his (and assumed it had been taken by mistake). Of course, theres no way of telling if the original theft was an honest mistake. So my question is not What should an ethical person have done? but rather What should an ethical person presume? Should one presume that most people want to do right and that these types of oversights can be ameliorated by a response like my friends? Or should one presume that most people are thieving heels? NAME WITHHELD, LOS ANGELES

title: Shaping Taksim Square
description: The decision by Turkeys prime minister to clean up Taksim Square has provoked outrage.

title: Trading a Daughter for a Strong Wind
description: In his latest program Pascal Rioult appears to be invoking Martha Graham. On Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Rioult, a French choreographer who has made New York his home since 1981 and who danced with Grahams company, opened a particularly ponderous program of works exploring Greek mythology (Iphigenia, based on Euripides Iphigenia in Aulis, and On Distant Shores, a study of Helen of Troy); transformation (Prelude to Night); and forceful unison formation (Bolero).

title: On the Market in Hilton Head, S.C.
description: Homes in gated communities with amenities that include pools, wine rooms, elevators, movie theaters, yachting and golf.

title: Who and Where Is the Original Who Made That? Maker?
description: If youve ever wondered who made that Who Made That? column in the front of the magazine, the answer is Hilary Greenbaum. It began March 7, 2011, in this very space when Greenbaum, a former designer at the magazine, published a blog post about some illustrations then appearing on Diet Coke cans. She followed up with investigations into the origins of subway tiles, the rainbow flag, album covers for the Decemberists and that chung-chung sound known to all watchers of Law and Order. The posts proved popular (Greenbaums theory: Since everything has gone so digital, I think people are becoming more interested in physical objects), which led to a weekly column (she recalls the one on snow globes, which involved an interview with the actor Corbin Bernsen, with particular fondness) and then to this weekends special Who Made That? Innovations Issue.

title: Pedro Almodovar: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the filmmaker Pedro Almodovar and the cast of his film, Im So Excited!

title: In Istanbuls Heart, Leaders Obsession, Perhaps Achilles Heel
description: ISTANBUL  On a normal day, Taksim Square is a mess of buses and crowds, a tangle of plazas, streets, shops and taxi horns. Turkeys prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is determined to clean it up and make it into a pedestrian zone, with a new mall, mosque and tunnels for traffic to move underground.

title: Errani and Vinci Return to Womens Doubles Final
description: Sara Errani endured a humiliating afternoon Thursday, but Fridays womens doubles semifinals gave her a chance at redemption. With Roberta Vinci, she enjoyed a 6-3, 5-7, 6-3 win over third-seeded Nadia Petrova and Katarina Srebotnik, putting the Italians in the French Open final for the second year running.

title: Aiming for the Hybrids Sweet Spot
description: Berkeley, Calif.  Using electricity as an automotive fuel, to most Americans, seems as alien as powering a car by Higgs bosons. Electricity, theyd say, might be fine for fueling exotic sport machines made by California start-ups  or for tiny Japanese mobility pods  but not the family sedans of Americas highways.

title: Making a Mountain Out of a Digital Molehill
description: ATLANTA  THE revelations this week that the federal government has been scooping up records of telephone calls inside the United States for seven years, and secretly collecting information from Internet companies on foreigners overseas for nearly six years, have elicited predictable outrage from liberals and civil libertarians.

title: Great Range, but Doesnt Travel Well
description: The Ford Fusion Energi and Honda Accord Plug-In Hybrid could have been satisfying to mainstream consumers. But their pipsqueak trunks kill the deal.

title: Redefining Under the Influence in Colorado
description: DENVER  With the recreational use of marijuana now legal in Colorado, officers who patrol the states roads face a new set of challenges. Though smoking or possessing small amounts of cannabis is no longer breaking the law, anyone who drives while impaired is still subject to arrest.

title: Claramae Turner, 92, Singer and Heart of a Song
description: Renowned for her lustrous voice, Claramae Turner sang more than 100 times with the Metropolitan Opera. But she is best known  or, more precisely, best unknown  for having introduced I Left My Heart in San Francisco, the sentimental ballad indelibly associated with Tony Bennett.

title: Where Rehab Meets Reality
description: Around dusk on Feb. 17, Dr. Drew Pinsky was sitting at the computer in his hillside home in Pasadena, Calif., when he received an e-mail from a friend with some troubling news. Mindy McCready, a 37-year-old country singer and a star of the third season of Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew, a television show that made its debut on VH1 in 2008, had shot herself at her house in Heber Springs, Ark.

title: Gunman Kills 4 in California Before He Is Killed
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Four people were killed and five wounded on Friday morning as a gunman, dressed in black and carrying an assault rifle, strode across Santa Monica firing at people, cars, a public bus and buildings before being shot and killed by the police at the Santa Monica College Library, the authorities said.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Istanbul, Germany and Nepal.

title: TimesTalks | Pedro Almodovar: Preview
description: The director discusses his comedy Im So Excited!, and explores the use of music and sexuality in his films.

title: Ex-Leader of Planned Mosque Near Ground Zero Settles Suit With Donor
description: The former leader of a proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero in Lower Manhattan has settled a lawsuit in which a donor accused him of spending charitable contributions on himself, both sides confirmed on Friday.

title: Staten Island Ferry, 1:15 P.M.
Russians Dreaming in French
description: After its early dominance of international film production was shattered by World War I, France never quite managed to sustain a studio system on the Hollywood industrial model. What the French achieved instead was an artisanal cinema built around independent producers, several of whom  like Adolphe Osso in the 1930s, Andr Paulv in the 50s and Anatole Dauman in the 60s and 70s  had tastes pronounced enough to establish identities for their firms. These maisons de production functioned more like book publishers than dream factories, attracting a certain kind of talent for individual productions rather than putting rosters of stars and filmmakers under contract for a steady stream of releases.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Hyperloop Theories and N.S.A. Surveillance
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Theyre Jumping Through Hoops, Dreamily
description: There are at least two kinds of lava in the world, and both move. One is the bubbling, molten rock expelled by a volcano; another is LAVA, Sarah East Johnsons all-female, environmentally conscious company, which mixes dance and acrobatics.

title: The Dancing Life, Condensed
description: Headlong Dance Theater, a Philadelphia company, has never existed under a set of choreographic rules. Formed 20 years ago by David Brick, Andrew Simonet and Amy Smith (though Mr. Simonet left last year),the group has staged works in hotel swimming pools, explored the cult of Britney Spears and constructed a performance journey for one audience member at a time led by a cellphone.

title: Sooner Than Expected, CBS Largely Finishes Upfront Sales
description: A second big English-language broadcast television network, CBS, has just about wrapped up its sales of commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 season in what is known as the upfront market.

title: The Tinkling of the Keys, the Slapping of the Thighs
description: Jazz musicians use their physical presence all the time in projecting an artistic persona, although its usually conveying muted concentration or communion, enveloping their instrument or listening to anothers with laser focus. Not too many jazz musicians in recent decades come close to physical comedy when they perform, as Fats Waller and Louis Armstrong did. There have been the Dutch players who poke fun at jazz convention with critical remove: Han Bennink and Misha Mengelberg and Willem Breuker. And then theres Stefano Bollani, who isnt much like any of them.

title: Four Classical Composers, Caught in Love Affairs With Popular Music
description: The season-ending program of 20th-century music that the Riverside Symphony and its music director, George Rothman, presented at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night was well thought out, smart and illuminating. Snazzy, too.

title: All Aboard for a Writers Views on His Adopted Homeland
description: MILAN  Thats very strange, Tim Parks, the polymath writer, said recently, waiting at the top of an escalator at the Porta Garibaldi train station in Milan. Your train didnt even appear on the board.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 7
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: President Obama on The Daily Show
description: In an Oct. 18, 2012, interview on Comedy Centrals The Daily Show, President Obama talked about how his wiretapping policies differ from those from the Bush era.

title: Putin Aide Denies Divorce Is Driven by a Relationship
description: MOSCOW  A spokesman for President Vladimir V. Putin took the unusual step on Friday of announcing publicly that Mr. Putin is not in a romantic relationship, trying to quiet speculation that he and his wife of 29 years are divorcing to allow him to remarry.

title: The Trial to Select USA-1 Bermuda Team
description: The 120-board final of the open trial to select the USA-1 Bermuda Bowl team will finish on Saturday. The match is John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst and Kevin Dwyer versus Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Zia Mahmood, Chip Martel, Michael Rosenberg and Chris Willenken.

title: Kendall Jenner, a Sister Who Does More Than Keep Up
description: Kendall Jenner seemed stilted, perhaps because she was being aggressively managed.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 7
description: More photographs.

title: Pussy Riot Takes Manhattan, Quietly
description: If there is ignominy in being anonymous at the premiere of your own movie, the ladies of Pussy Riot didnt show it. There they were, without their trademark bright balaclavas, sitting at the back of the Landmark Sunshine Cinema on the Lower East Side on Wednesday evening, awaiting the showing of an HBO documentary called Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer.

title: Movie Review: 'Wish You Were Here'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Wish You Were Here."

title: An Arab Cartoonist in Motion
description: Khalid Albaihs cartoons have become a symbol for uprisings across the Arab world. Watch how he does them.

title: Setting New Coordinates
description: Three years ago, Christopher J. Raxworthy, an associate curator of vertebrate biology at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, ventured to Madagascar in its rainy season to pursue his interest in chameleons. His account of that field expedition was the start of the Scientist at Work blog, and the first of many tales from the field told in words, photos and video by an array of adventurous and determined scientists.

title: Foreclosure Is New Blow to Nashville Symphony
description: For a while, the Nashville Symphony Orchestra seemed to have everything going for it. After a triumphant Carnegie Hall debut in 2000, it began to make compact discs prolifically, winning a handful of Grammys and a reputation for its championship of contemporary American music along the way. And it opened a sumptuous new concert hall, the 1,844 seat, $123 million Schermerhorn Symphony Center, in 2006.

title: President Obama on Surveillance
description: President Obama clip from June 7 discussing government surveillance.

title: Cartoons Seen Across the Arab World
description: Khalid Albaihs illustrations have captured the politics of his native Sudan as well as developments across the rest of the Arab world, where his work has inspired even more tumult.

title: All in Harmony
description: As the New York Philharmonics orchestra personnel manager, Carl R. Schiebler keeps rehearsals running on time, tracks down substitutes and serves as fixer. Mr. Schiebler, 75, was the St. Louis Symphony Orchestras second hornist and later its personnel manager before coming to the Philharmonic in 1986. When he is not taking care of one of his 106 orchestra members, Mr. Schiebler splits his time between his apartment on the Upper West Side and Pleasantville, N.Y., where he lives with his wife, Noriko Whyte, a pianist and music teacher.

title: A Look Nicer Than the Name
description: Welcome to the summer of the rash guard. If you dont already own one of these surfer mainstays, you probably will soon. And (unlike in summers past) it will be cute.

title: Cartoonists Pen Leaves Mark Across Arab World
description: DOHA, Qatar  THERE are many players in a protest  the sign makers, the rabble rousers, the logisticians. And then there are the political cartoonists, who sketch the events unfolding on the streets and, if they are like Khalid Albaih, inspire even more tumult.

title: As Criticism Grows, Curtailing Surveillance Program Seems Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON  New revelations about the scope of government surveillance elicited some bipartisan criticism in Congress on Friday, but beyond the bluster, prospects for a legislative response to curtail monitoring of Internet and telephone communications appear remote.

title: The I Dos, Unplugged
description: The attendant was stationed at the front door of my friend Michaels wedding. The ceremony is in the chapel, she said to the arriving guests. The ragtime band will be playing in the courtyard. The mini-cheeseburgers and lobster rolls will be served under the tent.

title: President Obama on Wiretapping in 2005
description: In 2005, President Obama, then a U.S. Senator, spoke about wiretapping.

title: Movie Review: 'The Internship'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Internship."

title: Student Social Climbing, but on an Indoor Bike
description: Like many college students, Madeleine Rosuck spent much of her first year at the University of Texas in pursuit of a good party. She road-tripped with 19 sorority sisters for a spring break beachside bacchanal, hit the weekend-long blur of fraternity parties known as Roundup  and panted through five classes a week at Cyc, an indoor cycling gym in Austin.

title: Where Angry Children Stomp, and Pop Has a Strut
description: Bit by bit, to marvelous effect, the choreography of the Broadway musical Matilda becomes central to the whole production. Most of its characters are caricatures. Their movement takes that caricaturish quality and makes it vivid in terms of rhythm, gesture and formal dance steps.

title: Worship, Austin Style
description: Sunday services at Vox Veniae, a Protestant church in Austin, Tex., feature a six-piece band and volunteer baristas. The 200-member congregation reflects the eclectic city.

title: Need a Theater? Broadway Vacancies Are Up
description: In a weak Broadway season defined by unusually long vacancies, the St. James Theater looked as if it finally had a new booking this spring, as posters for a Raymond Carver play went up on the marquee.

title: Standing Above the Cookie Crowd
description: The word from Venice, and the 55th go-round of the worlds oldest biennial of contemporary art, is that the hotshot young curator Massimiliano Gioni has a hit on his hands: a quiet success, the New York Times critic Holland Cotter wrote, that was largely achieved through a refreshing approach of mixing  desegregating, if you will  outsider and insider artists.

title: Live Streaming: TimesTalks With Pedro Almodvar
description: ArtsBeat streamed Friday nights conversation with the Spanish director Pedro Almodvar, whose latest film, Im So Excited, opens June 28. The conversation, at TheTimesCenter in Manhattan, was moderated by Lorne Manly, a New York Times journalist.

title: A Le Corbusier Rooftop Gets a New Life as an Arts Space
description: One of the greatest achievements of the pioneering architect and urbanist Le Corbusier is Cit Radieuse, an extensive apartment complex in Marseille, France, which he completed in the early 1950s. Often described as a vertical village, it has 337 apartments, a restaurant, a hotel, a bookstore and a nursery school. France classified it as a historical monument in the 1980s. When the buildings rooftop gym and solarium went up for sale in 2010, the French designer Ito Morabito, who goes by Ora-Ito professionally, purchased it as a collector might. Like you buy a piece of art, but architecture, he explained.

title: Breaking the Evangelical Mold at a Church With Ethnic Roots
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Last Sunday at Vox Veniae, a 200-person church in working-class East Austin, the volunteer baristas showed up an hour before worship services to make locally sourced coffee in the vaunted Chemex system, beloved of connoisseurs. To enhance the java-snob appeal, no milk or sugar was provided. Its a purist thing, one barista said.

title: Promoter Is Charged in Radiohead Stage Collapse
description: The Ontario Ministry of Labor has brought charges against Live Nation Canada for safety violations in connection with the stage collapse at an outdoor Radiohead concert last year that killed the bands drum technician, Scott Johnson, and injured three other workers, The Toronto Star reported on Friday.

title: Friday Night Music: Zaz
description: We Americans, we are an insular people. A European suggested that I might like Isabelle Geffroy, and when I looked up her performances I discovered that she has a huge multinational following  but none of my usual music sources here had even heard of her.

title: Comparing Two Secret Surveillance Programs
description: The targets and types of data collected by the two government programs recently revealed.

title: Gaza Farmers Near Fence With Israel Remain Wary
description: WADI GAZA, Gaza Strip  About 185 yards from the fence that separates Gaza from Israel, 300 rows of green chili pepper plants are sprouting on farmland that lay barren for years.

title: A Seasons Last Concert Restores a Works Lost Passages
description: For all the sturdy proclamations and occasional bluster in Mendelssohns Reformation Symphony, the real drama occurs at moments when intense dynamism yields to blessed simplicity. Thomas Crawford, the founder and music director of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, made the most of one of those crucial junctures on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall in the last concert of the ensembles 28th season but, by his own choice, pretty much missed another.

title: A Much-Anticipated Recital, Sans Shoes
description: The defining mission of Le Poisson Rouge, the popular Greenwich Village club and cabaret, is to present all kinds of contemporary music. On successive nights you can hear an indie rock band, a jazz singer or a string quartet playing Xenakis.

title: Retirement Risks of Bonds
description: Conventional wisdomsays people should hold more bonds as they age. Butultralow interest rates haveleft many would-be retireeswith a big problem:the chance that they will exhaust their bond portfolios before they die. The outlook is worse for people who retire earlier and withdraw more. Adding stocks to a portfolio increases therisk of big losses, but italso reduces the risk that youll outlive your money.

title: Obama on Drones
description: President Obama talks about drones.

title: Waving My Tweak Flag High
description: In my years of writing and performing songs Ive come to realize that small, even accidental, lyric changes can greatly improve (or screw up) a song. Sometimes I notice it in my own songs; an accident of vocal delivery on stage one night might turn a light bulb on and then remain an integral part of a song forever, leaving me to lament that my officially released album recording is weaker than the currently performed version.

title: Week in Pictures for June 7
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a scene in the South Bronx, a music hall in Hoboken, N.J., and a tribute to Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: What to Watch on Day 14 of the French Open
description: And then there were two. The top two. For the fourth time this year, it will be No. 1 vs. No. 2, with all three previous meetings won by the No. 1. Will Saturdays French Open womens singles final break that trend on Saturday? Unlikely.

Developing New Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
