description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills at Least 7 in Pakistan as New Prime Minister Announces Cabinet
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least seven people were killed late Friday when an American drone fired three missiles at a house in northwestern Pakistan, according to an intelligence official, hours after the countrys new prime minister announced his cabinet.

title: Golfing in Cape Breton
description: The Times photographer Piotr Redlinski explores the rugged landscape of Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, in a series of images from local golf courses.

title: Bill Cunningham | Tails, You Win
description: Short in front, long in back: some people call it indecision; others, the best of two worlds.

title: Restaurant Chains Try to Woo a Younger Generation
description: From sun-dried tomato wraps to agave-sweetened smoothies, restaurant chains are working to court an exceptionally particular generation  the millennials.

title: Martian Rock Another Clue to a Once Water-Rich Planet
description: The discovery of what appears to be a clay-rich rock on Mars adds to the portrait of the planet as one that once  in its youth, more than three and a half billion years ago  was a water-rich world with conditions amenable for life, NASA scientists said Friday.

title: Safety Agency Shuts Down Discount Bus Line
description: Passengers who paid $15 to ride Lucky Star buses between Chinatown in Manhattan and Boston were apparently lucky that they or their luggage did not fall onto Interstate 95 at high speed.

title: Pierre Mauroy, Socialist Who Led Changes in France, Dies at 84
description: PARIS  Pierre Mauroy, who as Frances first Socialist prime minister since the beginning of the Fifth Republic in 1958 pushed through some of the Socialist Partys most important overhauls, died on Friday in a hospital near Paris. He was 84.

title: David Simon, Creator of The Wire, Debates N.S.A. Surveillance With Readers of His Blog
description: David Simon, the former reporter behind the television drama The Wire, which President Obama calls one of the greatest shows of all time, came to the defense of his embattled fan on Friday, suggesting in a long post on his blog that the national eruption over the rather inevitable and understandable collection of all raw data involving telephonic and Internet traffic by Americans was misguided.

title: Get Ready to Watch Some Big Destruction
description: Heres something fun to do Sunday morning. Get up early and watch a building be imploded in your pajamas. That is  watch it in your pajamas. The building is not in your pajamas. It is on Governors Island.

title: Splits Appear in Policy Troika Addressing Europes Financial Crisis
description: BRUSSELS  After a series of nightlong crisis meetings on Cyprus, the European Unions economic policy chief, Olli Rehn, remarked that his wife had started complaining that he spent more time with Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, than with her.

title: She Rode Horses, Drove an S.U.V. and, the Authorities Say, Farmed Marijuana
description: There were many mornings, the authorities say, when a gray Mercedes GL4 S.U.V. pulled out from a driveway on a wooded street in Scarsdale, N.Y., and cruised through the Bronx before ending up inside an ugly, brick-face building in an industrial stretch of Queens.

title: More Space, and a Bigger Menu, Too
description: Modern, New Rochelles beloved pizza joint, moved this past winter from cramped quarters to a lofty space that was first a car showroom and later a restaurant supply store. As recorded on various social media sites, loyal patrons were variously elated and scandalized. But no one can dispute that the new home of this Italian-American emporium  with its vaulted ceiling, giant arched windows and granite floor  is a knockout.

title: Scam Suspects Become the Victims
description: The scams elaborate setup began Monday afternoon with a simple question on a Chinatown sidewalk, and built itself up in a series of seemingly chance encounters and grave predictions. Grave in tone, but also as in coming from a dead person below ground.

title: Homey Ambience, and a Changing Menu
description: Picador, on Elm Street in New Canaan, may succeed where previous occupants of its tiny space have failed over the years. This new 31-seat restaurant, which opened around Thanksgiving, is minute, but charming, like dining in a private home, with copper tabletops, several framed wall mirrors, carriage lamps, and a banquette along the end wall piled with big puffy cushions. One wall is decorated with a display of colorful Spanish ceramic plates.

title: Summer Shades of White and Ros
description: GIVEN THE NUMBER OF TASTERS last month at Brooklyn Uncorked, where only Long Island wines are sampled, vintners on the Island might expect a flood of summer visitors.

title: Choice for U.N. Post Gets Israeli Vote of Confidence
description: WASHINGTON  Samantha Power, President Obamas choice to be the next ambassador to the United Nations, is encountering resistance from pro-Israel groups for remarks she once made about Israel and the Palestinians. But on Friday, she got an unexpected vote of confidence from Israels representative in the United States.

title: Flavors of the Andes, Everywhere
description: Corn is not only a staple of the food at Cuzco Peru in Lynbrook, but it also finds its way into one of the soft drinks: chicha morada, made from purple corn here flavored with citrus juice, cinnamon and tiny cubes of apple.

title: Joey Covington, Rock Drummer, Dies at 67
description: Joey Covington, a drummer for the psychedelic rock band Jefferson Airplane in the early 1970s and a founding member of their bluesy spinoff Hot Tuna, died on Tuesday. He was 67.

title: Dont Forsake the Gray Wolf
description: KETCHUM, Idaho  IT has been celebrated as one of the great victories of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. After several decades of federal protection, gray wolves  once nearly wiped out in the continental United States  have reached a population of roughly 6,100 across three Great Lakes states and seven Western states.

title: Expansive Space, Portions and Flavors
description: To visit the sprawling Ria Mar Restaurant and Bar is to step into a holiday of plenty: a vast restaurant with two separate dining areas; a sea of tables; endless plastic pitchers of sangria; poster-size pictures; and a wave-shaped installation covering an entire wall in both rooms.

title: With Little Time Before Election, Senate Race in New Jersey Begins to Take Shape
description: The candidates for United States Senate in New Jersey have not even all declared themselves, but with a deadline to file petitions looming on Monday, the shape of the race to succeed Frank R. Lautenberg is already coming into view.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: For a Street Festival, Hats On!
description: THE ORGANIZERS OF THE INAUGURAL Hat City Streets Festival, to be held June 15 in Orange, hope no one shows up to the free daylong event bareheaded.

title: But for the Bloody Hands, a Fine Lad Indeed
description: WOMEN LOVE BAD BOYS, they say. But in J. M. Synges timeless comedy The Playboy of the Western World, a whole village falls in love with one  a young man who staggers through the pub door one evening and soon confesses that he has killed his father.

title: Cicada Sex: All Together Now
description: As part of the World Science Festival, the Staten Island Museum celebrated its insect collection with a night of drinks, art, music and conversation inspired by the mating strategies of bugs.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: In Bosnia, a Protest Over IDs Traps Hundreds in Parliament
description: It was a decidedly Balkan revolt and a rare explosion of people power in one of Europes poorest and most ethnically divided countries.

title: Christie, at G.O.P. Event, Finds Many Unburned Bridges
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Gov. Chris Christie addressed Mitt Romneys financial inner circle on Friday, and the most telling moment may have been the question-and-answer session that followed: No one brought up the hug.

title: Kentucky and New York Make Storied Rivals and Partners
description: Perhaps the lone uncontested aspect of the sport of thoroughbred racing in America is that its history and its future are rooted in the states of Kentucky and New York. Their longstanding competition that will gain a new chapter with Saturdays Belmont Stakes.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: United States automakers kept up strong sales, Boeings 787s returned to the air in Japan, and Wal-Mart shareholders gathered under the cloud of a bribery scandal.

title: An Invasion of 17-Year-Olds, Loud, Lusty and Six-Legged
description: There are a few acts of nature, such as the passage of Halleys comet or the transit of Venus, that are so rare and so dramatic as to seem like metaphors for the virtues of patience itself. But of all of these, the arrival of the 17-year cicadas, the noisy insects that nestled under the earth for that length of time and recently awakened by the millions to spawn, may be the grossest.

title: An Enchanted Evening Open to Possibilities
description: Even before the cute siblings sing their playful Dites-Moi, and before the American nurse and the French plantation owner tenderly embark on their romance, the production of South Pacific at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport exudes a sense of open-ended possibilities. The simple but elegant set designed by Josh Zangen does it, with four hanging, slatted panels evoking airy Pacific island architecture, and four rattan-like borders framing the stage, one behind the other.

title: A South Korean Stays in the Fairway and in Front
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  Continuing rain on Friday did not bother Chella Choi of South Korea, who took a one-shot lead at five-under 67 in the first round of the L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Richard Ramirez, the Night Stalker Killer, Dies at 53
description: Richard Ramirez, who claimed to be inspired by Satan when he killed at least 14 people in the Night Stalker attacks that terrorized California in 1985, died on Friday in a hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 53.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: The Plan to Change Taksim Square
description: In response to a plan by Turkeys prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, for a pedestrian zone, the square has become a stage for clashing worldviews.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 7, 2013

title: Dr. Js Slam Dunk
description: Julius Erving, known as Dr. J, was a basketball legend in the A.B.A. and then the N.B.A. when the leagues merged in 1976. A new documentary about his life, called The Doctor, will air on NBA TV.

title: Tech Companies Concede to Surveillance Program
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When government officials came to Silicon Valley to demand easier ways for the worlds largest Internet companies to turn over user data as part of a secret surveillance program, the companies bristled. In the end, though, many cooperated at least a bit.

title: Fifes and Drums as Performance Art
description: Social practice is a relatively new term for art that puts less emphasis on objects made for individual contemplation and more energy into projects involving participation, activism or community organizing. Of course, plenty of artists were making art like this before critics and scholars christened it social practice. One such artist is Allison Smith, whose exhibition Allison Smith: Rudiments of Fife and Drum combines elements of craft, performance and participation and is currently on view at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: In This Sport, Beware of Left Hooks, Jabs and Castling
description: The title highlights a contradiction, pairing an intellectual activity in which the combatants never touch and a combat sport in which opponents aim fists at each others chins. There is chess. There is boxing. And then there is chessboxing.

title: Video and Images From Scene of Santa Monica Shooting Spree
description: The shooting spree in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday, which left four people and the gunman dead, began on Yorkshire Avenue, where the Fire Department responded at 11:52 a.m. to a report of a structure fire, officials said.

title: News of U.S. Surveillance Draws Anger of Activists and Militants Abroad
description: Mohamed al-Hadi, an antigovernment activist in Syria, had just received a Skype briefing from rebels about the Ming military airport near the northern city of Aleppo, a protracted battleground in the countrys civil war. Then he learned that the United States government had the ability to monitor that call, as well as a broad range of other information transmitted through the Internet.

title: Weather Muddles Belmont Outlook
description: There will be no Triple Crown on the line for the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday and perhaps very little sunshine thanks to Tropical Storm Andrea. But there will be plenty on the line as the Kentucky Derby winner Orb has a chance to avenge his loss to Oxbow in the Preakness Stakes.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 8, 2013
description: Nobody is listening to your telephone calls.

title: Administration Says Mining of Data Is Crucial to Fight Terror
description: WASHINGTON  In early September 2009, an e-mail passed through an Internet address in Peshawar, Pakistan, that was being monitored by the vast computers controlled by American intelligence analysts. It set off alarms. The address, linked to senior Qaeda operatives, had been dormant for months.

title: The Senate vs. the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court
description: Four senators wrote a letter to the court asking it to provide summaries of its opinions on domestic spying, but the court resisted.  Here is the letter from the senators and the response from the court.

title: Congress Can Stop Privacy Abuse
description: Over the last three years, several measures were introduced in Congress that would have helped reduce or eliminate the abuses of communications surveillance revealed this week. Every one of them was voted down.

title: The I.M.F. Admits Mistakes. Will Europe?
description: The International Monetary Fund admitted this week that it made big errors in the first bailout of Greece three years ago, but it added that no matter what it did then the country would have suffered a deep recession. European Union officials, by contrast, still refuse to concede that their handling of the financial crisis has been deeply flawed.

title: Many Rival Nations Surge Past the U.S. in Adding New Jobs
description: The American economy may be the worlds biggest, but when it comes to job creation since the recession hit at the end of 2007, it is far from a leader.

title: Whats All the Fuss About Bikes?
description: New Yorkers will tolerate almost anything, including obvious inconveniences like overcrowded subways. Why, then, all the anxiety and hyperventilating over something that is indisputably a good thing: the short-term bicycle rentals that have become available in parts of the city?

title: Happy Belmont Day
description: Saturday is not a particularly noteworthy day in my life; no birthdays or anniversaries to commemorate, no real attached significance at all.

title: Racial Injustice in North Carolina
description: The North Carolina Legislature repealed the states Racial Justice Act this week, and the Republican governor, Pat McCrory, is expected to sign the bill. But the state cannot erase the detailed and irrefutable proof of ugly racial bias that led a state trial judge to resentence four death row inmates to life without parole because of this statute.

title: Collegial Charcuterie
description: Swine, a pork-based place at 531 Hudson Street in the West Village, is one of those establishments that pack a full menu of gastronomic trends into a fashionably monosyllabic name. On the one hand, the owners of the year-old restaurant have described it as a neighborhood dive and, indeed, there is a pinball machine beside the bar and a vintage Ping-Pong table in the basement playfully reclaimed for communal dining. On the other hand, the fare tends toward artisanal charcuterie and small-production wines. The clientele is similarly varied, including, on a recent evening, some European tourists, a liquor distributor and his date, and a group of seven lawyers who had dropped by to visit one of the proprietors, Cris Criswell, who, until three months ago, was working at their firm.

title: Corrections: June 8, 2013
description: SPORTS

title: Trix Alternative
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I must be getting better at these things. I felt this was one of the easiest Saturday puzzles Ive done in a while.

title: Nuclear Power Plant in Limbo Decides to Close
description: The owners of the San Onofre nuclear power plant in Southern California, which has been shut since January 2012, said on Friday that they would close it permanently because of uncertainty over when it could be reopened.

title: At Murder Trial, Jurors Hear of Turbulent Relationship
description: There were a few things about her younger boyfriend that Sylvie Cachay thought needed to change.

title: Obama and Xi Tackle Cybersecurity as Talks Begin in California
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.  President Obama, midway through much-anticipated weekend talks with President Xi Jinping of China, said Friday night that there was no parallel between the cyberattacks on American businesses and government interests that it blames on China and the United States governments surveillance of phone and Internet traffic to foil terrorists.

title: Spurs Stinginess With the Ball Draws Generous Attention Before Game 2
description: MIAMI  The first possession of the N.B.A. finals went exactly the way the Miami Heat had hoped, with Tim Duncan forced into a turnover that resulted in a fast-break dunk for Dwyane Wade.

title: Intelligence for Dummies
description: Question for the day: Do you feel more secure or less secure, now that you know the government is keeping a gargantuan pile of information about everybodys telephone calls in the name of national security?

title: A Giant Among Pygmies
description: For 40 years, Joe Durso, 58, has been strutting and fretting upon the Seaside Courts next to the Boardwalk in Coney Island, the mecca of one-wall handball, and a place that claims Mr. Durso as perhaps its greatest and most frustrated player.

title: How to Monetize Plagiarism
description: This is a column about Jonah Lehrer, the 31-year-old disgraced former New Yorker writer who recently  sigh  landed a contract for a book about love. (Yes, love.) But I want to start by recalling another disgraced former magazine writer: Stephen Glass.

title: China: Arrests in Poultry Factory Fire
description: Officials in Jilin Province have made two arrests in the investigation of a poultry factory fire that killed at least 120 people and injured at least 77 others this week, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. One of the men arrested was Jia Yushan, owner and president of Baoyuanfeng, the poultry processing company. The second man arrested was Zhang Yushen, the general manager. The companys bank account and the assets of Mr. Jia have been frozen, and the factorys license has been revoked, according to the Xinhua report, which was published Thursday. Survivors of the fire described encountering locked doors that prevented many people from escaping. The factory had been hailed in recent years as a model enterprise by local officials, but the deadly accident underscored the lack of rigorous safety inspections by officials.

title: Of Slippery Slopes
description: Maybe Im a bit pessimistic when it comes to governmental paternalism and the unrelenting erosion of civil liberties, but Ive always assumed that someone or something  including the government  is tracking, or could track, everything I do in an increasing virtual reality.

title: Mets Add Another Game to Their Growing To-Do List
description: Be it subfreezing temperatures, heavy snow or hammering rains, the Mets have faced Mother Natures worst this season.

title: Peru: Ex-President Is Denied a Pardon
description: President Ollanta Humala said Friday that he had decided not to grant a pardon to former President Alberto Fujimori, who is serving a prison sentence for human rights violations and corruption. Mr. Fujimori, left, has tongue cancer and other health problems; his family had requested the pardon in October, saying it was justified for medical reasons. Mr. Humala, who ran against Mr. Fujimoris eldest daughter, Keiko Fujimori, when he was elected in 2011, said that he reviewed material from doctors who examined Mr. Fujimori and took into account the nature of the former presidents crimes. A presidential commission had previously recommended against giving Mr. Fujimori a pardon. Mr. Fujimori was president from 1990 to 2000, when he led a successful fight against the Shining Path guerrilla group. In 2009 he was sentenced to 25 years in prison for overseeing death squads involved in two massacres that killed a total of 25 people.

title: Bike Shares One-Track App
description: Ah, to ride a bike through the streets of New York! The wind in your hair, a stench in your nose, the invigorating fear that your legs will give out, causing you to tumble backward down the steep slope of the Williamsburg Bridge.

title: The Blackhawks Bickell Outperforms Star Teammates
description: LOS ANGELES  When the Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley Cup in 2010, left wing Bryan Bickell did not meet N.H.L. requirements to have his name etched on the trophy. Should Chicago win the Cup in 2013, he might also see his name hammered onto the Conn Smythe Trophy, awarded to the player judged most valuable to his team during the playoffs.

title: Ex-Councilman in Capital Is Charged With Bribery
description: WASHINGTON  A former city councilor was charged with bribery on Friday after being accused of accepting cash from federal agents posing as business owners, rekindling attention to a long-simmering corruption inquiry of the District of Columbia government.

title: Biking to Work, and Around It
description: When Governors Island opened for the season last month, it meant a change of schedule for Leslie Koch: Until the island closes at the end of September, she works weekends, bicycling to the free ferry, then touring the islands 172 acres on pedal power. Ms. Koch, 51, is the president of the Trust for Governors Island, a nonprofit organization created by the city in 2010. She never knows what shell find on her rounds. If someones carrying something odd, she said, you just say its an art project, and usually youre right. She lives in a brownstone in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, with her husband, Douglas Grey, who produces entertainment for cruise ships, and an English golden retriever named Clara.

title: Teixeira Is Making Life Easier for Cano at the Plate
description: SEATTLE  It wasnt long after Robinson Cano slapped hands with Mark Teixeira at home plate after a three-run homer Thursday night that Teixeira turned his attention to the pitcher and followed with a blast of his own.

title: Roll Tape, Curtain Up
description: The Theater on Film and Tape Archive tapes about 50 Broadway, Off Broadway and regional theater performances each year.

title: After the Final Curtain, Act II
description: On a recent Thursday evening, a blue-and-white GMC motor home with tinted windows was parked in front of the Stephen Sondheim Theater on West 43rd Street. Cables ran from it, up over the theater marquee, through a window, and down into the theater, where they plugged into three cameras set up to record the evenings performance of The Trip to Bountiful, which has four Tony nominations heading into Sunday nights awards ceremony.

title: Want to Play at a Different College? O.K., but Not There or There
description: When a quarterback decided last month to transfer to another football program after one season at Oklahoma State, he thanked the coach, who thanked him back. Here were two parties seemingly in mutual agreement, on good terms, headed for an amicable divorce.

title: The Secrets of Nadals Success
description: In 2011, Novak Djokovic solved the riddle of Rafael Nadal on all three surfaces, besting Nadal on clay (Rome finals), grass (a decisive four-set victory in the Wimbledon final) and on hard courts (another solid four setter at Flushing Meadow). Nadal looked at once beleaguered and confused by Djokovics technical and tactical mastery, as if stymied by the puzzle of how to solve the Djokovic problem. One of Nadals favorite words at news conferences is solutions, but he seemed at a loss for words when he tried to explain how he was losing Grand Slam finals to someone other than Roger Federer.

title: The Hazards of Hecklers
description: Mark Leibovich on prominent and recent cases of political heckling, and the risks that come from engaging hostile interlopers.

title: Obama on Surveillance, Then and Now
description: As a senator, Barack Obama was a critic of the Bush administration,  saying it cast a false choice between liberty and security. As he engages in his own surveillance efforts, he has spoken of finding a balance.

title: Less Than a Fair Share
description: If you found yourself harboring skepticism or vague negativity toward the citys newly initiated bike-sharing program, it is possible that you were suddenly moved to defend it after witnessing The Wall Street Journals recent video interview with Dorothy Rabinowitz, an editorial board member who spent four minutes making crazy-lady assertions about cyclings hold on New York.

title: The New Arab Brooklyn
description: The Arab population in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the latest in a series of Arab enclaves appearing in New York City.

title: A Little Korea in Queens
description: People strolling for the first time on Northern Boulevard in Queens could be forgiven for thinking they had somehow been magically transported to Seoul.

title: Harriet Tubmans Great Raid
description: It is arguably the most beautiful scene ever recorded in war. Two Union gunboats, the Harriet A. Weed and the John Adams, converted ferryboats, churning up the Combahee River with their big side paddlewheels. Steam whistles signal, while in the bow of the Adams, a small, powerful woman is singing. From all around, hundreds hear Harriett Tubmans call and run for the boats, for freedom. At least 727 men, women and children escape, mothers carrying babies, including one pair of twins: the largest liberation of slaves in American history.

title: Little Guyana in Queens
description: No place has acquired as intense a Guyanese flavor as Liberty Avenue, the lively commercial corridor that divides Richmond Hill and South Ozone Park.

title: As Bruins Reach Finals, Empty Feeling for Penguins
description: BOSTON  The way the game was going, with goals at an absolute premium, the first one, whenever it came, seemed destined to be the only one. And so it was.

title: Whats on Bernankes Mind?
description: The Federal Reserve is closely watching the employment picture, as it considers when to pull back on its stimulus measures.

title: Take the A Train to Little Guyana
description: Sri Lankans have gathered on Staten Island, Arabs in Brooklyn, Ghanaians in the Bronx: A guide to the new immigrant enclaves of New York City.

title: After Brief Stumble, a Step Closer to Brazil
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  The National Stadium here is nicknamed the Office, a place where the United States took care of business in stunning fashion on Friday night as frustration whipped into elation.

title: Player Ratings: Jamaica 1, U.S. 2
description: Three World Cup qualifiers without a defeat  two wins and a draw  with two home games to come. With a possible six points from those two (Panama and Honduras), the United States can probably book its reservations for Brazil. Seems like a long way from the angst and hand-wringing after the first game in the Hex, a loss at Honduras.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) SAM & CAT Jennette McCurdy, who portrayed Sam Puckett on iCarly, and Ariana Grande, who played Cat Valentine in Victorious, team up in this crossover spinoff comedy about girls who meet cute in the back of a garbage truck, become best friends and roommates, and then go entrepreneurial with Sam & Cats Super Rockin Fun-Time Baby-Sitting Service. Above, from left, Cameron Ocasio, Ms. McCurdy and Ms. Grande in a scene from the show.

title: Chinas Export Growth Slows Amid Concern of Slowdown
description: HONG KONG  Chinese exports showed only modest growth in May, rising just 1 percent from a year earlier, officials said Saturday, an increase that was much lower than analysts expectations.

title: 100 Percent of the Game Is Half Mental
description: I thought of a wonderful little article by Allen Fox, the former Pepperdine mens tennis coach who played at the highest levels of the game and has since become the eminence grise of sports psychologists, as I watched the immensely likeable and charismatic Frenchman, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, play David Ferrer on Friday in a mens semifinal at the French Open. Fox recounts the 2000 Wimbledon final between Patrick Rafter and Pete Sampras. Like all of Foxs writings, the difficult and painful truths that tennis exposes are laid out like a cadaver awaiting a scalpel. Fox describes how each player allows the score  and their emotions relating to that score  to influence how they play and, even more importantly, their level of motivation as they compete in the match.

title: A Rain-Soaked Kickoff to the Governors Ball
description: The direst words on a concert ticket are rain or shine. They certainly were on Friday, the first of three days of the Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island.

title: IHT Quick Read: June 8
description: Europes reaction Friday to news of a sweeping international digital surveillance program by the U.S. government ranged from the outrage of citizens and politicians to the muted envy of some law enforcement agencies on this side of the Atlantic. Privacy is an emotional issue in Europe, where memories of state-sponsored snooping by communist and fascist regimes still linger. And so the revelation Thursday that the U.S. National Security Agency had obtained routine access to e-mail, Web searches and other online data from many of the biggest U.S. Internet companies  whose users stretch far beyond U.S. shores  prompted hand-wringing about Americas moral authority. If the U.S. complains about foreign governments spying and then it turns out it is doing the same thing  well, what are you complaining about? said Yaman Akdeniz, a law professor at Istanbul Bilgi University in Turkey, where anger over restrictions on civil liberties has fueled anti-government protests. Eric Pfanner reports from Serraval, France and James Kanter reports from Brussels.

title: Two Mariners Catch Fire as Kuroda Melts Down
description: SEATTLE  With a mere 26 runs batted in entering Friday, Jason Bay and Brendan Ryan of the Seattle Mariners had fewer R.B.I. combined than three Yankees  Robinson Cano, Travis Hafner and Lyle Overbay  had individually. They were tied with Brett Gardner.

title: Mandela Is Hospitalized Again, Deepening Worries Over Frailty
description: JOHANNESBURG  Former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa was hospitalized early Saturday to be treated for a recurring lung infection, the South African government said. It was the fourth time in less than a year that the 94-year-old anti-apartheid leader has been hospitalized, deepening concern about his increasing frailty.

title: The Weekend Word: Surveillance
description: Todays Times

title: Serving Up Our 2013 Belmont Picks
description: The Rails contributors welcome this years Belmont Stakes guest picker, the celebrity chef and horse owner Bobby Flay. Flay, the original guest picker on The Rail, was honored Thursday night with the Earle I. Mack Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation Champion Award, given to an individual for outstanding efforts and influence on thoroughbred racehorse welfare, safety and retirement. Flay, a newly appointed board member of the New York Racing Association, has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for thoroughbred retirement and is an outspoken proponent of owner responsibility to their horses.

title: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
description: Jammu and Kashmir: An Indian soldier was killed Friday in an incident of unprovoked firing from across the cease-fire line with Pakistan near the Poonch sector, about 110 miles southwest of the summer capital, Srinagar, The Associated Press reported.

title: Big Data Is Watching You
description: A few days before the story broke about the National Security Agency mining the data of citizens using Verizon, I walked by a newsstand and saw an issue of Foreign Affairs that had a feature on Big Data. I bought it. When I got onto Metro North, the man across the aisle was reading a book, its title: Big Data. We were both reading print media, I thought to myself: No trace. Unless we paid with our credit cards? I checked my e-mail before diving into the feature in Foreign Affairs: An e-mail from a friend, telling me she had a story idea for me. About Big Data. No doubt, all the outraged electronic references so many of us are suddenly making back and forth to each other about Big Data (on Facebook, Twitter, etc.) are being mined by various private and governmental institutions, revealing, via syntax, frequency and context, not only how well probably vote in 2016 but also what brand of hair conditioner we prefer.

title: Urban Trees as Triggers, From Istanbul to Oregon
description: As street protests spread across Turkey following an initial clash between police and demonstrators over the imperiled sycamore trees of Gezi Park(a rare green patch in the sprawl of central Istanbul), I was reminded of If a Tree Falls, the fine Oscar-nominated documentary on the roots of the Earth Liberation Front (Dot Earth coverage).

title: 3 Americans and an Italian Killed in Afghan Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two American soldiers and an American civilian working with them were killed in a so-called insider attack on Saturday in Afghanistan, officials said. In a second attack on international forces, an Italian soldier was killed when a grenade was thrown at him.

title: Depressing Draghi
description: A correspondent directs me, despairingly, to the last part of Mario Draghis latest press conference  and the correspondent is right, it does give cause for despair. Draghi is, after all, as smart and flexible an ECB president as were likely to get for a long time; quite possibly ever, because the euro might not last. Yet what he has to say about inflation manages to be wrong on multiple levels, and this kind of thing has to be damaging to ECB policy.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Williams Wins French Open Title
description: Serena Williams captured her most elusive title, beating Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-4, to win her second French Open title and her 16th Grand Slam title over all. Williams, 31, won 11 years to the day after her first title at Roland Garros and is the oldest French Open champion in the open era.

title: Following Up on Poverty Coverage in The Times
description: I heard from many readers after I wrote last Sunday about The Timess coverage of poverty. Ive rarely received more feedback on a column, and I appreciate the many thoughtful comments and e-mails.

title: Syrian Opposition to Sit Out Any Talks Unless Arms Are Sent, General Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Syrian opposition will not attend the proposed Geneva conference on the crisis in Syria unless rebel fighters receive new supplies of arms and ammunition, the top rebel military commander said Friday.

title: Turkey Turns to Taksim
description: Michael Kimmelman examines why Istanbul's Taksim Square evolved into the urban fissure that is growing in Turkish society.

title: Crisis Withdrawal Syndrome
description: Dean Baker complains, as he often does (and correctly so), about reporting on the fiscal outlook that reads a lot like editorializing  indeed, like a sponsored ad from Pete Peterson. But maybe he should show a bit of human sympathy: these guys are basically addicts trying to get off the stuff, and maybe its too much to expect them to go cold turkey.

title: Early Leader in Polls Usually Wins New York Mayoral Primary
description: The early Democratic front-runner in recent New York City mayoral races has a near perfect record in going on to win the partys nomination, according to an analysis of public opinion surveys conducted since 1989. If that pattern holds true in this years race, Speaker Christine C. Quinn of the City Council will very likely win the Democratic nomination in September. She has led in every primary poll conducted in 2013.

title: U.S. and China Move Closer on North Korea, but Not on Cyberespionage
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Even as they pledged to build a new model of relations, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings here on Saturday moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea and addressing climate change, but remaining sharply divided over cyberespionage and other issues that have divided the countries for years.

title: Chinese Link 47 Deaths in Bus Blast to a Suicide
description: BEIJING  An unemployed man intent on killing himself set off an explosion that engulfed a bus in flames and killed 47 people in the southeastern city of Xiamen on Friday, according to reports on Saturday by state-run news organizations.

title: Williams Rejoices, in French, After Winning 16th Grand Slam
description: PARIS  Serena Williams has tried to master French, as she has finally mastered the French Open again. So after she had served five aces in her last seven service points to beat Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-4, in Saturdays final, and had gone down on her knees and put her head to the clay in celebration, Williams kept up her recent habit of making her postmatch remarks to the crowd in the local language.

title: Largely Forgotten Champion, No Longer Dispassionate, Will Return as Host
description: WHITEFISH, Mont.  In the cedar dining room of Iron Horse Golf Club, David Graham sat with a glass of red wine and reminisced about his career, which included victories at the P.G.A. Championship and the United States Open. His eyes welled with tears as he talked about the illness that caused him to retire and forced him to confront his mortality.

title: The Titles He Won, the Things They Lost
description: MIAMI  On the day he was hired as the Boston Celtics coach in May 1997, Rick Pitino had thick black hair, a swagger in his step and a pocket full of Ping-Pong balls stamped with Tim Duncans name.

title: Variety: A Tasty Diagramless
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I do love a good fruit salad, and that appears to be what Fred Piscop has in store for us today, especially in the southeast, where the sliced PEAR gets incorporated into a GRAPE ARBOR.

title: U.S. Helps Allies Trying to Battle Iranian Hackers
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has begun helping Middle Eastern allies build up their defenses against Irans growing arsenal of cyberweapons, and will be doing the same in Asia to contain computer-network attacks from North Korea, according to senior American officials.

title: For Retirees, a Million-Dollar Illusion
description: A MILLION dollars isnt what it used to be.

title: Zimmerman Trial, Opening This Week, Will Raise Complex Questions
description: Was it murder when George Zimmerman shot and killed Trayvon Martin? Or was it self-defense?

title: When Presidential Words Led to Swift Action
description: WASHINGTON  These days it is hard to imagine a single presidential speech changing history.

title: A Search for Answers
description: Cullen Finnerty, who won three national football titles, did not return from a fishing trip. Searchers found his body, but many questions remain.

title: Questions Linger About Death of Former Quarterback
description: BALDWIN, Mich.  The search started the night of May 26, a Sunday, when Cullen Finnerty went missing in the woods here, amid towering white pines and shrubby scrub oak trees and owls and white-tailed deer. By Monday morning, helicopters circled overhead as cadaver dogs combed through the brush below.

title: Booker Formally Declares Candidacy for Senate Seat
description: NEWARK  Cory A. Booker, who has built national celebrity from his perch as mayor of this beleaguered city, brought another of the states most famous political figures here on Saturday as he officially declared his campaign for United States Senate.

title: Pound Your Fist if You Must, but Make Me Listen
description: This interview with  Paulett Eberhart, president and chief executive of CDI, an engineering and technology professional services firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Dumped by Mets, Perez Revives His Career as Mariner
description: SEATTLE  At the worst moment of his career, Oliver Perez swallowed hard, blinked several times to prevent tears from forming and told reporters what all ballplayers say, even if sometimes its hard to believe. He claimed he still loved the game.

title: In a Position to Cement a Role for the U.S. Team
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  There was no clock at the National Stadium, so Brad Evans had no idea that Fridays taut World Cup qualifying match had extended into added time.

title: Some Baby Steps on Money Funds
description: WHEN the Securities and Exchange Commission tried last year to safeguard investors in money market mutual funds, Mary L. Schapiro, its chairwoman at the time, ran into a buzz saw of opposition from industry lobbyists. Last week, Ms. Schapiros successor, Mary Jo White, tried her hand at bringing change to this $2.9 trillion market.

title: White House Plays Down Data Program
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration tried Saturday to marshal new evidence in defense of its collection of private Internet and telephone data, arguing that a secret program called Prism is simply an internal government computer system designed to sort through court-supervised collection of data, and that Congress has been briefed 13 times on the programs since 2009.

title: Sunday Dialogue: A New School Schedule?
description: Readers react to a proposal for a longer school year and day.

title: Seeing the World as Your Stage
description: IN days past, if you were born in the United States, you generally worked for an American company and an American boss in an American city. Everyone you interacted with  from your favorite clients to the company that manufactured your office supplies  was American.

title: Fixing the Digital Economy
description: TWO big trends in the world appear to contradict each other.

title: Loving the Midwest
description: AFTER we moved to St. Louis in 2007, my husband joked that we were self-hating Midwesterners. He grew up in Indiana, I grew up in Ohio, we met in Washington, D.C., and we landed in St. Louis  for my husbands job  by way of Philadelphia. If our friends from the coasts disparaged the heartland, we were quick to defend it. Privately, however, we were critical.

title: The Internship: Not the Movie
description: THE NEW YORKER last week carried a cartoon of a man delivering a commencement address to a graduating class, all in caps and gowns, and his advice was: Its an intern-eat-intern world out there!

title: Whos Minding the Schools?
description: IN April, some 1.2 million New York students took their first Common Core State Standards tests, which are supposed to assess their knowledge and thinking on topics such as The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and a single matrix equation in a vector variable.

title: Your Smartphone Is Watching You
description: ON Thursday, just after reports broke that the National Security Agency had been helping itself to data from just about every major American Internet company, an enterprising Twitter user set up an account called Nothing to Hide, which reproduced tweets from people expressing blithe unconcern about their governments potential access to their e-mails, phone records, video chats, you name it.

title: How Not to Be Alone
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I saw a stranger crying in public. I was in Brooklyns Fort Greene neighborhood, waiting to meet a friend for breakfast. I arrived at the restaurant a few minutes early and was sitting on the bench outside, scrolling through my contact list. A girl, maybe 15 years old, was sitting on the bench opposite me, crying into her phone. I heard her say, I know, I know, I know over and over.

title: Progress At Work, But Mothers Still Pay a Price
description: HERES an old riddle: a boy and his father are in a car crash and the father is killed instantly. The boy is airlifted to the best hospital in the region and prepped for emergency surgery by one of the top surgeons in the country. The surgeon rushes in, sees the boy, and says I cant operate on this patient. Hes my son. Who is the surgeon?

title: That Entrepreneurial Itch
description: IVE always been interested in gadgets and building things. When I was 12, I got my first camera and built a darkroom under a staircase in my familys house in a Detroit suburb.

title: No Learning Without Feeling
description: ITS sad, the kid at the far table told me, but its my favorite poem we worked on. He was talking about The Weary Blues, by Langston Hughes, and although his emotional language was rudimentary, his response was authentic. So we should read literature that makes us sad? I asked. He laughed. Well, sadness, Ms. Hollander, is something people pretty much feel every day. He looked up at me and smiled incredulously. The connection was obvious to him.

title: Peeping Barry
description: WASHINGTON  THE acid that corroded George W. Bushs presidency was fear  spreading it and succumbing to it.

title: A Feast of Golf History, and Dinner Near the First Tee
description: Its the family estate of American golf. It treasures its revered champions. It displays the trophies of more than a century of national tournaments. It whispers its landmark status. And it looks the part.

title: Shining Moments in Baseball Amid the Tarnish
description: To go by the ominous headlines and warnings of 100-game suspensions for 20 or more players, last week was sobering for Major League Baseball. There is no question about the seriousness of the scandal involving a defunct anti-aging clinic in Florida and the revelation that its owner, Anthony Bosch, will cooperate with baseballs investigation.

title: Meet the New Landlord
description: A lot of people were surprised by the upsurge in home sales and prices last year, especially in some of the nations most depressed markets. Nationwide sales prices rose 7.3 percent last year, according to one major index, while prices in hard-hit Phoenix surged 23 percent. Other trouble spots, including Las Vegas and Riverside County, Calif., have also had double-digit gains.

title: Immigration Headwinds
description: The bipartisan immigration bill that passed the Senate Judiciary Committee last month is now being sent to meet its fate on the Senate floor. While its chances of passage there look promising, there remains much uncertainty about how much  and how badly  the bill will be changed in the coming three weeks of debate.

title: The Weird World of Colonoscopy Costs
description: Colonoscopies are one of three standard ways to screen for colorectal cancer. So it is disturbing to learn that the cost of this routine procedure, performed on more than 10 million Americans each year, differs radically from state to state and even within the same metropolitan area.

title: Europes Social Contract, Lying in Pieces
description: What began as a debt and currency crisis in the European Union risks becoming a crisis of liberal democracy itself. Four years of grinding austerity across much of the Continent has caused millions of middle- and working-class voters to lose faith in the ability of mainstream political parties to protect their basic interests. It would be a sad paradox if the European movement, conceived in the ruins of fascism and two world wars, and for decades democracys best advertisement to the Communist East, undermined its democratic achievements in pursuit of a perverse economic dogma.

title: Want to Fix Social Security? Use the Right Wrench
description: SOCIAL SECURITY is expected to run out of reserves by 2033  a mere 20 years from now. With the public apparently opposed both to tax increases and to benefit cuts, the main politically feasible way to avoid such a fate seems to involve some monkeying with obscure aspects of the definition of benefits.

title: Hazy With a Chance of Apocalypse
Invasion of the Beetles, and a Ranchers Revenge
description: FOUR years ago, the trees on Larry Lipsons property in western Montana began to die. Not just one or two, but 10,000 of them. The culprit was the mountain pine beetle, which has ravaged 23 million acres of forests in the United States since 2000.

title: Chief Bill John Baker
description: Chief Bill John Baker leads the Cherokee Nation, which has 300,000 members and business interests that range from aerospace to casinos. The local economic impact of the tribe, which is based in northeastern Oklahoma, is $1.5 billion annually.

title: Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan, Advocate for the Poor, Dies at 83
description: Bishop Joseph M. Sullivan, whose work on behalf of the poor and downtrodden for Catholic Charities in Brooklyn and Queens earned him national recognition, died on Friday as a result of injuries from a car accident. He was 83.

title: Nearly Sunk, Bruins Snap Into a Juggernaut
description: BOSTON  The game had ended, the handshakes and pleasantries had been exchanged, and the Bruins gathered in their black jerseys and white hats for a team picture surrounding the Prince of Wales Trophy, given to the winner of the Eastern Conference finals.

title: An Oasis in a Desert of Customer Service
description: REMEMBER the recent column about DailyCandy, the e-mail service for discount deals, and the customer who sent e-mails for six maddening months, trying to get an $85 refund?

title: Dont Take Your Vitamins
description: PHILADELPHIA  LAST month, Katy Perry shared her secret to good health with her 37 million followers on Twitter. Im all about that supplement & vitamin LYFE! the pop star wrote, posting a snapshot of herself holding up three large bags of pills. There is one disturbing fact about vitamins, however, that Katy didnt mention.

title: Horses Dont Care if the Jockeys a Woman
description: The question is starting to wear on Rosie Napravnik, the way it did  and still does  on Julie Krone: what is it like being a female jockey?

title: Mr. Hot Stuffs Career Switch Pays Off Handsomely
description: When Mr. Hot Stuff had placed in two graded stakes and was being pointed for classics, the habit was funny, cute, good to lighten any mood around the barn. When hed lost 6, 7, 8, 10 races in a row, the trick was no longer cute.

title: Makeover Possible For Penguins After a Sweep
description: For years, the idea of Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin on different N.H.L. teams was unimaginable. But now that Pittsburgh has been swept from the playoffs by the Boston Bruins, the unimaginable could be on the Penguins off-season agenda.

title: Reliving Secretariats Magical Ride 40 Years Later
description: Forty years ago Sunday, Ron Turcotte unleashed Secretariat in the Belmont Stakes, prompting the track announcer Chic Anderson to exclaim as he thundered into the final turn, Hes moving like a tremendous machine! Secretariat went on to win by 31 lengths, setting a track and stakes record with a time of 2 minutes 24 seconds.

title: The Syria the World Forgot
description: LAST month, while we waited at the Lebanese border for our papers to be processed so that we could return to Syria, a woman traveling in our shared taxi pointed at the clouds gathering in the sky and said, The Orthodox will be happy.

title: Only Children: Lonely and Selfish?
description: CALL me a terrible mother. I have an only child. For now at least, Im planning to keep it that way, for my happiness and for hers. But the notion that an only child might be a happy one contradicts strong cultural beliefs. According to these, children like mine will end up rotten with selfishness and beset by loneliness.

title: A Golden Age for Intervention?
description: UNITED NATIONS

title: Weiner Criticizes Police Stops, but Offers No Alternative
description: Appearing before an African-American audience in Harlem on Saturday, Anthony D. Weiner criticized the Police Departments stop-and-frisk policy as excessive and promised that, if he became mayor, he would not use the tactic as a racial tool. He did not say, however, precisely how he would otherwise change the policy.

title: No Tie-Ins. No Touch Screens. No Apps.
description: ESTHER BERNSTEIN, 6 years old with long blond hair, pulled on a pair of blue slippers with a gray tassel over the toe. She grinned.

title: The Jokes on All of Us
description: EVERY compulsive joker knows that joking leads to trouble. And so it has for my boss, E. Gordon Gee.

title: Chronicling the Lives of Women
description: Abigail Heyman, who died on May 28 at 70, said her work as a photographer reflected the conflicts inherent in growing up female.

title: Emirates Balk at Activism in Region Hit by Uprisings
description: RAS AL KHAYMAH, United Arab Emirates  The white mosque, soccer field and wedding hall are still there.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 9
description: Senators from both parties will take to the Sunday shows this week to address the newly disclosed government initiatives to mine phone call and Internet data from the public. Are the measures too invasive or are they justified for preventing terrorist attacks?

title: The Chatter for Sunday, June 9
description: The thing that scares me is the values going up so quickly.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Palace Malice Wins Belmont Stakes
description: Palace Malice cruised to the lead turning for home and beat both the Preakness winner Oxbow and the Derby winner Orb to capture the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park on Saturday.

title: Resilient Miami Rarely Entertains a Losing Streak
description: MIAMI  Past performance is no guarantee of future results, in investing or basketball, but if the past five months mean anything, the Miami Heat will win Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals on Sunday night.

title: Fast One
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Elizabeth C. Gorski is the undisputed master of the artistic grid. Whether its drawing pictures with black squares or leaving us circled squares with which to play connect-the-dots, Ms. Gorski usually goes the extra length to give us some value-added in her puzzles. Youd be doing yourself a disservice if you race through this one.

title: What to Watch on Day 15 of the French Open
description: Like the womens final, the mens final at Roland Garros features a prohibitive favorite. But the fans at the crowd at the Philippe Chatrier Court got more of a match than many expected. Will the crowd on Sunday be as lucky?

title: Democrats Seek to End 20 Years of Texas Losses
description: Ambitious and sometimes wildly optimistic candidates for statewide offices are running all over the place, energized by the number of potential open seats on the 2014 ballots.

title: Experts Urge Focus on Aquifers in Push for Water From Mexico
description: As Texas lawmakers say farmers in the Rio Grande Valley are hurting because Mexico is not honoring a treaty on surface water delivery, experts caution that greater attention should be paid to water deep below the surface.

title: Attacker in Afghanistan Hid Bomb in His Body
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans spy chief, Asadullah Khalid, was taking no chances.

title: Decades Later, Revisiting a Death in the Family
description: Near the end of his extraordinary new book, Run, Brother, Run: A Memoir of a Murder in My Family, about the killing of his older brother, Alan, outside Houston in 1968, David Berg writes about going to see Joel and Ethan Coens 2007 film No Country for Old Men  not knowing that the film featured the actor Woody Harrelson in a supporting role.

title: Stephanopoulizing
description: My head will be talking tomorrow morning. I understand well be talking about New Jersey. You got a problem with that?

title: Abandoned Oil Wells Raise Fears of Pollution
description: LULING, Tex.  Amid the dry weeds on a 470-acre ranch here, a rusted head of steel pokes up, a vestige of an oil well abandoned decades ago. Across the field stand two huge, old wooden oil tanks, one of them tilting like a smokestack on the Titanic.

title: Low-Key Player Thrives With Low-Key Spurs
description: MIAMI  Danny Green has enjoyed living in San Antonio just as much as he enjoyed living on Long Island when he was a teenager. Green said the weather in San Antonio reminded him of North Carolina, where he played in college for four years and where, in 2009, he was an all-everything starter on the team that won the national championship.

title: Dropped Charges in Deadly Rape Provoke Fury in South Africa, and Pessimism
description: BREDASDORP, South Africa  As Anene Booysen lay dying, she whispered to her medics the name of the man who had assaulted her and left her lying in the dirt on a construction site, her bowels spilling from her abdomen.

title: Rough Road to Victory at Grand Prix in Greece
description: Leinier Domnguez Perez needed a little help to overcome a bad start and go on to win the Grand Prix tournament in Thessaloniki, Greece.

title: As Home Sales Heat Up Again, Buyers Must Resort to Cold Cash
description: LOS ANGELES  Bidding wars sound almost quaint. These days, the only way for would-be buyers to secure a home, it often seems, is to offer all cash and be ready to do so within hours, not days.

title: Buying Homes With All Cash
description: An increase in all-cash purchases of single-family homes and condos in areas like Los Angeles and Boston are squeezing many people out of the market and making it nearly impossible for first-time buyers to even compete.

title: Abigail Heyman, Feminist Photojournalist, Dies at 70
description: Abigail Heyman, a photographer whose stark portraits of women at work, at home and at weddings gave a visual concreteness to feminist doctrine of the 1970s about the oppressiveness of traditional female roles, died on May 28 at her home in Manhattan. She was 70.

title: The Perennial Senate Guests and the No-Shows
description: Senators often make the rounds of the Sunday news shows, and Republicans are the most frequent guests.

title: On the Sunday Morning Talk Shows, a Rather Familiar Cast of Characters
description: WASHINGTON  In mid-February, Senator John McCain went on the NBC program Meet the Press to explain his unhappiness with President Obamas nominee for defense secretary. A week later, he took to State of the Union on CNN to chat about sequestration (bad) and the attack in Benghazi (worse).

title: Police Call Santa Monica Gunman Ready for Battle
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The gunman whose rampage across this city on Friday left four people dead before he was killed by the police at Santa Monica College carried a vast arsenal with him, including a semiautomatic rifle, a handgun, a tactical vest and 1,300 rounds of ammunition, the police said Saturday.

title: Palace Malice, a Long Shot, Rewards a Promoter for His Patience
description: Before Todd Pletcher was a trainer with 200 horses in his stable, millions in his bank account, expensive suits and an exquisite haircut, he was a guy with eight horses who was in desperate need of clients. One of his first was Cot Campbell, a wily old Southerner with an affinity for plaid sports coats and porkpie hats who had pioneered the novel idea that horse ownership did not necessarily have to be exclusive to rich people.

title: Protesters Are Killed in Libya in Fight With Militia
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  At least a dozen people were killed here Saturday and dozens wounded after members of a powerful militia fired on protesters surrounding the groups headquarters in an outpouring of public anger at the armed bands that have been blamed for fueling political violence and undermining a fledgling state.

title: Long Before the 20th Inning, Harveys Twinge Gives the Mets Shivers
description: In a game lasting 6 hours 25 minutes on Saturday, a worrying scene at Citi Field gradually turned into a maddening one.

title: How the U.S. Uses Technology to Mine More Data More Quickly

title: Milestones for a Pair of Pettittes
description: SEATTLE  Andy Pettitte has enjoyed many special moments at the pinnacle of his profession. He has pitched 13 times in the World Series, been a 21-game winner, ridden on five parade floats and, best of all, celebrated the birth of four children who later rampaged around Yankees clubhouses for the better part of the last two decades.

title: Construction Worker Tied to Philadelphia Building Collapse Turns Himself In

title: Moscow Trial Sends Warning to Rank-and-File Putin Foes

Putin, then the prime minister, unexpectedly turned violent. As protesters grappled with riot police officers in helmets swinging truncheons, investigators say, Mr. Belousov threw rocks and pieces of asphalt, broke through the cordon and attacked police officers.

title: Exhibit A for a Major Shift: Justices Gay Clerks
description: WASHINGTON  As Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. was struggling with how to cast the decisive vote in a 1986 Supreme Court case that would end up devastating the gay rights movement, he told his fellow justices that he had never met a homosexual.

They sidestepped the super wicked issues impeding restrictions of the greenhouse gas of greatest concern, carbon dioxide, and staff released a joint statement on plans to cut releases of hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, a potent group of heat-trapping gases.

title: 36 Holes and No. 1 Foe Will Challenge Pressel
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  Morgan Pressel will start Sundays marathon day of golf as the leader of the L.P.G.A. Championship. She takes a two-stroke lead in a tournament that has endured more than five inches of rain in 10 days, forcing the field to play 36 holes Sunday.

title: Ariel Kaminer Says Whats Meh
