description: The Harperley Hall duplex created by Madonna Ciccone way back in a former century, when she and Sean Penn were a hot item and she was very much a Material Girl on the rise in the matter of shrewd real estate acquisitions, sold for $16 million in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom center-hall colonial in Nassau and a New Jersey horse farm with a ten acre property.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: An Upper West Side co-op in a brownstone; a Red Hook home with a detached guesthouse/studio; and an East Village co-op with a working fireplace.

title: Where We Are Shapes Who We Are
description: IN the early 1970s, a team of researchers dropped hundreds of stamped, addressed letters near college dorms along the East Coast and recorded how many lost letters found their way to a mailbox. The researchers counted each posted letter as a small act of charity and discovered that students in some of the dorms were more generous than others.

title: A Wider View of Indias Foreign Policy Reveals Clear Strategy
description: Shinzo Abe has ruffled quite a few feathers since his return as Japans prime minister in December. His cabinet ministers visit in April to the controversial Yasukuni Shrine, which honors Japans war dead, was condemned by China and South Korea, and in no time, Japan became the target of North Korean saber-rattling and American finger-wagging. So it ought to have elicited more surprise when Abes soft-spoken Indian counterpart, Manmohan Singh, plainly declared his comfort with his hosts worldview on a recent visit to Tokyo.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: If Anything, an Invitation to Talk

title: The Weekend Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Talk of Takeover Grows at Health Management Hospital Group
description: Ever since the chief executive of Health Management Associates, the for-profit hospital system, abruptly announced nearly three weeks ago that he would be leaving to lead a religious mission in South America, speculation has mounted about whether the company could be headed for a takeover.

title: Image of the Day: June 14
This Summer, New York Loves Horse Racing
description: Say what you will about the wisdom, or the inadvisability, of governments direct involvement in horse racing in New York, there are certain programmatic areas in which a close collaboration with the state can have a powerful and positive impact.

title: Polls Show Chemical Weapons Affect Publics View on Syria
description: The Obama administration, which had long resisted sending weapons to antigovernment forces in Syrias civil war, has decided to supply them with small arms after concluding that the troops of President Bashar al-Assad have used chemical weapons against them, according to American officials.

title: An Old Hand at Only 26
description: The precocious French conductor Lionel Bringuier, all of 26, took the podium at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday to lead the New York Philharmonic in an impressive program. It is not often that a conductor of any age can bring out the musically daring elements of a crowd pleaser like Dukass Sorcerers Apprentice. To those who remember Mr. Bringuier from his New York debut in 2008, when he conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, also at Avery Fisher Hall, he must have seemed almost a seasoned maestro in comparison. He has certainly been rising fast, making appearances with major international orchestras. He takes over as chief conductor of the distinguished Tonhalle Orchestra in Zurich next year and is just completing his sixth and final season as resident conductor with the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Mr. Bringuier made his official debut with the New York Philharmonic in 2009, conducting the chamber ensemble in Brittens War Requiem, a performance led overall by Lorin Maazel. But this was his first time conducting the full orchestra on his own.

title: Paul Cavaco: Finding the Look That Suits His Age
description: Paul Cavaco, 61, a founder of Keeble Cavaco & Duka (today known as the fashion public relations agency KCD) and a former fashion director at Vogue and Harpers Bazaar, has been the creative director of Allure magazine for almost 14 years. He was born and raised in New York.

title: A Rented Truck Was the Stage for Romantic Comedy
description: InJuly 2010, Jean Ann Douglassappeared in a puppet play about a gorilla, a man and a chimpanzee. She played the left arm of the gorilla.

title: How to Avoid an Estate Battle After You Die
description: It might seem that a woman who died at 104 after spending 20 years in a hospital despite being healthy enough to live in one of her three stately homes, accumulated a vast collection of dolls and preferred to communicate in French even though her father had been a United States senator would have little to teach the rest of us.

title: Where the Bridal Bouquet Is All Around You
description: The ever-present risk of a thunderstorm or insect swarm aside, for those who delight in moonlight and stars, the first day of summer or the dazzle of a fall day, nothing will do but a garden wedding.

title: A Quick Search Ends in the Village
description: A three-year stint in downtown Seattle was more than enough for Jean Z. Poh and Giordano Contestabile. They couldnt wait to move to New York.

title: Defining Real Estate Broadly to Avoid Corporate Taxes
description: Shares of the information storage company Iron Mountain dropped about 15 percent last week on the news that the I.R.S. was tentatively adverse toward at least one aspect of its plan to convert into a Real Estate Investment Trust, or REIT. The primary legal issue appears to be whether Iron Mountains racking storage units qualify as real estate assets.

title: New Jersey Declares Clarence Clemons Day
description: Heres further proof that in New Jersey the members of Bruce Springsteens band are folk heroes akin to knights of the round table: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has signed a resolution declaring Jan. 11 to be Clarence Clemons Day, wire services reported. That day was Mr. Clemonss birthday.

title: Inside Istanbuls Taksim Square
description: Panoramic photos of the main protest camp.

title: In Student Housing, Luxuries Overshadow Studying
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.  Brenden Heiland had breathed the vanilla lavender-scented clubhouse air. He had seen the beach volleyball court, toured the game room equipped with billiards, Ping-Pong and air hockey tables, and learned with delight of the Friday pool parties with a D.J., free food and snow cones, spiked with rum for those of age.

title: Robot at the Wheel on Fords Test Track
description: The Ford Motor Company uses robotically controlled trucks on its test track.

title: Toppling Spain at European Under-21s Will Be a Tall Order
description: It may not be the Champions League or the World Cup but the Under-21 European Championship always proves a great showcase for tomorrows star players. And with the group stage complete, this years tournament in Israel is not without its standout players and performances. Some of those expected to shine have not disappointed, but other more unfamiliar players and teams are also making a name for themselves. All the while, the question of experience has become a major theme of the competition.

title: Violent Protests in Brazil
description: Demonstrators against increases in bus fares clashed with police in So Paulo on Thursday.

title: Daughter to Dad: Girlie Pajamas, Please
description: My daughter loves Spider-Man  the Peter Parker version, the movie version, not the young comic book hero of Chris Huntingtons recent essay. While we dont know why, I suspect its the love interest as much as her favorite colors. Whenever theres a scene between Peter Parker and Mary Jane, she has a tentative, all-encompassing smile. Maybe thats me projecting adult emotions on a 5-year-old, but no other superhero or franchise sticks like Spider-Man: T-shirts, boxers, sweatshirts, her favorite shoes, her favorite drinking glass, her favorite car, her favorite puzzle, the action figures on her night stand that she rearranges before bedtime, her pajamas.

title: Looking for Clementine Hunters Louisiana
description: Some three hours drive from Baton Rouge, in the northwest corner of Louisiana, lies the curving Cane River, and along it, fields planted with cotton, soy, corn and pecans, worked today by machinery. But when Clementine Hunter, arguably the states most beloved artist, was born on Hidden Hill Plantation in the 1880s, slavery was an institution of living memory, and most African-Americans, including Clementine and her family, worked as field hands. In the artists case, she picked cotton on Hidden Hill (which has been renamed Little Eva Plantation) and then, when her family moved, at Melrose Plantation. It was there that, in her 50s, Clementine Hunter picked up a paintbrush and embarked on what became a remarkable career.

title: Escaping to Bangkoks Green Lung
description: Falling coconuts, papaya groves, Buddhist temples, nine-foot-long pythons and miles of bike-friendly elevated sidewalks snaking through the jungle: Welcome to Bang Krachao, a smog-free, government-protected oasis of green that the mighty Chao Phraya River wraps around.

title: On the Scillies, Exotic Gardens, Windswept Ruins
description: Through the mist, I could make out the empty beaches and crystal clear water surrounding St. Marys, the largest of the Isles of Scilly. The view from the airplane window hinted at what draws the visitors who flock there to windsurf, sail, watch gig races and spot the seaside fauna  puffins, gray seals  that make the islands their home.

title: In Utah, a 100-Mile Trek With a 4-Year-Old Boy
description: We roared across the Wyoming-Utah border at sunset; windows down, stereo cranked, muffler cracked. Behind the wheel was a well-tattooed, pierced 24-year-old. Riding shotgun, a 44-year-old writer with three-day-old stubble (that would be me). And in the back, buried beneath coloring books and blankets, a cherubic boy. We were all three in search of goats.

title: Cruz Is Said to Sign a One-Year Contract
description: The Pro Bowl receiver Victor Cruz signed a one-year, restricted free-agent tender with the Giants on Friday, according to a person with knowledge of the deal. The move gave both sides more time to work out a long-term agreement.

title: Even Michael Pollan Breaks Rules on the Road
description: In his new book, Cooked: A Natural History of Transformation, Michael Pollan makes a confession: although hes spent his career extolling the virtues of eating fresh, local and organic food, he has put little time into cooking it at home.

title: One-Pot Mujadara
description: Melissa Clark puts her own twist on mujadara, a traditional Middle Eastern dish of lentils and rice, by adding spring greens.

title: A 4-Piano Rite With Bang
description: Last night i saw this ballet by igor stravinsky on tv, a friend messaged me late last month, adding how he wished he could see it live. It was so modern it could have also been performance art.

title: A Modern Immigrant Finds the Spotlight
description: The pirogi were warm, the honey-cherry liqueur was uncorked and the muggy basement of Word, a bookstore in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was standing-room-only.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A New Spin on the Hulk
description: Theres plenty of activity on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week. Alan Moore appears twice, with an old classic (yet another collected edition of Watchmen, illustrated by Dave Gibbons, at No. 2) and something newer (the super-powered police procedural Top 10, with Gene Ha handling the art, at No. 3).

title: Modern Maturity for the Original Cute Ute
description: Its hard for an elder statesman to get respect anymore, even in auto showrooms. Take the Toyota RAV4, which created an entirely new vehicle segment when it arrived on the scene in January 1996 as the original cute ute.

title: From One of a Kind to One Among Many
description: Toyotas RAV4, the original compact crossover, remains a sensible, enjoyable ride. But it struggles to distinguish itself in a now-crowded class.

title: With Sticky Rice, the Attraction Is Mutual
description: My first true taste of sticky rice was in Thailand, on a backcountry bus trip.

title: Off Campus, Life in Luxury
description: The market for luxury student housing is growing.

title: The Week in Pictures for June 14
description: Pictures include a building implosion on Governors Island, pedestrians in the rain in Manhattan and an invasion of cicadas on Staten Island.

title: The Unspoken Stigma of Workplace Flexibility
description: Assume for a moment that your employer let you decide when and where you worked  you might arrive early so you could leave in time to care for a child, or work part of the week from home. Or perhaps you want to reduce your hours for a while to care for an aging parent. How would you be perceived if you raised your hand for one of these options?

title: Syrias Wounded Generation
description: At an after-care center near Turkeys border with Syria, civilians and combatants recover from life-altering injuries. The Timess Mac William Bishop speaks to casualties of Syrias brutal civil war.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, Iran, Hong Kong and the West Bank.

title: Kids on the Stage and on the Stairs, and Sometimes Both at Once
description: Ballet Tech is about dancing, and dancing, and opportunity, and children, and dancing, the choreographer Eliot Feld said on Thursday. He spoke as Kids Dance, the performing arm of the New York City Public School for Dance, a school for fourth through eighth grades also known as Ballet Tech, returned to the Joyce Theater for a four-day run.

title: Week in Review: Waiting to Be King of Goldman
description: In the glow of television, many messages. | The stimulus comment that agitated traders. | To billionaires failed deal, add rebuke from S.E.C. | Trader covets Goldman office where a friend is sitting tight. | In a shift, interest rates are rising. | Insurers inflating books, New York regulator says. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says tech companies tread lightly in statements on U.S. spying. | A rise in broker requests to wipe the slate clean.

title: Los Angeles Reality, via Pittsburgh
description: I have not slept in three days, Mac Miller said, so I apologize if Im a little weird. Actually, Mr. Miller, the Pittsburgh-born rapper, was less weird than wiped. Hes in one of his busiest periods since his 2011 debut, Blue Slide Park, entered the Billboard charts at No. 1, the first independent album to do so in 16 years. His follow-up, Watching Movies With the Sound Off, is due Tuesday from Rostrum Records.

title: A Game of Chance (Audience Spins First)
description: Here are three words that strike fear in the hearts of many: participatory dance performance.

title: A Humble Lentil Dish Not Just for Hippies
description: The menu at the Lebanese restaurant didnt do the dish any favors. Vegetarian brown lentils and rice cooked with onions, the description read. It sounded like a dreary incarnation of 1960s hippie cuisine: salubrious, drab, bland.

title: Take That, Big Brother!
description: Edward J. Snowdens disclosure that the United States government is collecting phone and Internet records kick-started a wave of creative commentary on government surveillance.

title: Flute, Church Organ, African Drums and Rock Guitar
description: Nicole Mitchell

title: Automakers Push Back Against Consumer Protections
description: When the transmission in Sarah and Scott McKinneys 2004 Audi A6 failed after five years, the repair cost thousands of dollars. Audi wouldnt cover it, the McKinneys say, though the problem was a common one  so widespread that it later became the subject of a federal class-action suit.

title: A Sudden Outbreak of Annoying Noises
description: Ford F-150 pickups with clunking driveshafts and Toyotas with noisy brakes are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Rough Road Ahead, but a Robot Driver Takes It in Stride
description: ROMEO, MICH.  A Ford Transit van slams its way over concrete obstacles in a test of durability here at the automakers proving grounds some 40 miles north of Detroit. The continuous on-road torture is punishing and could wreak havoc on both chassis-components and a drivers spine, but this test driver doesnt mind.

title: U.S. Allies Weigh Response to Chemical Weapons Charge
description: PARIS  The Syrian government on Friday denounced the Obama administrations assertion that Syrian forces had used chemical weapons as full of lies, even as the Americans finding produced strong reactions around the world.

title: Seeing in the Dark
description: The designer Alex Trochut typically expresses himself through typography or illustration  or a merging of the two  and those skills were on display in the magazine a few months ago in his illustrated headline for one of our feature stories. But he has ventured far beyond those familiar applications in his new project, Binary Prints, which was inspired by and features as its subjects electronic musicians like James Murphy, Caribou, Four Tet and Damian Lazarus. Trochuts posters can be seen at this Web site created for them and in an exhibition that opens this week in Barcelona.

title: Small Grains, Big Nutrition
description: Small grains can pack a big nutritional punch, writes the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman, who this week continued her exploration into cooking with grains. She writes:

title: Mujadara: One Pot or Two
description: In this weeks A Good Appetite column and in the accompanying video, I refer to the Middle Eastern lentils and rice dish called mujadara as a one-pot meal. Thats how I learned how to make it: by cooking the lentils and rice together in the pot.

title: No Pritzker Prize for Denise Scott Brown
description: The Pritzker Prize jury will not revisit its decision to exclude the architect Denise Scott Brown from the 1991 prize given to her design partner and husband, Robert Venturi, with whom she worked side by side.

title: Luke Janklow: Not Exactly Bookish
description: It was a breezy afternoon in early June, and Luke Janklow, the heir apparent to the powerful literary agent Morton L. Janklow, was trying to recall what he had been up to the last month. I dont go out that much, he said, opening the calendar on his computer in his 13th-floor office overlooking Park Avenue.

title: About Last Night | Jason Wu Hosts a Summer Soiree for the Young Friends of ACRIA
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Open Trials for the Bermuda Bowl
description: The winners of the open trial in Orlando, Fla., this month for the Bermuda Bowl world championship were young. Kevin Dwyer is 24; John Kranyak, 29; Gavin Wolpert, 30; and Kevin Bathurst, 34. They have added two old-timers for the championship in September in Bali, Indonesia: Steve Weinstein, 49, and Bobby Levin, 55.

title: Greek Broadcaster Fights Closure
description: ATHENS  The Greek government might come under pressure to reopen the state broadcaster, ERT, as one of the countrys highest courts weighs an appeal by a union representing more than 2,600 of the broadcasters employees.

title: Researchers Find Biological Evidence of Gulf War Illnesses
description: In the two decades since the 1991 Persian Gulf war, medical researchers have struggled to explain a mysterious amalgam of problems in thousands of gulf war veterans, including joint pain, physical malaise and gastrointestinal disorders. In some medical circles, the symptoms were thought to be psychological, the result of combat stress.

title: CUNY Leaders Retirement Comes With Paid Sabbatical and Teaching Job
description: For a scholar, it is the dream retirement benefit: a full year just to read and write, with no committee meetings in sight. For Matthew Goldstein, a mathematician who will step down this summer as chancellor of the City University of New York, that year comes with an added nicety: a $490,000 salary, the same amount he is earning this year.

title: Doomed Health Reform
description: Aaron Carroll has a fun piece full of quotations about how an expansion of health coverage is doomed to failure, doctors will refuse to participate, and so on. What makes it fun is that the health expansion in question is Medicaid, and all of the quotes are from 40 or more years ago. As he says, after quoting from a 1969 article,

title: Differing Views on Privacy Shape Europes Response to U.S. Surveillance Program
description: PARIS  Olaf Storbeck, a German columnist, has decided to ditch Googlemail b/c Prism, he wrote on Twitter. A London-based writer for Reuters, he is now a customer of Swissmail, a Swiss provider that charges a fee, and he says he is tinkering with a VPN, a virtual private network of the kind used by many corporations.

title: Oh, for the Days of a Courtly Vampires Love
description: Back at home in Bon Temps, La., momentarily safe from attack by vampires hungry for her tasty fairy blood, Sookie Stackhouse recalls the simple days of white dresses and well-mannered, if fanged, admirers. I want to be that girl again, she says, wearily. Fans of True Blood, hearing their heroine speak that line in the shows Season 6 premiere on Sunday night, can only reply, Amen, sister.

title: Music in Istanbul Is Intermission for a Protest
description: ISTANBUL  After days of being the target of tear gas and police water cannons, protesters in Gezi Park, in Taksim Square here, were tense on Wednesday night, girded for conflict. Instead they got a piano performance.

title: Friday Night Music: More Zaz
description: Whats funny is that the lyrics arent all that different from Paula Abduls The Way That You Love Me. But somehow, even though that was actually one of Paula Abduls better hits, I like this a whole lot better

title: The Rotunda That Dazzles
description: The Guggenheims James Turrell exhibition opens Friday, perfectly timed to the summer solstice. Part of a countrywide celebration of Mr. Turrells light-and-space art (solos have already opened at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art), its among the most eagerly awaited shows of the season.

title: Brooklyn Talent on a New Screen
description: The fifth annual BAMcinemaFest, Brooklyns celebration of independent cinema, kicks off Wednesday, offering its customary eclectic assortment of documentaries and narrative features. The festival, running until June 28, continues to showcase Brooklyn talent, this year including the filmmakers Shaka King (Newlyweeds); Eliza Hittman (It Felt Like Love); and Zach Clark (White Reindeer).

title: Nourishing Cocoon at Lincoln Center
description: Lincoln Center Theaters LCT3 program for emerging artists is having a lustrous moment, with this years Pulitzer Prize for Disgraced, which it presented last fall, and a Pulitzer finalist in 4000 Miles, from two seasons before.

title: Experimenting on All Sides
description: Summer dance has mercifully improved since Sam Miller took over as the president of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. For this seasons River to River Festival, Mr. Miller, who is always thinking of ways to invigorate the dance world, has selected 12 choreographers  including Luciana Achugar, Vanessa Anspaugh, Reggie Wilson and Souleymane Badolo  to show works over a two-year period. Its an experiment, as much for the artists as it is for audience members.

title: Drinking Buddies on the Road Again
description: You might not instinctively choose as drinking buddies two women who found fame with the McNuggetini: vanilla vodka shaken with a chocolate milkshake, poured into a martini glass rimmed in barbecue sauce and adorned with a Chicken McNugget. Or, dinner, dessert and booze in one chalice of multitasking, proclaims Alie Ward in the video that earned her and Georgia Hardstark a gig as the Cooking Channels Classy Ladies.

title: Random Acts of Performance
description: If, as Shakespeare said, all the worlds a stage, its even truer that all New York Citys a concert hall. Hardly a day goes by when you wont stumble upon spontaneous music in the citys parks and public spaces.

title: The Pendulum of Country
description: If youre looking for a fight on an almost-summer night, you could do worse than the Hunter Hayes show. There wont be fisticuffs, per se  only a battle for the soul of country music. Mr. Hayes is, depending how you look at it, the logical endpoint of several years of country de-toughening or a welcome reframer of the genre for those who find Luke Bryan too stern. Mr. Hayess self-titled 2011 debut album is sneaky, though: basically a savvy teen-pop heartache opus in light Music Row outerwear.

title: From I Hate Her to Icon
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  Cher, Dolly, Madonna, Barbra, Bette. Ask someone to name a gay icon, and one or all of those names would come to mind.

title: E.P.A. Backs Out of Role in Palisades LG Headquarters
description: In a rare about-face, the Environmental Protection Agency has withdrawn its involvement in the construction of a new corporate headquarters to be built in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., on the grounds that its height would disrupt the natural beauty of the Palisades.

title: A K-9 Graduation
description: A ceremony marked the completion of training for eight police dogs and they went on active duty with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: A K-9 Graduation
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority Police Departments canine unit held its graduation ceremony on Friday at Grand Central Terminals Vanderbilt Hall on Friday. Eight dogs were added to the active duty force.

title: Urgently Trying to Get Messages to Audiences
description: The life of a song doesnt necessarily end at the conclusion of its recording, or of a live performance of it. Songs have intended ears, targets in their cross hairs. Sometimes, to understand a song, to really hear it, it helps to know where and how its meant to land.

title: Questcor Pays $135 Million to Acquire Rights to a Competitors Drug
description: A pharmaceutical company that has reaped huge profits by selling a 60-year-old drug for $28,000 a vial has eliminated the most obvious threat of competition from a much cheaper drug by acquiring the rights to it.

title: In the Footsteps of Clementine Hunter
description: The artist lived her entire life in Louisiana, and her work flowed from her environment.

title: Ecuador Legislature Approves Curbs on News Media
description: When President Rafael Correa of Ecuador won re-election this year, and for the first time captured a majority in the National Assembly, he vowed to push forward with major proposals that had been stalled in his earlier terms. On Friday he gained a victory that he had long coveted when the Legislature passed a law regulating the news media, which he says will force news organizations to act fairly and which opponents say will quash freedom of expression.

title: Player in Leaks Case, Out From Behind Camera
description: The filmmaker Alex Gibney recalled bumping into his fellow documentarian Laura Poitras at the airport last year, when they both happened to be taking the New York-to-London flight.

title: The Meaning of Daring
description: The choreographer Patricia Noworol, who grew up in Poland and moved to Germany as a teenager, is fond of emotional and physical extremes. In the United States premiere of ?Culture, performed at Danspace Project on Thursday, she is the queen bee. She perches on a high ladder wearing a hot pink robe while shrieking into a microphone, dances topless under strobe lights and lectures the audience about arts financing.

title: How Flexible Is Your Employer?
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at how workers are perceived if they use a more flexible work arrangement  say, working early and quitting early, or cutting back on hours when caring for an elderly parent.

title: Unwelcome Innovation Earns Gamers Jeers
description: LOS ANGELES  Even though new video game systems depend on technological innovation, players are a conservative lot, suspicious of change. That partly explains why they gave a sustained ovation for old-fashioned games on disc during a Sony presentation this week here at the industrys trade show, E3.

title: Laurie Andersons Wall-to-Wall Summer
description: Laurie Anderson has a disarming way of making intense levels of activity seem matter-of-fact, even laid-back. In a spacious room on the upper floor of her TriBeCa duplex, with a glorious view of the Hudson River, she briefly looked over the shoulder of an assistant who was editing a video recording of the Chinese dissident artist (and, lately, musician) Ai Weiwei, with whom Ms. Anderson will perform, via Skype, at the Luminato Festival in Toronto on Sunday. She then padded down a spiral staircase to her studio, where, one afternoon this week, her stage equipment  a small keyboard, an iPad, a MacBook and her trademark electric violin  was powered up and ready for rehearsal or experimentation.

title: No False Advertising Here
description: The name says it all. But even if you didnt know what Farm to Table Bistro was called, you could see immediately that this Fishkill restaurant fits right into the movement for locally sourced eating.

title: BMW Announces Details and Prices for the 2014 4 Series Coupe
description: BMW released details  and photos  of its 4 Series Coupe on Friday, just in time for the weekend. So here they are, the 428i and 435i models, available in three different trim levels: Luxury, Sport and M Sport. Predictably, the Luxury trim caters to fancy gadgets, while the Sport and M Sport are tailored to the speed freaks amongst BMWs customers.

title: U.S. Agencies to Develop Standards for Bed Rails
description: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration and the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced on Friday that they have called for a committee to update voluntary standards for adult portable bed rails, which have been linked to the deaths of hundreds of elderly patients.

title: Week in Pictures for June 14
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a building implosion on Governors Island, pedestrians in the rain in Manhattan and an invasion of cicadas on Staten Island.

title: Song for My Father
description: I have been writing and singing songs for over half my life. And as I get older Ive noticed that the things I write about have changed. Im 46 now and I find myself writing a lot about middle age. I dont take life for granted as I once did. When I see my hometown Ohio area code light up on my phone, I sometimes worry it might be that call. My mom is an older lady now. She had a knee replacement and her hair is turning white and shes having a harder time getting around. My dad is 80 and hes one of two siblings left out of nine.

title: A Vineyard With a View (and Food, Too)
description: At some restaurants, being there is the real feast. So it is with the restaurant at Sharpe Hill Vineyard, which Steven and Catherine Vollweiler opened two decades ago in a quiet corner of Connecticuts Quiet Corner, the northeastern part of the state.

title: Bill Cunningham | Darned If They Do
description: Men answer the question: wear socks or expose your ankles?

title: Keeping Up With Medical Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Storm: New York Prepares, but the Rest?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dosas, Big and Bigger
description: Its a puzzle to a chicken tandoori and lamb biryani gal like myself that the typical dosa joint has 6,000 items on the menu. Four thousand of these items are made of rice and lentils, sometimes with spices and sometimes with special spices. And the star among these items is the pancake. I was tempted to say the humble pancake, but there is nothing humble about a dosa. Bragging rights go to the dosa that can overhang its plate by the most inches. Or feet. This is not an exaggeration. Not much of one, anyway.

title: Helping Syrias Rebels
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Lobby in the Vatican
description: To the Editor:

title: Todays Scuttlebot:  Cyberwarlord for the U.S., and Power Strips on the Road
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: After $98,000 Crime at Tiffany, Security Tips From a Pawnshop
description: Tiffany & Company has been selling jewelry in New York City since 1837, but it would seem the famous name could learn a thing or two from an uptown clerk named Mattie Simon in East Harlem, and, in particular, what happens when she calls out for a cup of black coffee.

title: Greedy Gardeners
description: ROOFTOP vegetable gardens were one thing, but the urban agricultural movement has gone a step too far. A new brand of activists want to incorporate fruit trees into the fabric of city life by turning our limited green space into woody groves filled with apples, cherries and plums. One group, the Guerrilla Grafters, has gone so far as to graft the branches of fruit trees onto street-side ornamental trees in San Francisco.

title: Wheeler, Mets Pitching Prospect, to Face Braves on Tuesday
description: The Mets will have plenty of decisions concerning their rotation once the prized prospect Zack Wheeler joins the staff next week. But the first of those decisions was officially made Friday when Mets Manager Terry Collins confirmed that Wheeler would be pitching the second game of Tuesdays split doubleheader in Atlanta. The Mets ace Matt Harvey will pitch the opener.

title: Nuclear Plants, Old and Uncompetitive, Are Closing Earlier Than Expected
description: Washington  When does a nuclear plant become too old?

title: Judge Rejects Fort Hood Shooting Suspects Defense Strategy
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Days after the Army major charged in the Fort Hood shooting rampage here in 2009 argued that he had carried out the attack to protect Taliban leaders from American soldiers, a military judge effectively tossed out his defense, ruling on Friday that the claim had no legal merit.

title: With Treetop Trail, Philadelphia Zoo Opens Grounds to Prowlers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Near the entrance to the Philadelphia Zoo, a new, long tubular cage hangs about 20 feet above the ground, twisting through trees and around buildings as it leads into the zoos densely packed campus.

title: A Peaceful Piano Protest
description: With his piano parked at Taksim Square in Istanbul, the pianist Davide Martello led protesters in a rendition of The Beatles Let It Be.

title: Close to Nature, and Perfection
description: Never mind that a restaurant named Agricola, the Latin word for farmer, has a distinctly manufactured feel. (A design firm and a branding firm were hired to create the rustic American effect.) The restaurant is a beautiful place in which to dine, and many of the dishes are, or are on their way to becoming, excellent.

title: Judge at War Crimes Tribunal Faults Acquittals of Serb and Croat Commanders
description: PARIS  A judge at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has exposed a deep rift at the highest levels of the court in a blistering letter suggesting that the courts president, an American, pressured other judges into approving the recent acquittals of top Serb and Croat commanders.

title: A Chinese Push for Urbanization
description: China is contemplating a drastic plan to move 250 million rural residents into towns and cities over the next dozen years.

title: Bad Idea, Mr. President
description: AMMAN, Jordan  ACCORDING to Bill Clinton, Barack Obama risks looking like a fool if he decides not to intervene militarily in Syrias continuing civil war. Likening the situation to his decision to intervene in Kosovo in 1999, Mr. Clinton said Tuesday that if he hadnt used force to stop Serbias campaign of ethnic cleansing, critics might have said: You could have stopped this by dropping a few bombs. Why didnt you do it? Mr. Clinton believes that Mr. Obama could end up looking like a total wuss if he doesnt intervene. And it seems hes going to act.

title: New Bridge Over Danube Helps Dissolve Old Enmities
description: VIDIN, Bulgaria  The European Union hardly basks in popular favor these days. But in this isolated corner of the blocs poorest periphery, leaders and locals on Friday celebrated a tangible benefit of membership  a $340 million bridge spanning the Danube that should help strengthen trade and ties between two impoverished members, Romania and Bulgaria.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: In Colorado, Nature Takes a Fiery Toll Despite a Communitys Efforts to Prepare
description: DENVER  For years, families in Black Forest, Colo., did what they could to keep the flames at bay. They scooped up pine needles and trimmed low-hanging branches around their homes. They chopped down saplings and hauled dead trees to the community mulcher.

title: A Search for Sexual Freedom Gone Awry
description: There is a rumor going around that in the 1960s any reasonable adult in search of casual sex could find it in a New York minute. But Neil Simons Last of the Red Hot Lovers, which first opened on Broadway in 1969, proves there were exceptions. And the Schoolhouse Theaters lighthearted new production of that comedy, in the theaters newly renovated space, brings back those days with a clear eye and a warm heart.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Clinton and Christie, 2 Politicians Sharing Wonk-Speak
description: CHICAGO  They first bonded over basketball and sparred in the rough and tumble of a political campaign, admiring each other as master politicians.

title: And With a Roof, Theyd Cost Even More
description: BOSTON  If you thought housing prices were spiraling up again, consider the lowly parking space.

title: The Other Side of the Story
description: The deck is always stacked when we debate keeping the nation safe.

title: Getting to the Frank Talk About Sex
description: Did you know that Dr. Ruth Westheimers parents had to get married, as people used to say? Do you want to know when Dr. Ruth, as she is known in her professional life as a sex therapist, first had sex? Mark St. Germains Becoming Dr. Ruth, now at TheaterWorks Hartford, will tell you.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Trying to Sell Wall Street on the Value of Marijuana
description: Kalvin Savanh grew up in Portland, Ore., and, during high school, he said, he grew marijuana. About 15 years later, Mr. Savanh, 33, still helps grow it  but now it is legal.

title: Disbelief, Merrily Suspended
description: ROLAND RUSINEK AND NOAH PLOMGREN, the actors who portray opera singers in Ken Ludwigs Lend Me a Tenor, do not look a bit similar. Nevertheless, their characters are mistaken for each other throughout most of Act II in Mr. Ludwigs clever farce, which has been revived frequently since its 1989 Broadway debut.

title: A Chance to Do Better on Greece
description: The International Monetary Fund now has a chance to show what it has learned from past policy mistakes on Greece, mistakes it acknowledged last week. This week a delegation from the fund, the European Central Bank and the European Commission was in Athens to review Greek compliance with the terms of the latest bailout agreement, a condition for releasing this months $4 billion installment. Greek officials said they hoped the European examiners would show new flexibility on changing the agreements more counterproductive requirements.

title: Hel-LO! Youre  Who Again?
description: It takes a certain amount of guts to go to your class reunions.

title:
Heavy Pressure
Led to Decision
by Obama on
Syrian Arms
description: WASHINGTON  For two years, President Obama has resisted being drawn deeper into the civil war in Syria. It was a miserable problem, he told aides, and not one he thought he could solve. At most, it could be managed. And besides, he wanted to be remembered for getting out of Middle East wars, not embarking on new ones.

title: The E.P.A. Backs Off on Factory Farms
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is obliged under the Clean Water Act to monitor Americas waterways and shield them from the toxic runoff from factory farms. But the growth of that industry, and its courtroom tenacity, has far outstripped the E.P.A.s efforts to restrict runoff from manure lagoons and feedlots.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Apple releases hardware and mobile software upgrades, a new study warns of peril in voice-activated car technology and Airbus flies its new A350.

title: Used to Leading, Vonn Is Content to Follow for Now
description: ARDMORE, Pa.  Lindsey Vonn sat on a stone wall 20 yards from the first tee at the Merion Golf Club on Friday afternoon. Her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, had just teed off, striding down the fairway with thousands of fans in his wake.

title: Locust Moon
description: I saw the first fireflies of June the other night. They looked a little aqueous, as if they were phosphorescing in a liquid darkness. I watched them with pleasure, wishing I were bioluminescent myself. It wasnt the darkness of the night that bothered me. It was the way it had become dark. Usually, even on cloudy evenings, I can feel the light rising skyward from the pastures, retreating with the sun. But that night it seemed as though the farm was gradually sinking deeper and deeper in a tide of shadows.

title: In Gospel Songs of Yore, Clues to the Speeches of Martin Luther King Jr.
description: When Jonathan Rieder was growing up in Philadelphia during the 1950s, infatuated with rockabilly and rhythm and blues, he sometimes rose early enough to inadvertently tune in to the Sunday-morning gospel show on WHAT. Those worship songs sounded different from his favorites, which aimed more at the hips than the spirit. For the Rieder family, fervently unobservant even in its own Jewish faith, Christianity stood at an alien distance.

title: Lottery Numbers
Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Push for Speed Cameras Turns to School Zones
description: A leader of the State Senate is adopting a new strategy focused on young New Yorkers to try to build support for a bill to install speed-tracking cameras that has languished in the Legislature for years.

title: Two Public Schools in New York Are Spared the Tear-Down of Development
description: After being considered as sites for new high-rise apartment buildings, two public schools near Lincoln Center have been saved from the wreckers ball, city education officials said on Friday.

title: A Britons Bitter Farewell to China Echoes Loudly
description: MOGANSHAN, China  MARK KITTO is still here. But he is leaving soon, he swears. It will happen sometime this summer, he said, after a final road trip with his family to the outer reaches of the Chinese empire, where two decades ago as a British soldier he joined a 59-day expedition to cross the Taklamakan Desert.

title: Minnesota Man, 94, Is Investigated for Nazi Ties
description: WASHINGTON  After more than three decades in existence, the Justice Departments Nazi-hunting team is facing what could end up being its last investigation after reports emerged Tuesday that a 94-year-old Ukrainian immigrant in Minnesota had led a Nazi SS unit accused of burning villages during World War II.

title: An Idol, Aging but Still in the Spotlight
description: There is one and only one center of attention in the Two River Theater Companys fabulous production of Nol Cowards Present Laughter. He is Garry Essendine, played here by the remarkable Michael Cumpsty. Mr. Cumpsty  whose appearance on Broadway last year as Judy Garlands supportive accompanist in End of the Rainbow brought him a Tony Award nomination  is an Englishman with square-jawed looks that would have been at home on a soccer field. But he slides into the silk pajamas, luxurious dressing gowns and witty repartee of a 1930s Coward leading man with championship ease.

title: Notes From the Underground
description: When East End or Busk, a new musical series at the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, begins its summerlong run on June 22, five acts that visitors may, or may not, recognize from New York Citys subways will descend on the premises.

title: Medicare Panel Urges Cuts to Hospital Payments for Services Doctors Offer for Less
description: WASHINGTON  A federal advisory panel said Friday that Congress should move immediately to cut payments to hospitals for many services that can be provided at much lower cost in doctors offices.

title: Behind Scolding of the F.D.A., a Complex and Gentle Judge
description: The judge whose vehement ruling ordered the Obama administration to surrender and make the morning-after pill available to all ages without a prescription is strikingly soft-spoken, so much so that to hear him in chambers, a visitor must sometimes lean forward from the raspberry-and-chartreuse striped sofa that is a legacy from his parents 1940s Brooklyn living room.

title: Only Two Players in U.S. Open Enter Weekend Under Par
description: ARDMORE, Pa.  Merion is an old-fashioned beauty, with shapely fairways and greens and a lineage that can be traced to Bobby Jones and Ben Hogan, peerless names in golfs Social Register. She reached maturity in a more genteel time, when decorum prevented any gentleman from insinuating that she was an easy conquest.

title: Unexpected Dcor
description: The ebony spleenwort (Asplenium platyneuron) is a fern with a strange name and a preference for growing where few other plants will. In New York Citys five boroughs, it is most frequently found squeezing its roots into the mortar of abandoned forts, railroad trestles, bridges and the foundations of old buildings.

title: Seafood Smugglers to Pay $22.5 Million
description: Three men convicted in 2004 of smuggling sea bass and rock lobster from South Africa were ordered on Friday by a federal court to pay that nation $22.5 million in restitution, the largest amount ever awarded for such a crime.

title: U.S. Opens Latest Fashion: Boots
description: ARDMORE, Pa.  After Tiger Woods completed his delayed first round of the United States Open on Friday, his white golf shoes were muddied, and his gray pants were spattered.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 15, 2013
description: To hell with you if you do not believe in our election.

title: Before Cabby Was Killed, His Dream Came True
description: After moving to New York from Nigeria about a decade ago, Uro Ama Orji worked long hours as a cabdriver with one goal in mind, his family said: to bring his five children to the United States.

title: Unearthing Memories of the Vietnam War
description: The war in Vietnam ended four decades ago, but it still weighs on the men and women who served there, and even on those who, for one reason or another, did not. Philip F. Napoli, an assistant history professor at Brooklyn College, movingly delivers a belated salute to the former group in Bringing It All Back Home: An Oral History of New York Citys Vietnam Veterans (Hill and Wang, $27).

title: Mets Favor Wright, but All-Star Voting Does Not
description: David Wright, by his own admission, has gotten tired of seeing his ugly mug on the video screen at Mets games. Yet there he is, looming over center field, as a voice-over urges fans at Citi Field to punch their ballots for Wright. A huge Twitter hashtag in white chalk spells out #VOTEMETS behind home plate.

title: Some Protesters in Turkey Disavow Agreement With Premier to End Park Sit-In
description: ISTANBUL  Taksim Square is mostly back to normal: the taxicabs line up in front of fancy hotels, whose doormen no longer clutch gas masks, and outdoor cafes are bustling again.

title: Home Away From Home
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Boy, this one really hung me up, and on a Saturday, one would expect nothing else, but boy, did I mention that this one really hung me up?

title: Spurs Defend 11-Year-Old Anthem Singer
description: SAN ANTONIO  The national debate over immigration touched down in an unusual spot this week: the N.B.A. finals.

title: The Sculptor Backstage
description: Working as the stage doorman of the Longacre Theater on West 48th Street in the theater district, Regan Kimmel sits in a small room inside the alleyway entrance and buzzes in the cast and crew.

title: This Isnt How to Stop Hacking
description: WUHAN, China  When we landed in China early this week, we hadnt realized that a long holiday, the Dragon Boat Festival, was about to begin. It took us a little while to figure out why traffic was so light in Beijing, and why the offices where we were meeting officials were so deserted.

title: These Children Are Our Future
description: Now that high school graduation season is winding down, its worth taking a moment to remember that in the sea of flowing gowns lurk some unsettling statistical realities. On many measures of childhood well-being, the last decade in the United States has been one of stagnation. We remain an outlier in many ways among developed countries.

title: Corrections: June 15, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Court in Venezuela Orders Release of a Judge Once Scorned and Jailed by Chvez
description: During the three and a half years that she was held in prison or under house arrest, Judge Lourdes Afiuni became a symbol of political persecution for many in Venezuela under President Hugo Chvez. On Friday, a court in Caracas, acting at the governments request, ordered Ms. Afiuni to be set free in the latest sign of a shifting political landscape in post-Chvez Venezuela.

title: Yankees May Need Rodriguez After All
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Speculation has swirled over whether Alex Rodriguez would be healthy enough to return this season from off-season hip surgery, and whether the Yankees even wanted him back.

title: The Blackhawks Biggest Fan, or the Biggest One in Congress, at Least
description: CHICAGO  As the Blackhawks and the Bruins skated into overtime Wednesday night, then another and yet another, Representative Mike Quigley was watching 700 miles away in Washington as he always does when he cannot be at United Center: alone.

title: Million-Anecdote Baby
description: A friend of mine has an adult child with cancer, a young man just old enough to be beyond the age of coverage under his parents health care plan. After nearly killing him, the dreaded Hodgkins lymphoma is in remission. But hes still a pariah in the eyes of the insurance industry, which means they can deny him a policy that might save his life.

title: Prison Sentence for 2 Musicians Who Released Album of Protest Songs
description: Two Tibetan musicians detained about a year ago by Chinese security officers have each been given a two-year prison sentence, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London. The two musicians, Pema Trinlay, 22, and Chakdor, 32, from Ngaba in Sichuan Province, produced an album called The Pain of an Unhealed Wound. The album has 12 songs, among them ones that praised the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, and the scores of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since 2009 to protest Chinese rule. The singers were sentenced in February, but news of the punishments has only now begun to emerge, Free Tibet said in its news release on Thursday. About 120 ethnic Tibetans in Chinese-ruled regions have self-immolated. Many of the monks who set themselves on fire came from the Kirti Monastery in Sichuan Province on the eastern edge of the Tibetan plateau. The monastery has been in conflict with the Chinese authorities since 2008, during a widespread Tibetan uprising.

title: Millions Spent to Deport Militant Cleric in Britain, but He Still Hasnt Left
description: The British government said Friday that it had spent the equivalent of $2.7 million to date on legal expenses related to its efforts over the last decade to deport the militant Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada, including more than $1 million in legal aid for the clerics lawyers. The Jordanian cleric, whose real name is Omar Mahmoud Mohammed Othman, arrived in Britain on a false passport in 1993.

title: Yankees May Need Rodriguez After All
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Speculation has swirled over whether Alex Rodriguez would be healthy enough to return this season from off-season hip surgery, and whether the Yankees even wanted him back.

title: Facebook Discloses Basic Data on Law-Enforcement Requests
description: 12:10 a.m. Saturday, June 15, 2013 | Updated Added Microsofts release of more data on Friday night.

title: Local Stop: Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: The Brooklyn Navy Yard dates to 1801, and at its peak in World War II, 70,000 people worked there. But it closed in 1966, and today it is a model of eco-friendly adaptive reuse.

title: A Birthplace of Ships, Transformed
description: The Brooklyn Navy Yard dates to 1801, when an entrepreneurial shipbuilder named John Jackson sold his land on Wallabout Bay, in the East River, to the federal government. At the yards peak in World War II, 70,000 men and women worked there. But it never recovered from a severe postwar decline, and the government closed it in 1966. The city turned the site into an industrial park, and today it seems to be a model of eco-friendly adaptive reuse. Only Building 92, which houses an interactive museum and job center, is regularly open to the public, but tours by bus and bicycle allow visitors to see the campus. To get there, take a bus to Flushing Avenue, the F train to York Street or ride a bike  if you dont have one, there are Citi Bike stations nearby.

title: Louisiana: One Killed and Five Hurt In Second Chemical Plant Blast
description: One person was killed and five people were injured in a chemical plant explosion in Donaldsonville, La., on Friday night, the state police said, a day after another fatal explosion at a chemical plant in the neighboring town of Geismar. The two explosions did not appear to be related. Fridays was caused by a truck offloading material at the C. F. Industries plant, which produces nitrogen, among other chemicals, for fertilizers, said Lt. John Cannon of the Louisiana State Police. The Thursday explosion, at a plant owned by Williams Companies Inc., based in Tulsa, Okla., killed two people and injured dozens. The Labor Departments Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating the blast at the plant, which makes ethylene and propylene, highly flammable gases.

title: A Myanmar in Transition Says Little of Past Abuses
description: YANGON, Myanmar  The former head of military intelligence, once feared and loathed for the torture his agents inflicted, now runs an art gallery. Myanmars former dictator, U Than Shwe, is reportedly enjoying a peaceful retirement in a secluded compound, while family members who grew rich during his military rule live luxurious lifestyles that contrast with the crippling poverty that afflicts most of the country. And a former top general in what was one of the worlds most repressive governments, U Thein Sein, is president, hailed both inside the country and abroad as a great reformer. He has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Jerome Karle, Nobelist for Crystallography, Dies at 94
description: Jerome Karle, who shared the 1985 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with a former college classmate for creating what is now an essential tool in the development of new drugs, died on June 6 at a hospice in Annandale, Va. He was 94.

title: Redesign for Living
description: Vishaan Chakrabarti, 47, has been a force in New York real estate for decades, working as director of the Manhattan office for the Department of City Planning and later as a senior executive at the Related Companies. Now he is the Marc Holliday associate professor of real estate development and the director of CURE, the Center for Urban Real Estate, at Columbia Universitys Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. He is also a partner at SHoP Architects, and recently published his first book, A Country of Cities: A Manifesto for an Urban America. Despite his many hats, Mr. Chakrabarti finds time on Sundays to work with his wife, Maria Alataris, also an architect, on renovations for their home near Union Square and to relax with their 5-year-old daughter, Avia, and 11-year-old son, Evan. The family lives on the top floor of a co-op on West 17th Street and was recently joined by a Havanese puppy, Hero.

title: A Building Famous for Its Parties (Not to Mention Art)
description: From the outside, 404 East 14th Street, a former warehouse near First Avenue that runs through the block to East 13th Street, is unremarkable at best. The 13th Street facade is dominated by its fire escape; the focal point on the more commercial 14th Street side is a McDonalds with a 24-hour express window.

title: N.H.L. Trophies Awarded
description: After helping the Blackhawks to a narrow victory over the Bruins in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, the Chicago captain Jonathan Toews logged a second narrow victory over Boston on Friday when he edged the Bruins Patrice Bergeron for the Frank J. Selke Trophy as the N.H.L.s best defensive forward of 2013. Toews received 1,260 points from voters to Bergerons 1,250.

title: Philadelphia Zoo Plans to Give Animals a Way to Roam
description: While other zoos have adopted trail systems in limited areas, the Philadelphia Zoo is the worlds first with a plan to rotate animals throughout its grounds.

title: Marcum Slips in Bid to Stay in Rotation With Loss to Cubs
description: For the next two weeks, the Mets will be holding auditions for the right to remain in the pitching rotation. With the call-up of the top prospect Zack Wheeler to start in Tuesdays doubleheader against the Atlanta Braves, the Mets will have three pitchers fighting for two spots.

title: Joseph A. Unanue, Former Chief Executive of Goya Foods, Dies at 88
description: Joseph A. Unanue, who as chief executive helped Goya Foods become the largest family-owned Hispanic food company in the United States, died on Wednesday at his home in Alpine, N.J. He was 88.

title: Voting in Iran
description: Iranians said that they saw an election as a way to send a message about their displeasure with the direction of the country.

title: Reinvestigating the Friedmans
description: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The letter to the Nassau County district attorneys office was succinct and unambiguous.

title: Christie Speaks With Bill Clinton
description: Gov. Chris Christie speaks to former President Bill Clinton about disaster preparedness in New Jersey and lessons other governors can take away from Hurricane Sandy.

title: Bruins Depth Meets Its Match in Blackhawks
description: CHICAGO  The Boston Bruins are no longer a team that plays four lines. The team that used 12 forwards and whose fourth line destroyed the Rangers in the second round has changed. It is now a team led by star forwards.

title: In Queens, a Casino Bet Gone Bad
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon I set out to explore South Ozone Park in Queens, in particular a stretch whose racial composition  according to recent census data, about a quarter white, a quarter Asian, 10 percent black and 11 percent biracial, with 30 percent of residents belonging to the statistical category of other  makes it one of the three most diverse patches of the city. Ethnically, too, it contains multitudes: Dominicans and Puerto Ricans live alongside Ecuadoreans, Indians, Pakistanis, Chinese and people who look as though they might be cast in the production of anything succumbing to Italian-American caricature.

title: Ask a Transportation Officer
description: Next up in Metropolitans Q. and A. series is Pamela Elsey, 59, who as assistant chief transportation officer for New York City Transit plans whether and when your subway line will be repaired or improved.

title: Messier Interviewed for Rangers Coaching Job
description: Mark Messier confirmed to NHL.com that he was interviewed for the Rangers vacant coaching position. Obviously the Rangers would be a dream come true for a lot of coaches, Messier said. The former Vancouver coach Alain Vigneault has already interviewed for the job, and the former Buffalo coach Lindy Ruff is also a candidate. The Los Angeles Times reported that the Kings assistant coach John Stevens, a former Flyers head coach, was in the mix as well.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE DARK KNIGHT RISES (2012) In this final installment in the director Christopher Nolans trilogy, Christian Bale stars as Batman, who has now retreated into the shadows  and his playboy alter ego, Bruce Wayne, who has gone into seclusion at Wayne Manor years after the death of his foe Harvey Dent and the woman both men loved. Now Bane (Tom Hardy, above left, with Mr. Bales), an overmuscled brute who wears a mask that supplies him with a pain-relieving gas, is intent on destroying Gotham City. Bruce must also contend with Selina Kyle (Anne Hathaway), a cat burglar in search of a clean slate. Gary Oldman is back as Commissioner Gordon, and Michael Caine as Alfred, the Wayne family butler. After repeatedly sending Batman down Gothams mean streets, Mr. Nolan ends by taking him somewhere new, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critics pick. Thats precisely the point of a late sequence in which he shifts between a multitude of characters and as many locations without losing you, his narrative thread or momentum. Like the scenes-within-scenes from his last movie, Inception, she said, the controlled fragmentation works on a pleasurable, purely cinematic level. But, Ms. Dargis added, it also serves Mr. Nolans larger meaning in The Dark Knight Rises and becomes his final say on superheroes and their uses because, as Gotham rages and all seems lost, the action shifts from a lone figure to a group, and hope springs not from one but many.

title: Simmons Upset With SportsCenter for Editing His Joke
description: Bill Simmons is one of the most powerful voices at ESPN. He writes an influential column, runs the Grantland Web site and is a key part of the 30 for 30 documentary series. This past season, he got another job that appealed to his love of basketball, as part of the revamped N.B.A. studio show on ESPN and ABC Sports.

title: Offense Still Absent as Yankees Lose Fourth Straight
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Weary, battered and undermanned is no way for a Yankees team to arrive in Orange County, home to many agonizing defeats for them over the years. They had lost 25 of their last 37 games at Angels Stadium since 2005, and that poor record was accomplished with players like Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and Jorge Posada.

title: IHT Quick Read: June 15
description: NEWS As a group of rebels gathered in an apartment in Aleppo, Syrias largest city, debating the value of the United States decision to provide them with weapons, government forces nearby began pounding an opposition-held neighborhood. The opposing events led the group to focus on a question asked on Friday by many in Syrias beleaguered opposition: Would the promised aid come in time, or would be it be too little, too late? An older rebel who leads a few dozen fighters on one of the front lines in Aleppo was skeptical. Ill believe that America is helping us when I see American arms in my groups hands, not statements and food baskets, said the 40-year-old fighter, who calls himself Abu Zaki. Ben Hubbard reports from Cairo.

title: Iran Moderate Wins Presidency by a Large Margin
description: TEHRAN  In a striking repudiation of the ultraconservatives who wield power in Iran, voters here overwhelmingly elected a mild-mannered cleric who advocates greater personal freedoms and a more conciliatory approach to the world.

title: Google Calls U.S. Data Request Disclosures a Step Backward for Users
description: Even as tech companies were given permission to publish some data on national security requests for users data, Google said the authorization did not go far enough.

title: Experiments With Democracy in Bhutan
description: Bhutan does things differently in South Asia, and nothing illustrates this so as much as the way it has conducted its transition to democracy.

title: McCartney Plays to a Reverent Crowd at Bonnaroo
description: MANCHESTER, Tenn.  I cant remember seeing a show  of music or really anything else  with so much privileged space and veneration around it as Paul McCartneys two-and-a-half-hour concert here on the second night of the Bonnaroo festival.

title: Police Storm Park in Istanbul, Setting Off a Night of Chaos
description: ISTANBUL  After 18 days of antigovernment demonstrations that presented a broad rebuke to the countrys leadership, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered the riot police to storm the center of the protest movement in Gezi Park on Saturday evening, setting off a night of chaos in downtown Istanbul.

title: The Early Word: Reinforcements
description: Todays Times

title: Rangers Said to Choose Vigneault as New Coach
description: CHICAGO  Alain Vigneault has agreed in principle to become the next coach of the Rangers, a person with knowledge of the situation indicated Saturday. The Rangers officially declined to comment on the reports, but an announcement of Vigneaults hiring could come as soon as Sunday, an off day between Games 2 and 3 of the Stanley Cup finals between the Chicago Blackhawks and the Boston Bruins, if final details between Vigneault and the Rangers are worked out quickly.

title: Worthwhile Canadian Comparison
description: Im in Toronto, where I just received an honorary degree from the University of Toronto; and my thoughts have naturally turned, as they dont do often enough, to matters Canadian. For it seems to me that Canada offers a useful test case for theories about what lies behind the Great Recession and the Not-So-Great Recovery.

title: Hong Kong Demonstrators Show Support for Snowden in N.S.A. Leak Case
description: HONG KONG  Chanting slogans like Shame, U.S. government, demonstrators marched from a downtown park to the United States Consulate on Saturday to urge that Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor accused of leaking documents about American surveillance programs, be allowed to remain in Hong Kong.

title: Attacks Test New Pakistan Government
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Islamic militants blew up a bus carrying female university students in Baluchistan Province in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday and then attacked a hospital complex where the wounded had been taken and local officials had gathered to comfort them, leaving at least 23 people dead.

title: A Fathers Day Quandary: Go See the Mets or Not
description: The prospect of attending a major league baseball game for free with my two sons and my Dad on Fathers Day would normally be as good as it can get.

title: Suddenly, Retiree Nest Eggs Look More Fragile
description: MANY Americans dont have enough money to carry them through retirement  and many of them know it.

title: Mandelas Grandson Says Ex-Leader Is Recovering
description: QUNU, South Africa  A week after he was hospitalized with a serious lung infection, former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa has started to recover, his grandson said Saturday.

title: For Snowden, a Life of Ambition, Despite the Drifting
description: WASHINGTON  In 2006, when Edward J. Snowden joined the thousands of computer virtuosos going to work for Americas spy agencies, there were no recent examples of insiders going public as dissidents. But as his doubts about his work for the Central Intelligence Agency and then for the National Security Agency grew, the Obama administrations campaign against leaks served up one case after another of disillusioned employees refashioning themselves as heroic whistle-blowers.

title: Pope Fills Key Job at Troubled Vatican Bank
description: ROME  Three months into his papacy, Pope Francis took his first significant step on Saturday toward making changes at the troubled Vatican Bank, naming a trusted prelate to fill a key vacancy in an indication that the pope intends to keep a close watch on the institution.

title: Caste Is Not Past
description: BANGALORE, India  CASTE is not a word that modernizing India likes to use. It has receded to the unfashionable background. Newspapers reserve their headlines for the newer metrics of social hierarchy: wealth and politics, and those powerful influencers of popular culture, actors and cricket stars.

title: 13 Major Winners Miss the U.S. Open Cut
description: ARDMORE, Pa.  Merion Golf Club has a history of crowning notable champions. But in the 2013 United States Open, 13 major winners did not make the cut when the rain-delayed second round was completed Saturday morning. The excluded group included ngel Cabrera, a former winner of the event and the runner-up at the Masters in April, and Graeme McDowell, another former Open champion who was second last year and considered a favorite heading into this event.

title: Variety: A Parental Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The quote that makes up todays acrostic is only a small part of a live performance that BILL COSBY gave in 1983, although I know most of it by heart. So do my kids as well as my parents, because the points Mr. Cosby made are universal when it comes to parenting and family-raising.

title: China Sets New Rules Aimed at Curbing Air Pollution
description: HONG KONG  Chinas cabinet has adopted 10 measures to improve air quality in the latest move aimed at responding to the dense smog that has repeatedly enveloped Beijing and other major Chinese cities in recent years.

title: Can School Reform Hurt Communities?
description: NEW ORLEANS  BEFORE Hurricane Katrina, about 74 percent of this citys schools were considered failing, based mainly on their standardized test scores. By 2012, that figure had dropped to 42 percent, even as the bar for passing was raised. Average ACT scores for the citys public school students have inched up. In 2011, black students in New Orleans outperformed their peers in the rest of Louisiana for the first time since the state test scores have been tracked.

title: U.S. to Keep Warplanes in Jordan, Pressing Syria
description: WASHINGTON  Ratcheting up the pressure on President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, the United States will keep American warplanes and antimissile batteries in Jordan, officials said Saturday.

title: Spurs and the Heat Show the Rewards of Continuity
description: SAN ANTONIO  Springtime drama in the N.B.A. unfolds on parallel tracks, one lined with elation and triumph, the other with futility and despair, not all of it confined to 94 feet of hardwood.

title: Why Colorados Fire Losses, Even with Global Warming, Need Not Be the New Normal
description: 11:53 a.m. | Updated below |As Coloradans grappled with the impact of the states latest wildfire disaster, some writers were quick to call this the new normal due to greenhouse-driven climate change.

title: In Countrywide Case, Watchdogs Without Any Bark
description: FOR the last two weeks, a justice in New York State Supreme Court has heard testimony in one of the most pivotal cases of the financial crisis. The hearings will tell whether Bank of America can extinguish legal liability for more than a million Countrywide Financial loans by paying $8.5 billion in cash and agreeing to loan servicing improvements in a settlement struck with 22 investors in 2011.

title: In California, Bolts May Hold Up a Bridge in More Ways Than One
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The plan was to finish construction on the new eastern stretch of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and open it on Labor Day. Then the existing bridge, which partly collapsed in 1989 during the last major earthquake here, would be demolished.

title: No Country for Slow Broadband
description: WASHINGTON  THERE is a popular story going around about the state of Americas broadband networks: service is pitifully slow, hugely overpriced and limited to the richest neighborhoods  whereas in Europe, service is cheap, fast and widespread because regulators force big companies to make room for smaller service providers.

title: For a Horse of the World, a Finale in a Regal Race
description: There is no denying that Animal Kingdom is a citizen of the world. His father was Brazilian and his mother German. He has won the most famous race in the United States, the Kentucky Derby, and the globes richest, the Dubai World Cup. His talent has united an international cast of horsemen: an English-born trainer, an Australian breeder, an Arab sheik and 20 American partners.

title: Solving a Structural Issue
description: Bolts on the new Bay Bridge have failed, possibly delaying the bridge opening.

title: Bill McDermott of SAP, on Knowing What You Want
description: This interview with  Bill McDermott, co-chief executive of SAP, the software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: I Know What You Think of Me
description: Recently I received an e-mail that wasnt meant for me, but was about me. Id been ccd by accident. This is one of the darker hazards of electronic communication, Reason No. 697 Why the Internet Is Bad  the dreadful consequence of hitting reply all instead of reply or forward. The context is that I had rented a herd of goats for reasons that arent relevant here and had sent out a mass e-mail with photographs of the goats attached to illustrate that a) I had goats, and b) it was good. Most of the responses I received expressed appropriate admiration and envy of my goats, but the message in question was intended not as a response to me but as an aside to some of the recipients co-workers, sighing over the kinds of expenditures on which I was frittering away my uncomfortable income. The word oof was used.

title: A Wearable Alert to Head Injuries in Sports
description: HARD knocks to the head are a constant concern in contact sports  and not just in football or boxing, where recent attention has focused. Millions of girls and boys play hockey, soccer, lacrosse and other sports where blows to the head from collisions and falls are part of the game, even in youth leagues and on high school teams.

title: Ralph Graves, Who Strove to Keep Life Magazine Afloat, Dies at 88
description: Ralph Graves, a former writer, editor and executive at Time Inc. who as the last managing editor of the weekly Life magazine strove to keep an American institution afloat in its turbulent final years, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Smith Impresses Jets, but Role Is Unclear
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Geno Smith has made clear that he intends to be an upright, in-the-pocket, strong-armed quarterback in the N.F.L., and when training camp opens next month, he is squarely in the running to start that way with the Jets.

title: The Next Iranian President
description: Hassan Rowhani, a moderate, has been elected the next president of Iran.

title: Patience Yields Dividends for Brewers and Gomez
description: Before batting practice last week, by his locker in the Milwaukee Brewers clubhouse, center fielder Carlos Gomez wore a T-shirt with the logo of the Boras Corporation. Gomez is a proud client, and Scott Boras secured him a three-year, $24 million contract before this season, even though his career on-base percentage, to that point, was .294.

title: What Sweden Can Tell Us About Obamacare
description: LAST month, for the 37th time, the House of Representatives voted to repeal Obamacare, with many Republicans saying that its call for greater government involvement in the health care system spells doom. Yet most other industrial countries have health care systems with far more government involvement than we are ever likely to see under Obamacare. What does their experience tell us about Republican fears?

title: Messages Galore, but No Time to Think
description: IM old enough to remember a simpler time in the office, when talking  whether in person or on the phone  was the main way to communicate. I once had a job where I filled out those pink While You Were Out slips for employees who had stepped away from their desks.

title: Sunday Dialogue: How the Court Decides
description: Should the justices take the effects on society into account?

title: What Periwinkle Looked Like
description: MONTEMURLO, Italy

title: TimesTalks Luminato Festival Video: Willem Dafoe and Robert Wilson
description: The film and stage actor Willem Dafoe and the avant-garde director Robert Wilson, whose staging of The Life and Death of Marina Abramovic will have its North American premiere at the Luminato Festival, talk with the New York Times contributing culture writer and author John Rockwell.

title: Charles Bengochea of HoneyBaked Ham, Carving a Career
description: I WAS born in Havana, but in 1959 my family left Cuba as the political regime was changing. I later became a naturalized American citizen.

title: Fears of National ID With Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Drivers license photographs and biographic information of most Americans would be accessible through an expanded Department of Homeland Security nationwide computer network if the immigration legislation pending before the Senate becomes law.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, June 16
description: I never put online anything about where I live, my family, my pets. Im even careful about what I like.

title: My Father, the Stranger
description: The photographer Diana Markosian travels around the globe to see the father she never knew.

title: My Father, the Stranger
description: I KNOCKED on the door of a stranger.

title: Dodgers and Yankees: A Gathering Made for Autumn
description: When the Dodgers played in Yankee Stadium, it was always the World Series back in the day. Back in the decades, actually, from 1941 to 1981.

title: Mattingly Proudly Wears Dodger Blue, but Pinstripes Still Befit Him
description: LOS ANGELES  When Don Mattingly, at heart still the plain-spoken, small-town boy from Evansville, Ind., flies into New York and takes in the sweeping views of Manhattan, he cannot help feeling at home.

title: Sources With Secrets Find New Outlets for Sharing
description: AT the end of the 1975 thriller Three Days of the Condor, a C.I.A. researcher played by Robert Redford, with the code name Condor, stands in front of The New York Times building.
