title: WikiLeaks Says It Is Working to Negotiate Asylum in Iceland for Snowden
description: WASHINGTON  WikiLeaks activists in Iceland are discussing with government officials there the possibility of asylum for Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who disclosed hundreds of classified documents on N.S.A. surveillance, Julian Assange, the founder of the antisecrecy group, said Wednesday.

title: Michelle Obama Promotes Healthy Eating With a Grass-Roots Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  The tables, which stretched the length of a full city block, were covered with pork lettuce wraps, catfish, spring rolls, all manner of vegetable soup and something called lunchtime waffles. Sam Kass, Michelle Obamas senior policy adviser on nutrition, leaned over a pork dish, stabbed it with a fork, then delivered his approbation. Fantastic.

description: ATHENS  The poignant image made its way around the world: A blond violinist, tears streaming down her face as she played Elgar in a studio orchestra of Greeces state broadcaster to protest Prime Minister Antonis Samarass unilateral decision last week to shut the broadcaster down and fire its 2,600 employees.

title: Tear Gas Fired Outside Stadium in Brazil, but Protest Still Spreads Inside
description: Tear gas once again filled the air outside a gleaming stadium in Brazil as the police in the northeastern city of Fortaleza blocked an estimated 35,000 protesters from approaching the venue where the national team, known as the Seleo, met Mexico on Wednesday afternoon in a tune-up for next years World Cup.

title: Turkish Liberals Turn Their Backs on Erdogan
description: ISTANBUL  For Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the antigovernment protests that have shaken Turkey have come with a jarring paradox: some of the protesters voted for him, most prospered from his economic policies, and some of the liberal intellectuals and columnists now calling him a dictator helped him win three successive elections with their writings.

description: Using 3-D printing technology, Ryan McMaster created components for a dolly system to use with his D.S.L.R. camera.

description: SNOWMASS, Colo.  John Denver was a troubadour of Colorado, singing of clear skies and country roads, sunshine on his shoulder and Rocky Mountain highs.

title: Obama Asks Russia to Join in Reducing Nuclear Arms
description: BERLIN  Fifty years after John F. Kennedy famously assured Europeans that the United States would protect them against a nuclear-armed Soviet Union, President Obama on Wednesday marked the changed times by calling on Russia to join him in cutting the worlds two largest nuclear arsenals to well below the level of the Kennedy era.

title: Gauging the Natural, and Digital, Rhythms of Life
description: Walking, sleeping, talking: its the stuff of everyday life. Add sensors that track all of it, and suddenly everyday life becomes an opportunity for knowledge.

title: Why India Trails China
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  MODERN India is, in many ways, a success. Its claim to be the worlds largest democracy is not hollow. Its media is vibrant and free; Indians buy more newspapers every day than any other nation. Since independence in 1947, life expectancy at birth has more than doubled, to 66 years from 32, and per-capita income (adjusted for inflation) has grown fivefold. In recent decades, reforms pushed up the countrys once sluggish growth rate to around 8 percent per year, before it fell back a couple of percentage points over the last two years. For years, Indias economic growth rate ranked second among the worlds large economies, after China, which it has consistently trailed by at least one percentage point.

title: Lebanon, Overrun by Syrian Refugees
description: ZAHL, Lebanon  MY eyes kept being drawn to the shoes. The tiny pink running shoes with Velcro straps, on the feet of the 2-year-old girl sitting quietly on her mothers lap. She fidgeted only a bit  jostling occasionally with her 7-year-old twin sisters while her father told a United Nations worker what had driven his young family 20 miles from Syria to this small town in Lebanon. They did not merely leave; they fled. And not once, but three times.

title: Superstitious James Says His Headband Will Reappear
description: MIAMI  The first question for LeBron James before the Miami Heats practice Wednesday was not about Game 7 of the N.B.A. finals, his ever-developing legacy or his triple-double performance in Tuesdays 103-100 overtime victory. It was not even about the Spurs. James was asked about his headband or, rather, the absence of it.

title: West Virginia, Still Home
description: In this Op-Doc video, and a related online interactive documentary, Hollow, I share the experiences and memories of hard-working people who live amid the coal fields of McDowell County, W.Va. They are struggling to save their rural community  in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people (since 1950, the county has lost 80 percent of its population).

title: Preparing for the Pope
description: In April, in the sunlit city of Natal, Brazil, two men knocked on Sandra Abdallas door to apply for a painting job. Their pitch, as she described it in an e-mail: they were evangelical Christians and therefore more reliable than the competition. They didnt drink, raise hell or steal, as a Catholic might. In a country that boasts the largest Roman Catholic population in the world  and a quickly rising tide of evangelicals  those are fighting words. Not least to Pope Francis, an Argentine who will visit Brazil next month, in the first trip of his papacy.

title: Andy Warhol and the Persistence of Modernism
description: The June 20th issue of The New York Review of Books contains a devastating portrayal, by the art critic Richard Dorment, of the activities of The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts and its (now dissolved) sister institution, the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board. The foundation was established, according to Warhols will, to provide for the advancement of the visual arts, and was to be funded by the sale of a large number of works the artist left to his estate. The board was assembled for the purpose of deciding whether a given work was an original Warhol. As Ill explain, that task is hardly straightforward.

title: Injured Making an Arrest, Bear the Police Dog Becomes a Celebrity

description: Jonathan Harris is a digital artist and designer. His projects combine elements of computer science, anthropology, visual art and storytelling, seeking to reimagine how humans relate to technology and to each other, Mr. Harris says on his Web site.

title: Kidd Adds Throwing Out First Pitch to Busy Schedule
description: Jason Kidds first six days as coach of the Nets have been a whirlwind of interviews and appearances, learning and organizing, settling in and reaching out to whomever might be willing to help him wade into his new career.

description: Along with  and because of  dramatic social and demographic changes, America is quickly dividing itself into two separate nations, regional enclaves of rigid politics, as the idea of common national priorities fades further into a distant past.

title: Lawsuit Named for OBannon Has Other Critical Participants
description: For Sonny Vaccaro, the Ed OBannon lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. is an important part of a personal crusade. He wants to see the organization, his nemesis, in court, its inner workings exposed. He prays he will be called to testify. He is not shy about the stakes, with the latest hearing in the case scheduled for Thursday.

title: G.E. Makes the Machine, and Then Uses Sensors to Listen to It
description: Thomas Edison invented tomorrow here.

title: British Court Rules Against Sanctions on Iranian Bank
description: Britains Supreme Court ruled that sanctions imposed on a commercial Iranian bank were invalid because the British Treasury had sought them improperly through a secret court proceeding in a misuse of Britains antiterrorism laws. The decision raised new questions about the countrys secret courts and was a vindication for the Iranian bank, Bank Mellat, which had spent four years fighting the sanctions designation that had banned it from operating in Britain. In Washington, the Treasury Department sharply criticized the British ruling and warned that Bank Mellat, which has been accused of financing Iranian nuclear and ballistic missile activities, remained under sanction by both the European Union and the United States. A Treasury Department statement said Bank Mellat has no place in the international financial system.

title: One-Sided Bill on Asbestos Injuries
description: Republicans rammed a bill through the House Judiciary Committee last month that would make it harder for plaintiffs injured by asbestos to get fair compensation. The bill is supposedly designed to root out fraud and abuse, but there is no persuasive evidence of any significant fraud or abuse. Before plunging ahead with this misguided attempt to protect asbestos companies from lawsuits, Congress ought to commission an objective study of whether there is even a problem that needs fixing.

title: Turkey in Turmoil
description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan had many opportunities over the last three weeks to resolve the political crisis in Turkey peacefully and quickly. However, with almost every statement and directive he has made the situation worse, increasing concerns at home and abroad over his authoritarian tendencies and Turkeys future as a democratic model in the Muslim world.

title: A Second Chance for Ex-Offenders
description: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission took on an important issue last year when it reaffirmed and updated a ruling that barred employers from automatically denying people jobs based on arrest or conviction records. The guidance made clear that an arrest alone was not proof of illegal conduct or grounds for exclusion. It also explained that, when considering an applicant with a criminal conviction, the employer must take into account the seriousness of the offense, the time lapsed since the offense and the relevance of the crime to the specific job being sought.

title: Will the Protests Change Brazil?
Digitizing Sports to Slake a Thirst for Stats
description: When Joe Inzerillo started taping baseball games for the Chicago White Sox a quarter-century ago, about all he needed was a video camera, some blank tapes and a bunch of VCRs. He would edit the tapes and send copies to the video staff members for the opposing team  job done.

title: How to Tweet in Mandarin
description: BEIJING  Lunch had run late, and by the time we got back to our hotel, Hung Huang was already in the lobby waiting for us. Blunt, opinionated and wickedly funny, Huang is one of the countrys top fashion editors. But she is better known for her acerbic posts on Weibo, a microblog, where she has 7.5 million followers. As we introduced ourselves  four journalists on a three-city tour of China  she passed around a picture that someone had texted her.

Instead the man who was responsible for protecting the personal information of Facebooks more than one billion users from outside attacks went to work for another giant institution that manages and analyzes large pools of data: the National Security Agency.

title: Sony Rebuffs New Call to Sell Entertainment Unit
description: TOKYO  Sonys chief executive, Kazuo Hirai, reiterated on Thursday that the companys music and movie businesses were not for sale, striking a cautious tone on a renewed push by the American activist investor Daniel S. Loeb to break up Sonys sprawling empire. He added that the companys board would continue to study the matter.

title: Condoms Approved for Schools in Massachusetts
description: The Boston School Committee on Wednesday approved making condoms available in the districts high schools. The new policy allows students to obtain condoms, and counseling, from school health centers or trained staff members, unless parents opt them out, and makes sexual education a required part of school health curricula. The district first made condoms available through health centers in some of its schools in the mid-1990s; in the past few years, a coalition of students and community leaders campaigned to broaden access to condoms and sexual health education in the district.

title: Henri Cartier-Bresson: Living and Looking
description: The journalist and filmmaker Sheila Turner-Seed interviewed Henri Cartier-Bresson in his Paris studio in 1971 for a film-strip series on photographers that she produced for Scholastic. After her death in 1979 at the age of 42, that interview, along with interviews that Ms. Turner-Seed had conducted with Bruce Davidson, Cornell Capa, Lisette Model, W. Eugene Smith, Don McCullin and others, sat like a time capsule in the archives of the International Center of Photography in New York.

title: Data You Can Believe In
description: Earlier this year, senior members of President Barack Obamas campaign team took a trip to Las Vegas. Nevada holds a special place in Obama-wonk lore as the place where his monthslong strategy of defeating Hillary Clinton by slowly and surely amassing delegates emerged. But the operatives were not there in March for any political reason. They were there to make money  specifically to land what they hoped would be the first corporate client for their new advertising business, Analytics Media Group (A.M.G.). Its bland name obscures its relatively grand promise: to deliver to commercial advertisers some of the Obama campaigns secret, technologically advanced formulas for reaching voters.

Jackie Calmes reports from Berlin.

title: On Nuclear Cuts, a Split Over Whether Senate Backing Is Needed
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State John Kerry called Senator Bob Corker on Tuesday to discuss President Obamas renewed drive for arms control. On that much, at least, the two agree. Exactly what was said, however, has quickly become a point of contention.

title: Pollution in Singapore Hits Record Level
description: HONG KONG  As pollution in Singapore soared to record levels on Thursday, local officials pressed Indonesia to curtail the widespread burning of forests, which they say is causing the stubborn haze enveloping the city-state.

Broder writes.

title: The House That Jinnah Built
description: LONDON  Last year some friends and I visited Flagstaff House, the residence in Karachi of Pakistans founder, Muhammad Ali Jinnah, who championed progressive secular democracy. We made our way through the high-ceilinged rooms past dust-covered furniture, photographs and personal items like shoes. We were almost alone. We couldnt sign the guest book, which was mostly blank, because the ink in the pen provided had dried up.

title: J.W. Andersons Shared Wardrobe
description: LONDON  Whether the J.W. Anderson collection was about genderbending for this new millennium or not, the designer sent out a collection that seemed fresh. The initiative came not so much from the pants  big Oxford bags, pleated at the waist and puddling over the feet. The effect was rather in the tunic tops, cut on sparse, geometric lines, maybe sliced at an angle, baring shoulders or with flourishes at the neckline. There were no men in frills this season but a defiantly female halter top with a girlie floral pattern.

title: Daily Report: Deepening Ties Between N.S.A. and Silicon Valley
description: Increasingly deep connections between Silicon Valley and the National Security Agency reflect the degree to which they are now in the same business. Both hunt for ways to collect, analyze and exploit large pools of data about millions of Americans. The only difference is that the N.S.A. does it for intelligence, and Silicon Valley does it to make money, James Risen and Nick Wingfield report in The New York Times.

Will its messy, multiparty, multiethnic democracy hobble its economic rise? Are sections of Indian population being tempted by authoritarian Chinas faster economic growth? These are some of the most argued questions of our times.

title: Wall Street Jitters
description: The Federal Reserve expects to start pulling back later this year from its economic stimulus efforts, the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday. Increasingly confident in the durability of economic growth, the central bank plans to gradually scale down its monthly purchases of Treasury securities and mortgage-backed bonds beginning later this year and ending when the unemployment rate reaches 7 percent, which may happen by the middle of next year, Mr. Bernanke said, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times. After that, the central bank would take several more years to unwind the rest of its stimulus campaign.

title: The Night the Hockey Nets Opened
description: It was, as NBCs voice-of-hockey Mike Emrick likes to call it, fire wagon hockey. If you saw the score of Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals and thought it was a typo, you were not alone. Yes, there were 11 goals. There were 90 shots on goal. And yes, it was the kind of freewheeling, back-and-forth play that was banned from the N.H.L. in the mid-90s when it was decreed that all games, particularly in the playoffs, must resemble the battle scene from Braveheart. The Boston Bruins and the Chicago Blackhawks pitched all that in the Charles River and decided this game would be a race to six goals. The Blackhawks won. In overtime. Naturally.

title: New Ways to Get Around Salt Lake City
description: A handful of new transportation options make it easier to get around the Utah capital without a car. This spring Salt Lake City opened the TRAX Green Line, a light rail route linking the airport and downtown. The six-mile ride costs $2.50 one way and, with the exception of overnight hours, runs every 15 minutes on weekdays and 20 minutes on weekends.

Only one, the new musical Aladdin, has been confirmed for Broadway, set to open next spring at the New Amsterdam Theater after a tryout run in Toronto. A spokesman for Disney declined to comment on the projects, but a rundown was compiled from theater artists and executives with knowledge of the plans, who all spoke on condition of anonymity because the projects  other than Aladdin and The Jungle Book  are considered confidential.

title: 36 Hours in Vancouver, British Columbia
description: Between the jaw-dropping confluence of mountains and sea, some of the best ethnic food in North America and public transit bliss courtesy of the Canada Line and SkyTrain, Vancouver is much more than an erstwhile Olympic site, or a place to stop over on your way to some other destination. Where else can you find an international brand of exoticism that rivals Hong Kong, Nordic-style order and a limitless array of shops, restaurants and top-notch accommodations? An abundance of outdoor options  whether it is hiking or biking in Stanley Park, kayaking in False Creek or skiing on nearby Grouse Mountain  only adds to the appeal. The city doesnt take its natural gifts for granted; in recent years it has become so eco-friendly that some stores dont even offer plastic bags. With its multitude of immigrant communities and northwest Canadian culture of extreme friendliness, Vancouver feels just different enough to be intriguingly foreign but familiar enough to be easily conquered in a weekend.

title: Vancouver Views

title: Home-Cooked Challenge: Whats for Breakfast?
description: First off, let me just say that a wiser person than I would not have paired the Home-Cooked Challege with the first week of what I should have dubbed the free-range summer challenge, the one in which my four children, on the weeks they dont have camp, roam the house, trails and fields while Im working for three days a week, playing with one another, the animals and the neighbors. Its not that this isnt going well. Its that a) I also added the I Dont Have an Office Anymore challenge, in which we remodel the part of the house with the office in it and I work in the kitchen and b) my visible presence serves as a constant reminder that if only I would, I could drive them to the end of the driveway with all their stuff for their lemonade sale, read the words one is struggling with in the book shes reading (every other one) and c) when three children coated head to toe with mud appear in your doorway with the plan of heading upstairs to clean up, I challenge you not to take a minute to get them towels and redirect them to the hose  and so on.

title: Extremism Rises Among Myanmar Buddhists

title: Home Depot Outflips Private Equity
description: Home Depot has outflipped and outstripped private equity. A buyout consortium led by the Carlyle Group acquired Home Depots wholesale arm for $8.5 billion just before the real estate bubble popped. On paper, the firms should recoup their HD Supply investment and then some in an upcoming initial public offering. But Home Depot fared even better.

On a drizzly March afternoon, she returned to Blessed Sacrament School, where she began her celebrated, if improbable, journey from her South Bronx childhood to the Supreme Court. But instead of a joyous reunion, it was more of a valedictory for her and the children  the school is closing for good.

title: The Gun Report: June 20, 2013
description: Look at our first item today. It is nearly unfathomable: two people having a domestic dispute fire a gun and kill their 6-month-old daughter. I know I sound like a broken record, but this is the kind of gun violence that we couldand shouldbe working hardest to prevent. It does not require new legislationalthough legislation that called for gun owners to keep their guns locked in their homes would certainly be welcome. It does not require we spend large sums of money. What it requires is a cultural change, in which gun owners take their responsibility more seriously. Why is this so hard?

title: Image of the Day: June 20
Linking Loyalty Programs
description: Major hotel chains like Marriott offer frequent guest club members a large number of hotels where they can spend their loyalty points. Now two smaller hotel groups are linking their loyalty programs, offering consumers more places to use their virtual currency. Hyatt Hotels Corporation, which operates 450 hotels worldwide (Park Hyatt in the Maldives, below), and MGM Resorts International, which has 12 hotels in Las Vegas, will link loyalty programs starting this month. title: Fermi Laboratory Names New Director

Dr. Lockyer, who was born in Scotland and raised in Canada, worked as a particle physicist working at Fermilab studying quarks. Dr. Lockyer will take office on Sept. 3. He is replacing Pier Oddone, who has held the post since 2005 and is retiring on July 1. Jack Anderson, Fermilabs chief operating officer, will serve as interim director until Dr. Lockyer arrives.

title: The Dangers and Benefits of Taking a Partner

title: Director of Ashmolean Museum at Oxford to Step Down

In 2016, the Ashmolean will present a Rembrandt exhibition organized by him.

description: The Navy announced on Wednesday that it had finally charged three football players at the Naval Academy with rape, sexual assault and lying to investigators after they allegedly gang-raped a female midshipman while she was passed out from drinking. The three midshipmen will face court martial proceedings and, if they are tried and convicted, could be sent to prison for 20 years or more. Well see how that goes.

title: Group Keeps Long-Distance Watch on Iran and Possible Sanction Violations
description: Inside a nondescript Midtown Manhattan office, a couple of computer analysts spend their days peering intently at large screens of satellite mapping surveillance data, watching dozens of little blips moving like snails. Each one, they said, represents a ship controlled by Iran or its trading partners.

title: Astors Son Remains Free at Least Another Day

title: Something for Every Taste in Next Glimmerglass Season
description: As it often does, the feisty and inventive Glimmerglass Opera, in Cooperstown, N.Y., will offer a broad range of styles within a compact program during its 2014 season next summer. Its schedule, which the company announced Thursday, includes four works including a staging of Carousel, the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical theater classic, which is part of the program of bringing musicals into the opera repertory that Francesca Zambello undertook when she became the companys artistic and general director in 2010.

description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  If 60 Minutes were being dreamed up today, its producers might very well have ditched the idea and gone with 6 Seconds instead.

title: New York City Ballet Announces Fashion-Focused Fall Gala
description: New York City Ballet will hold its annual fall gala celebrating dance and fashion on Sept. 19, featuring three world premieres, the company announced Thursday. Participants this year include the choreographers Benjamin Millepied, working with the Dutch designer Iris van Herpen; Justin Peck, whose new ballet will showcase costumes by Prabal Gurung; and Angelin Preljocaj, working with Olivier Theyskens.

title: House Rejects Farm Bill as Food Stamp Cuts Prove Divisive
description: WASHINGTON  The surprise defeat of the farm bill in the House on Thursday underscored the ideological divide between the more conservative, antispending Republican lawmakers and their leadership, who failed to garner sufficient votes from their caucus as well as from Democrats.

title: Living With Cancer: Seeking Intimacy
description: A week or so after a procedure, I found a sticker on my body. Not a Disney sticker or a Dora the Explorer sticker, put there maybe by a godchild or nephew, but a 1 1/4-by-1-inch white rectangle with a steel nipple at the center.

title: More Young People Ditching Credit Cards
A College Where the Exams Are Terrifying
description: What are little boy monsters made of? In Pixars Monsters University, they arent made of slugs, snails and puppy dog tails  theyre monstrous versions of those ingredients, only cuter, fuzzier, brighter, wilder and woollier. A stomping, creeping menagerie, they embody a Popsicle-hued rainbow of seeming diversity, from their googly eyes to their hydra heads and sticky tentacles. In this passable prequel to Pixars magical 2001 film Monsters, Inc., anything and every being seems possible. Or so believes the young Mike Wazowski (voiced by Noah Johnson and Billy Crystal), who thinks that if he studies hard enough, he too can become one of his worlds Scarers.

description: The designer describes what she brings for adventures with her family.

title: Climbing Everest  On Your Phone
description: Though the numbers of those attempting to summit Mount Everest have reached levels alarming to some, the vast majority of us have had to make do with second-hand accounts. Now theres a high-tech virtual option: the new Mount Everest 3D app offers tours of the worlds highest peak from any angle.

description: 6:36 a.m. | Updated

title: Brooklyn Pub Surrenders to Human Rights Commission
description: The Welsh pub in Brooklyn that got in trouble for a want ad offering British applicants a leg up has given up its fight against the New York City Human Rights Commission.

title: In-Laws and Outlaws
description: My husband and I are in our late 50s and recently wed. We met long after our separations from our previous spouses. My family loves him, and his likes me  except for a sister-in-law (who is married to his brother). She refuses to acknowledge my presence or speak to me. It cant be about me because she doesnt really know me. I try to make the best of it at family functions, but its still weird and hurtful. Recently, she came to our home for dinner. She brushed past me when she came in and ignored my greeting. Any advice?

title: Rethinking the Highway
description: Upgrades to the corridor between Denver and Boulder, Colo., will make it the first in the nation to offer a full array of options to encourage less driving.

title: Jean-Louis Scherrer, French Fashion Designer of the 60s, Dies at 78
description: Jean-Louis Scherrer, the couturier whose luxurious dresses and rich embellishments were symbolic of a fruitful period of French fashion in the 1960s, when designers like Yves Saint Laurent and Andr Courrges were establishing their own houses, died on Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 78.

title: Brazils Protesters, in Their Own Words
description: As my colleague Simon Romero reports, Brazil is braced for another round of protests on Thursday, with demonstrations planned for dozens of cities, even after the authorities retreated from plans to raise bus fares across the country in the face of massive street protests.

title: Highway Expansion Encourages More Than Just Driving
description: DENVER  Driving to Boulder from here offers a spectacular mountain panorama, but the nearer view is anything but impressive. U.S. 36, the unlovely highway that connects the cities, is crowded and often painfully slow, dotted with malls, fast-food restaurants and other commercial flotsam.

title: Celebrating Scandinavian Culture
description: If youre like the Miser, you tend to associate Scandinavia with fording frigid fjords and skiing over snowy white expanses, not cavorting in warm breezes on sun-splashed summer days. This weekend, however, several free events presented by Scandinavian expats are set to upset those expectations.

title: Berdych Hopes to Rekindle His Wimbledon Magic
description: STOKE PARK, England  Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic may be among the select few to have experienced the thrill of walking onto Centre Court for a Wimbledon final, but he is taking nothing for granted after crashing out in the first round in straight sets last year to Ernests Gulbis.

title: The Workout Unplugged
description: Vintage exercise machines have recently become the padded shoulders of the workout world: swept aside for a fresher look. The so-called functional-fitness trend, with workouts devised to help people perform daily activities like lifting, bending and climbing stairs, are relegating machines like leg presses and biceps curlers to second-class status on the gym floor.

title: How Cynthia Rowley Packs for Trips
description: The designer Cynthia Rowley travels so often with her husband and two young daughters that she has packing  particularly the quick, all-in-one-bag kind  down pat. I have a checklist I keep at home, she said. Its inside her medicine closet along with toiletries, her familys passports and a wad of cash. Its like Im on the lam.

description: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

title: The Lubitsch Touch, in Song
description: Released in October 1934, The Merry Widow brought to an end the spirited series of musicals  operettas, really  that Ernst Lubitsch had begun with his first sound film, The Love Parade, in 1929, and continued through Monte Carlo (1930), The Smiling Lieutenant (1931) and One Hour With You (1932). (All four of those films are available in an essential box set from Criterions Eclipse line, Lubitsch Musicals.)

description: Campo de Ourique, a district with a long history, has never been a tourist area. But thats changing.

description: LONDON  New rules to be discussed by European Union ministers on Friday would ban menthol and slim cigarettes, a move intended to improve the health of Europeans but one that has divided it broadly along cold war lines.

title: I Believe in Family Dinner. We Just Dont Achieve It Very Often.
description: Ive just published a book about family food, but in my house, regular family dinner doesnt exist. In fact, our family dinner has never looked the way its supposed to.

description: The Times is reporting that a deal has been struck to keep comprehensive immigration reform moving forward in the Senate, by addressing Republican objections that the bill is too weak on border enforcement.

title: Supporters of Immigration Bill Offer Amendment Focused on Women
description: Saying the immigration overhaul bill now before the Senate would discriminate against future immigrants who are women, 13 female senators have introduced an amendment that would make it easier for foreign women to come to the United States under a new merit system in the legislation.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Mesmerized Stare, and Googles Weird Questions
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Taking a Seat at Soccers Table, but Cautiously
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Two months ago, in a ballroom at the Westin Playa Bonita in Panama City, Sunil Gulati became one of the 25 most powerful people in world soccer. So as he sat in a hotel restaurant here Tuesday morning, why was it hard to know whether to offer congratulations or condolences?

title: Accidents and Accountability
description: One miscalculation leads to another in Three Worlds, Catherine Corsinis severe, anxiety-producing French drama about the chain of consequences after a hit-and-run accident. The 16th feature by Ms. Corsini, the film is a rigorous moral inquiry that puts its characters  but especially its ambitious young protagonist, Al (Raphal Personnaz)  through the wringer.

title: Blazing a Path Out of the Shadows
description: The beef is nearly black and as chewy as toffee. It looks practically torn by hand, hunks of it scattered among the shriveled yellow-white skins of once-green chile peppers that have been blanched and sun-dried until leached of color. They still burn.

title: Hunan Manor
description: Inside the Chinese restaurant just south of Grand Central Terminal.

title: Cross Over
description: Colum McCanns new novel, TransAtlantic, lifts off with a roar. The year is 1919, just after the end of the First World War: It was that time of the century when the idea of a gentleman had almost become myth. The war, McCann writes, had concussed the world. And yet here are two gentlemen, Jack Alcock and Arthur Brown, ready to set off in a modified bomber, a Vickers Vimy  It looked as if it had borrowed its design from a form of dragonfly  to fly the Atlantic, from St. Johns in Newfoundland all the way to Ireland. If they succeed, theyll make history. They will make a brand-new world.

title: Show Some Spine
description: A plague of womens backs is upon us in the book cover world. Weve recently seen Finding Casey, by Jo-Ann Mapson; The Unruly Passion of Eugnie R., by Carole DeSanti; and The Headmasters Wager, by Vincent Lam, all showcasing a nape-and-shoulder combo on the jacket. The Pretty One, by Lucinda Rosenfeld, features three women with their backs turned; The Smart One, by Jennifer Close, has its heroine turned away, undoing her wrap dress; and a bride stands facing a beach on Beautiful Day, by Elin Hilderbrand.

title: New York Citys Unemployment Rate Dips Slightly
description: New York Citys unemployment rate dipped to 8.3 percent in May, its lowest level in more than four years, despite a sharp drop in the pace of hiring, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

title: Thrilled to Death
description: The usual portal for wickedness and darkness in modern American horror fiction is youthful sexuality. Surging hormones summon demons. Thats why big-breasted baby sitters, once theyve tucked the kids in and phoned their boyfriends to tell them to sneak over, had best keep an eye out for slashers on the stairs. Thats why campgrounds full of teenagers in shorts so often lure scar-faced intruders from the woods. Who are these monsters? The thwarted and the spurned, their psyches warped by repression and rejection. They feed for a while on others erotic vitality but are ultimately defeated by these same energies in the form of some brave lass or lad who drives a stake or fires a lucky shot, restoring health and order to the world.

title: Tribune Falls Afoul of Its Own Tax Strategy
description: It was perhaps the cleverest corporate tax strategy ever devised: no matter how much money the company made, neither it nor its shareholders would ever owe a penny in federal income taxes.

title: Facebook Is Betting Longer Videos Are Better
description: Whats the perfect length for video shot and shared via a mobile phone  15 seconds or six?

title: Why Bernankes Remarks Set off Global, Contagious Market Fears
description: NEW YORK  It was a one-two punch. On Wednesday, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, testified that the Fed could foresee the day it would stop buying up U.S. bonds to goose the economy. The next day saw reports that Chinese banks had become reluctant to lend to one another, causing interest rates in the interbank market to spike to punishingly high levels.

title: Ross Stores Fined in Sales of Defective Clothing
description: WASHINGTON  The Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday that a leading discount department store had agreed to pay a $3.9 million fine for failing to report that it continued to sell defective childrens clothing after the agency warned that the clothes could cause injuries or deaths.

title: Solid in the Playoffs, Bostons Rask Shows a Sudden Vulnerability
description: BOSTON  Minutes after scoring the overtime goal that won Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals, Chicago defenseman Brent Seabrook uttered nine words that might be greeted with skull-imploding bewilderment in New York and Pittsburgh.

Obama to Pick Bush-Era Justice Dept. Official to Lead F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday plans to announce the nomination of James B. Comey, a senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, to become the next director of the F.B.I., according to White House officials.

title: Palestinian Premier Submits Resignation After Just Two Weeks in Office
description: JERUSALEM  The newly appointed prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Rami Hamdallah, submitted his resignation on Thursday after only two weeks in office, a signal of continuing internal political disarray amid the already complicated American efforts to restart the peace process with Israel.

title: National Parks Raise Guard Against Virus
description: DENVER  David Breskin was in line for the breakfast buffet at the Old Faithful Inn at Yellowstone National Park this week when he noticed something unusual: hotel employees in gloves were handing out plates and serving eggs and French toast.

title: A Director Whose World Is the Stage
description: Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the candlestick. So runs the nursery rhyme whose opening Jack OBrien has made the title of his exuberant theatrical memoir, and its even apter than he may realize. Its not just that a director as successful as he has had to be nimble and quick-witted to thrive in a precarious profession.

title: Albanese Takes Mayoral Bid Underground
description: Hi, Sal Albanese said the other day, greeting a commuter on the Seventh Avenue line. Im Sal Albanese.

title: High-Mileage Alterations
description: Walking through his gutted Brooklyn brownstone row house, Arthur Michel points out the stacks of original woodwork that he has set aside and plans to reuse  fireplace mantels, pocket doors and shutters. The 1887 house is in the Park Slope Historic District. Yet the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission was not concerned with goings-on inside, only with what Mr. Michel planned to do with the front windows and exterior ironwork.

title: Bloomberg Charity to Underwrite Mobile Guides for Museums
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs company, Bloomberg LP, has long provided financial support to museums to help underwrite audio guides.

title: Devoted To Choir, In Life And Death
description: To gag or to weep, that is the question. You may do both while watching Unfinished Song, a shamelessly sentimental, manipulative comic tear-jerker about a British chorus, the OAPz (for Old-Age Pensioners); a grumpy old man; and his saintly wife.

title: A Sugar Barons Scattered Art Collection
description: The 19th-century sugar tycoon William Hood Stewart ran a plantation in Cuba with thousands of acres and hundreds of slaves. Stewart invested the profits partly in European paintings.

title: Loan Modifications, Proactively
description: Homeowners who have fallen behind on their mortgage payments should check their mail carefully in coming weeks. Lenders will be offering loan modifications without even being asked.

title: Oracle to Leave Nasdaq for the Big Board
description: Oracle, one of the most prominent technology companies listed on the Nasdaq, is defecting to a rival exchange.

title: Fourth Grader Disappears; Exotic Quest Ensues
description: Bureau of Missing Persons, a new play by Lila Rose Kaplan, is sprinkled with bits of absurdity and magical realism and other charms. But the whimsical frills ultimately do not make up for the underwritten characters, who remain disconnected from one another and ultimately from the audience too.

title: James Gandolfini: Famous for TV, Marvelous in Movies
description: Updated, Sept. 13, 2013

title: Disabilities and Drama in an Irreverent Mix
description: In a waiting room full of actors, a handsome guy recognizes an attractive woman. In Neil LaButes mini-drama Call Back, Brad (Jonathan Todd Ross) knows he has met Denise (Mary Theresa Archbold) before, but cant remember where  or her name. It turns out that they shared a lot more than a casual conversation.

title: The ABC of It
description: An exhibit exploring the world of childrens literature opens Friday at the New York Public Library.

title: After French Loss, Djokovic Turns Focus to Wimbledon
description: STOKE PARK, England  Novak Djokovic is hoping to move on from his difficult loss to Rafael Nadal in the French Open semifinals two weeks ago.

title: Questions of Identity, Images of Crisis
description: I, YOU, WE, the Whitneys latest collection show and the last one for the Breuer building before the museum decamps to the meatpacking district, makes a useful prequel to the New Museums recent exhibition NYC 1993: Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star. Everything here dates from the 1980s and early 90s, otherwise known as the era of identity politics. And this show is unusually, almost unfashionably, forthright about those politics, foregrounding them with a string of pronouns.

title: The Woman at Jesus Side, and in His Bed
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At the end of the central scene in the first act of the composer Mark Adamos ambitious new opera The Gospel of Mary Magdalene, which had its premiere here on Wednesday night at the San Francisco Opera, Mary takes Jesus, called Yeshua in this work, to bed.

title: Finding Meaning in the Mundane
description: LONDON  Gary Humes paintings dont give much away. When he depicts a person, it is often little more than an outline; a plant is only a shape rendered in rich colors and varied textures. Its as if he wants viewers to create their own narrative. Yet walking through the galleries at Tate Britain, where a midcareer survey of his paintings recently opened, Mr. Hume, 51, isnt nearly as mysterious as his work suggests.

title: Bedtime With Puritans and Wild Things
description: The great green room and the purple crayon are here; so are the wild things and the poky puppy, Charlottes web and Alices wonderland, the very hungry caterpillar and the stinky cheese man. It is a reunion of creatures, characters and creations, gathered from memories of childhood and parenthood, and celebrated in The ABC of It: Why Childrens Books Matter, a remarkably rich new exhibition at the New York Public Library.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Singapore, Iraq and Russia.

title: Charlotte Moorman Performs the Cello
description: The French conceptual artist Jean Dupuy captures the cellist in performance at 405 East 13 Street. Moorman is wearing a mask of Pablo Casals.

title: Alice Munro Says She Is Retiring
description: Alice Munro, right, the short story writer, is retiring from the writing life, she told an interviewer in Canada. Ms. Munro, 81, had just accepted the Trillium Book Award for her latest collection, Dear Life, when she told Mark Medley, an editor from The National Post: Im probably not going to write anymore. And, so, its nice to go out with a bang. Asked if you really think this is it for you, she responded, Oh yes. Told that her fans would be disappointed, she said: Well, tell them to go read the old ones over again. Theres lots of them. Ms. Munro, an Ontario native who is considered a master of the short story, won the Man Booker International Prize in 2009. In her review of Dear Life in The New York Times in December, Michiko Kakutani wrote that Ms. Munro creates tales that have the scope and amplitude of novels: whole lives are condensed into a handful of pages, the progress of love is charted over the years as passion gives way to restlessness or deeper commitment or something more ambiguous.

title: A Brief History of a Legendary New York Art Building
description: It didnt look like much, but the blocklong building at 404 East 14th Street in New Yorks East Village was one of the most vibrant artistic hubs in the city during the 1960s. A former button factory, it offered enormous lofts (and $300 rent) that energized its residents to experiment on a larger scale  and host giddy bacchanalias as well. A new exhibit at Tibor de Nagy Gallery brings together the paintings, sculpture, photographs, films, correspondence and poetry of its famous inhabitants, from Claes Oldenburg to Allen Ginsberg. Here, a few of their memories about the buildings glory days.

title: When My Music Was Your Music
description: The sound of dial-up connections may be quaint in Alex Winters Downloaded, but not the issues in the film, the latest in VH1s enlightening series of Rock Docs. In tracing the rapid rise and gradual emasculation of Napster, the peer-to-peer file-sharing service that flourished in the 1990s, Downloaded tells a fascinating story about how college students harnessed the Internet to enable people to trade favorite songs, and how a blindsided music industry, ignorant of the Webs potential, effectively shut them down.

title: Always Growing, and Open to Change
description: About 20 men and women assembled in a ballet studio in Chinatown on a recent Monday evening to rehearse a sequence of austere and meticulously choreographed movements in silence. Peering over a piece of paper covered in tiny handwriting, Jamie Benson, a choreographer leading this rehearsal of the Shakedown Dance Collective, called out instructions while the group flowed through a series of arm movements, hand gestures, dips and bends.

title: Iron Supplements May Reduce Pregnancy Risks
description: A large review of studies concludes that taking iron supplements during pregnancy reduces the risk for maternal anemia and for having a baby with low birth weight.

description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: First a Bombing, Then a Truth Thats Elusive
description: The Attack opens with the image of a man and woman embracing, the world blurred behind them. Her face to the camera, the woman cries as they hold each other, but its unclear whether he can see her tears. Her unexplained weeping and the ill-defined backdrop make an apt start for this intelligent, involving movie thats by turns a murder mystery and a politically charged argument about contemporary Palestinian identity. That its also about a troubled marriage becomes evident when the man, a successful Palestinian surgeon living and working in Tel Aviv, is awoken one night and discovers that both his wife and his safe, cosseted world have disappeared after a suicide bombing.

title: Rosneft to Send $60 Billion Worth of Oil to China
description: The Russian state oil company, Rosneft, intends to sign a major contract to supply China with more than $60 billion of crude oil, a deal that could signal a small shift away from Western Europe toward Asia.

title: Follow the Leader; Hes Deep in the Pack
description: Leadership in jazz isnt always as clear-cut as it seems. An ensemble discipline, it often involves hierarchies as a matter of course, but the business of directing energy or driving a narrative can be anybodys game. Thats worth keeping in mind whenever the conversation turns to the saxophonist Mark Turner, who has been one of the most productive and vital artists of the last dozen years, without releasing his own album in that span.

title: For Headquarters and Pirates, a Test of Wills and Wits
description: In A Hijacking, his assured, intense second feature, the Danish director Tobias Lindholm turns tedium and frustration into agonizing suspense. Unfolding over a span of weary, stressful months, its action mainly confined to the below-deck parts of a cargo ship and a suite of sterile corporate offices in Denmark, the film is at once a probing psychological case study and a ripped-from-the-headlines exploration of modern sea piracy.

title: Panel Adopts New Rules for Taxi of Tomorrow
description: One month after a judge blocked the Bloomberg administrations initial plans for a near-uniform fleet of yellow cabs, the Taxi and Limousine Commission on Thursday approved an adjusted set of rules in a bid to introduce its Taxi of Tomorrow as scheduled this fall.

title: These Dead Dont Walk. They Run.
description: I know what some of you are thinking. Zombie apocalypse? Really? Again? But if you start complaining about the lack of originality in summer movies, honestly, when will you stop? (The answer in my case is Labor Day or cocktail hour.) And in many ways, when compared with Man of Steel, Iron Man 3 and Star Trek: OMG Ricardo Montalbn!, World War Z is pretty refreshing.

title: Lawmakers Approve Use of Lever Voting Machines for Falls Mayoral Voting
description: ALBANY  Acknowledging that New York City election officials say they cannot count votes cast on electronic machines fast enough to smoothly administer this years mayoral election, the State Legislature on Thursday night voted to allow the city to redeploy its old lever voting machines.

title: Spare Times for June 21-27
description: Midsummer Night Swing (Tuesday through July 13) Dancing feet will fill Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center for the season opener of this alfresco series, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis, which has its own silver anniversary this year, will provide the big-band music for the evening.

title: Spare Times for Children for June 21-27
description: Geppetto

title: New Light Fixture for a Famous Rotunda
description: James Turrells exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum will probably be the bliss-out environmental art hit of the summer. This is primarily because of the ravishing Aten Reign, an immense, elliptical, nearly hallucinatory play of light and color that makes brilliant use of the museums famed rotunda and ocular skylight. The latest site-specific effort from Mr. Turrell, Aten Reign is close to oxymoronic: a meditative spectacle.

title: For American Heroes, a Poke in the Eye
description: Where Did I Go Wrong? asks the title of a 1991 painted and collaged work by Llyn Foulkes. Its what Clark Kent is wondering in the work, as with furrowed brow he reads a newspaper with a banner headline blaring War! over news of the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war. Rendered as a cartoon cutout, Clark sits on a bulbous rock formation in a desolate Western landscape, his shirt open to reveal his Superman costume.

title: A Complicated Actor Who Made a Complicated Mob Boss Indelible
description: I feel like I came in at the end of something great, Tony Soprano told his therapist in the first episode of The Sopranos, the series that turned a little-known actor named James Gandolfini into the definitive postmodern mob boss.

title: Mourning the Loss of a Star as He Was Preparing to Return to HBO
description: It might have been one of the most talked about television events in recent years: James Gandolfini was coming home to HBO in a new series, his first since his indelible portrayal of the mob boss Tony Soprano on The Sopranos.

title: The East Coast of California
description: OVER six months in 2011 and 2012, dozens of art institutions in Southern California joined forces in a festival of exhibitions, Pacific Standard Time, celebrating the history of contemporary art in Los Angeles. The project was a big success and continues to generate energy. A jolt of it hits New York City this week in an unheard-of convergence here of major California shows.

title: From Tony Soprano to Chris Christie
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  THE first time I saw James Gandolfini on the screen, as the comically pathetic heavy called Bear in the film Get Shorty, I felt a flash of recognition. There was something familiar about the weakness and vulnerability he carried with him beneath his bullying, macho airs. The hurt in his eyes hurt me to look at it. I later learned that we had grown up at the same time not far from each other in suburban Bergen County, N.J. On summer afternoons in the 1960s, my mother used to drop a friend and me off at the movie theater in Westwood, Mr. Gandolfinis birthplace.

title: Collision Over the House Farm Bill
description: The Houses rejection of the farm bill by a 195 to 234 vote on Thursday was a stunning defeat for Speaker John Boehner, who supported the legislation and brought it to the House floor for a vote. Mr. Boehner was unable to win support from 62 Republicans on the partys conservative fringe, who cast no votes because they believed the $20.5 billion cut in the food stamps program did not go deep enough. Nearly all Democrats also voted no because that draconian cutwould have eliminated food assistance for nearly two million people.

title: Profits Without Production
description: One lesson from recent economic troubles has been the usefulness of history. Just as the crisis was unfolding, the Harvard economists Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff  who unfortunately became famous for their worst work  published a brilliant book with the sarcastic title This Time Is Different. Their point, of course, was that there is a strong family resemblance among crises. Indeed, historical parallels  not just to the 1930s, but to Japan in the 1990s, Britain in the 1920s, and more  have been vital guides to the present.

title: Of Songs, Stories and WikiLeaks
description: Two kinds of drone figured in The Language of the Future, Laurie Andersons two-part, two-night performance for the River to River Festival on Tuesday and Wednesday: Stories on Tuesday and Songs on Wednesday (though stories and songs were included on both nights). There were the minimalist musical drones  often double-stops bowed on her electric violin  that have been part of her songs since she emerged in the 1980s. And this week, topically, there were airborne drones: a pair of remote-controlled aircraft, like flying black spiders the diameter of a Frisbee, that darted over the audience during part of Songs on Wednesday.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 10:30 P.M. (Cooking) TRIPPING OUT WITH ALIE & GEORGIA Alie Ward and Georgia Hardstark, the Cooking Channels Classy Ladies, embark for points of debauchery  first stop, Las Vegas, fueled by absinthe  in their latest foray into cocktail wizardry. Theyre inventive, yes, as they recreate drinks and nibbles for post-travel parties back home. But nothing can top the McNuggetini, the potion that made them famous: vanilla vodka shaken with a chocolate milkshake, poured into a martini glass rimmed with barbecue sauce and adorned with a Chicken McNugget. Or, dinner, dessert and booze in one chalice of multitasking, Ms. Ward, above left, with Ms. Hardstark, proclaims in the video that led to their stint as go-to gals for frothy drinks packing a punch. Were kind of like dudes in dresses, Ms. Ward said recently in an interview. We wear vintage, because you can get away with a lot more when you look like Grandma.
