description: PARIS  Searching for court time in Paris? You might be able to book one atop a train station, an Aston Martin dealership (with a view of the Eiffel Tower), a chapel, a fire station, a parking garage a stones throw from the Pantheon or even a supermarket. There are also courts on the ground floor if youre afraid of heights. Paris is a compact city. It can be crisscrossed on bike in under an hour. City planners have had to be creative to squeeze courts into the citys confines. As a result, there are a host of unique courts packed into the most unusual spaces. Heres a look at some of the most memorable.

title: The One-Handed Backhands Vanishing Act
description: With another Wimbledon fast approaching, lets first settle the issue of extinction by reassuring tennis connoisseurs everywhere that there will always be one-handed backhands  one-handed slice backhands.

title: Finding Focus in Coffee Shop Chatter
description: Mike Mason speaks with Anahad OConnor about a new Web site that offers coffee shop noise to help make workers more efficient.

title: Wimbledon Draw: Nadal and Federer Land in Same Quarter
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The biggest news out of the draw ceremony for this years Wimbledon came when the fifth chip was pulled and the No. 5 seed, Rafael Nadal, landed in the same quarter as No. 3 Roger Federer, the defending champion, and in the same bottom half as No. 2 Andy Murray, who has No. 6 Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in his quarter.

title: Mediobanca to Sell Stakes
description: LONDON  Mediobanca announced plans on Friday to sell stakes in a number of Italian companies for a combined 1.5 billion euros, or $2 billion, as the financial giant looks to untangle itself from the countrys struggling corporate sector.

title: Bookshop Memories in a Changing India
description: In the summer of 1984, two years before I was born, my father, Ajit Vikram Singh opened a small corner bookshop, Fact & Fiction, in South Delhis Vasant Vihar area, opposite a decrepit cinema hall that would screen films like The Sex Life of Animals to a packed audience. Nearly 30 years later, its disheartening to see him disillusioned with the Indian book industry.

title: LeBrons Odds of Catching Jordan
description: On Thursday, after LeBron James and the Miami Heat won their second consecutive N.B.A. championship, I noted on Twitter that James was on the same pace as the Chicago Bulls great Michael Jordan. Both James and Jordan won their first championship at 27 and their second at 28, I wrote. Jordan went on to win four more N.B.A. titles, for a total of six.

title: Michael Dell Defends His Leveraged Buyout Offer
description: Michael S. Dell on Friday defended his $24.4 billion bid to buy control of Dell Inc., arguing that an alternative proposal by Carl C. Icahn would severely weaken the computer company.

title: Music Video Premiere | The Latest from the Saxophonist Colin Stetson, Featuring Justin Vernon of Bon Iver
description: The saxophonist Colin Stetson loved a series of abstract, visually rich videos created by the videographers Isaac Gale and David Jensen in 2011 for the indie rock band Bon Iver, with whom Mr. Stetson has recorded and toured. So when it came time to make a video for Who the Waves Are Roaring For  a haunting track from his latest solo album, New History Warfare Vol. 3: To See More Light, that features plaintive, distorted vocals from Bon Ivers Justin Vernon  he got in touch with the duo.

title: Chinas Credit Squeeze Relaxes as Interest Rates Drop
description: BEIJING  Chinas credit squeeze eased Friday after lending resumed among banks and financial institutions that had been desperately seeking cash through the week in the interbank market.

title: F.A.A. to Consider Relaxed Rules for Devices on Planes
description: 7:56 p.m. | Updated A working group assigned by the Federal Aviation Administration to research the use of electronics on airplanes is expected to recommend relaxing the ban on portable devices during takeoff and landing.

title: Taliban Consider Canceling Talks With U.S. and Afghanistan
description: DOHA, Qatar  Taliban leaders were debating on Friday whether to cancel peace talks with the Americans and the Afghan government because of criticism of their use of their flag and formal name at their new office here.

title: What Were Reading
description: Hawk Wakawaka Wine Reviews: Lives in wine: a visit with Stu and Charles Smith of Smith-Madrone, Napa Valley mountain men who make great wines.  Eric Asimov

title: Britain Releases the Last of Its X-Files
description: LONDON  Britains front-line defense against alien invasion from outer space has fallen victim to spending cuts, according to documents released on Friday.

title: Series Was an Exclamation Point for James and for Stern
description: MIAMI  If there was one thing we knew about a thrilling N.B.A. finals that carried David Stern on its shoulders to the finish line of his three-decade playoff run as commissioner and chief baby sitter, it was that the series and the season would not conclude with Jeff Van Gundy signing off the network telecast by suggesting the Miami Heat consider trading LeBron James for Dwight Howard.

title: Putin Puts Pensions at Risk in $43 Billion Bid to Jolt Economy
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  Faced with meager growth worldwide and a worrisome ebbing of Russias own oil and gas revenues, President Vladimir V. Putin announced an ambitious and risky economic stimulus program on Friday along with a novel amnesty plan for imprisoned white-collar criminals that was intended to improve investor confidence.

title: Morgan Stanley Cleared to Buy Rest of Wealth Management Business
description: Morgan Stanley plans this month to buy the remaining stake in the wealth management joint venture it formed with Citigroup in the depths of the financial crisis.

title: Live, From the House of Souvlaki ...
description: Gilda Radner, John Belushi, Bill Murray and other S.N.L. cast members hanging out in Times Square in the 1970s.

title: The 6.9.13 Issue
Buddy Cianci Enjoys Life Without the Squirrel
description: Your terms as mayor of Providence, R.I., have been called Buddy I [1975-1984] and Buddy II [1991-2002]. There has been a lot of talk lately that you are going to run again in 2014, for Buddy III.  I enjoyed being mayor, but talk radio and television give me a lot of exposure, and I can do things on my own terms. People once in a while will say: We need you back. Will you run again? My usual answer is, Why would you wish that on me?

title: My Kids Are Obsessed With Technology, and Its All My Fault
description: A few months ago, I attended my daughter Josies kindergarten open house, the highlight of which was a video slide show featuring our moppets using iPads to practice their penmanship. Parental cooing ensued.

title: My Manhattan Fantasies Realized. Sort Of.
description: A night that involved two Manhattan fantasies began with my wife and me and time to kill in the West Village. Last December we stopped into a bar to get a drink before meeting friends for dinner. The place was one of those meticulously set-designed mirages meant to evoke a speakeasy, lighted by softly glowing Art Deco fixtures. The drinks had names like Mata Hari and required muddled juniper berries.

title: Horticulture Heist
description: My wife and I love plants. While walking through our local shopping center, we noticed a particular plant that we both liked and decided to get it for our patio. We visited two local garden centers; neither had the plant. My wife thought she could grow it from cuttings, so we went back and took about three or four cuttings from one of the many plants that were scattered around the shopping center. The plant was not hurt or damaged in any manner or form, but my gut instinct told me that this was wrong. Was it? JULIAN SOLOMONS, HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF.

title: Max Brooks Is Not Kidding About the Zombie Apocalypse
description: Ive never seen a zombie movie where someone drank from a puddle and died of explosive diarrhea.

title: Who Made That T-Shirt Cannon?
description: It weighed 90 pounds, including the tanks, says Tim Derk of the T-shirt cannon he helped invent when he worked as the Coyote mascot for the San Antonio Spurs in the 1990s. It was like carrying a TV set on your back. The gun was probably at least four feet long. It used a cast-iron pipe  the kind that goes into the floor underneath your commode. It just weighed a ton. Of course, someone else might have tried the stunt before Derk, but when he dressed up as Rambote  Rambo meets the Spurs Coyote  and sprayed the cheap seats with freebies, few sports fans had seen anything like it.

title: Autopsy on Gandolfini Finds Actor Died of Natural Causes, Family Spokesman Says
description: 11:14 a.m. | Updated

title: Portrait of the Musician as a Young Reader
description: The drummer Ahmir Thompson, better known as Questlove, a co-founder of the Roots, has written many times about the formative music in his life. Now that hes an author  of the recently published memoir Mo Meta Blues  I was curious about what reading material shaped his childhood.

title: Pride and Perseverance
description: Out to lunch with a friend one day in 1969, the British novelist Barbara Pym was doing what she always did  gathering details of the life around her as if they were jewels dropped in her path by a generous deity. Why arent more of these elderly ladies wearing canvas shoes? she scribbled in her ever-present notebook. In the restaurant all those clergymen helping themselves from the cold table, it seems endlessly. Then she stopped abruptly. But you mustnt notice things like that if youre going to be a novelist in 1968-9 and the 70s, she scolded herself. The posters on Oxford Circus Station advertising Confidential Pregnancy Tests would be more suitable.

title: Editors Choice
description: WHAT DO WOMEN WANT?: Adventures in the Science of Female Desire,  by Daniel Bergner. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.99.) When it comes to the study of womens sexuality, Bergner writes, there are fewer established facts than you would think.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE ART FORGER,  by B. A. Shapiro. (Algonquin, $14.95.) In 1990, 13 works of art were looted from a Boston museum, including a Rembrandt, a Vermeer and several sketches by Degas. Shapiros nimble mystery revisits this brazen theft: more than two decades on, a stolen Degas painting seems to resurface and Claire Roth, a talented yet struggling artist, is lured into reproducing the long-missing masterpiece.

title: Inside the List
description: PRIMATOLOGY: Readers of Carl Hiaasens new Florida mystery, Bad Monkey  it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3  wont be surprised to learn that there is, in fact, a bad monkey in its pages: Driggs, an animal performer who works on Johnny Depps pirate movies until hes caught masturbating on wigs in the costume trailer. My vision of the monkey was of a show business monkey that just crashed and burned, Hiaasen said on NPR recently. Sort of a Lindsay Lohan of monkeys. He added that he was struck by pop cultures recent turn toward the simian: In every movie it seems you go to now, and TV sitcoms and everywhere you look, theres sort of a gratuitous monkey, he said. I wanted a monkey with a back story.

title: Charged Images
description: When a supposed friend and collector tells the painter-art star Eric Fischl: Youve got to face it, man. You didnt make the cut  meaning that after rocketing to the top in the art boom of the 1980s, his prices arent holding in the 90s, hes no longer one of the artists who matter  I felt sucker-punched myself. Fischl says the collector was just being matter-of-fact, but really? One of the many reasons to read Bad Boy (written with Michael Stone) is how vividly it recreates the precariousness and ambivalences of life in the upper tiers of the international art world. But the collectors jab also alerts us that its a rise-and-fall story weve been reading, not just a jolly succession of triumphs.

title: Legend Retold
description: Even in its fragmentary and unfinished form  about 40 pages of text, a bit more than four cantos of what was evidently intended to be a much longer narrative poem  The Fall of Arthur is recognizably the work of J. R. R. Tolkien, veteran of the Great War and future author of The Lord of the Rings. This is an incomplete but highly compelling retelling of perhaps the most famous and familiar legend in the British tradition, a retelling the authors son and literary executor, Christopher Tolkien, believes was begun in the early 1930s and abandoned by 1937. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year The Hobbit was published, offering readers their first glimpse of a fantasy universe that would shape the imaginative life of the 20th century and beyond.

title: Just Around the Corner
description: Before reading this rich, sensory novel, my literary familiarity with Sri Lanka came mostly from Michael Ondaatjes rollicking memoir, Running in the Family. But it was enough of an introduction, with all its extravagant, hilarious dysfunctions, to pique my interest in the island nation. Ru Freemans assured second novel is a much quieter yet rewarding portrait of a community of families on a dead-end road in Colombo, the countrys capital. They are a mixed lot on Sal Mal Lane: Sinhalese, Tamils and Burghers, descendants of European colonizers. Down this road live the comfortably middle class and the dirt poor; the sick, the heartbroken and viciously prejudiced; youngsters vivacious with talent, or misshapen by abuse; and a few residents in their middle and later years who are roused by the arrival of the Heraths, a family with four lively children.

title: The Beloved Country
description: In 1992, when the mujahedeen arrived in Kabul, young Qais Akbar Omar expected to see heroes in uniforms and shiny boots. Instead, the Holy Warriors had beards, mustaches and smelly shoes that wrapped up stinky feet. Omars father and grandfather were hopeful, but the liberation was short-lived. Soon, fighting broke out across the city. It was like when a forest catches fire, Omar writes; both the dry and the wet burn. The family retreated to their basement before the onslaught of rockets and snipers forced them to abandon their home altogether. Piling into their Volga, Omar and his mother, father, three sisters, baby brother, two aunts and seven cousins set out for safer ground.

title: Natural Lawyer
description: Most of us live our partisan politics through the media, which generally means cross-firing tweets, posts and cable news shows about the latest scandal as interpreted by a rotating stable of Washington strategists, party faithfuls and pundits. But behind the klieg lights, there has always been a less topical, more abstract debate between liberal and conservative academics and philosophers about the nature of human flourishing and the political and social institutions that best promote it.

title: Bless the Borrowers
description: Robert Kuttners title refers, first, to the medieval institution that was the fate of improvident souls in England who could not repay their debts, including Daniel Defoe. In 1692, Defoe was committed to Kings Bench Prison in London, where he began to agitate for a change in the legal system. Forcing debtors to rot, Defoe not disinterestedly pointed out, was injurious to both parties, since after a debtor was confined in prison both he and the creditor lost through his prolonged distress. Society responded, eventually, with bankruptcy laws, but it is very much Kuttners point in Debtors Prison that we  America and Europe in the age of the financial crisis  have yet to absorb the principal lesson of Defoes bitter experience.

title: When Two Paths Meet
description: Deploying flatulence as a plot device takes nerve. Chaucer got away with it in The Millers Tale, thanks to the bawdy, rowdy nature of the story. In her ambitious new novel, Questions of Travel, the Sri Lankan-Australian novelist Michelle de Kretser gets away with it too, when her main characters, Ravi and Laura, finally have an encounter that seems like a prelude to some greater connection  or at least a reckoning or revelation. But the moment passes with Ravis gas. This willful non-event is the culmination of de Kretsers cool play with conventional reader expectations about how much, and how meaningfully, two disparate lives should matter to each other when they finally converge after pages and pages of parallel-track narratives.

title: Do as I Say
description: At first glance, it would seem that Wendy Moore, a lively English journalist and social historian, has written an account of Victor Frankensteins reluctant endeavors to present his monster with the wife the lonely creature so desperately craves. Not so. Moores extraordinary subject is the compellingly repellent historical figure Thomas Day, a childrens book writer and ardent abolitionist.

title: Illiberal Arts
description: More than a century ago, the president of Harvard, A. Lawrence Lowell, issued a warning to Americas colleges and universities. Institutions, he said, are rarely murdered. They meet their end by suicide. . . . They die because they have outlived their usefulness, or fail to do the work that the world wants done. Most of the institutions he had in mind are still around today, but the doomsday talk is back. William J. Bennett, secretary of education under President Reagan, and Jeffrey Selingo, an editor at The Chronicle of Higher Education, believe our system is self-destructing. Their tones are different  Bennett and his co-author, David Wilezol, write in an expectant mood of good riddance, while Selingo is sympathetically alarmed  but their views are grimly consistent. College costs are up. Learning and graduation rates are down.

title: Natural Born Killers
description: The Italian criminologist Cesare Lombroso makes for an unlikely hero. In the late 1800s, Lombroso proposed that criminals were evolutionary throwbacks who could be identified by primitive features like sloping foreheads and large jaws, and he went on to posit an evolutionary hierarchy of the races, with northern Italians at its apex. Such ideas inspired Mussolinis racial laws in the 1930s, and are at the core of some of the ugliest social movements of our time.

title: Inside Story
description: Why would you read a six-volume, 3,600-page Norwegian novel about a man writing a six-volume, 3,600-page Norwegian novel? The short answer is that it is breathtakingly good, and so you cannot stop yourself, and would not want to.

title: Annus Mirabilis
description: If Christian Caryl had set out to write a book about 1968, showing how the many convulsions and uprisings of that astonishing year were connected, his task would have been an easy one. It might be difficult to prove cause and effect between, say, the May events in Paris and the chaos at the Democratic convention in August, but as people might have said at the time, something was in the air. It wasnt mere coincidence that led to youth revolts all over the world. In the case of 1989, such connections are even more obvious.

title: How Crowdfunding Worked for One Timely Start-Up
description: Last fall, I wrote a post about the crowdfunding campaign of a start-up known as braGGs. The company, based in Alexandria, Va., has developed a patent-pending bra for women who have had reconstructive breast surgery  reconstructed bras for reconstructed girls, as the Web site puts it.

title: What I Love | Rick Elice and Roger Rees
description: The couple share a duplex in Emery Roths storied masterwork the Beresford, on Central Park West.

title: Upstairs at the Beresford
description: When the actor Roger Rees and the playwright Rick Elice became a couple in 1982, work kept them in separate cities: first London, then Los Angeles for Mr. Rees, New York for Mr. Elice. Jet lag was chronic, the frequent-flier miles many.

title: Farm Bills Fate in House Bodes Ill for Immigration Reform
description: WASHINGTON  The story of the 113th Congress was on display during a single afternoon this week.

title: Despair
description: A clip from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs new song, "Despair," which was shot on the observation deck of the Empire State Building.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The State of Higher Education
description: This week, Andrew Delbanco discusses two new books about the state of higher education; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Andrew OHehir talks about The Fall of Arthur, by J. R. R. Tolkien; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: The Fork Less Taken
description: The North Fork of Long Island is designed by nature for exquisite sunsets and private contemplation.

title: On the North Fork, the Un-Hamptons
description: Around 75 miles east of New York City, just past the Rip van Winkle revival unfolding in somnolent Riverhead, the Long Island Expressway ends in a blaze of commercial glory at the Tanger Outlets. Soon after that, Long Island succumbs to a severe case of geological split personality and sprouts an intriguing pair of sibling peninsulas. Naturally theres a bit of a rivalry.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The State of Higher Education
description: This week, Andrew Delbanco, Julie Bosman, Andrew OHehir and Gregory Cowles.

title: One Coalition Partner Quits Greek Government
description: ATHENS  Greeces fragile three-way coalition was dealt a serious blow on Friday, the anniversary of its creation, when its smallest party withdrew to protest Prime Minister Antonis Samarass shutdown of the state broadcaster, the latest in a series of unilateral decisions that have enraged his partners in government.

title: Summer Shows Its Stripes, Woven in Orange, Green and Brown
description: As the pasty hordes descend on Jones Beach on Long Island for the first weekend of summer, rentals of umbrellas, striped in the traditional orange, green and brown, will suddenly shoot into high demand. For the park, the umbrellas are a modest side business, in place since its Jazz Age opening. For beachgoers, they are a $10 concession to worried mothers and lecturing dermatologists, a bright buffer from the blazing summer sun.

title: Book Review Podcast: Grading Higher Education
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Delbanco reviews two new books about the state of higher education in the United States. Mr. Delbanco writes:

title: Reasons to Get a Flu Shot
description: The flu vaccine is far from 100 percent effective, but researchers have calculated that over the past six years it has prevented millions of illnesses and tens of thousands of hospitalizations.

title: The Idea of Bonnaroo
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss this years Bonnaroo music festival.

title: The Farmers Market: Strawberries
description: Strawberries are now in abundance at the farmers market. Here are ideas for ways to use them beyond rinsing and popping directly in your mouth (nothing wrong with that).

title: Remembering James Gandolfini, Remembering Staten Island
description: The first thing I did after hearing the news of the death of James Gandolfini, who died suddenly Wednesday in Italy at age 51, was eat a bowl of shredded wheat. Then I spent 30 minutes on the treadmill. While I was on the treadmill, I thought about Anthony Salvio.

title: Working to Revive a Movie House That Lived in a Palace
The Gun Report: June 21, 2013
description: So, Heidi, began the email to Heidi Yewman from Michele Kort, her editor at Ms. Magazine. I wanted to let you know that, in the comments to the gun-nut post below, someone put your address out there. Ive been super careful NOT to approve any comments that mentioned where you might live.

title: S.E.C. Has a Message for Firms Not Used to Admitting Guilt
description: The days of cop-out settlements in big securities cases may be waning.

title: In Harlem, Looking for Something Not Hotel-Like
description: As a singer and actress, Esther Joy Stilwell lived out of a suitcase for six years. After her graduation from the University of Oklahoma, she performed throughout the world, touring in Cats and Monty Pythons Spamalot.

title: Happy to Be a Puppet
description: Is being an artist a gift or a curse? That question is at the heart of A Dancers Dream, a sinister and whimsical reimagining of two Stravinsky works, The Fairys Kiss and Petrushka, in which a young woman is blessed (or is it burdened?) by the realization that she is a ballerina.

title: Animated Family Fun in Macao
description: If you see Shrek wandering a resort in Macao, dont be surprised. The Las Vegas of Asia, as its often called, is poised to expand its appeal beyond serious gamblers to families with the July opening of the new DreamWorks Experience at Cotai Strip Resorts.

title: Learning to Spot Frailty
description: Doctors should screen all adults over age 70 for frailty, a medical syndrome that affects 5 percent to 10 percent of people in this age group, according to a new consensus statement from six international medical organizations.

title: After Adversity, a Passion Unchecked
description: Asked by a student about her musical inspirations after a recent Baroque master class at Juilliard, the violinist Rachel Barton Pine gestured toward the stickers of heavy metal bands plastered on her violin case. When theyre onstage, theyre getting everyone headbanging, she said. Within classical music my goal is to do the same thing, to give 150 percent and get everyone caught up in the emotions.

title: Sprint May Be Off the Table, but Dishs Deal Appetite May Remain
description: Charles W. Ergen is regarded as one of the wiliest negotiators in the business world. But in a little over a week, Mr. Ergen, chairman of the Dish Network, has been dealt two tough hands, one at Sprint Nextel and the other at Clearwire.

title: He Likes His Horror Personal and Global
description: LOVELL, Maine  Rosies General Store serves breakfast all day, and its the type of place where residents of this town of 1,140 will stop in to buy lottery tickets, a loaf of bread or the special jumbo lobster roll. Its also the inspiration for the Sweetbriar Rose, a diner in Stephen Kings 2009 opus about a small town cut off from the outside world by a mysterious and impenetrable dome.

title: European Ministers Agree to Stricter Tobacco Laws
description: LONDON  Cigarette packs in Europe would have to carry bigger health warnings, and cigarettes with menthol or other flavorings face a total ban, under an agreement that European Union ministers struck on Friday after spirited negotiations.

title: Video: Yeah Yeah Yeahs Perform Atop Empire State Building
description: In its 82-year history, the top of the Empire State Building has been the site of countless family outings, marriage proposals and, of course, one very memorable date gone awry. But as near as we can tell, it had never been the site of an indie rock performance, not a preapproved one anyway.

title: Beyond Tony Soprano
description: James Gandolfinis memorable movie performances suggested a great film career in the making.

title: Touring, the Wyoming Way
description: BOISE, Idaho  The pounding on his cargo-van doors started as soon as Jalan Crosslands head hit the pillow. After a thousand miles of rough road and his fifth straight night onstage, the bone-tired banjo man had kicked off his boots and collapsed on the mattress in his old Dodge 3500 outside Pengillys, the saloon here where he and his fellow musicians had jammed well into the early morning.

title: Just Another Career Criminal Writer
description: LOS ANGELES  On a set so authentically dressed to resemble a boxing gym that you could almost smell the mildewed towels, a man on the floor was howling in pain as two burly-looking goons dragged him by the ankles. Anyone familiar with the work of Ann Biderman, the creator of the series being shot, Ray Donovan, would instantly recognize that the scene incorporated three of her favorite subjects: violence, Los Angeles and thugs.

title: Not Too Young for the Blues
description: If you ask Buddy Guy who embodies the future of blues guitar, he will point to a 14-year-old boy from Massachusetts named Quinn Sullivan. Remember that name, Mr. Guy said in a recent interview. He sounds like Eric Clapton, B. B. King, me, Hendrix, everybody, man!

title: Mediobancas Stake Sales Are a Hopeful Sign for Italy
description: There are many reasons to worry about Italys prospects, but Mediobanca is no longer one.

title: Movie Review: Monsters University
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Monsters University."

title: Summer Bean Salads
description: Bean salads are a great choice for summer picnics, and most recipes can easily be adapted to accommodate any vegans in the crowd. This week the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman turns to summer bean salads:

title: Food Network Drops Paula Deen
description: Paula Deen, the self-proclaimed queen of Southern cooking and a sugary mainstay of the Food Network, was dropped by the network on Friday, after a bewildering day in which she failed to show up for an interview on the Today show and then in two online videos begged her family and audience to forgive her for using racist language.

title: For Episcopal Churchs Leader, a Sermon Leads to More Dissent
description: Curaao, the Dutch island off the Venezuelan coast, is nice this time of year. Actually, its nice any time of year. The temperature is in the low 80s and the seawater is nearly as warm. It must be a nice place to give a sermon. But for Katharine Jefferts Schori, since 2006 the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, memories of Curaao will always be associated with the controversy that greeted her upon her return  another controversy in what has already been a rocky tenure as the head of a troubled, shrinking church.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Gettysburg, Pa; Quebec
description: Gettysburg 150th, Pennsylvania The Gettysburg 150th anniversary commemoration will observe the Battle of Gettysburg for 10 days from June 28 through July 7 in Gettysburg, Pa. Some 400 events focused on the Civil War are on the schedule: battle re-enactments featuring horse-drawn cannons and cavalrymen on horseback, soldier encampments, living history programs and special tours and exhibitions, including the opening of the Seminary Ridge Museum. Visitors can walk in the footsteps of Confederate soldiers in the mile-long Picketts Charge Commemorative March, led by National Park rangers representing each of the assaulting brigades. Gettysburg College is showing a 15-minute film about the Gettysburg Address throughout the summer, and offering Witness to History, a historical walking tour app of the college and town, both free.

title: A Lifetime of Changes, From Roommate to Spouse
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Selling Park Avenue Condos at $250,000 a Minute
description: Harry B. Macklowe flew an Emmy-award-winning film crew to southern England, hired the famed tightrope walker Philippe Petit and bought the song rights to a Mama Cass classic, all for a four-minute movie to market his latest condominium development.

title: A 1930 Theaters Beauty Survives
description: A nonprofit group that recently held a film premiere at the United Palace in Washington Heights hopes to turn it into a place for special movie events.

title: Suzuki Faces Possible Air Bag Recall, Complicated by Bankruptcy
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether air bag problems warrant recalling about 205,000 Suzuki vehicles, the 2006-11 Grand Vitara and the 2007-11 SX4, according to a report posted on the safety agencys Web site.

title: The Art of the Chosen People
description: Like New York, the art world has a lot of Jewish people. The sole curatorial theme of Jew York, a sweeping joint exhibition at the Zach Feuer Gallery in Chelsea and Untitled on the Lower East Side, is works by the chosen people, but it has no specific agenda beyond that. I just wanted to put everyone in the room together and see what happens, Feuer explained, and not make some grand academic statement about Judaism. Feuer and Carol Cohen and Joel Mesler of Untitled (all members of the tribe) approached the exhibition in a hands-off way that defied stereotypes about both art-world types and the Jewish people. They simply asked artists to submit whatever work they wished. Of the 100 they approached to participate, only four or five didnt want to be outed. (All happened to be of a certain generation that came to prominence during the 1980s.) Several others responded with the news that they were not, in fact, Jewish.

title: Irelands Turnaround May Not Be So Rosy
description: TWO years ago, even as other troubled European economies continued to deteriorate, some economic statistics seemed to indicate that Irelands troubled economy had turned the corner and was growing again.

title: Video: Slow-Moving Burglar Carries a Cane
description: The plastic brace on the mans right foot is trailing straps, and there is a cane in his hand. He takes little steps, and his hip rolls each time he sets down his right foot. There is nothing furtive about the man, whose image was captured by a surveillance camera for a few seconds as he hobbled down a sunlit street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, one morning last month. So why are the police looking for him?

title: This Weeks Movies: World War Z, Monsters University and A Hijacking
description: In this weeks video, Times critics offer their thoughts on World War Z, Monsters University and A Hijacking. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Action on Expanded Gambling as Albanys Legislative Session Sputters to End
description: ALBANY  Lawmakers agreed on Friday night to ask voters to authorize expanded casino gambling across New York State, but planned to end their annual legislative session without approving new measures to combat corruption in the capital.

title: Week in Pictures for June 21.
description: Pictures include a canine graduation at Grand Central Terminal, Sal Albanese in Queens, and workers atop St. Patricks Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Cecil Taylor Wins the Kyoto Prize
description: The improvising pianist Cecil Taylor, a pioneering, influential and highly experimental musician and a longtime Brooklyn resident, is one of this years recipients of the Kyoto Prize, awarded each year by the Inamori Foundation in Japan, the foundation announced on Friday. Mr. Taylor, 84, is this years laureate in the category of arts and philosophy; different fields across technology, science, art and philosophy are considered on a rotating basis, and there has been a recipient in music every four years. (The last musician laureate in 2009 was the conductor and composer Pierre Boulez.) The prize comes with a cash gift of 50 million yen (approximately $510,000), to be given at a ceremony in Kyoto in November. This years other laureates are the electronics engineer Dr. Robert H. Dennard and the evolutionary biologist Dr. Masatoshi Nei.

title: The Sweet Spot: Cinematic Kryptonite
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie thats not very super.

title: Disappointing Fall for Rock Center, a News Program With Big Ambitions
description: If Rock Center With Brian Williams has proved anything in the last year and a half, it is this: However hard it is to gather an audience for any kind of show in prime time, for news programming, the task is even harder.

title: S.E.C. to Require Admissions of Guilt
description: In some settlement cases, the Securities and Exchange Commission will now demand that defendants go beyond the current neither admit nor deny standard.

title: In Europe, a Few Coins for a Wealth of Culture
description: I figured I might someday take an amibitious cultural jaunt through Europe, catching a classical concert at La Monnaie in Brussels, a musical off Las Ramblas in Barcelona, and cutting-edge dance performances in Berlin  all from the best seats in the house. I just imagined it would have wait until I retired as the Frugal Traveler columnist and retrained as, say, a plastic surgeon to the stars.

title: A Rinse and a Roll on a River in Nepal
description: I will admit that after 25 days of third world travel with my future in-laws, my motives for going off to paddle some difficult white water last year were complex. Yes, Ive been a kayaker for a decade, and the Bhote Koshi River, which pours down the Tibetan Himalayas into Nepal  rated Class V during high water, but in winter a classic Class III, according to one outfitter  appeared to be within my abilities.

title: North Korean Diplomat Blames United States for Tensions but Calls for Peace Talks
description: In a mix of diplomacy and bombast, North Koreas ambassador to the United Nations called Friday for the United States to accept its recently revived proposal for direct peace talks, even as he blamed the Americans for all tensions on the Korean Peninsula starting with the war more than 60 years ago.

title: Home-Cooked Challenge: Kids in the Kitchen
description: The Home-Cooked Challenge isnt about what were subtracting from our kitchen  or at least, it shouldnt be. Its about what were adding. Ive been focused on whats not here (snacks and other processed and prepackaged foods) mostly because we turn to those easy alternatives so readily. Unless I took the snack foods out, I knew from experience that wed keep turning to them.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Ramen, takoyaki (fried octopus) and sushi: those are only some of the foods that will be served during Mitsuwas Japanese Gourmet Fair through Sunday. The megamarket, located in Edgewater, N.J., will bring together local vendors and some from Japan who will feature more than 100 products.

title: Image of the Day: June 21
Oracle and Salesforce: a Data-Sharing Deal
description: Some of the best trash-talking in tech may be over. The Oracle Corporation and Salesforce.com, two of the more contentious competitors in software, are about to announce a close alliance involving software delivered via cloud computing.

title: Catching Grief and Little Else, Goalie Moves On
description: CHICAGO  Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford faced a crush of news media at his locker Friday afternoon. He spoke in French to reporters from his native Montreal, and then in English. The topic, no matter the language, was the same: his glove.

title: Theres a Fly in My Tweets
description: ROCHESTER  MANY important public health questions are difficult and costly to answer. What kind of risks do highly localized sources of pollution, like dry cleaners that use volatile chemicals, pose to the health of nearby residents? Are people with many friends healthier, or do those friendships increase the likelihood of infectious disease? Do frequent visits to public spaces like bars, gyms and restaurants affect a persons health?

title: Flooding Inundates Part of Canadian Province
description: Heavy rains have contributed to flooding in parts of the Canadian province of Alberta, where officials said Friday that about 75,000 people have been displaced from their homes. Swollen waterways burst banks, streets were flooded and in at least once instance the wreckage of a house was swept away by raging waters in the Bragg Creek area.

title: Shares in Gogo Slip in Market Debut
description: After a promising debut, shares in Gogo Inc. have hit some turbulence.

title: Top D.J.s to Headline the TomorrowWorld Festival
description: The organizers of one of Europes largest electronic dance festivals plan to stage a three-day concert near Atlanta in September, and have secured a lineup that includes most of the top D.J.s in the world, including Tiesto, Afrojack, David Guetta and Calvin Harris.

title: Appeals Exhausted, Astor Case Ends as Son Is Sent to Jail
description: Anthony D. Marshall, the disgraced 89-year-old son of the Manhattan society doyenne Brooke Astor, finally surrendered on Friday to begin a prison sentence for stealing millions of dollars from his mother during her final years of life, ending a seven-year legal odyssey that came to define his own waning years.

title: Billboard Will Not Count Jay-Zs Sales From Samsung Deal
description: Billboard has decided it will not count in its chart tally a million albums that Jay-Z plans to distribute through Samsung as free downloads to owners of its Galaxy mobile phones.

title: F.A.A. May Relax Restrictions on Electronic Devices on Planes
description: If youre reading this just as the flight attendants are making the shut down your portable electronic devices announcement, take heart. Soon you may not have to speed-read your final words before taking off. The F.A.A. is considering loosening its ban on portable electronic devices during takeoff and landing, Nick Bilton and Jad Mouawad report. Thats right. You and your fellow passengers may be able to keep on texting and e-mailing and shopping and playing video games until youre above the clouds. A decision is expected in September.

title: The Sparks Flew Before They Even Met
description: Lindsay Benner, a professional juggler, honed her talents at Fishermans Wharf in San Francisco after graduating college. As the finale to her street performance there, Ms. Benner would select two men from the audience, climb up and stand on their folded arms, then juggle flaming torches above their heads.

title: The Sweet Spot: Cinematic Kryptonite
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie thats not very super.

title: Kids Love the Darndest Things
description: The students in Cathy Gabels fifth-grade class at Central School in Mamaroneck, N.Y., have become fans of the magazines regular Who Made That? column, which explores the origin stories of everyday objects. Earlier this year, some of the students wrote to Pagan Kennedy, who writes the weekly column, and were encouraged after receiving a thoughtful response. Ever since that day, Gabel wrote to me in an e-mail, they have felt a deep connection to the article, running to see the magazine section when it arrived on Saturday mornings, barely able to wait until Monday morning to discuss it in class. They were thrilled to see an entire issue devoted to their favorite magazine feature, and sent us this photo of them showing their approval. You can also see this photo on the Reply All page in Sundays magazine.

title: Vitoria Rother
description: Vitoria Rother, 17, student.

title: Paula Deen Issues Video Statements
description: 5:42 p.m. | Updated A third video has surfaced in which Ms. Deen apologized to Matt Lauer for missing her appearance on the Today show on Friday.

title: Friday Night Music: Belated Toronto Edition
description: OK, I screwed up: last Friday I was in Toronto, and I gave you a French singer; then I headed for France. I should have saved Zaz for this week, and given you a Toronto band last week. But anyway, heres Toronto-based Austra. Not at all my to my usual taste, but Ive featured them once before  they may be electronic, but I do find some of their songs echoing in my head days after:

title: Silvia Dias
description: Silvia Dias, 31, economist.

title: Love of a Garden Is a Thorn in This Relationship
description: The venerable New York Grand Opera Company recently ended decades of summer performances under the skies in Central Park, citing what its conductor, Vincent La Selva, called the increasing unpredictability of the weather.

title: Tapping Artisanal Beers and Booze at Hotel Bars
description: Hotel restaurants have long poured private label wines. But with the rise of artisan distilling and craft brewing, bespoke selections are now the toast of hotel bars around the world.

title: Secrets, Non-Secrets and Leaks
description: Sometimes you can understand why the government keeps secrets because those secrets could endanger lives or derail military operations, or simply because they might be embarrassing. No one should have been shocked when the Obama administration was outraged at Edward Snowdens leaks of documents describing massive surveillance of Americans by the National Security Agency.

title: As the Baseballs Fly Farther in Japan, the Games Commissioner Is Criticized
description: TOKYO  If the cover-up is often worse than the crime, the Japanese version of that axiom may apply to Ryozo Kato, the commissioner of Nippon Professional Baseball.

title: London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus: Der Freischtz
description: In his last years the eminent conductor Colin Davis, who died in April at 85, had debilitating stretches of poor health. But he was clearly inspired for a concert performance in April 2012 of Webers opera Der Freischtz with the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus and an impressive cast. LSO Live recently released a vibrant recording drawn from two performances at the Barbican in London.

title: Daniel Wohl: Corps Exquis
description: No disrespect to the participants on Corps Exquis (New Amsterdam), the deliciously lovely new album by the French-born New York composer Daniel Wohl, but I cant easily imagine the music on the disc being performed live. In fact, the nine selections on the CD are part of an evening-length, multimedia performance piece, meant to be played by real people in real time. Even so, I have a hard time imagining how these vivid, detailed and engaging compositions might sound in three-dimensional space.

title: Alan Feinberg: Basically Bull
description: In 1613John Bull left England for Flanders, where he soon took up a position as organist at Antwerp Cathedral. If his reputation as a composer and keyboard virtuoso preceded him, so did fame of another kind. The man hath more music than honesty and is as famous for marring of virginity as he is for fingering of organs and virginals, wrote George Abbot, the archbishop of Canterbury. Of all Elizabethan composers, Bull had the most picaresque life, punctuated with fistfights, adultery and, possibly, a stint as a spy. But it is in his astonishingly virtuosic and forward-looking compositions that his roaming curiosity reveals itself fully.

title: Looking Back At California
description: With solo shows by Paul McCarthy, Ken Price and James Turrell on view, New York is having a major California moment, and it expands exponentially with the opening on Sunday of State of Mind: New California Art Circa 1970 at the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Originating at the Orange County Museum of Art in Newport Beach, Calif., this group show focuses on the blossoming of Conceptual art, performance, video and installation work on the West Coast in the 1960s and 1970s as alternative art spaces and artist-run galleries grew in number and university art departments accommodated avant-garde practices.

title: A Reunion For Mourner
description: If you saw Wallace Shawns Designated Mourner the last time it was produced in New York, you are one of a lucky few. Thats because the play, a series of monologues about intellectuals and artists living in an unnamed Western country under a brutal regime, had a production so intimate that it played to an audience of 20. Good news for those who couldnt secure what was one of hottest tickets that last time, in the summer of 2000: The original cast (Mr. Shawn, Deborah Eisenberg, Larry Pine) is reuniting for a revival at the Public Theater.

title: Exile in Paris, The Soundtrack
description: Paris was yesterday. So were the soulful ballads that come out of Dale Turners sax in Round Midnight, Bertrand Taverniers 1986 tribute to black expatriate jazz musicians in 1950s Paris  a melancholy slow jam of a film. Its story of a worshipful young Frenchman (Franois Cluzet), who watches over the alcoholic Dale, could easily be cloying, and sometimes is. But Mr. Tavernier knew what he was doing when he cast the real-life sax man Dexter Gordon as Dale. Tall and elegant, Gordon wanders through the film and Paris like a living, breathing, muttering monument, capturing something ineffable about exile in every distracted glance toward the heavens.

title: Stravinsky, With Puppets
description: In May 2010, during his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert showed what a night at the symphony could be if a conductor thinks big. Working with the director and stage designer Doug Fitch Mr. Gilbert presented an exhilarating production of Ligetis bleakly satirical opera Le Grand Macabre, resourcefully transforming Avery Fisher Hall into an opera house and drawing a dazzling account of this challenging modernist score from the Philharmonic players. The following spring Mr. Gilbert and Mr. Fitch collaborated again on an enchanting production of Janaceks Cunning Little Vixen.

title: The Rise and Fall Of a Tabloid Dream
description: Excluding commercials, Anna Nicole, a made-for-television movie Saturday night at 8 p.m. on Lifetime, is only about 90 minutes long. That seems like a not very generous allotment for the task at hand: telling the story of one of the most eventful, calamitous pop-culture lives of recent years.

title: Moves From Brazil, By Way of France
description: Although visually spectacular, the rambunctiousness of hip-hop dance can make it hard to transfer it from the street or dance club, where it can appear unfettered, to the formality of the stage, where its energy must be contained within bounds. One internationally successful attempt to theatricalize hip-hop is Compagnie Kfig, a French-based troupe of Brazilian dancers thats bringing two productions for an all-male cast to the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Popcast: The Idea of Bonnaroo
description: This week: The 12th Bonnaroo music festival, which wrapped up last Sunday in Manchester, Tenn.

title: Big Ticket | A Floor Full of Light, Sold for $13.5 Million
description: An elegant loft that commands the entire 15th floor of the Franklin Tower, an 18-story luxury condominium at 90 Franklin Street in TriBeCa, sold for $13.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: For a Fee, Seeking Owners of Unclaimed Money
description: NOT long after his mother died in December 2010, John Sinclair said he began receiving calls from a company that claimed it had found money belonging to her, which it would divulge for a fee. Mr. Sinclair, a social worker outside of Cleveland, said he ignored the calls until a few months ago.

title: 2004 Showdown Shaped Reputation of Pick for F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON  If it were not for a now famous scene in a hospital just blocks away from the White House, it is unlikely that James B. Comey would have been standing in the Rose Garden on Friday to be introduced as President Obamas nominee for the director of the F.B.I.

title: Food Matters | A Winning Seafood Spot in Venice
description: It might surprise some people, but seafood isnt represented all that well here, said the chef Greg Daniels about the Los Angeles waterfront community of Venice. Formerly the executive sous chef at the Jean-Georges restaurant Perry St. in Manhattan, Daniels headed west to change that with Salt Air, a new beach bistro that was opened this week by the restaurateur David Reiss and the socialite couple Moise and Carol Ann Emquies on the trendy shopping strip of Abbot Kinney Boulevard.

title: Week in Review: Cracking Down on Consultants
description: Regulator in New York sets tough bank fine. | Regulators are divided regarding consultants. | Consultants may face tighter rein from Albany. | Headhunter for the rich turned on them, says Andrew Ross Sorkin.

title: Umbilical Adventures of Sons and Mother
description: The Silver Cord, a musty 1926 play by Sidney Howard, has little to hold the interest of a modern audience, but the Peccadillo Theater Companys revival of it at the Theater at St. Clements at least gives you a few things to think about during the frequent moments when your attention may wander.

title: Catsimatidiss Theatrical Bond With La Guardia
description: Ask anyone running for mayor of New York City which municipal chieftain they most admire, the answer is bound to be Fiorello H. La Guardia, the diminutive firebrand who brought airports, wisecracks and man-of-the-people populism to City Hall during the Great Depression and World War II.

title: In a Conductors Playlist, Some Daunting Chasms
description: Anyone whos ever compiled a playlist for a radio show, dance floor or iPod knows that the main objective is picking cuts that sound good together. Theres a special joy in hooking up tracks that are intrinsically connected, especially if the glue in the seams doesnt show. The program Alan Gilbert assembled for the concert that the New York Philharmonic presented on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall  the third installment in the Gilberts Playlist series  succeeded on both counts.

title: Joo Renato da Silva
description: Joo Renato da Silva, 47, computer instructor, So Paulo.

title: Quinn Goes to Bat for Theater Troupe Over Parking Fees
description: The play is apparently not the thing to catch the conscience of the New York City Department of Transportation, which has billed the Drilling Company for the parking spaces the theater troupe uses for its free Shakespeare in the Parking Lot performances, and has required the company to purchase automobile liability insurance.

title: William
description: William, 25, computer technician.

title: Sabrina Menedotti
description: Sabrina Menedotti, 22, writer, So Paulo.

title: Madalena Vilar
description: 19, student, So Paulo

title: In Immigration Reform, Republican Support for Citizenship Hinges on Obstacles
description: Two Republican senators reached a deal this week on a plan to strengthen the border security provisions of the immigration overhaul currently working its way through the Senate. Many G.O.P. legislators have said that tough border security measures are needed to garner enough Republican votes to pass a bill that also provides a path to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Indonesia, Singapore and India.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Buying a Tenant-Occupied Condo

title: For CNN, Fame Trumps News on Sunday Nights
description: CNN unveils its Sunday-night makeover this weekend, and if the goal was to look a little bit more like every other cable channel, then mission accomplished.

title: The Calm Before the First Serve
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The reporter sitting next to me said he loved the All England Lawn Tennis Club on days like Friday.

title: Favorite Summer Dishes: One Vote for Porgy
description: Summer has officially hit town. It would be impossible to select the most summery dish in New York City (please feel free to offer your own nominations below), but I believe a strong case could be made for the the Caribbean-style porgy at M Pche.

title: Maurizio Cattelans Shocking Window Displays at the Palais de Tokyo
description: When the Italian polymath Maurizio Cattelan announced his retirement from the art world in 2011 on the eve of a major retrospective at the Guggenheim, few people really believed him, and for good reason. The perennial prankster has continued to produce imagery via Toilet Paper, the salacious biannual he creates with the commercial photographer Pierpaolo Ferrari. Since its inaugural issue in 2010, the magazine has regularly published 2-D works with the same eccentric qualities as Cattelans sculptures. (An anthology was released last year.) Its spreads are scabrous and surreal, cartoonish and sublime: an eyeball staring from a mans mouth, a playing card held between a womans buttocks, a half-eaten bar of soap. Though much of the work will elicit laughter, Cattelan and Ferrari take it very seriously. Toilet Paper images are the realization of everyones most intimate, hidden and unspeakable desires and urges, Cattelan said. What makes a Toilet Paper image is the attempt to say something terrible while staying quiet.

title: Family Tragic in Its Own Way, and Comic in All the Others
description: Aunt June is a special kind of born-again Christian, and not just because she is played by Eve Plumb, who will forever be the put-upon middle daughter of The Brady Bunch. June may pray for her sinful relatives right in front of them (and she considers listening to NPR a sin). She may take courses at Oral Roberts University. But at the end of the day, June relaxes in a designer negligee given her by a male admirer (although her divorce, at least her second, is not final) and enjoys numerous glasses of wine.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Morningside Heights co-op on the top floor of a prewar building; a West Village one-bedroom with a shared garden; and four-bedroom in Brooklyn Heights with two baths.

title: So Paulo Protesters Speak Out
description: Demonstrations against an increase in bus fares in Brazil started in So Paulo. They have since spread through the country and expanded in scope to criticize public services and corruption.

title: Ex-Enron Chiefs Sentence Is Cut by 10 Years, to 14
description: The prison sentence of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron who spearheaded the pervasive fraud that destroyed the energy company, was reduced by 10 years on Friday after a federal judge approved a deal between his lawyers and prosecutors.

title: Brother, Can You Spare My Sanity?
description: Here they are, New York, the ultimate brother-and-sister act, a pair of genetically matched hams who combine the narcissism, fearfulness, shabbiness and splendor of every actor who ever walked the boards. They are also competitive and codependent in a fierce, scary way that is particularly associated with show people and siblings. Just put them on a stage, then step back and watch them burn, possibly to a pile of ashes.

title: Crazy, Wacky and Elegant
description: I had this idea of all the holidays you can think of, but somebody had taken them before me, said the designer Richard Mishaan about his dining room for the first Holiday House Hamptons, a show house with a festival theme opening Sunday. Not to be discouraged, Mr. Mishaan, one of 24 designers outfitting a 7,900-square-foot building in Bridgehampton, N.Y., painted his walls the sublime azure of a glacial lake, added bright blue miniatures of the Venus de Milo and Winged Victory of Samothrace, and declared the room a celebration of the French artist Yves Kleins birthday.

title: Homophobia in the Ring Delivers Fatal Blows
description: ST. LOUIS  Toward the end of Terence Blanchards Champion, which received its premiere this week at the Opera Theater of Saint Louis here, the protagonist, Emile Griffith, relives the terror of being attacked by homophobic thugs. I killed a man and the world forgives me; I love a man and the world wants to kill me, he sings despairingly.

title: Paying Artful Homage
description: Thursday was art appreciation day in fashion. It started with a morning press conference at the Guggenheim Museum, where Dior, with the designer Raf Simons present, announced its sponsorship of the Guggenheim International Gala honoring James Turrell and Christopher Wool.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A Cos Cob contemporary on 1.19 acres bordering the Mianus River and 1920 house in Pelham with additional living quarters above a three-car garage.

title: When Too Much Is Just Right
description: I JUST WENT to this amazing party in Venice, said Barbara Berger as she walked into the lobby of the Four Seasons hotel on Monday morning, lugging a cheap red wheelie to a table in the lobby.

title: Who Needs the Critics? Go Cryptic Instead
description: For all but the most knowledgeable pop-music fans, Jay-Zs three-minute commercial during the N.B.A. finals last Sunday might have been perplexing. The black-and-white spot showed a rumpled Jay-Z working on music in a studio. Its documentary style created the impression the viewer was eavesdropping on a session as the rapper talked with producers in poetic terms about an album. It ended with a cryptic text message on screen, The Next Big Thing Is Here and below it the Web site magnacartaholygrail.com.

title: Cacio e Pepe With Favas and Peas
description: Melissa Clark adds fava beans and fresh peas to a classic Italian dish of pasta with black pepper and cheese.

title: Molly: Pure, but Not So Simple
description: At a party not long ago in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Kaitlin, a 22-year-old senior at Columbia University, was recalling the first time she was offered a drug called Molly, at the elegant Brooklyn home of a cultural figure she admired. She was, like, 50, and she had been written about in the Talk of the Town, said Kaitlin, who was wearing black skinny jeans and a tank top. This woman was very smart and impressive.

title: Set for Changes, Rangers Introduce Vigneault as Coach
description: The Rangers introduced Alain Vigneault as their coach Friday, ushering in a more creative and attack-minded approach to hockey. But the occasion was almost as much about who was not there  primarily John Tortorella, the Rangers previous coach, and Mark Messier, the former Ranger who was passed over for the job.

title: These Beans Look Better Undressed
description: I knew that in Italy they dont necessarily peel their fava beans. But I wasnt prepared for the actuality when I ordered cacio e pepe pasta with favas at a small trattoria in Rome on a recent vacation.

title: Shes Done With Washing It Away
description: Im 57 but look like an old lady. Thats because my hair is gray.

title: From the Middle Ages to the Middle-Aged
description: THERE ARE MANY magical perks in the Harry Potter universe that we might want in our world, but we can be thankful that others stay firmly bound between book covers. Foremost among them: the Dementors, those floating wraiths made of mildew and hate who suck all the youthful life out of you like some malevolent spiritual vacuum cleaner.

title: Bright Spots Amid Low Ratings for Hannibal
description: The ratings for the NBC drama Hannibal, which stars Mads Mikkelsen as the serial killer Hannibal Lecter, have almost been as scary as the character himself.

title: An Advice Book by a 28-Year-Old? Not Quite
description: There was a crucial moment in the life of Kelly Williams Brown when she realized that she had not made the necessary leap into adulthood: she was moving into a new apartment, and her furniture, made of particleboard, disintegrated in the rain.

title: Names (And Campaigns) That Rankle
description: As it reintroduces the Cherokee nameplate, Jeep says it is sensitive to concerns about racial stereotypes. In the past, some automakers were not so cautious.

title: Finding Unclaimed Assets, for a Fee
description: In a just-published Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan examines businesses that charge fees to reunite people with unclaimed assets. States have more than $40 billion in their unclaimed property programs, from paychecks and insurance deposits to stocks and retirement accounts.

title: Tesla Fast-Tracks Battery Swapping While Fighting a Legislative Attack
description: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=shdHVGYQonQ

title: They Didnt Pack Sunscreen, or Anything Else
description: When you hear about Naked and Afraid, the new Discovery reality series that puts a woman and a man in the jungle for 21 days with no food, water or clothes, questions arise. Some have to do with sunscreen, but the two important ones are:

title: Kias Great Pretender
description: From style to features, the 2014 Forte comes across as a pricier midsize car trapped in a slightly smaller body.

title: Daredevils Latest Test: Remaking Japans Democracy
description: TOKYO  AT age 70, Hidetoshi Masunaga still skis, doing so in a manner that would terrify people half his age. He dons a helmet, points his skis straight downhill and barrels along like a one-man rocket in a test of his own courage and physical endurance.

title: Devices Given to Chinese Legal Advocate Had Tracking Spyware, N.Y.U. Says
description: BEIJING  Dissidents inside China have long been accustomed to a lack of privacy in their daily routines. Phone conversations are monitored, e-mails are read and public security agents trail human rights activists when they venture outside their homes.

title: A Pretty Package With a Lot of Toy Surprises Inside
description: Every automotive underdog might take a hint from the Kia Forte: if youre a back-bencher in a house of big names, it cant hurt to make your car pretty.

title: As Hezbollah Fights in Syria, Life Changes in a Lebanese Border Town
description: HERMEL, Lebanon  The procession was small as Hezbollah funerals go, just a few hundred people winding past wind-tossed olive trees through this remote Bekaa Valley village. Still, the mourners honored the fighter killed in Syria with the usual solemn choreography: the coffin draped with a flag, the uniformed Boy Scouts bearing his portrait, the women carrying babies and wreaths of roses.

title: When Cars Assume Ethnic Identities
description: Coming to a showroom near you for 2014: the first sport utility vehicle in its class equipped with a 9-speed automatic transmission. Its also the first to offer a parallel-parking feature. And, in 4-wheel-drive models, the rear axle disconnects automatically, for fuel efficiency.

title: What Difference a Fee Makes
description: A change in plan fees of just 1 percentage point could make a difference of 17 percent, or $15,000, over 20 years in the value of a hypothetical retirement account starting with $25,000.

title: The Baby Name Remix
description: From locations to inanimate objects to names that scream swagger, musicians and their partners are known for extending their creativity to naming their children.

title: Providing Kim Kardashian and Kanye Wests Baby With Direction
description: Maybe they should just call her Kimye. When Kim Kardashian and Kanye West had a baby girl on June 15, the Twittersphere went agog over possible baby names. It starts with a K. It doesnt start with a K. And so on. By Friday morning, when North West was reported by TMZ and others, the name became a trending topic on Twitter worldwide.

title: The Man Who Captured a Times Square That Is No More
description: This weekends Look section features rare photographs of the early Saturday Night Live cast hanging out in New York City in the mid-70s. The pictures are from a larger series taken in Times Square by a photographer named Kenneth Siegel, who died at the age of 44 in 1994.

title: Wrights New York Showroom, Now Just a Memory
description: A small landmark of New York City architectural and automotive history disappeared recently, almost without notice. The theatrical auto showroom designed by Frank Lloyd Wright at 430 Park Avenue, at 56th Street, had displayed a number of European brands over the years, notably Mercedes-Benz from 1957 to 2012.

title: Ford Brings Back the Dial
description: Have the Luddites won, or has common sense prevailed?

title: Summer Inspiration From Vietnam
description: When it comes to fresh Vietnamese-style rolls like this one, which usually contain a few cooked prawns, along with herbs and rice vermicelli, a few questions tend to arise.

title: What Else Could a $30 Billion Border Surge Buy?
description: Yesterday we learned that two Senate Republicans have joined forces to revive the immigration legislation thats wallowing in Congress due to inter-party bickering. Bob Corker of Tennessee and John Hoeven of North Dakota are calling their deal a border surge. As Lawrence Downes wrote on this blog, This obviously calls to mind similar surges in harsh desert regions where the United States is deploying troops and drones.

title: Nieses Injury Is One Step Back for Mets Staff
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets this week seemed to be accelerating faster than ever toward their often-discussed but still-hypothetical future, when a successful club will coalesce around a young pitching staff.

title: Prospect Park Lake, 8:45 A.M.
description: On Thursday, the mallard ducklings hatched. On Friday they went for a walk and soaked in the sun.

title: The Train Line Fixer

Many Egyptians are discontented with Mr. Morsi over his running of the country and the state of the economy, and his opponents are calling for mass protests on the anniversary, June 30, that they hope will drive him from power. Fridays protesters, most of them from the Muslim Brotherhood and other Islamist groups, marched under a banner saying No to Violence and accused the opposition of trying to subvert the democratic process. Egypts intense political polarization and violent language from activists on both sides have raised fears that the anniversary protests will unleash new unrest.

title: Breaking Medicines Color Barrier

Augusta, a freeman born in Norfolk, Va., wrote to President Lincoln requesting to serve as a surgeon to some of the coloured regiments, or as physician to some of the depots of freedmen. The 37-year-old Augusta had attended Trinity Medical College in Toronto; as he explained in his letter, I was compelled to leave my native country, and come to this on account of prejudices against colour, for the purpose of obtaining knowledge of my profession; and having accomplished that object  I am now prepared to practice it, and would like to be in a position where I can be of use to my race.

The nautical theme at this three-week-old tiki-chic hot spot hits you over the head with a coconut. Life preservers, white bamboo walls, palm trees, a wooden captains wheel, the servers red shorts: all accounted for. The people who brought the bar Moby Dicks to the Hamptons last summer have brought the Hamptons to Manhattan this time. The succinct menu features wood-fired rectangular pizzas and other items from the center grill; the fit and fashionable guests pay in advance and receive a numbered buoy to place on their picnic table. Celebrities seem to blend in, and dogs get their own water dishes. Music wafts pleasantly, and the after-work vibe is so jaunty, you might never want to leave.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) TO ROME WITH LOVE (2012) In this tribute to the Italian cinema of the 1950s and 60s by Woody Allen, a retired, and overly psychoanalyzed, music promoter (Mr. Allen) travels with his wife (Judy Davis) to Rome, where their daughter (Alison Pill) has lost her heart to an earnest lawyer devoted to left-wing causes (Flavio Parenti). Meanwhile in this shuffled anthology, a young newlywed loses her way to the Trevi Fountain and into the arms of a movie star while her befuddled husband tries to keep his relatives in the dark, substituting a prostitute (Penlope Cruz, above with Alessandro Tiberi) for her at dinner. An ordinary Roman (Roberto Benigni) is plunged into a swirl of media celebrity. And a fledgling architect (Jesse Eisenberg) finds his relationship with his kind, if bland, girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) blown to smithereens when her neurotic actress friend (Ellen Page) shows up for a visit. Alec Baldwin plays the older architect  a ghost? a specter of the younger mans self?  who witnesses the ordeal. One of the most delightful things about To Rome With Love is how casually it blends the plausible and the surreal, and how unabashedly it revels in pure silliness, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The limitations of To Rome With Love, as frothy as the milk atop a cappuccino, are finally inseparable from its delights. Some of the scenes feel rushed and haphazardly constructed, and the dialogue frequently sounds overwritten and under-rehearsed. But this may just be to say that we are watching late-period Woody Allen. Complaining would be as superfluous  though also, perhaps, as inevitable  as psychoanalysis.

description: Sometime early in the last decade, official Washington discovered Indias strategic value. The emblem of this revelation was the Bush administrations civil-nuclear agreement, unveiled with great fanfare in 2005. The agreement was technically designed to allow peaceful nuclear cooperation with India despite its status then as a nonproliferation pariah, but the real purpose, as one architect of the accord put it, was to forge the strategic partnership based on common values that had eluded both countries for many decades and demonstrate how valuable Washington deemed the U.S.-Indian partnership to be in meeting U.S. grand strategic objectives.It was an act of faith: two big, diverse, sometimes exasperating democracies, the United States and India would surely find a way to do wonderful things together. India would be an ally in global causes, a counterweight to China, a shining example of democratic development.

If such a decline continued, there would be no women getting married by 2043!

title: Syria Scorecard
description: ISTANBUL  IF you look at it from 30,000 feet, what were actually dealing with in the Middle East today are the long-delayed consequences of the end of the Ottoman Empire. When the Ottoman Empire collapsed as a result of its defeat in World War I, the colonial powers Britain and France were right there, for their own interests, to impose their own order on the diverse tribes, sects and religions that make up the Arab East. When the British and French left after World War II, they handed power, in many cases, to monarchs, who, in many cases, gave way to generals, who, in all cases, kept their diverse populations in line with iron fists.

But she had recently dropped out of a nearby private university after two years of study and with nearly $80,000 in student loans. Now she worked at Dunkin Donuts.

The city made this mandatory for such restaurants about five years ago, hoping that informed gluttons might be reformed gluttons: that if we had more knowledge about where our efforts to slim down were going wrong, wed have more power to change them.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (Lifetime) DEVIOUS MAIDS Subtitle this new series, which counts Eva Longoria among its executive producers, Desperate Housekeepers. Five maids bound by their personal struggles navigate the upstairs-downstairs attitudes of their Beverly Hills employers in this take on the telenovela Ellas Son ... la Alegra del Hogar. The story begins as one of their peers, Flora (Paula Garcs), is murdered in the home where she works during one of the years fanciest society events. Marisol, played by Ana Ortiz, works for some troubled newlyweds and tries to learn the truth about Floras death. Dania Ramrez is Rosie, who left her son in Mexico to work as a maid and nanny for a couple of uppity actors. Roselyn Snchez is Carmen, an aspiring singer who would like her pop-star employer to help jump-start her career. And Zoila (Judy Reyes) and her teenage daughter (Edy Ganem, above right with, from left, Ms. Snchez, Ms. Ramrez and Ms. Reyes) are the maids for an emotionally unstable but very wealthy woman. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said that despite amusing touches, the show is relentlessly arch and tongue in cheek in a way that seemed fresh when Desperate Housewives began in 2004, but now is less so. She added: There is more to these hard-working women than their laundry skills  they are called devious for a reason  but the story lines and dialogue may be a bit too cute and contrived to hold viewers interest for long. Its the cast, she said, that commands attention.
