title: In California, Celebrating Gay Marriage With Travel Deals
description: The recent Supreme Court rulings on same-sex marriage will affect a number of aspects of American life, and travel is one of them.

title: Contraceptives Stay Covered in Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Despite strong resistance from religious organizations, the Obama administration said Friday that it was moving ahead with a rule requiring most employers to provide free insurance coverage of contraceptives for women, a decision that has touched off a legal and political battle likely to rage for another year.

title: Three Unsayable Words
description: Brad DeLong finds Allan Meltzer inveighing against quantitative easing, and notes that Meltzers story (in which its all Obamas fault) is completely at odds with data on both investment and interest rates.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Carlotta Manaigo.

title: Bylsma Picked for Olympic Job
description: The choice of Dan Bylsma as coach of the United States mens hockey team at the Sochi Olympics in February  which will be announced on Saturday  comes as no great surprise, despite his lack of international experience. But it is also notable for what it says about John Tortorella, once thought to be the favorite for the job, and how he harmed his chance to coach the American team.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Fall of Galleon
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Frank Partnoy reviews The Billionaires Apprentice, Anita Raghavans detailed look at the spectacular fall of the Galleon Group hedge fund when its founder, Raj Rajaratnam, and Rajat Gupta, the former head of McKinsey & Company, were each convicted of securities fraud. Mr. Partnoy writes:

title: At Sardis, Carrin Is at a Loss on the Theater
description: The campaign trail has taken New York Citys mayoral candidates all kinds of places  the A train, the Harvard Club and a geodesic dome on Rockaway Beach  in their quests for votes.

title: Connecting Crime Scenes Present to Past
description: The Times's Serge F. Kovaleski on how investigators connect the dots between current and old criminal investigations, like the two cases pending against the N.F.L. player Aaron Hernandez.

title: Varied Alliance to Press House on Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Even as they were popping corks on Thursday night after a strong bipartisan vote in the Senate to pass an immigration bill, supporters of the overhaul were laying plans for the far more difficult task of moving something similar through the Republican-controlled House.

title: Weekend Fare
description: La Maison du Chocolat, which has four boutique locations in the city, will offer free tastings of its strawberry and classic chocolate ice cream flavors until 6 p.m. today.

title: Facebook to Shield Ads From Offensive Content
description: Facebook said on Friday that it would remove ads from pages that contain controversial content, as it tries to protect advertisers from appearing next to offensive material beyond their control.

title: Noodles & Co. Proves Irresistible in Tough Week for I.P.O.s
description: 6:32 p.m. | Updated

title: Could Brothers and Sisters Share a Cabin at Camp?
description: Our two kids will attend overnight camp this summer for two weeks. Theyll join their bunkmates and sleep, for the first time in their lives, in separate spaces.

title: Fewer Hospitalizations for C.O.P.D. Patients
description: You dont see supermarket products emblazoned with ribbons to help support research on chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Major corporations dont sponsor walkathons for thousands of cheering supporters.

title: The Sweet Spot: Parks and Trepidation
description: A. O. Scott and David Carr are joined by the architecture critic Michael Kimmelman to talk about public spaces and projects which, at times, can lead to political upheaval ... and even revolution.

title: A Romance in the Style of Byron or Keats
description: He met her, he said, as words on a page.

title: The Sweet Spot: Parks and Trepidation
description: In this weeks episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr are joined by the architecture critic Michael Kimmelman to talk about public spaces and projects which, at times, can lead to political upheaval  and even revolution.

title: To Explain the Fed, Choose a Vice
description: The search for the best metaphor to describe the tapering of the Federal Reserves monthly bond purchases later this year rolled forward on Friday.

title: Big Ticket | Park-Centric Luxury for $17.53 Million
description: Three is a charm for the collaboration of Zeckendorf Development and its go-to architect, Robert A.M. Stern, at 18 Gramercy Park South. As a sequel to the jaw-dropping sales they logged by building the billionaire magnet 15 Central Park West, this smaller-scale but equally park-centric luxury condominium represents their first crack at refurbishing a landmark in a fussy historic district, and their third closing of the month again netted the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. Several more of the 16 homes there are in contract.This time the floor-through residence was No. 11 (the previous sales were Nos. 9 and 5). The cost was precisely $17,539,356.25  the original asking price of $17,225,000 plus transfer taxes. And the closing gift from the sponsor was the usual $350 key that opens the locked gates of Gramercy Park, Manhattans only truly private park.

title: Christies Leader Returns Ancient Bronzes to China
description: At a ceremony in Beijing on Friday, the family of one of Frances wealthiest businessmen officially returned to China two bronze animal heads that were among the treasures looted in the 19th century from the imperial Summer Palace near Beijing by invading British and French troops.

title: Nets Sales Pitch to Stars: This Isnt East Rutherford
description: Once upon a time, about three decades ago, the New Jersey Nets installed a parquet floor at their arena in East Rutherford in a transparent attempt to mimic the storied tradition of the Boston Celtics. Unfortunately, the Nets had no workable business foundation to go along with the floor.

title: T-Mobile to Pay $308 Million for More Spectrum
description: T-Mobile USA, the fourth-largest American carrier, has agreed to pay $308 million to pick up a swath of spectrum, the radio waves that carry phone calls and data. The spectrum would enable the carrier to expand its new fourth-generation wireless network in 29 cities for 32 million people, the company said Friday.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Health-Centric Homes, for a Price
description: Coming soon to a neighborhood near you: an empathic multimillion-dollar home that passively treats the occupants body like a temple. The second coming of sustainable real estate, it will fuse green technology with nourishing all-about-me amenities and direct them indoors. Homebodies, take note: the residence is designed to make the people it shelters healthier.

title: Patriots Put Principles on Display
description: The moment the police led Aaron Hernandez away in handcuffs, he became expendable to the New England Patriots, despite the millions of guaranteed dollars that remained on his contract and the long legal process yet to play out.

title: Sharing a Potluck of Links, Not Food
description: More and more, we are looking to consume less and less  at least when it comes to online content.

title: Ask a Location Scout
description: The final subject in Metropolitans Q. and A. series will be Kevin Breslin, a location scout for television commercials who has arranged thousands of shoots, including the New York Lottery If I Had a Million Dollars spots.

title: Temp Workers, Permanent Problems
description: I found my first job out of college through a temp agency, which sent me to a brand-name bank where I stood in a windowless closet in a polyester-blend suit and heinous square-toed shoes filing carbons of personal portfolio data for individual-wealth-management clients. I was grateful to be hired, but during those humid, lifeless hours, I did think fondly of the days when I shoveled horse manure for $5 an hour.

title: Sony Begins Upfront Sales of Ads for PlayStation 3
description: Sony has already taken part in the upfront market for the sale of commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 season, for properties like the GSN cable channel and the Crackle digital video Web site. Now, the company is expanding the upfront selling process to the PlayStation 3 video game system.

title: Robson Riding a Pop Culture Wave
description: WIMBLEDON, England  After an emphatic straight sets upset of No. 10 Maria Kirilenko in the first round, Laura Robson faced a different sort of pressure in her second round match, playing the role of the overwhelming favorite.

title: Tank Topics
description: I was at a burger joint in Nashville with my wife and young daughter. A tough-looking guy in his late teens or early 20s came in wearing a tank top with a vulgar statement printed on it. [Trust the man, readers. This shirt was not family-friendly.] Amazingly, two older women joined him, one of whom seemed to be his mother. I am all for freedom of speech, but I found the shirt offensive. I was also embarrassed for my family, the other patrons and even his mother. We prevented our daughter from seeing it, but what else could I have done?

title: 2 Hard-Charging Oligarchs Returning to Global Energy Market
description: LONDON  They were once the partners of the British oil giant BP, until that arrangement spun apart in turmoil and litigation.

title: Comme des Garons
description: Rei Kawakubo showed her spring 2014 collection in Paris.

title: Where Win-A-Trip Winners Are Now
description: Erin Luhmann is a Minnesotan student of journalism who won Nick Kristofs win-a-trip contest this year, and will be traveling with him to report on development in Africa next week. For her first blog post, Erin checked in on former win-a-trip winners, to get a sense of where they are now and how the trip affected their career paths.

title: Anatomy of a Scene Video: Laurence Anyways
description: Xavier Dolan, the writer, director and editor of Laurence Anyways, discusses a scene from his film about the male-to-female transition of Laurence, played by Melvil Poupaud. In this scene, after Laurence comes out to his mother (Nathalie Baye) as transgender, the two have a conversation.

title: Comme des Garons: Spring 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Givenchy
description: Paris

title: A Comeback on Chiles Coast
description: There were hundreds of brightly colored houses clinging to a labyrinth of hills in Valparaso, Chile. The cobblestone streets were a maze. The Andes were in the distance, and the azure Pacific Ocean glittered from beyond.

title: Givenchy: Spring 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Getting Your Feet Wet at Water Parks
description: The first moments inside a water park complex almost always jar your senses. A rush of moist, chlorine-scented air fills your nose. Bright, cartoon colors, not to mention characters, surround you. And then there is the continuous loop of pop tunes vying with an endless whir of water  splashing, spraying, gurgling, rushing, dumping. On this last point, a caution to the uninitiated: if a bell or gong sounds, it is worth glancing up since it is likely to be a warning that some enormous vat of water overhead is preparing to dump its contents, and everyone but you knows it.

title: Restaurant Report: Tamer Pasta Bar in Florence
description: The dining scene in Florence is mostly dominated by well-established trattorias, either tucked away in neighborhoods far from the city center and frequented by locals or situated in the heart of town and overrun with tourists. The opening of Tamer late last year breaks this pattern: its a hip spot in the residential Santo Spirito area that serves modern renditions of food from all over Italy and beyond.

title: Their Kingdom and a Horse
description: Friends and fellow poets knew the couple belonged together. The two of them, however, took a while to discover that.

title: The Return on College, Around the World
description: As my colleague Eduardo Porter wrote this week, there are major returns from going to college. This is true around the world, but it is especially true in the United States.

title: The Conviction Integrity Review of People vs. Jesse Friedman
description: Read the Conviction Integrity Review of People vs. Jesse Friedman.

title: Movie Review: 'White House Down'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "White House Down."

title: The Week in Pictures for June 28
description: Subjects include a rally in the Village after a ruling on same-sex marriage, umbrellas at Jones Beach and a retirement celebration for a beloved principal.

title: When an Assignment Abroad Is Over: What Will You Miss Most?
description: PARISA friend who has lived and worked on three continents offered some advice when I moved to Paris for a job three years ago.

title: Dripping With Opportunity, Some of It Wasted
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Fans who came to the All England Club on Friday probably could be forgiven if they thought they were getting the leftovers.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Maison Martin Margiela Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Why No Byline or Named Source for an Article About a Leak Investigation?
description: A careful reader of The Times, David Smollar of San Diego, makes some astute observations about an unusual article in Fridays paper. The article caught many peoples eyes because it lacked a byline. It also quoted Jill Abramson, the executive editor, and it used an unnamed source to confirm an NBC News report that a retired Marine officer, Gen. James E. Cartwright, is a target of a leak investigation about American cyberattacks on Irans nuclear program.

title: A Courtship With Its Own Song
description: Wendi Bergamini, a Broadway actress, and the composer and lyricist Michael Weiner did not meet during a show. But he did turn her initial brushoff into a song for his new Broadway musical, First Date.

title: An Indian Artist Extends Her Reach
description: The poetically named Shantala Shivalingappa was born in India, but raised in Paris, where she trained in Kuchipudi, a South Indian classical dance style, with her mother, the well-known dancer and choreographer Savitry Nair. Ms. Shivalingappa, who will perform at Jacobs Pillow this week, is generally acknowledged as one of the greatest current practitioners of Kuchipudis flowing lines, percussive footwork and dramatic narratives.

title: Professors Work, Then Beethoven
description: The faculty of Columbia University will be bolstered by an important addition when the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas begins a professorship at the school this September. Mr. Haas, a composer associated with the French spectral school, in which timbre and resonance are particularly important, has dazzled with otherworldly pieces like In Vain, a psychedelically beautiful soundscape performed in pitch darkness. On Tuesday at the Austrian Cultural Forum, the conductor Michel Galante and the Argento Ensemble will perform the American premiere of the original version for soprano and eight instruments of Mr. Haass Atthis  a work inspired by the love poems of Sappho. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, 11 East 52nd Street, 212-319-5300, acfny.org; free.)

title: Regular Guys at Iwo Jima
description: With support-the-troops sentiment strong these days, occasionally a movie will use real soldiers or veterans in scenes. Act of Valor is a recent example. But the precedents for this go back a long ways and include Sands of Iwo Jima, the 1949 saga starring John Wayne as the classic irascible sergeant named Stryker. The film is too formulaic and jingoistic to be considered great, but maybe its just right for Fourth of July week. It plays on Thursday at 4 p.m. and Saturday at 2 p.m. at the Museum of Modern Art, part of the monthlong exhibition Allan Dwan and the Rise and Decline of the Hollywood Studios.

title: From Brooklyn, an Ode to Joy
description: The mission is a mouthful  to invest the experience of public space with wonder, to resurrect art history from the bowels of despair, and to impregnate the institutions of art with the joy of mans desiring  but since its from the Bruce High Quality Foundation, that brash, Brooklyn artist collective, it wont elicit so much as a blink from art world insiders. There is, however, considerable curiosity surrounding The Bruce High Quality Foundation: Ode to Joy, 2001-2013, which runs through Sept. 22 at the Brooklyn Museum. Included in the show are photographs, videos, paintings, installations  the works (even a 10-foot-tall inflatable rat.)

title: Neighbor Describes Witnessing Confrontation in Florida Murder Case
description: SANFORD, Fla.  A prosecution witness who saw portions of the altercation between George Zimmerman and Trayvon Martin on Feb, 26, 2012, took the stand on Friday, bolstering the defenses contention that Mr. Zimmerman was on the ground being beaten by Mr. Martin when the fatal shot was fired.

title: Movie Review: The Heat
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Heat, starring Melissa McCarthy and Sandra Bullock.

title: The Many Sides of a Violist
description: A common way to map the reach of the violist and composer Eyvind Kang is to enumerate his affiliations. For years he has been a regular collaborator with the performance artist Laurie Anderson; likewise with the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell. He has also done sturdy work with the doom merchant Stephen OMalley, and provided fine filigree for singer-songwriters like Beth Orton and Laura Veirs. Genre, or any clear iteration of style, is probably the least illuminating handle on him.

title: An Uphill Battle Daily in Court
description: In 1961 Clarence Earl Gideon was arrested on charges of stealing soda, beer and a small sum of cash from a pool hall in Panama City, Fla. Unable to pay for a lawyer, he represented himself at trial, and was later convicted and sentenced to five years in prison. Mr. Gideon appealed his conviction to the Supreme Court, which ruled unanimously that the right to counsel in a criminal case is fundamental to the American justice system. Fifty years after that landmark case, Gideon v. Wainwright, some 15,000 public defenders nationwide represent the majority of the 12 million people arrested annually who could not otherwise afford counsel.

title: Something Off Key at a Gospel Choir
description: Few crucibles test the mettle of adolescents as thoroughly or harrowingly as all-male prep schools, where lads on the cusp of adulthood bend, warp, grow and sometimes shatter. The hothouse atmosphere of such institutions has proved a fertile environment for dramatists from Robert Anderson (Tea and Sympathy) to Alan Bennett (The History Boys). Now Tarell Alvin McCraney, the author of the brilliant Brother/Sister trilogy, brings his singular sensibility to the subject with Choir Boy, which opens on Tuesday at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Rising Rates, and the Rent vs. Buy Decision
description: Mortgage rates have been rising, making it a bit more expensive to borrow to buy a home.

title: The Many Rebellions of Dobie Gillis
description: If you enjoy a study in contrasts, first spend an evening watching any of todays teenager-centered television offerings  on CW, ABC Family, even TeenNick or the Disney Channel. Then sample a few episodes of The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis, which ran from 1959 to 1963 and was one of the first shows to depict life from the teenage perspective.

title: Wearing a Wire at the Opera, Secretly, of Course
description: The Metropolitan Opera House has been justly acclaimed for its excellent acoustics. And not just in the choice seats. Many opera buffs assert that the best seats in the house are the most affordable ones: up in the balcony and family circle.

title: Another Giant Slayer Makes a Quick Exit
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Roger Federer is out of Wimbledon, and now, much less surprisingly, Sergiy Stakhovsky is, too.

title: Daniil Simkin, Standing Out, Reaching Out
description: There was no shortage of technical prowess during an American Ballet Theater matinee of Le Corsaire at the Metropolitan Opera House in early June. In the central roles, the Russian stars Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev were earning thrilled bursts of applause for the height of their jumps and the speed of their multiple turns.

title: Violence Erupts Anew in Volatile Chinese Region
description: HONG KONG  Violence erupted on Friday in Chinas volatile far western Xinjiang region, the second time in two days that tensions between the largely Muslim Uighur minority and Chinese security forces have brought bloodshed to the area.

title: People Will Say Theyre in Love, and They Are
description: Charlotte dAmboise, the actress now playing Fastrada in Broadways Pippin, thought that her romance with Terrence Mann would last about as long as an intermission.

title: Naughty Revenge, Just Plain Naughty and Not Plain at All
description: Tyler Farr

title: Movie Review: 'I'm So Excited'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "I'm So Excited."

title: Week in Review: Corzines Legal Battle May Last Years
description: Suit accuses Jon Corzine of a failure at the helm. | Cost of public projects is rising, and pain will be felt for years. | Bank gains by putting the brakes on traders. | Exit from the bond market is turning into a stampede. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that economists are asking: Did Ben Bernanke tip the Feds hand? | Mass layoffs at a top-flight law firm. | Deals in the works involving two luxury retailers.

title: Melissa Clark Answers Your Pie Questions
description: Nows your chance to perfect your techniques for making pie crust, topping and summer fruit filling. Melissa Clark of the Dining section will answer your questions in a live chat on all things pie, just in time to bake for the Fourth of July. So join Ms. Clark on Dinings Facebook Page on Monday, at 4 p.m. Eastern time, and bring your questions. Happy baking!

title: This Week's Best-Seller Lists
description: The Times's Pamela Paul and Gregory Cowles discuss the top-selling books of the week.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Celebrating Orwells 1984, and Uber in Taipei
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Christies Marriage Problem
description: Among the questions left unanswered by the Supreme Courts ruling on the Defense of Marriage Act is whether a majority of the justices actually think all Americans have an equal right to marry. So while the federal government can no longer treat gay and straight married couples differently, the individual states can keep discriminating.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 28
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: After Political Appointment in Bulgaria, Rage Boils Over
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Delyan Peevskis mother used to head the national lottery and leads a growing media empire with strong political and economic connections in this small, impoverished and notoriously corrupt Balkan nation. So perhaps it was not surprising that the appointment of Mr. Peevski, 32, to head the powerful State Agency for National Security sparked protests that have been attended by thousands every day over the past two weeks and show no sign of losing steam.

title: As the Tides Shift, a New Flagship Docks
description: Big flagship luxury sedans are relics. Artifacts left over from a time when social standing was reflected in the length of a cars wheelbase and how upright its grille stood. A time when Mercedes wasnt reaching down-market and Hyundai wasnt aiming for the heights. Back when the sight of a new Cadillac put a companys employees on high alert that the boss was on site, and not just that some drone in Section G had leased a CTS.

title: Meet the New Boss ...
description: The Lexus LS 460 gets a new face for 2013 and an interior fit for a captain of industry.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 28
description: More photographs.

title: After Before Midnight': A Short Screenplay
description: This weeks Riff examines how time exists onscreen including in the recent film Before Midnight. That movie is the third in a trilogy, each produced nine years apart and each following two characters, Jesse and Celine, as their lives overlap and intertwine often through long, digressive, yet oddly profound conversations. (Heres more on the films and their co-star and co-writer Julie Delpy.)

title: When Fuel Economy Improves, but Filling the Tank Costs More
description: The math seems so straightforward: as engines get smaller and fuel economy improves, the cost of driving will fall, right?

title: Splitting Hairs on Required vs. Recommended
description: Given the price difference between regular-grade and premium gasoline, car buyers should always consider the vehicles fuel requirement, as listed in the owners manual, as part of the total cost of ownership.

title: Catfish Returns to Average Numbers
description: In January, Catfish: The TV Show, the documentary series on MTV that follows Nev Schulman and his videographer, Max Joseph, enjoyed a brief moment in the spotlight when when the Notre Dame football player Manti Teo became the most high-profile example of someone who was catfished  that is, the victim of a hoax involving a faked online identity. But so far, any interest from that incident has not translated into higher ratings for the show.

title: Nice to Meet You ... Again
description: Are the pixels making us pixilated? In my case, it goes like this: Ill run into a Facebook friend whom I havent seen in more than a decade. Reminiscing about the party we met at in, say, 1998, Ill recount how all of us revelers had gone up to the roof that night with sparklers.

title: Empanadas, the Pies With a Passport
description: The empanada is the little meat pie that could, a native of Spain that traveled the world, touching down in Latin America, the Caribbean, Eastern Europe, Africa, South Asia and the British Isles.

title: Yuvi Alperts Holiday in Havana
description: The mens accessories designer Yuvi Alpert creates pieces that are informed by the ways the modern man moves through the world. Theres an appealing international flavor to his simple, elegant, unbling-y jewelry line Yuvi by Yuvi Alpert (the latest collection shows in Paris this weekend); and Men in Cities, his monthly limited-edition releases of affordable mens accessories, like wallets, bracelets and neckties, is meant to simplify shopping for guys on the go.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Thor That Wows
description: At No. 9 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is Volume 1 of Thor: God of Thunder, which reprints the first five issues of the latest series devoted to Thor, one of Marvels top heroes. The series is written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Esad Ribic. The first word to describe the result of this creative team is: Wow.

title: Getting Japan to Spend
description: TOKYO  Daisuke Horii just collected his summer bonus. It was only slightly more than last year, but enough to compel the 34-year-old shopping mall clerk to Tokyos electronics district to look for some high-end speakers.

title: Taking a Cue From Bernanke a Little Too Far
description: Financial advisers have been fielding calls from shaken investors in recent weeks, particularly retirees, who are nervous that a bond market crash is on the horizon.

title: French Businessman Investigated on Suspicion of Fraud
description: PARIS  Bernard Tapie, a wealthy businessman and erstwhile politician, is being formally investigated on suspicion of fraud in a corruption scandal that centers on a $535 million state payout to him in 2008, the office of the Paris state prosecutor and Mr. Tapies lawyer announced on Friday.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A five-bedroom stone- and brick-faced ranch in Plainsboro, N.J., and a four-bedroom wood-frame house in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Riske Finally Breaks Through at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It took 18 points in the final game of her second-round match at Wimbledon for 22-year-old Alison Riske of Pittsburgh to do something shed never done before in her career: win a match point at a Grand Slam.

title: Angst at the A.S.P.C.A.
description: One of the first times Cindy Adams went to a board meeting of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, tempers flared.

title: A Vacation Under the Sea
description: Travelers may be able to sleep among the oceans depths, surrounded by coral reefs, in two luxury underwater hotels planned for Dubai and the Maldives.

title: Do You Wanna Know a Secret?
description: THE revelation that the National Security Agency has been secretly amassing huge amounts of data about Americans phone and Internet use has sparked a lively debate about the proper role of secret information in a free and open society.

title: App Smart Extra: To-Do Lists, File Sharing and Other Home Worker Needs
description: This weeks App Smart column was all about apps for smartphones and tablets that can help home workers make the most of their time and the quiet environment. This is a handy trick because for some people, like your columnist, many out-of-office working tasks can actually be carried out on a tablet or phone  no PC required.

title: High-Performance Machines With Zero Horsepower
description: Imagine your new Lamborghini racing down the road, the wind tousling your hair, the tires straining through a corner, the adrenaline pumping.

title: Milan Mens Fashion Week, the Sun Also Sets
description: MILAN  Henry James, of course, said it best.

title: How to Decide Where to Give
description: In a Wealth Matters column published today, Paul Sullivan takes a look at what inspires people to give to charities, and how that inspiration affects the philanthropies they support. Some donors direct their charitable contributions to organizations that can measure the impact of their work, while others, like Mr. Sullivan and his family, place more importance on a sense of personal connection to a cause.When deciding whether to give money to a charitable cause, do you place more emphasis on metrics or emotion? What causes have you felt driven to support, and why?

title: On Nuclear Waste Bill, Senators Look to Public for Help
description: After the Obama administration abandoned plans in 2009 to bury nuclear waste at a repository in Nevadas Yucca Mountain, a spot chosen by leading senators more than 20 years earlier, a study commission recommended that a new location be picked through a consent-based process.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A one-bedroom on East 51st Street, a Park Ave. co-op with 10-foot beamed ceilings and a Brooklyn three family built in the 1930s.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Syria, the Philippines and Senegal.

title: Everyones a Dancer at the Philharmonic
description: In the original 1911 scenario of the ballet Petrushka, with music by Stravinsky and choreography by Fokine, the opening scene takes place in the bustling St. Petersburg square during the Shrovetide Fair. There are rowdy crowds, street hawkers, drunken revelers and puppet shows.

title: Abbotts All Set for Governor to Make Move
description: Greg Abbott has a shiny political rsum, an astonishing amount of money in the bank and has geared up for a statewide campaign with careful and deep planning on the ground and in the air.

title: Take a Phrase, Wrap It in a Song, E-Mail It on Friday
description: Most Monday nights when hes not on the road, the Austin singer-songwriter Bob Schneider tests at least one new song in front of an audience at the Saxon Pub.

title: Characters Finding Their Voices by Singing in the Choir
description: At the all-black Charles R. Drew Prep School for Boys, the official school song is the Presbyterian hymn Trust and Obey. But the striving upperclassmen begin a day there by belting out the civil rights anthem Keep Your Eyes on the Prize.

title: In 9/11 Museum to Open Next Spring, Vastness and Serenity, and Awe and Grief
description: You thought it was as bad as it would get, and then it got worse.

title: Secret Court Declassifies Yahoos Role in Disclosure Fight
description: In the secret court that authorizes national security surveillance requests, everything is considered confidential  even the existence of communications between companies and the court. But this week, the court drew back the curtain slightly, declassifying the fact that Yahoo was the company that fought the court in a momentous case in 2008.

title: Where Astros Played, Conventioneers in Suits Could Gather
description: HOUSTON  Ryan Bokros was 8 years old when he attended his first baseball game at the Houston Astrodome. It was 1985. The dome was bursting with people, the famous scoreboard bright with lights and the space bigger than anything he had ever seen.

title: A Week of Beauty and Joy
description: If you define a balletomane as someone who cares primarily about dancers, then the balletomanes peak season is American Ballet Theaters annual eight-week run at the Metropolitan Opera House. The luminaries include international visitors like Roberto Bolle, Natalia Osipova, Ivan Vasiliev and Diana Vishneva. Next week brings the company debut of the remarkable Danish dancer Alban Lendorf in The Sleeping Beauty.

title: Playing Up the Spicy Aspect of a Summer Fruit Pie
description: Summer isnt just fruit-pie season in my kitchen. Its crumb-pie season, too. Because while in theory one could put a crumbly brown-sugar topping on any kind of pie, tangy, high-acid summer fruit pies work best.

title: Dipping Into Eastern Modes, Spicing Up the Tarantella
description: Traditional songs at rocket speed: thats the music of Canzoniere Grecanico Salentino, who played a breakneck, euphoric set at Joes Pub on Thursday night. Songs that may date back millenniums flew by in a whirlwind of tambourine rhythms and the call-and-response of raw voices that also aligned in harmony. Silvia Perrone, a dancer in a bright red dress, twirled and skipped at center stage, barefoot.

title: Games of Hide and Seek and Experiments for Horns
description: They can do majestic and they can do scary. They do heroic really well. And theyre experts at wake-up-and-face-Judgment-Day.

title: Campaigning Hard for Presidential Plays
description: Lyndon Baines Johnson was a larger-than-life figure, no doubt, but is Broadway big enough for two plays about that president?

title: Makeshift Thrones Fit for No King, and Angels Unfurling Their Wings
description: Rachel Cohen and Jody Sperling call their double bill, which opened at Danspace Project on Thursday, Wood & Silk: A Shared Evening of Textural Choreography. You cant actually touch their work, but the common denominator is an interest in combining moving bodies with various kinds of material. The aesthetic is homemade, and the potentially wondrous alchemy of simple things and imagination comes with the risk of pitiful bareness if the magic doesnt happen.

title: Motion Picture Academy Seeks to Expand Membership
description: LOS ANGELES  Reversing a policy that has more closely restricted membership in the last decade, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Friday invited an unusually large group of film professionals  276 in total, including the actors Milla Jovovich and Joseph Gordon-Levitt  to join its ranks.

title: Friday Night Music: Elephant Revival, The Pasture
description: Dango Rose directs me to a video from their upcoming album. I like this in particular because you can see Bonnie Paines footwork  shes playing a soundboard as well as the washboard:

title: Plum Chutney Crumb Pie
description: Melissa Clark adds homemade fruit chutney to a plum pie. Its as easy as making applesauce and brings a layer of complexity to a summer fruit dessert.

title: From Across the Pacific, Good Old American Fare
description: A tense and elaborate crime drama ending in a Peckinpah-style shootout. A classic tear-jerker about a woman doing menial labor to support her ungrateful son. A loopy, candy-colored musical. A warmhearted biopic about a national hero.

title: Art Fatigue in London
description: LONDON  The spring auctions here, which ended on Thursday night, were a sharp contrast to those that recently took place in New York. There was not a night in London over the last two weeks when sales reached nearly $500 million, as happened in May at the Christies evening sale of postwar and contemporary art in New York.

title: Snapchat Without the Chat
description: Its like Instagram without the corollary of regret and recrimination: Snapchat is touted as the fastest way to share a moment with friends.

title: Variations on the Plum Crumb Pie
description: In my recent column and video, plums take center stage in a spicy crumb-topped pie. But summer pie should be all about ease. And if you cant find plums, do not run around town looking. Substitute blueberries or peaches, or a mix of the two. A rhubarb-strawberry combination would work well too, though you might have to increase the sugar to make up for rhubarbs astringency.

title: Dylan Lauren: Giving an Active Life a Splash of Color
description: Dylan Lauren, 39, is the daughter of Ralph Lauren and founder of Dylans Candy Bar. She lives with her husband, Paul Arrouet, on the Upper East Side.

title: Bill Cunningham | Urban Druids
description: Summer is the time of the solstice and Manhattanhenge, when the setting sun aligns with the grid of the city's cross streets, illuminating facades on both sides with a lacy tracery.

title: Experts and Juniors on Bridge Base Online
description: Except in July and August, every Wednesday at 11 a.m. Eastern time, two experts partner with juniors from around the world for an hour on Bridge Base Online. These sessions are arranged by Valerie Westheimer of New York City and Paula Mittleman of Boynton Beach, Fla., and kibitzers are welcome.

title: Syrian Rebels Claim Big Gains in City Where Protests Began
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebel fighters in southern Syria claimed on Friday to be in control of most of the city of Daraa, the cradle of the 2011 uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, after having battled his forces there for two weeks. The assertions, if confirmed, would represent a rare military victory for the insurgency, which has been struggling since it lost the stronghold city of Qusayr near the Lebanon border on June 5.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Jon S. Corzine faces a federal suit over the collapse of MF Global, Ireland slipped back into recession and problems with counterfeit food and liquor have grown.

title: No Ones Seen It, but Netflix Renews It
description: Netflix, unlike so many of its rivals on cable and broadcast, doesnt share any ratings, so we wont know how popular Orange Is the New Black is after the show has its debut on the service. But we can surmise that it is already pretty popular inside Netflix.

title: Portrait of a Young Model in Paris
description: I loved this shot from the backstage at Ann Demeulemeesters show  the romantic gloom of it. The picture captures the mood of the collection, with its lean silhouette, wide-striped trousers, modified cloche hats, and flowers embroidered in jet black.

title: Berluti Holds a Picnic, Givenchy Misses
description: Ill have more to say about Berluti and the clothes of Alessandro Sartori in my review of the Paris mens shows, but what a fabulous party he and his boss, Antoine Arnault, threw tonight at Hotel Sully  just a wee shack  in the Place des Vosges. Much of the fashion/cocktail action took place in the grass-covered courtyard and then there was a barbecue. Hamburgers, hot dogs, kebobs, salads, and French fries, served buffet style.

title: Week in Pictures for June 28
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a rally in the Village after a ruling on same-sex marriage, umbrellas at Jones Beach and a retirement celebration for a beloved principal.

title: Video of Deadly Clashes in Alexandria, Egypt
description: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and David Kirkpatrick report, violent street battles gripped Egypt on Friday as supporters and opponents of the countrys Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, held competing protests that devolved into fierce clashes in several cities. The violence was particularly fierce in the port city of Alexandria, where three people, including one American citizen, were killed and the local headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood, of which Mr. Morsi is a leader, was set ablaze.

title: 17 Years Have Passed and Date-Krumm Plays On
description: WIMBLEDON, England  When Serena Williams was just 15, Kimiko Date-Krumm was competing in the Wimbledon semifinals. Its such a long time ago that Date-Krumm said that she can barely remember the tournament and it is doubtful eitherplayer could have dreamed that 17 years later they would face each other on Court One for a place in the last 16.

title: The Wrenching Story of Her Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: City Homicides Drop Sharply, Again; Police Cite New Antigang Strategy
description: The number of homicides on record in New York City has dropped significantly during the first half of the year  to 154 from 202 in the same period last year  surprising even police officials who have long been accustomed to trumpeting declining crime rates in the city.

title: Cohen Declines to Testify in SAC Insider Case
description: Steven A. Cohen has declined to testify before a grand jury, raising the stakes in the governments long-running insider trading investigation into his giant hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors.

title: Is America a Leader in Broadband, or a Straggler?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Couples Who Sued in California Are Married
description: LOS ANGELES  The two couples who sued to overturn Californias ban on same-sex marriage were married late Friday afternoon, just hours after the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, lifted the stay that had been in place.

title: A Manhattan Bar Crawl of Sorts, With Thefts on Tap and on Tape
description: It was a busy Friday night in March at Petite Abeille, a Belgian cafe on East 20th Street near Stuyvesant Town. Regulars lined the bar. Everybody knew one another, which made it all the more shocking when one of the women shouted, My wallet! Someone stole my wallet!

title: Deadly Clashes in Egypt
description: Cairo saw dueling, but peaceful, rallies on Friday by supporters of President Mohamed Morsi and antigovernment protesters while demonstrations in other cities turned violent.

title: A New Respect for Marriage
F.B.I. Will Fight the Mafia With Fewer Investigators
description: The New York office of the F.B.I. confronts an array of challenges  from cyber and financial crime to global terrorism  that would have been unimaginable half a century ago when it first squared off in earnest against the mob. And so, in recent years, more and more agents have been assigned to those modern threats and fewer to the L.C.N., the bureaus shorthand for La Cosa Nostra.

title: Suicide by Pills Is Cited in Death of Guantnamo Detainee
description: WASHINGTON  A Yemeni detainee who was found dead last year at the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, committed suicide by taking an overdose of psychiatric medication, according to a military report made public on Friday.

title: How Is Your Bond Portfolio Allocated?
description: This weeks Your Money column addresses the big sell-off in the bond market, in which a fear of rising interest rates has caused investors to dump their funds.

title: Pub Fare for High Rollers
description: A piece of advice for those venturing to eat at Dan Rooneys, a new restaurant at the ever-expanding Empire City Casino at Yonkers Raceway: after consigning your car to a valet, take the escalator to the second floor, weave your way through the chiming slot machines and, just beyond the case of silver trophies, step out onto the terrace overlooking the racetrack. There, at dusk, one can watch beautifully gaited harness horses as they trot around the same dirt oval where Seabiscuit once outran his competitors.

title: An Adoptee Returns to South Korea, and Changes Follow
description: SEOUL, South Korea  ALL her life, Jane Jeong Trenka struggled to belong.

title: Pikes Peak Veteran Rod Millen Races to the Clouds Once More in an E.V.
description: A few years ago, Rod Millen might have laughed at an offer to race an electric car in the annual Pikes Peak International Hill Climb. Millen, 62, is a nine-time winner in the famed Race to the Clouds, including five victories in the Unlimited division.

title: Zoilo Almonte Gains Attention for Hot Start and His First Name
description: Baseball has had at least 22 players go by the nickname Heinie. There have been three players named Urban, three named Hideki and three with the first name Rogers. But until Zoilo Almonte was summoned to the Yankees from the minors, there had been only one Zoilo.

title: Bloomberg Says Math Backs Police Stops of Minorities
description: Ratcheting up the rhetoric over New York Citys stop-and-frisk police practices, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that the Police Department stopped white people too frequently, and nonwhites not frequently enough, in investigating murder suspects.

title: Protests in Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Skills, on the Wane
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Killer Angels
description: One-hundred-and-one summers after the Battle of Gettysburg, a family of four stopped their Nash Rambler at the site during a 1,000-mile drive from the New York Worlds Fair to Tallahassee, Fla. The father was a New Jersey-born former boxer, paratrooper and policeman who became a creative writing instructor at Florida State after enrolling to study opera. Before arriving at the park he had published dozens of science-fiction short stories, but nothing about history. But he had researched several Gettysburg participants for the trip, and he fascinated his daughter Lila and son Jeff with stories of his favorites while the family walked the grounds. They ended up staying for several days, because Michael Shaara was in the early stages of creating his masterpiece novel, The Killer Angels.

title: Hepatitis Threat Forces Another Frozen Fruit Recall
description: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that it had identified another product contaminated with Hepatitis A, which was the cause of a recall of frozen organic berries earlier this month.

title: Jesuits in the New World
description: To the Editor:

title: In Tight Race, Quinns Troops Hit the Streets
description: In the Bayside section of Queens, a volunteer had barely begun her sales pitch for Christine C. Quinns mayoral campaign when the middle-aged man who answered the door cut her off. She was the one responsible, in the City Council, for giving Bloomberg a third term, he barked. I hold that against her.

title: Farmers Look to New Ways of Irrigating in a Drought
description: DUMAS, Tex.  Deep in the Texas Panhandle, where the decline of the Ogallala Aquifer has left farmers fearful for their future, Harold Grall is hoping his field of tiny green corn plants will survive with minimal watering.

title: What Do You Reveal Onstage?
description: Ah, yes. Back to the songwriting series! Ive missed writing about songwriting. Maybe youve missed me, too, a little. Why do we write songs, by the way? Usually we write for a reason  to express a feeling, to tell that boy what we think of him, or to sing the baby to sleep. Sometimes we write songs to be famous, but not usually. The best songs are useful in our daily lives. So therefore anywhere we sing a song can be a kind of stage.

title: On Grass, Riske Is in Her Element
description: Alison Riske knows how to play on grass. She broke through at Birmingham three years ago, getting through three tough qualifying matches, then making a deep run to the semifinals, where she lost in three sets to Maria Sharapova. The All England Club gave her a wild card that year, but Riske lost a close match to Belgiums Yanina Wickmayer in the first round.

title: Shopkeepers and Now Restaurateurs, Too
description: The look of Giffords, which opened for business in Kent in February, sends a clear signal that this is a different kind of restaurant from its predecessor, the long-running Docs Trattoria. The co-owners, Michael Moriarty and James Neunzig, had the interior redesigned with vibrant blocks of color that evoke the work of the artist Josef Albers.

title: With Pierce and Garnett, Nets Get Upgrade in Scoring and Snarling
description: The lights will go up, the Broook-lyn chants will resume and, in the giddy haze of opening night at Barclays Center next fall, a brooding, solitary figure will approach the basket stanchion closest to the home teams bench  and ram his head into it. Repeatedly.

title: Transit Union Spurns Lhota
description: In January, when Joseph J. Lhota, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced his run for mayor, the leader of the largest union of transit workers in the city was asked if the group would consider endorsing Mr. Lhotas candidacy.

title: Bhutan Is No Shangri-La
description: DAMAK, Nepal  BEFORE my family was expelled from Bhutan, in 1992, I lived with my parents and seven siblings in the south of the country. This region is the most fertile part of that tiny kingdom perched between Tibet and India, a tapestry of mountains, plains and alpine meadows. Our house sat in a small village, on terraced land flourishing with maize, millet and buckwheat, a cardamom garden, beehives and enough pasture for cows, oxen, sheep and buffaloes. That was the only home we had known.

title: Scavenger of Golf Balls Is Found Stabbed to Death
description: For most golfers, every shank, hook and slice is agony. But for the people who scavenge the ponds and rough edges of golf courses, the little white balls that land out of play are as good as cash.

title: Visit by Obama Is Overshadowed by Mandela Vigil
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela always wanted to go quietly. Despite his stature as a global icon, he sought a dignified withdrawal from public life in recent years; privately he told aides of his desire for a quiet funeral, stripped of pomp.

title: Lottery Numbers
Something About Wimbledon Agrees With Lisicki and Pironkova
description: WIMBLEDON, England  For two women playing third-round matches Saturday at Wimbledon  Sabine Lisicki and Tsvetana Pironkova  the slick grass has proved a fast track to the business end of tournaments in a way that other tournaments have not.

title: Planted, Grown, Gathered and Dropped Off
description: Earlier this month, when sugar snap peas, arugula, spinach and strawberries began to appear at East End farm stands and local farmers markets, they also turned up on the doorsteps of some Long Island residents.

title: Gulbis, Knocked Off Course by Malaria, Fights Her Way Back on Tour
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  Her caddie, Greg Sheridan, was the first to grow alarmed at her growing list of symptoms. Something seemed definitely off about Natalie Gulbiss condition.

title: A Preview of the 9/11 Memorial Museum
description: Jarring transitions between the serenity of vast spaces and the grief of destruction and loss will meet visitors to the exhibition space.

title: Publisher Drops Book Deal With TV Chef Paula Deen
description: Paula Deen got a rare bit of good news on Thursday: Her new cookbook hit No. 1 on the best-seller list at Amazon.com, as thousands of fans  many of them springing to her defense as she faces accusations of racism  ordered the book months before its October release.

title: Expect the Unexpected
description: Every once in a while, something happens that challenges your entire view of the order of the universe. For instance, this week the U.S. Senate actually passed something. Meanwhile, in Texas, liberal Democrats and the abortion rights movement won a huge political victory.

title: Dinner Before the Show, or Just Dinner
description: There are several kinds of dining experiences to be had at the flashy Nico Kitchen + Bar, tucked into the eastern end of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark. You might choose an evening when theres a performance next door and the place is humming with fans who can pass directly into the theater at showtime. Or you might opt for a quieter night, when the enormous main dining room feels as cavernous and calm as a cathedral. In that case a better choice might be one of the handsome brown banquettes in the bar area, which can be bustling at happy hour but intimate a bit later on. Or maybe lunch, when there are lots of suits from the nearby office buildings and government offices, as Nicos guiding force, Ryan DePersio, put it in a telephone interview after several recent visits.

title: Horse-Butchering Plan Gains as U.S. Agrees to Inspect
description: A plant in New Mexico that plans to slaughter horses to produce meat for human consumption moved a step closer to operation on Friday when the Agriculture Department said it would provide legally required inspection services.

title: Cultural Revolution Vigilantes
description: Even now, nearly six months later  during which time Amazon.com has been flooded with hundreds of negative reviews condemning her; a Web site was set up attacking her; and her friends and colleagues have been bombarded with e-mails denouncing her  it is a little hard to understand why Ping Fus memoir, Bend, Not Break, has aroused such fury in some quarters of the Chinese immigrant community.

title: Honda Fit Is Recalled 2nd Time to Fix Switch That Could Cause a Fire
description: Honda said Friday that it was recalling about 686,000 vehicles worldwide for a second time, because its initial attempt to fix an electrical problem that could cause a fire was not adequate.

title: Proper Partner
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  So theres this guy named Joe Krozel, and he likes to break records. Hes done it a lot (No, I am not going to go count. Just trust me on this) and his thing seems to be looking for new ways to push the envelope.

title: While N.S.A. Leaker Stays in Hiding, Russian TV Builds a Pedestal for Him
description: MOSCOW  While Edward J. Snowden has remained mysteriously hidden from sight during his visit to Russia this week, Russian television has been making him a hero.

title: Glossy Ibises Are Like 21st-Century Pterodactyls
description: Along the Atlantic coast, summer afternoons arrive on the wings of the glossy ibis (Plegadis falcinellus). These dark birds seem to appear magically, suddenly haunting shallow mud flats and wet meadows where just minutes earlier none had been.

title: Dangerous Divisions in the Arab World
description: Even in a region where violence has become all too commonplace, the killing of four Shiite men in Egypt last weekend seemed particularly vicious. According to news reports, a cheering Sunni Muslim mob armed with clubs, swords and machetes raided a house in a Cairo suburb where about 30 people were marking a religious festival and beat, stabbed and lynched the four men. Video footage showed the victims bodies, bloodied and motionless, being dragged through the streets. Among those killed was a prominent Shiite cleric, Hassan Shehata.

title: A Damaging Decision on Generic Drugs
description: Consumers grievously harmed by generic drugs may find it virtually impossible to win compensation for their injuries as a result of a Supreme Court decision issued on Monday. By a narrow 5-to-4 margin, the court overturned lower court rulings that had awarded a New Hampshire woman $21 million for pain and suffering and other damages.

title: American Mayors: Let Them Smoke Pot
description: It has been more than seven months since voters in Colorado and Washington State chose to legalize marijuana for recreational use, in contravention of federal drug laws. It has been more than three months since Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he would announce his departments response to the new statutes relatively soon.

title: Senegal Cheers Its President for Standing Up to Obama on Same-Sex Marriage
description: DAKAR, Senegal  In Senegal, never mind about same-sex marriage: gay men and lesbians are abused by the police, beaten and sometimes tortured, with impunity. They are threatened by mobs, mocked on the front pages of newspapers and subject to criminal prosecution for being gay. And the persecution is even more severe elsewhere in West Africa.

title: F.D.A. Approves a Drug for Hot Flashes
description: The first nonhormonal drug to treat hot flashes won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, offering a new alternative to menopausal women.

title: The Zimmerman Trial
description: This first week of testimony in the George Zimmerman trial has proved to be nothing short of fascinating.

title: Corrections: June 29, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Sex and the H.I.V. Morning-After Pill
description: I RECENTLY had a serious H.I.V. scare after an episode of unprotected sex. The next day, at Whitman-Walker, a clinic in Washington that specializes in treating gay patients, I began a monthlong regimen of the drug Truvada, a form of post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP. It has to be taken within 72 hours after potential contact with the virus that causes AIDS. The price tag would normally be $1,200, but I was able to get a subsidy the manufacturer gives to low-income earners.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Former Mexican Governor Gets 11 Years for Taking Drug Bribes
description: MEXICO CITY  A former Mexican governor was sentenced on Friday to nearly 11 years in prison in the United States after pleading guilty in New York to a federal charge of conspiring to launder millions of dollars in drug cartel bribes to allow cocaine to move freely through his state.

title: Reactions to DOMA on Social Media
description: The Supreme Courts decision to overturn the Defense of Marriage Act on Wednesday sparked a wave of video reactions on Instagram and other social media.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 29, 2013
description: One hundred years from now, no one will be alive who remembers 9/11. The story has to tell itself.

title: Masterpieces, Revised by a Playful Restorer
description: Few people in the art world will forget an incident that occurred a little over a year ago, when a parishioner in a church near Zaragoza, Spain, took it upon herself to restore a fresco of Jesus  and ended up ruining it. Its unlikely that Kathleen Giljes exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich will receive as much attention as the hapless Cecilia Gimnez, whose story immediately spread on the Internet. But if Ms. Gimnez offered a tragicomic lesson in the pitfalls of do-it-yourself conservation, Revised and Restored: The Art of Kathleen Gilje shows the work of a skilled practitioner-turned-artist who consciously blurs the lines between restoring art and making something new.

title: N.F.L. Star and Murder Victim: Where Diverse Paths Crossed
description: BOSTON  Odin Lloyd did not own a car, so, just after dawn, he would pedal his bicycle from his Fayston Street home past blocks checkered with overgrown yards and rusted fences in one of Bostons roughest neighborhoods.

title: After Leaks, Obama Leads Damage Control Effort
description: WASHINGTON  Standing in the grand presidential palace in Senegal this week, President Obama detoured from his diplomatic mission to Africa to offer a message to his own constituents back home.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Inspired by Nature, Tweaked With Satire
description: On a sunny afternoon last month, John Alexander sat in his studio in Amagansett, surveying a boatload of motley figures on a large painting in progress he had titled Lost Souls.

title: Updates to Drivers Education Reflect New Dangers on the Road
description: DES PLAINES, Ill.  The drivers education simulator lab here seems straight from the 1970s: A dozen teenagers tucked into low-slung black vinyl drivers seats, their steering wheels creaking in unison as a grainy movie plays and a narrators grandfatherly voice gently asks, Are you identifying the potential signs of conflict?

title: Jim Hudson, Who Intercepted Pass to Help Jets Win Title, Dies at 70
description: Jim Hudson, the defensive back whose interception on a trick play helped propel the Jets storied upset over the Baltimore Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex. He was 70.

title: Celebrating the Evolution, and Craft, of Boat Building
description: IN HIS PLAINTIVE 1989 SONG The Downeaster Alexa, Billy Joel gave voice to the plight of Long Island fishermen suffering after a ban on striped bass fishing that went into effect a few years earlier. The ban was one of the factors, along with increased regulation, overfishing and aggressive development on the Long Island coast, that helped cause the waning of the fishing industry, and in turn, a perhaps less obvious decline: that of the boat-building trade.

title: Sabathia, in Bid for 200th Victory, Veers From Dominating to Defeated
description: BALTIMORE  Through five innings Friday night, C. C. Sabathia looked as if he might earn his 200th win in grand style. He had not allowed a hit and was pitching as sharply as he had been all season.

title: A Peek Inside the 9/11 Memorial Museum
description: A tour inside the National September 11 Memorial and Museum in New York, as it unveils some of the exhibits that will go on display when it opens to the public.

title: Adm. Frank B. Kelso Dies at 79; Tied to Tailhook Scandal
description: WASHINGTON  Adm. Frank B. Kelso II, who retired under pressure as chief of naval operations in 1994 in the aftermath of rampant sexual misconduct by Navy officers at an aviation convention known as Tailhook, died on Sunday in Norfolk, Va. He was 79.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Out to the (Extremely) Old Ball Game
description: Men in uniform are not traditionally jeered at for being unmanly.

title: Harvey Is Sharp, but Bullpen Is Not
description: The futility of the 2013 Mets can ruin any night, even one when Matt Harvey pitches. On another evening when Harvey, the Mets ace, was dazzling, the bullpen collapsed and cost him a victory.

title: Mets Wheeler Scouts Harvey and Himself
description: The most meaningful games the Mets will play this year are the ones that cast an eye toward future seasons, when the team hopes to contend. For that reason, any Matt Harvey start is worth watching, but so are starts by the prized rookie Zack Wheeler.

title: Arizona Is Fertile Ground for New York Matzo
description: YUMA, Ariz.  Here, on a Christian farmers land  five miles from the Mexican border, lies the holiest of fields for some of New Yorks most observant Orthodox Jewish communities. Wheat harvested on these 40 acres is destined to become matzo, the unleavened bread eaten by Jews during the eight days of Passover.

title: An Island Lifesaver
description: All ambulance workers have their war stories. Ben Jones has them going back to World War II.

title: All Eyes on the Elephant
description: In his work Topsy: The Startling Story of the Crooked-Tailed Elephant, P. T. Barnum and the American Wizard, Thomas Edison (Atlantic Monthly Press, $27), Michael Daly vividly revives a rollicking pachydermal tale that riveted New Yorkers a century ago and still survives in a gruesome YouTube video.

title: Rangers Decide to Keep Richards
description: The Rangers announced Friday that they would not use their remaining compliance buyout this summer, ensuring that Brad Richards will return to the team for at least one more season.

title: Stanzas for a Romantic Season
description: Pop songs never seem to mention winter love or autumn love. But summer love  now thats a genre all its own. Guilt-free and removed from the usual fidelities, summer love is the troubadour of romance: it entertains and distracts us, and then moves blithely on. The following poems were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

title: N.F.L. Wont Promote Enrollment in Health Insurance Under New Law
description: The National Football League is not participating in an effort with the Obama administration to help promote enrollment in health insurance plans under the new health care law, a spokesman said. The statement came after two Republican Senate leaders wrote to the heads of six major professional sports organizations, including the N.F.L., expressing concern that they would help encourage people to sign up in the new health insurance programs set to begin next month. Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary for health and human services, has been in talks with various groups to help with enrollment efforts. But the senators, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and John Cornyn of Texas, warned that doing so might not be a good idea. Given the divisiveness and persistent unpopularity of the health care law, it is difficult to understand why an organization like yours would risk damaging its inclusive and apolitical brand by lending its name to its promotion, the senators wrote.

title: Hardaways Name Is Familiar, but His Game Is Not
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Tim Hardaway Jr. stared at his No. 5 Knicks jersey, surrounded by photographers prepared to capture the moment. Hardaway, the Knicks first-round pick, then flashed a familiar smile as cameras clicked.

title: A Night Owl With a Canine Alarm
description: Mark Elijah Rosenberg is the founder and artistic director of Rooftop Films, which has been screening new independent films atop various New York City buildings every summer since 1997. The group has since branched out to farms and boats, among other venues, and has screened films in at least a half-dozen other cities. Mr. Rosenberg, 38, lives in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, with his wife,  Stephanie Frances Skaff, a musician and writer, and their dog, Dizzy.

title: Taking Back Hernandez Jerseys
description: The New England Patriots are offering new jerseys to all fans who want to get rid of the ones they bought with Aaron Hernandezs name. Hernandez is being held in jail on a first-degree murder charge. The team has released him and removed all Hernandez jerseys from its souvenir store at Gillette Stadium. The team said fans could go to the store on the weekend of July 6-7 for a free jersey of comparable value. (AP)

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) ANNA NICOLE (2013) Agnes Bruckner, above, plays Vickie Lynn Hogan, a Texas high school dropout and single mother who takes a job as a dancer at a topless bar and changes her name. As Anna Nicole Smith, she marries the octogenarian millionaire J. Howard Marshall (Martin Landau) and earns comparisons to Marilyn Monroe in a Playboy pictorial. But her husbands death brings an end to her financial support, and drinking, pill-popping and drastic weight fluctuations take their toll. Soon her son, Danny (Graham Patrick Martin), dies of an overdose while visiting his mother and newborn sister in the hospital. Not long after, Anna dies. Rounding out the cast are Adam Goldberg, as Annas boyfriend Howard K. Stern; Virginia Madsen, as her mother, Virgie Arthur; and Cary Elwes, as Marshalls son, E. Pierce Marshall.

title: Shaking Up the Stage
description: Dixon Place, the Lower East Side performance space, has been host for all sorts of odd and eyebrow-raising work, but Gregg Mozgala may have introduced a new kind of discomfort this month with a scene that found him sucking on Sara Buffamantis toes.

title: The Mob and Angela Clemente
description: At the end of February, a 300-page report, tersely titled, New York Systemic Corruption, was received for review by the Justice Departments Office of the Inspector General in Washington. In three bound volumes, it detailed a series of oft-made, and explosive, allegations: that in the 1990s, while trying to stem the Colombo family war, federal prosecutors and agents for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York knowingly allowed two moles in the mob to kill while they were on the governments payroll.

title: Camping for Feminism
description: On Thursday morning, Courtney Cook, a 17-year-old art student from Winnetka, Ill., who was spending the week with her mother at the Jade Hotel downtown, sat in the Lexington Avenue offices of the nonprofit group Choices in Childbirth and talked about her maternal fantasies. Id like to have a baby like right now, Ms. Cook explained to a group of peers and educators, but I know its not a good time. Although she doesnt plan to have a child until she is 30, she had become obsessed with motherhood after hours of watching A Baby Story, a reality series on the procreation-obsessed cable network TLC. Such is the extent of her fascination that she keeps pictures of nurseries on her Pinterest board.

title: U.S. Student Killed in Egypt Protest Was Drawn to a Region in Upheaval
description: The American student who was killed in Egypt on Friday during street protests in Alexandria was an idealist, an Arabist and a linguist, drawn to the Middle East despite  or perhaps even because of  its political unrest, friends said.

title: Unable to Visit With Mandela, Obama Honors His Legacy
description: JOHANNESBURG  The possibility of a meeting between the two historic figures  the first black president of the United States and the first black president of South Africa  was so tantalizingly close. But with Nelson Mandela fighting for his life in a Pretoria hospital, President Obama abandoned his hope for a visit and instead on Saturday used every stop here to talk in emotional and sweeping terms about what Mr. Mandela meant to the world, and to him.

title: Visit by Obama Is Overshadowed by Mandela Vigil
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela always wanted to go quietly. Despite his stature as a global icon, he sought a dignified withdrawal from public life in recent years. Privately he told aides of his desire for a quiet funeral, stripped of pomp.

title: The Weekend Word: Covered
description: In Todays Times

title: Violence in Restive Chinese Region Prompts Crackdown
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Communist Party leadership has started a security crackdown in the far western region, Xinjiang, vowing to apply high pressure methods after two outbursts of violence there in recent days pitted members of the Uighur ethnic minority against police forces, state television reported Saturday.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Givenchy Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Whos a Journalist? A Question With Many Facets and One Sure Answer
description: Behind almost every correction in The Times, there is a story. In the case of the correction about Alexa OBrien, the story is a particularly interesting one.

title: Letters to the Sports Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Acelaland Versus Mayberry
description: Hmm. One thing Ive noticed in recent discussions is that on the right, the Acela  Americas only sorta-kinda high-speed passenger train  has become a symbol of liberal elitism. Whats that about?

title: The Always-Wrong Club
description: Aha. Floyd Norris reminds us of the 23-economist letter from 2010, warning of dire consequences  currency debasement and inflation  from quantitative easing. The signatories are kind of a whos who of wrongness, ranging from Niall Ferguson to Amity Shlaes to John Taylor. And they were wrong again.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Berluti Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Paul Venables, on Asking for the Toughest Jobs
description: This interview with   Paul Venables, founder and executive creative director of Venables Bell & Partners, an advertising agency in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Cahill Returns Not a Moment Too Soon for Red Bulls
description: The Red Bulls will attempt to avoid on 0-fer, 0 for June, when they face the Houston Dynamo on Sunday afternoon in the clubs first home game since the first day of the month.

title: Risk for Redskins in Makeover of Team Mascot
description: Few teams in the N.F.L. have faced more pressing off-season concerns than the Washington Redskins, whose star quarterback, Robert Griffin III, hopes to be ready for training camp as he continues to rehabilitate his surgically repaired right knee.

title: After Fighting Mobile Trend, Intel Now Embraces It
description: Intel, which became a global behemoth by making the chips that drive most of the worlds desktop computers and laptops, missed the mobile revolution. In tablets and smartphones, the company is a bit player.

title: Dior Homme
description: The complete spring 2014 collection shown in Paris.

title: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Mariano Rivera: A Singular Pitcher
description: As Mariano Rivera walked to the mound June 19, a Yankee fan might have felt a pang of doubt. A combined 18 walks and hits had pockmarked his previous five and two-thirds innings over eight outings, more base runners, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, than Rivera had ever allowed over any other eight-game stretch in his major league career.

title: Rangers Have Needs but Not High Picks
description: Gordie Clark, the Rangers player personnel director, hopes to add defensive depth and a goaltender in the N.H.L. draft on Sunday.

title: Egypt, Its Streets a Tinderbox, Braces for a Spark
description: CAIRO  Thousands of members of the Muslim Brotherhood, many wearing hard hats and armed with makeshift clubs, are camped near the presidential palace in anticipation of a battle to defend their ally, President Mohamed Morsi. In three days of protests against him around the Nile Delta, gunmen have killed at least five Brotherhood members and set fire to several of its offices.

title: For the No. 1 Pick, the Avalanche May Set Aside Sentiment
description: Sundays N.H.L. draft at Prudential Center in Newark will begin either like a fairy tale, or like a fairy tale overturned. It all depends on whether the Colorado Avalanche take defenseman Seth Jones with the first overall pick or choose the talented center Nathan MacKinnon instead.

title: Variety: An Alarming Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Ill confess, I had never heard of a ha-ha before todays discussion. That may have slowed me down. You just dont see too many of them in the part of the Bronx where I grew up.

title: Its No Secret Lakers Want Howard Back
description: LOS ANGELES  When two billboards with an image of Dwight Howard accompanied by the word STAY went up last week in Los Angeles  one on Hollywood Boulevard and the other across the street from Staples Center  it was rather unbecoming.

title: President-Elect of Iran Says He Will Engage With the West
description: TEHRAN  Irans president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, said Saturday that he would engage with the West and fulfill his electoral promises to allow more freedom for the Iranian people.

title: Kerry Extends Israel Trip Amid Speculation on Talks
description: JERUSALEM  In a hectic day of shuttle diplomacy with senior Israeli and Palestinian leaders in two capitals, Secretary of State John Kerry struggled on Saturday to close a deal to revive dormant Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: Best Brother Was Saved for Last, Bobcats Think
description: The Zeller brothers each took a turn being Indianas Mr. Basketball. They reached a combined height of just under 21 feet, and each attended a powerhouse athletic university. But like most of the groups of three or more brothers to make it to professional sports, one will probably stand above the rest.

title: Actors Today Dont Just Read for the Part. Reading IS the Part.
description: Gabra Zackman is a new kind of acting star: she is heard, but unheard-of.

title: Horschels Mantra: Clothes Make the Man
description: BETHESDA, Md.  Billy Horschel had a 50 percent success rate during his early days as a professional golfer. It had nothing to do with hitting greens in regulation or keeping the ball out of the rough. It had everything to do with having his wardrobe vetted by his wife, Brittany.

title: At Wimbledon, Promise, Steeled by Early Trauma for Gmez
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Lucas Gmez, the Mexican national junior tennis champion, was humbled at the French Open in early June. He was beaten, 6-1, 6-0, in the third round of the junior tournament by second-seeded Nikola Milojevic of Serbia after expressing strong belief in his ability to win.

title: Eddie Plank: A Favorite Son of Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa.  This weeks commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg, the turning point in the Civil War, might also bring renewed attention to Eddie Plank, a relatively unappreciated baseball star in the early 20th century who spent most of his life here. The battle, fought on the first three days of July in 1863, stamped Little Round Top, Seminary Ridge and Picketts Charge into Americas military lexicon.

title: The Padres Season Doesnt Add Up
description: When the San Diego Padres lined up along the third-base line at Citi Field on April 1, they did not look like contenders. Their opening day third baseman was the journeyman Cody Ransom. The right-hander Andrew Cashner, a perpetual ace in waiting, was again a reliever. The starter that day was Edinson Volquez, with Clayton Richard to follow in Game 2.

title: A Gallant Officer
description: One day during the summer of 1863, in Union-occupied Nashville, Tenn., Anna Rhoads visited the headquarters of Gen. Walter C. Whitaker and requested a meeting with him. Perhaps to her surprise, he granted one.

title: New Kind of Baseball Bat Is Tapered for Safety and Comfort
description: Bats have not changed much since Honus Wagner became the first player to have his name burned onto a Louisville Slugger.
