True, they are lighter now, with rounded ends, and since Barry Bonds used it, many players have switched to maple from the traditional white ash. But the general shape is unchanged.

title: Who Sets the Terms for Interviews?
description: TAKING a summertime break from the weighty issues of leaks, false balance and anonymous sources  to which Im sure to return  I am again hanging out the public editors shingle. I will do my best here to answer what I call Perfectly Reasonable Questions from those who read The Times closely and with a critical eye.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Our Notions of Gender
description: When a child identifies with the other gender, what to do?

title: Thomas A. Drake
description: Thomas A. Drake is a former senior executive at the National Security Agency who, in 2006, leaked information to the press about wasteful government spending and alleged snooping on the citizenry.

title: Stuck Team Bus Gives First Stage a Chaotic Finish
description: BASTIA, France  The Tour de Frances first visit to Corsica started uneventfully Saturday as riders rode calmly out of a picture-perfect harbor town under sunny skies.

title: June 29: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: David Rogers, Stage Adapter of Offbeat Material, Dies at 85
description: Flowers for Algernon, Daniel Keyess novel about a mentally handicapped man who is temporarily transformed into a genius, has been read by millions and recreated in many forms, including the 1968 film Charly (playing the title role, Cliff Robertson won an Academy Award). But singing along with any version was impossible until David Rogers reinterpreted it as the musical Charlie and Algernon.

title: Takin It to the Streets
description: THE former C.I.A. analyst Paul R. Pillar asked this question in a recent essay in The National Interest: Why are we seeing so many popular street revolts in democracies? Speaking specifically of Turkey and Brazil, but posing a question that could be applied to Egypt, Israel, Russia, Chile and the United States, Pillar asks: The governments being protested against were freely and democratically elected. With the ballot box available, why should there be recourse to the street?

title: Germans Loved Obama. Now We Dont Trust Him.
description: BERLIN  IN May 2010, I received a brown envelope. In it was a CD with an encrypted file containing six months of my life. Six months of metadata, stored by my cellphone provider, T-Mobile. This list of metadata contained 35,830 records. Thats 35,830 times my phone company knew if, where and when I was surfing the Web, calling or texting.

title: Democrats Get a Gift From the Roberts Court
description: BACK in the days when Republicans were reading polls through rose-colored glasses and imagining a Mitt Romney landslide, one of their most plausible arguments was that many pollsters were simply misreading the likely composition of the electorate. There was no way, this theory ran, that core Democratic constituencies would turn out at the same rates as in 2008, when Obamamania was at its peak. Instead, 2012 was set up to be what the conservative writer Ben Domenech called an undertow election, in which reduced turnout among young voters and minorities would drag the incumbent down to defeat.

title: A Nation of Brewmeisters
description: Eighty years after the end of Prohibition, Mississippi has become the last of the 50 states to legalize one of the more innocent offshoots of the era of the Drys  home brewing, a hobby long suppressed in the states but lately generating a frothy head of popularity. Assorted limits remain in states and localities about the amount of beer that can be brewed as well as bans on transporting home brew into the community. But after some moralizing debates this year about demon beer, Alabama lawmakers repealed the total ban in May; in Mississippi, home brewing becomes legal on July 1.

title: The Talented Justice Kagan
description: Elena Kagan is the first Supreme Court justice appointed in almost 40 years who wasnt a judge before she arrived at the court. In a good way, it shows. Since she was sworn in three summers ago, the evidence has mounted that she is achieving a goal that other justices say they strive for and yet seldom attain: writing readable judicial opinions that non-lawyers can understand.

title: Mandela and Obama
description: GATHERING valedictory material on Nelson Mandela as he faded in a Pretoria hospital the other day, I came across a little book called Mandelas Way. In this 2010 volume, Rick Stengel, the ghostwriter of Mandelas autobiography, set out to extract lessons on life, love and courage he had learned from three years of immersion in Mandelas life.

title: The Best Hope for Frances Young? Get Out
description: THE French arent used to the idea that their country, like so many others in Europe, might be one of emigration  that people might actually want to leave. To many French people, its a completely foreign notion that, around the world and throughout history, voting with ones feet has been the most widely available means to vote at all.

title: The End of Car Culture
description: PRESIDENT OBAMAS ambitious goals to curb the United States greenhouse gas emissions, unveiled last week, will get a fortuitous assist from an incipient shift in American behavior: recent studies suggest that Americans are buying fewer cars, driving less and getting fewer licenses as each year goes by.

title: Souring on Shark Fin Soup
description: WHEN I was a kid, shark fin soup was de rigueur at wedding banquets. Somebody got married, and slurp  there we were, eating the stringy soup at an elaborate 10-course affair in a private party room in Chinatown. It was pleasing, but in the salty, gelatin-thickened way of Thanksgiving gravy. Shark fin itself is virtually tasteless  the soups flavor relies heavily on chicken stock, ham and a generous pour of Chinese red vinegar. We ate it because everyone else did, and everyone else ate it for the same reason.

title: I Love L.A.
description: The photographer Lloyd Ziff revisits Los Angeles, the place of his childhood dreams.

title: I Love L.A.
description: Frank Lloyd Wright said, Tip the world over on its side and everything loose will land in Los Angeles. Oscar Levant said, Behind the phony tinsel of Hollywood lies the real tinsel. I say, I love it all. I love the real tinsel and the phony tinsel, too.

title: Why Healthy Eaters Fall for Fries
description: LAST Tuesday, Connor Moran, a limit-the-red-meat, increase-the-greens, eat-salad-for-lunch kind of guy, stopped into a Bronx Dunkin Donuts for his usual black coffee, no sugar, no cream.

title: Berdych Continues His Dominance Over Anderson
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Tomas Berdych of the Czech Republic shrugged off a first-set service lapse and powered his way to a 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, 7-5 victory over Kevin Anderson of South Africa.

title: Booze as Muse
description: MY first real job in journalism was as a junior editor at Esquire, a magazine with a venerable literary pedigree. I imagined myself having three-martini lunches with Tom Wolfe, and explaining to Tom (surely we would be on a first-name basis by the third martini) that his latest 25,000-word article was not bad, exactly, but needed another run through the typewriter before we could even think of publishing it.

title: Lost: Pink Dog With Sneakers. Return to West Hollywood.
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  This citys new dog is certainly conspicuous: fluorescent pink, weighing as much as a grown man, wearing sneakers on his paws and a water bottle strapped to his back.

title: A Not-So-Powerful Federal Reserve
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gospel According to Me
description: The booming self-help industry, not to mention the cash cow of New Age spirituality, has one message: be authentic! Charming as American optimism may be, its 21st-century incarnation as the search for authenticity deserves pause. The power of this new version of the American dream can be felt through the stridency of its imperatives: Live fully! Realize yourself! Be connected! Achieve well-being!

title: For a Day, Wimbledon Turns Most Hospitable to the 20-and-Under
description: WIMBLEDON, England  On a day that featured 31-year-old Serena Williams defeating 42-year-old Kimiko Date-Krumm, youth had its moment in the sun. Yes, the sun was out at Wimbledon on Saturday after two days of on-and-off rain.

title: Curtis W. Tarr, Innovative Leader of the Draft, Dies at 88
description: Curtis W. Tarr, who as director of the Selective Service System in the later years of the Vietnam War sought to make the lottery system for the military draft fairer by reducing the number of student and medical deferments granted to young men, died on June 21 at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 88.

title: The New Prostitutes
description: Take the Long Hill Road exit off I-95 in eastern Connecticut and curl south toward the waterfront city of Groton and youll find each of the places that briefly employed Maureen Brainard-Barnes. There is the TJ Maxx and the AutoZone and the Stop and Shop. And the Chesters chicken counter, where she made the potato wedges. And the shopping center with the Groton Cinema 6, where she picked up discarded snacks from the carpet in exchange for free admission and a bag of popcorn.

title: No Letup on the Right to Choose
description: Wendy Davis, a Texas state senator, got national attention last week for her marathon filibuster against an extremist package of abortion restrictions. Ms. Daviss dramatic gesture is unlikely to stop the hard-right Texas Legislature from passing the bill, and there are many similar measures around the country that are part of a nonstop attack on womens reproductive rights by Republican lawmakers and anti-abortion groups.

title: A Gun Maker Moves On
description: One of Connecticuts gun manufacturers, PTR Industries, is departing the state in a melodramatic huff for gun-friendly South Carolina, complaining about the tightened gun safety laws enacted in Hartford by conscience-stricken legislators following the Newtown gun massacre of 20 children and 6 educators last December.

title: Buford Hold the High Ground
description: Neither side in the Civil War lacked for blowhards and glory seekers among its general officers corps. Many still command our attention 150 years later, and theirs are the names we often tend to recognize, while the steady, unassuming sort  those who did their jobs and sought no recognition  have often gone unheralded.

title: The Future of Voting Rights
description: When five justices of the Supreme Court disabled the Voting Rights Act last Tuesday, they left it to Congress to find a new formula to restore one of the great landmarks of equality and once again protect the nations most fundamental democratic right. That is unlikely for the moment given Congressional dysfunction, as the justices certainly knew, but it is hardly impossible in the months and years to come.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, June 30
description: Around the world, food fraud is an epidemic.

title: Have a Great Vacation (if Its Approved)
description: JUST about every time I plan a vacation, I worry that I wont be able to go. You cant leave, my boss might say, because were just too busy to spare you. (In that case, I think indignantly, theyd better reimburse me for the plane ticket and the hotel room.)

title: Politics Aside, a Common Bond for Two Economists
description: ONE of the cool things about hanging around a place like Harvard, where I have been a professor for almost 30 years, is that you get to meet some supertalented people long before the world recognizes their talents. I had a vivid reminder of this just a few days ago, when President Obama appointed Jason Furman as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, a position that I held under George W. Bush.

title: Tremors From the Feds Grand Experiment
description: BEN S. BERNANKE and the Federal Reserve have been conducting a gigantic monetary experiment aimed at reducing unemployment, speeding up the economy and reviving the housing market.

title: How Audubon Societys Chief Took Wing From Journalism
description: I WAS born in California, but I moved every year that I was in grammar school. My father was a sales manager for Paper Mate, and it moved him around. I lived in several states, and the experience shaped me: change became normal and inevitable. I decided that I could roll with it or be crushed by it, and I learned to roll with it.

title: No English!
description: MADRID

title: Stealth Wear Aims to Make a Tech Statement
description: THE term stealth wear sounded cool, if a bit extreme, when I first heard it early this year. Its a catchy description for clothing and accessories designed to protect the wearer from detection and surveillance. I was amused. It seemed like an updated version of a tinfoil hat, albeit a stylish one.

title: Local Officials Asked to Help on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The White House is recruiting mayors, county commissioners and other local officials to promote and carry out President Obamas health care law in states like Florida and Texas, where governors are hostile to it.

title: The Real John Roberts Emerges
description: This time a year ago, the conservative chief justice whose vote saved President Obamas health care law was a figure of mystery. In fact, The Mystery of John Roberts was the title I gave to one of my Opinionator columns for The New York Times last summer. The right-wing blogosphere had turned on him venomously. Liberals didnt know what to make of his crucial vote, or of him. What was his game? Was he for real?

title: The Cochrane Collaboration
description: The Cochrane Collaboration, which pushed Roche to release clinical trial data about Tamiflu, is an international network of experts who conduct exhaustive analyses of medical treatments.

title: Breaking the Seal on Drug Research
description: PETER DOSHI walked across the campus of Johns Hopkins University in a rumpled polo shirt and stonewashed jeans, a backpack slung over one shoulder. An unremarkable presence on a campus filled with backpack-toters, he is 32, and not sure where hell be working come August, when his postdoctoral fellowship ends. And yet, even without a medical degree, he is one of the most influential voices in medical research today.

title: Kvitova, Hoping to Regain 2011 Form, Advances at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England  On a Friday at Wimbledon 12 years ago, Tim Henman was on the verge of beating Goran Ivanisevic and advancing to the mens final. He breezed through the third set, 6-0, and led in the fourth, 2-1.

title: Generous Goodbyes
description: C.E.O.s often walk away with millions in stock, bonuses and retirement benefits when they leave their companies. These 10 departing executives received the 10 largest exit packages in 2012.

title: How the Figures Were Calculated
description: TO measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

title: Executive Pay by the Numbers
description: Here are the 200 most highly-paid chief executives at U.S. public companies in 2013. The list, compiled by Equilar, an executive compensation data firm, includes firms with revenue over $1 billion.

title: Golden Parachutes Are Still Very Much in Style
description: MOST employees who leave a company are typically offered modest severance  in some cases a corporate pension, and perhaps a retirement party hosted by co-workers. For many chief executives of corporations, the rewards are far, far richer.

title: An Unstoppable Climb in C.E.O. Pay
description: WHEN we made our annual foray into the executive pay gold mine in April, chief executives earnings for 2012 showed what appeared to be muted growth on the year. The $14 million in median overall compensation received by the top 100 C.E.O.s was just a 2.8 percent increase over 2011, the figures showed.

title: Sore Arm Doesnt Deter Gee in Victory Over Nationals
description: Early Saturday morning, Manager Terry Collins explained that the Mets would have to monitor Dillon Gee from start to start, grant him extra rest when possible and show general precaution while handling his forearm tendinitis, which has flared up and pained him on a sporadic basis this season. Collins left open the possibility of Gees going on the disabled list at some point.

title: The Cool of Veronique Nichanian
description: The top trends for next spring are suits with mismatched trousers, the shirt jacket, neat windbreakers, ocean-to-sky shades of blue, and faded pencil stripes and dot prints. At Herms on Saturday night, Veronique Nichanian managed to hit all of those notes, and not break a sweat.

title: Bylsma Takes Dream Job as U.S. Mens Hockey Coach
description: It is not a prerequisite for becoming coach of the United States Olympic mens hockey team, but Dan Bylsma has watched Miracle, the movie about the 1980 squad coached by Herb Brooks that won the gold medal.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Dior Homme Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: California Couples Line Up to Marry After Stay on Same-Sex Marriage Is Lifted
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The words spouses for life echoed throughout City Hall on Saturday as hundreds of same-sex couples were married in stairways, rotundas and seemingly every open space in the building.

title: Matching Wits
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  The first theme entry I solved in Alex Vratsanoss and Jeff Chens Matching Wits puzzle was the venerable father of modern blues MUDDY WATERS, so as a nod to him, todays blog post will be written in the rhythm of a blues riff.

title: Rena Price Is Dead at 97; Catalyst for the Watts Riots
description: Rena Price was in her kitchen in the Watts section of Los Angeles on Aug. 11, 1965, when a neighbor came to tell her that the police were arresting her 21-year-old son, Marquette Frye. She immediately raced to the corner of 116th Street and South Avalon Boulevard, her red-flowered dress billowing.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 30
description: With the exact whereabouts of Edward J. Snowden unknown,Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, will join ABCs This Week on Sunday to discuss how his antisecrecy group has helped Mr. Snowden in the wake of his disclosures about the National Security Agency.

title: Ghanas Crackdown on Chinese Gold Miners Hits One Rural Area Hard
description: MINGLIANG, China  To the people of Shanglin County, gold is a curse.

title: Vows: The Showmance
description: Leslie Stifelman and Melissa Rae Mahon, of the musical Chicago, have been performing together on Broadway for seven years. Their son, Jack, was born in March.

title: Philip E. Slater, Social Critic Who Renounced Academia, Dies at 86
description: Philip E. Slater, a social critic and author, pursued success in the conventional way in the first half of his life. He studied hard, graduated from Harvard, became a tenured professor of sociology and wrote a best-selling book, The Pursuit of Loneliness.

title: In Support Groups for Gay Military Members, Plenty of Asking and Telling
description: ALBUQUERQUE  During his eight years in the Air Force, Staff Sgt. Justin Lahl grew adept at keeping his sexual orientation a secret  wincing inwardly when fellow airmen made homophobic wisecracks, nodding with a smile when others would caricature gay people for laughs.

title:
Justice Still Elusive
in Factory Disasters
in Bangladesh
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Inside Courtroom 21, the two judges peered down from high wooden chairs as lawyers in formal black robes presented their motions. Activists and victims watched from the back. And a few steps away, a portly man with a thick black beard remained silent. He was the suspect. He did not seem especially nervous.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Comme des Garcons Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Republicans Paint Clinton as Old News for 2016 Presidential Election
description: WASHINGTON  Stuart Stevens, the top strategist for Mitt Romneys presidential campaign, declared to an audience of reporters at a breakfast last month that electing Hillary Rodham Clinton would be like going back in time. Shes been around since the 70s, he said.

title: Johannesburg Center Is Helping to Preserve the Legacy of Mandela
description: JOHANNESBURG  Sello Hatang pulled open a long, yellow drawer and grabbed a cream-color parchment. It declared Nelson Mandela an honorary citizen of the State of Washington.

title: Ecuador Leader Says Biden Called About Asylum Request
description: QUITO, Ecuador  President Rafael Correa of Ecuador said Saturday that Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had asked him in a telephone call not to grant asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive former security contractor wanted in the United States.

title: Makarova Caps Disappointing Showing for Russian Women
description: WIMBLEDON, England  When Ekaterina Makarova lost in three sets to Petra Kvitova early Saturday afternoon, she capped a disappointing showing for the Russian women at Wimbledon. Makarova, the No. 25 seed and the last Russian woman remaining in the tournament, fell 3-6, 6-2, 3-6.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Miharayasuhiro Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

title: Hoping a Yankees Revival Starts With a Loss
description: BALTIMORE  The Yankees had what for them seemed like a breakout game Friday, despite its ending in a 4-3 loss to the Baltimore Orioles. They outhit the Orioles by 11-5 and scored three runs, far better production than they could muster Thursday, when they were stifled in a two-hit shutout.

title: Syria Attacks Rebel-Held Area in New Push to Retake City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian military used airstrikes and heavy artillery to assault rebel-held areas of the central city of Homs on Saturday, residents and antigovernment activists said, as the government renewed efforts to retake that perennially restive and divided city.

title: After Protests, Brazilian Presidents Popularity Plummets
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The approval rating of Brazils president, Dilma Rousseff, plunged in June to 30 percent from 57 percent, reflecting swelling anger against the government since protests spread to more than 100 cities in recent weeks in a broad repudiation of political corruption, deplorable public services and costly stadium projects for the 2014 World Cup.

title: Last Words of the Condemned
description: Texas has executed 500 inmates since it resumed carrying out the death penalty in 1982. Read selected excerpts of inmates last words.

title: After Rare Struggles, Park Reasserts Her Dominance at U.S. Womens Open
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  For three months, the worlds best female golfers have been waiting for Inbee Park to falter, stumble, collapse under the growing weight of her dominance over the L.P.G.A. Tour.

title:
Taking Outsize
Role in Syria,
Qatar Funnels
Arms to Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  As an intermittent supply of arms to the Syrian opposition gathered momentum last year, the Obama administration repeatedly implored its Arab allies to keep one type of powerful weapon out of the rebels hands: heat-seeking shoulder-fired missiles.

title: Mixed Day for Tomic Siblings
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It was a mixed day for the Tomic family. While Bernard Tomic had one of his best wins of the year in knocking off Richard Gasquet in four tight sets, his younger sister Sara had a Wimbledon debut to forget.

title: From Americas Busiest Death Chamber, a Catalog of Last Rants, Pleas and Apologies
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex.  Karl Eugene Chamberlain went to his neighbors apartment that night in Dallas under the pretense of borrowing sugar. He returned later, forced her into a bedroom, bound her hands and feet, raped her and then used a rifle to shoot and kill her. His victim, Felecia Prechtl, 29, was a single mother with a 5-year-old son.

title: Lottery Numbers
More Proof of a Revival After a Victory in Moscow
description: Boris Gelfand continued his career renaissance with a first-place finish at the Tal Memorial tournament last week.

title: Seppi Is Proving Unbeatable, if Stretched to Five Sets
description: WIMBLEDON, England  If Andreas Seppi can push Juan Martin del Potro to a fifth set Monday, he might have gained all the momentum needed to pull out a victory over the favored del Potro.

title: An Embarrassing Loss, Even by the Yankees Recent Standards
description: The Yankees season has been spiraling rapidly downward the last few weeks, but it reached new depths Saturday as the team closed in on the mathematical midpoint of the season.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 30
description: It is gone  that unity is gone completely.

title: W.H.O. Issues Guidelines for Earlier H.I.V. Treatment
description: People infected with H.I.V. should be put on antiretroviral therapy even sooner than they are now, the World Health Organization said Sunday as it released new treatment guidelines.

LeVine of St. Louis, was married there Saturday evening to Max Abraham Hyman, the son of Judith Liebman Hyman and Charles G. Hyman of New York. Rabbi Matthew S. Cutler performed the ceremony at the St. Louis Palladium.

description: Sarah Samantha Adler and Christopher John Noelcke were married Saturday at Meadowood Napa Valley, a resort in St. Helena, Calif. The Rev. Peadar Dalton, who is an ordained Roman Catholic priest, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

Bernstein of New York. Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr., a federal judge on the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, officiated.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (Showtime) RAY DONOVAN If Hollywood honchos need anything fixed, Ray Donovan (Liev Schreiber) is the man they call. Working with two associates  Avi (Steven Bauer, above center with Mr. Schreiber and Katherine Moennig) and Lena (Ms. Moennig)  he cleans up messes for studios and law firms, primarily Goldman/Drexler, led by his confidant and mentor, Ezra Goldman (Elliott Gould), and his partner, Lee Drexler (Peter Jacobson). But Rays life is a mess. His wife, Abby (Paula Malcomson), a hard-core Boston Southie, is still adjusting to living in the Los Angeles suburbs. His brother Bunchy (Dash Mihok) was abused by a priest and has the alcohol problem to prove it. Another brother, Terry (Eddie Marsan), boxed too long and developed Parkinsons. And the ghost of their little sister, who committed suicide when she was a teenager, haunts them all. Now Rays father, Mickey (Jon Voight), a gangster with the Irish mob, has been unexpectedly released from prison. The Season 8 premiere of Dexter, which finds Deb (Jennifer Carpenter) giving Dexter (Michael C. Hall) the silent treatment, leads in at 9.

title: Monsters University Holds Off White House Down at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Big guns and heavy star power took aim at the weekend film box office, but Monsters University, an animated frolic from Disneys Pixar unit, was still standing when the dust settled. In its second weekend, Monsters University had about $46.2 million in North American ticket sales, and about $171 million in domestic sales to date. That put it well ahead of The Heat, a heavily armed action comedy starring Melissa McCarthy and Sandra Bullock. The Heat placed second with $40 million in weekend sales for 20th Century Fox.

title: Via Stravinsky, a Girl and a Doll, Rapturous and Mechanized
description: The story told by the New York Philharmonic program A Dancers Dream last week was curious, even chilling. In a program note, the director-designer Doug Fitch called it a kind of ber fairy tale, amalgamating themes shared by fairy tales around a single young woman who slips into the world of her own imagination and is swept away by muses to become a ballerina. Yes, but a ballerina of a particularly restricted kind. That heroine was played by the New York City Ballet principal Sara Mearns, and the programs particular fascination was that it extended her in two directions weve never seen before. She began, in Stravinskys Baiser de la Fe (The Fairys Kiss), as a child; she ended it, however, in his Petrushka as a dancing doll.

title: Brick Announces Lineup for Game Play Festival
description: The Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has announced the lineup for the 2013 Game Play festival, its annual fusion of live theater and video games. Among the shows to be presented are Legendary, Maybe, in which digital puppeteers use characters from World of Warcraft and Far Cry 3 to adapt stories written by the Roman historian Livy; No Oddjob, a one-man show written and performed by David Lawson that explores what happens when video games seep into your dreams; and That Cute Radioactive Couple, a comedy inspired by post-apocalyptic games like Fallout and BioShock, written and directed by Charles Battersby. The festival begins on Friday and runs through July 28. A complete schedule is at bricktheater.com.

title: Still Stepping Into the Unknown and Testing Fate

On Friday night at Town Hall, in the centerpiece of the Blue Note Jazz Festival, Mr. Shorters longtime quartet headlined a triple bill that attested to his immense and continuing influence on jazz.

title: Working to Combat the Stigma of Autism
description: Autism, or the fear of it, chased one Korean mother from her Queens church. I very carefully told the mom: I think your child is a little different. Why dont you take the test for autism? said the Rev. Joy Lee of the Korean Presbyterian Church in Flushing. She told me, Oh no, my child will be O.K. So then she quit. After that, she did not pick up the phone.

title: A Peacock in Spite of Himself
description: This is R&B 101, Bruno Mars announced Saturday night at Barclays Center, fixing a stare on one woman in the audience. He cued the band to crescendo, and then to stop on a dime, leaving empty air just as he exhaled a silky damn. Afterward he paced the stage with an exaggerated peacock strut while encouraging his bandmates to try to outsuave him. I dont mean to toot my own horn, Mr. Mars said when they were done, his megawatt smile turned up to gigawatt, but, Beeeeep!

title: Jennifer Lopez Faulted for Turkmenistan Show
description: The singer Jennifer Lopez has drawn scrutiny for performing at an event on Saturday night in Turkmenistan and singing Happy Birthday to the countrys president, Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, who was in attendance. According to The Associated Press, a publicist for Ms. Lopez, above, said in a statement on Sunday that said she would not have appeared if she had known that there were human rights issues in Turkmenistan. Mr. Berdymukhammedov has been criticized by human rights organizations for a pattern of oppressive rule since he became president in 2006. The statement also said that despite Mr. Berdymukhammedovs presence, the event was not political. It was hosted by the China National Petroleum Corporation, which made the birthday request toward the end of the concert, and Ms. Lopez graciously obliged. Her fee for the performance was not disclosed.

title: The Rev. Norman Eddy, a Minister in East Harlem, Dies at 93
description: The Rev. Norman Eddy, a Yale-educated minister from Connecticut who settled in a blighted East Harlem neighborhood in 1951 and helped start a pioneering drug treatment program, a tenants group, a housing project, a credit union and the myriad self-help organizations that have sustained his work there for over 60 years, died on June 21 in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Journalism, Even When Its Tilted
description: In a refracted media world where information comes from everywhere, the line between two isms  journalism and activism  is becoming difficult to discern. As American news media have pulled back from international coverage, nongovernmental organizations have filled in the gaps with on-the-scene reports and Web sites. State houses have lost reporters who used to provide accountability, so citizens have turned to digital enterprises, some of which have partisan agendas.
